HEADLINE: High Demand For Energy Spurs Mergers 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Two mergers announced yesterday in disparate parts of the energy industry may not seem to have much in common, but they point to an effort by some companies to capitalize on growing demand for gasoline and electricity and lagging supplies.
 The Williams Companies, which builds power plants, transports natural gas and trades electricity, confirmed that it would buy the Barrett Resources Corporation in Denver for $2.5 billion in cash and stock, topping a hostile bid made by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. At the same time, the Valero Energy Corporation, one of the nation's largest refining companies, said it planned to acquire a competitor, the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation, for about $4 billion in cash and stock. 
 A couple of years ago, few companies would have placed their bets on businesses like natural gas exploration or oil refining, which have historically made little money. Natural gas prices were depressed for years before a sharp upswing began last spring. Profit margins in refining had been extremely narrow, with oil companies generally making their money on the difference between pumping the oil from the ground for a few dollars and selling it on the commodities markets for much more. 
But the booming economy of the last few years stoked consumption of natural gas and petroleum products, especially gasoline and heating oil. And so far, the slowdown has had almost no effect on how much electricity Americans use or how much they drive. Demand for gasoline is expected to be 1.4 percent higher this summer than last year, according to the Energy Information Administration, the analysis unit of the Energy Department.
"Over the last decade, neither natural gas nor refining has been a high-profit segment of the industry," said Kate Warne, senior energy analyst with Edward Jones, a brokerage firm based in St. Louis. "But those parts of the industry that are usually ignored are hot now. People are looking for assets and to operate them more efficiently."
The bidding war that broke out for Barrett was indicative of the renewed interest from big companies like Shell in natural gas producers in North America. "This should be a sign to the industry that North American natural gas is a long-term investment opportunity," said Wayne Andrews, energy analyst with the investment firm Raymond James & Associates. "If the industry recognizes that, you could see future takeouts."
Three months ago, the Phillips Petroleum Company announced that it would buy the Tosco Corporation, the nation's largest independent refiner, for about $7 billion in stock and at a significant premium over Tosco's share price at the time. In mid-April, the power generation company Calpine Corporation completed its acquisition of Encal Energy, a Canadian oil and gas producer. 
The market greeted the Phillips deal with skepticism, echoing years of doubt about the refining business. Most major oil and gas companies like BP Amoco have been gradually divesting themselves of much of their marginally profitable refining business to focus on the big money in crude oil production. But increasingly, analysts and companies are asking whether the recent healthy margins in petroleum refining are as ephemeral as many had predicted. Valero's deal, for example, has been greeted more favorably by the market, analysts said, despite the decline in its share price yesterday.
Valero would exchange 1.228 shares of its common stock for about half the outstanding shares of Ultramar Diamond Shamrock common stock and would pay $55 a share in cash for the remaining shares. That would represent a 29 percent premium over Ultramar's closing price of $42.71 a share on Friday. Valero would also assume $2 billion in debt. Shares of Valero fell $2.77 yesterday, to $42.70, while Ultramar Diamond rose $7.79, to $50.50.
Gasoline inventories going into the peak summer driving season are below last year's historical lows. As a result, prices are climbing. President Bush is "very concerned" about prices, a White House spokesman said yesterday. The Energy Information Administration revised an earlier forecast for the average price of gasoline this summer, raising it 11 cents, to $1.60 a gallon, a record in nominal terms. Adjusted for inflation, however, it is still below average summer prices in the mid-1980's. 
Prices have been buoyed by the narrowing gap between consumer demand and gasoline supply. More people are driving farther from home to work, more vehicles are on the road and more of them are gasoline-greedy sport utility vehicles. Despite high fuel prices last year, driving behavior changed only slightly. With the Bush administration eschewing conservation, consumption is unlikely to fall drastically over the coming years. 
While demand has soared, the amount of oil that can be refined in the United States has fallen. Because of environmental regulations and low returns, no new refineries have been built in the country since the 1970's. With its acquisition of Ultramar, Valero will become the second- biggest refiner in the country, trailing only Exxon Mobil.
"You have a situation that has evolved over a long period of time," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "You eventually get into a bottleneck, and you can't get out of it overnight. That's why refining looks like an investment."
There are, of course, potential hazards to such a big refining position. High gasoline prices may eventually push people to conserve once more. A deep recession could dampen demand, too.
But both Valero and Williams may benefit from the increasing Balkanization of the country's energy market. Each company, for example, is well positioned to cash in on California's energy woes. Refining margins in the state are even higher than they are nationwide because of a special brand of clean-burning gasoline used there that cannot be imported in large amounts. If its acquisition is approved by the Federal Trade Commission, Valero will have three refineries in the lucrative California market. 
Williams's deal would enable it to lock in natural gas to supply power plants it is building nationwide. Williams will buy half the shares of Barrett for cash and the rest with stock. The company will pay $73 in cash, or 1.767 of its shares, for each Barrett share. Williams will also assume $300 million in debt. Shares of Williams fell $2.39, to $39.28, while Barrett rose $2.85, to $70.15.
Because Barrett's fields are in the Rocky Mountains, the supply of natural gas that Williams is acquiring will be particularly crucial to serving California, the Southwest and Texas, where power demand is booming. Calpine and Williams have both entered long-term deals with California to supply power and buying gas fields reduces their exposure to the volatility of gas prices on the commodities markets.
"When you build power plants, you have to cover the other end of that: your fuel," Mr. Andrews said. "There are two ways to do it: you can enter into long-term contracts and pay very high prices on the futures markets or buy natural gas producers. Williams benefits whether it burns the natural gas or sells it." 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 9, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about two acquisitions in the energy industry, which point to an effort by some companies to capitalize on the growing demand for gasoline and electricity, referred incorrectly to the nation's capacity for refining oil. Although the gap between supply and demand has tightened, capacity has risen since 1994, not fallen.

HEADLINE: Bush Declares Freer Trade A Moral Issue; Chides Critics 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7 

 BODY:
President Bush took on critics of his free trade agenda today, arguing that his administration's effort to break down tariffs was "a moral imperative" that would help clean up the environment and promote workers' rights.
 Mr. Bush, who will send his trade proposals to Congress this week in preparation for a vote in the fall, used a speech at the State Department to urge lawmakers to give him the authority to negotiate trade treaties the world over that would not be subject to amendments by the Senate. 
 "One tool I must have is renewed U.S. trade promotion authority," Mr. Bush said at a meeting of the Council of the Americas, an organization that promotes trade in the Western Hemisphere. "I urge the Congress: restore our nation's authority to negotiate trade agreements, and I will use that authority to build freedom in the world, progress in our hemisphere and enduring prosperity in the United States." 
The White House knows it is in for a battle. Labor unions and their backers on Capitol Hill have vowed to fight against giving the president such a free hand in trade negotiations. Even as the president spoke, 61 senators sent him a letter warning that they would oppose any new trade agreement that did not allow the United States to protect its companies against unfair trade practices by foreign governments.
Mr. Bush will face the same political crosscurrents that his predecessor encountered. Every president since Gerald Ford has had the ability to negotiate trade deals that had to be voted up or down by lawmakers without changes. But the authority lapsed during the Clinton administration, and the White House was unable to win Congressional support to restore the negotiating power, which is known as fast track.
"When President Clinton tried to get fast track authority and started counting heads, he dropped it," said Representative Jack Quinn of Buffalo, who heads a group of Republicans who support unions. "The votes weren't there then, and I haven't seen much change."
The White House is well aware of that. "Will it be easy?" Nicholas E. Calio, Mr. Bush's legislative director, said in an interview. "No. This issue is always a difficult one. It takes a lot of work and a lot of education. We're talking to all sorts of different people. There are some whom it's not worth talking to, because they'll never in a million years be with you. But if anybody is at all open, even a little open, we'll talk."
Mr. Bush today asked the business leaders, diplomats and government officials who make up the Council of the Americas to help turn critics around. "I'm counting on the council's help to bring sanity to the United States Congress," he said.
But Mr. Bush also signaled that he would be willing to deal with the detractors. "My administration wants to work with Congress and to listen to what the members have to say," he said. "We've been especially impressed by the fresh, new thinking of many members about how to advance environmental and worker protection concerns in ways that open trade rather than closing trade."
Robert B. Zoellick, the president's trade representative, has sought to bridge the gap between Democrats, who insist that trade pacts should impose sanctions on countries that fail to protect workers and the environment, and Republicans, who see such requirements as a form of protectionism. Forging a compromise has proven difficult.
In making his case, Mr. Bush decried what he called "a new form of protectionism."
"It talks of workers, while it opposes a major source of new jobs," he said. "It talks of the environment, while opposing the wealth-creating policies that will pay for clean air and water in developing nations. It talks of the disadvantaged, even as it offers ideas that would keep many of the poor in poverty.
"Open trade is not just an economic opportunity, it is a moral imperative. Trade creates jobs for the unemployed. When we negotiate for open markets, we're providing new hope for the world's poor. And when we promote open trade, we are promoting political freedom."
When it comes to trade pacts, Mr. Bush has his eyes all over the map. Besides the hemisphere-wide pact that he pursued at the recent summit meeting in Quebec, Mr. Bush is seeking trade agreements with such countries as Jordan, Chile and Singapore, as well as a new round of global trade accords. He also said China, which reached a trade agreement with the United States at the close of the Clinton administration, would benefit from political changes as a result of liberalized trade policies.
"Look at our friends in Mexico and the political reforms there," he said. "Look at Taiwan. Look at South Korea. And someday soon I hope that an American president will end that list by adding, 'Look at China.' "

HEADLINE: Tapping a Thirst for Latin Cinema; 
Films Win Festival Raves but Struggle to Reach Their Markets

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
In Fabian Bielinsky's film "Nueve Reinas" ("Nine Queens"), a swindler takes his reluctant apprentice out on the street to show him they are hardly alone in their pursuits. Looking around, they easily spot people being robbed, or about to be, by a purse snatcher, a car thief, a shoplifter.
 Although the film is set in Buenos Aires, Mr. Bielinsky said, its atmosphere of deception and self-interest is universal. 
 "The film reflects not reality but a particular mood, a mood that sometimes everybody goes through," he told a sold-out audience at the Museum of Modern Art last month during the New Directors/New Films festival. "Is everybody lying? Is there anybody that's not part of this big scheme?" 
With "Nine Queens" Mr. Bielinsky has become one of the new voices in Spanish-language cinema that are catching the attention of audiences at home and abroad. Filmmaking has gone through steep ups and downs in Latin America, cycles often tied to economic and government upheavals, film industry experts say, but the trend now is up, in production, film quality and popular appeal.
Latin American filmmakers may also find a huge potential American audience in the growing Hispanic population, industry representatives say, although movie distributors have yet to tap that market.
"At the most hopeful, Latin America is in a position Asia was in at the end of the 1980's, when there were a lot of promising people who have now emerged as major directors," said Richard Pena, program director for the Film Society of Lincoln Center. "There's certainly the talent there for filmmakers to broaden their audience so they become a permanent voice in world cinema like they were in the 60's and part of the 70's."
In the last two years, Mr. Pena said, Latin America has produced films "that have really captured the imagination of audiences around the world." He noted that at the Berlin International Film Festival this year, the most discussed film was "La Cienaga" ("The Swamp") by Lucrecia Martel, about Argentina's collapsing middle classes.
Last year at the Cannes International Film Festival, he said, a strong Latin American presence was felt with knockouts like Mexico's "Amores Perros," roughly translated as "Miserable Loves." Cuba, Peru, Colombia and Chile are other countries with smaller but notable Spanish-language productions that have played at recent film festivals.
"The decade itself has been up and down," said Geoffrey Gilmore, director of the Sundance Film Festival, "but at the end of the day there's a much stronger sense of national cinema than there was in the beginning."
One example of a revitalized film industry is that of Argentina, which has a long history of cinema. Private film schools have multiplied in the last decade and have about 10,000 film students today, compared with fewer than 100 in the early 1980's. Nearly 50 Argentine films were made last year, double the rate of the 1990's, said Manuel Antin, dean of the Film University, a private film school in Buenos Aires. He said that one distinguishing quality of Argentine filmmakers now is a preference for realistic themes and settings, often shot in black and white.
The Film Society of Lincoln Center is showcasing some of these films through May 17 in a program called "Passionate Stories, a Passion for Storytelling: Recent Argentine Cinema" at the Walter Reade Theater. Among them are "76 89 03," which traces key years in contemporary Argentine history, and "Tesoro Mio," ("My Treasure"), a film noir based on a real bank embezzlement case.
"We're learning to navel-gaze, to see ourselves like we are," Mr. Antin said. "We've always had cinema that exposed conflicts of a national character -- the disappeared, the dictatorship -- but they were works of fiction."
Today's films are helping create new audiences in Latin America, where homegrown filmmakers usually find it hard to compete with American movies. In Mexico, films like "Amores Perros" have been as much a draw as Hollywood films, filmmakers there say. But finding money to finance productions is still the main struggle for directors.
In Argentina, productions depend on subsidies, loans and grants from the government, which uses a percentage of admission tickets to foster filmmaking. But Mr. Antin said that about half the money ends up going elsewhere in the government budget.
"It's encouraging that there are so many people who want to make films, but the financial problems are endemic," said Mr. Bielinsky, 42, who won a contest for new talent sponsored by a major production company, the Patagonik Film Group, which financed the $1.3 million "Nine Queens," his first feature film.
A popular way to deal with the financial problems, capitalize on a common language and exploit each other's markets is in co-productions with European countries like Spain, whose moviemaking has also blossomed over the last decade.
Jerry Carlson, a film studies professor at City College of New York who specializes in Latin American cinema, said that even major Hollywood studios had dabbled in collaborations like "Bossa Nova," a Brazilian production in English and Portuguese released by Sony Pictures Classics. "It does bode well for the acceptance of all cinema as a truly international medium," he said.
Because of the size of each nation's audience, few films can recoup their cost just exhibiting in their home country, film industry experts say, but Latin American filmmakers have found it difficult to reach international markets.
Gabriel Retes, a Mexican filmmaker for 28 years who is working on "@festival.ron," a semiautobiographical film about a director who goes to film festivals in five countries trying to sell his movie, said that the biggest obstacle was "Hollywood's invasion."
"Hollywood has swept the movie theaters, even in our countries," he said. "And when I say Hollywood, I'm not talking about American cinema, because there are many independent American filmmakers who can't get a screen either."
But in the United States, the huge growth of the Latino population is a beacon of hope. Events like last month's Havana Film Festival New York 2001, a sampling of Cuban and Latin American cinema featuring winners of the annual Havana Film Festival in Cuba, have expanded to include more films and venues. Kenneth Halsband, the festival director, said there were plans to extend the event to Los Angeles next year. And the Film Society of Lincoln Center has scheduled four Spanish-language programs, the most it has held in a single year. The Spanish Cinema Now series, an annual tribute to films from Spain being held Dec. 7 to 27 this year, is among their most popular programs.
But distributors and exhibitors of foreign films, like Daniel Talbot, president of New Yorker Films and operator of the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, note that Latinos in the United States are hardly a guaranteed audience for Latin American films. The public for these films, he said, is drawn from the same limited pool that goes to any foreign movie: an ethnically mixed group of slightly older, reasonably well-traveled, college-educated people. Although interest varies film by film, he said, "these are subtitled films that reach a minority audience."
So is there a better market in the United States for Latin-theme American films? There have been both smash hits and flops in the genre, people in the film industry in the States note, but this is largely uncharted territory because relatively few have been made. Latino filmmakers have the same complaint as their Latin American counterparts: it is hard to find financing, in their case from Hollywood.
A limited study of Latino movie-going habits by the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute in California, conducted in 1999 for the Screen Actors Guild, found that for most Latinos, subject matter, not ethnic considerations, was the deciding factor in choosing a movie. But Latinos were six to seven times as likely to watch Latino-theme movies or movies starring Hispanic actors as to watch movies of a similar genre without a Latino theme or actors.
The study estimated that Latinos spend over $528 million a year on movie admissions.
Moctesuma Esparza, producer of "Selena," "Price of Glory" and other Latin-theme movies, argues that both Latin American cinema and American Latin-theme productions can look forward to growing audiences. For Latin American films to tap this audience, though, they must be marketed to Latinos and made accessible in Latino neighborhoods, he said.
Leon Ichaso, who is the director of films like "Crossover Dreams" and "El Super" and just completed a film about the life of the Puerto Rican poet and playwright Miguel Pinero, said it was up to Latinos and Latin Americans to coalesce so they can finance and distribute their films and develop the market themselves.
"There's a history of Hollywood failures that we pay for," he said. "Producers and directors need to talk among ourselves to create a cinema that is not a fad or a boom but that stays."

HEADLINE: A New Show at the Apollo Raises Hopes in Harlem 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Since the 1930's the Apollo Theater in Harlem has been known for its variety shows, with acts like the tap-dancing Nicholas Brothers, the comedian Redd Foxx and the jazz singer Ruth Brown, and the weekly amateur nights, which started the careers of Sarah Vaughan and Ella Fitzgerald. 
 Now, as the Apollo starts a $6 million renovation, the theater is planning to install a production with an open-ended run. The theater is to announce today that a new revue, "Harlem Song," is in the works, celebrating the history of Harlem since the 1920's through song, dance, dialogue, photographs and film. 
 The new production appears to be part of a larger effort to jump-start this struggling landmark. In March, Derek Q. Johnson, a co-chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, stepped down to become president of the Apollo, saying that his priorities would be fund-raising and making the Apollo part of a major cultural center on 125th Street. 
"Harlem Song" is to be written by George C. Wolfe, the writer-director who is producer of the Joseph Papp Public Theater. The show is expected to begin an extended engagement next May, offering performances only on weekends -- three on Saturday, three on Sunday -- with the production going on hiatus each January through March. During the rest of the week the Apollo is to feature touring acts as well as the usual Amateur Nights on Wednesdays and begin originating its own attractions, said David D. Rodriguez, executive director of the Apollo Theater Foundation, which runs the theater. The Apollo is owned by New York State. 
"We want it to be a permanent attraction at the theater," said John Schreiber, an entertainment executive, who is producing the show with David Goodman, a former vice president for special programming and projects at Warner Brothers, and Frank Wildhorn, the composer of shows like "Jekyll and Hyde." The show will be produced in association with the foundation, which will share in the proceeds.
"It will speak to all sorts of audiences: the Harlem community, students, church groups from Maryland, traditional theatergoers, eventgoers," Mr. Schreiber added. "Harlem is the fourth most visited tourist attraction in New York."
Those involved say they hope that by drawing people to the Apollo, Harlem's other cultural offerings will benefit. With this in mind, Mr. Schreiber said, $1 of every ticket sold will be donated to the Harlem Strategic Cultural Collaborative, a consortium of nine arts organizations including the Studio Museum in Harlem, the Boys Choir of Harlem and the National Black Theater.
Barbara Ann Teer, founder and chief executive of the National Black Theater, said she was glad that "Harlem Song" planned to share its proceeds with the neighborhood's established cultural institutions. "I think it's wonderful that they want to acknowledge the groups that have been here and stayed the course," she said.
The creators say they also plan to reach out to schools in the area, inviting 200 students to the show every week without charge and developing a curriculum guide with Dr. Howard Dodson, a member of the Apollo board and director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem. "They'll get the most entertaining history lesson ever," Mr. Schreiber said. 
Mr. Schreiber, who produced last year's New Yorker Festival and met Mr. Wolfe there, said he asked Mr. Wolfe's advice for an Apollo show that would honor Harlem's heritage. Mr. Wolfe expressed interest in doing it himself. 
"I wanted to use my talent and my personality to help bring some energy into the community -- let me give something," Mr. Wolfe said. "Also, it means dealing with things I love, which are history and rejuvenation."
That doesn't mean "Harlem Song" will be a living, breathing wax museum or a history pageant, Mr. Wolfe said. "Harlem is one place where myth and reality have been dancing with each other since the beginning," he said. "I'm interested in exploring that." He said it would also be exciting to see his name on the Apollo marquee for the first time.
"It's not history from a distance," he added. "It's history that has an intimacy." One sequence, for example, will take place on the night in 1938 when Joe Louis fought Max Schmeling. "That fight, it was American idealism fighting facism and Naziism," Mr. Wolfe said. "It was a mythic, titanlike battle that affected everyone."
The show will also look at rent parties of the 1930's, when blacks who moved to Harlem from the South gathered to contribute to one another's monthly rent payments. "Fats Waller and Willy (the Lion) Smith would be playing," Mr. Wolfe said. "It was a way for newly arrived Southerners to acclimate themselves to an urban environment." In creating "Harlem Song," Mr. Wolfe has joined forces with his team from the award-winning shows "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk" and "Jelly's Last Jam." It includes the choreographer Ken Roberson, the composers Daryl Waters and Zane Mark, the set designer Riccardo Hernandez and the projection designers Batwin & Robin Productions Inc.
As to how he would juggle the show with his responsibilities at the Public, Mr. Wolfe suggested that he would share the directing duties, adding that he was used to having a lot on his plate. "I don't see it violating any time and space at the Public," he said. 
The show, which will cost some $5 million to mount, will have a top ticket price of about $45, Mr. Schreiber said. The show expects to bring in more than 400,000 people in a nine-month period. "It's not just an art story, it's an economic development story," Mr. Rodriguez said.
The Apollo could use the boost. In 1998 the New York attorney general, Dennis C. Vacco, sued the theater and six members of the foundation's board, including Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem congressman who was then the board's chairman, and accused them of mismanaging the Apollo's finances. Although Mr. Rangel denied wrongdoing, he resigned as chairman and agreed later to leave the board as part of a settlement with Mr. Vacco's successor, Eliot L. Spitzer.
The theater, which has 1,463 seats, is to start its renovation next month, including redoing its marquee and facade. Next month, for the first time, Dance Theater of Harlem will perform its season at the Apollo. And during the July 4 weekend the Apollo will test its first off-site Amateur Night t on the Mall in Washington, with local amateurs and the Smithsonian Institution as a co-sponsor. 
He said the planned schedule for "Harlem Song" harked back to the theater's early days. "For a number of years the Apollo had five shows on weekdays, seven shows on weekends," he said, adding that the dancer Maurice Hines "has said he would start the first show in the last row and work his way up through the day."

HEADLINE: A Hard Choice in Peru 

BYLINE:  By Steven Levitsky and Cynthia Sanborn; Steven Levitsky is an assistant professor of government at Harvard University. Cynthia Sanborn is a professor of political science at Universidad del Pacifico in Lima, Peru.

 BODY:
The American media has followed recent events in Peru with a mixture of fascination and horror. A year ago, Peru drew international attention when President Alberto Fujimori and his cronies maneuvered to steal their way to a third term. Then, while much of the international community prepared to recognize the election as a fait accompli, a leaked videotape revealed the extraordinary web of corruption spun by spy chief Vladimiro Montesinos, prompting Mr. Fujimori's resignation and the holding of new elections on April 8. The results of that election also stunned observers.
 A runoff contest early next month pits frontrunner Alejandro Toledo, a former shoeshine boy of indigenous descent who led the opposition to Mr. Fujimori last year, against none other than ex-president Alan Garcia, whose mismanagement and abuse of power in the 1980s generated the worst economic crisis in Peruvian history. Are voters suffering from "bad memory," as a leading U.S. newspaper recently editorialized? 
 Not necessarily. The roots of Alan Garcia's political resurgence lie in the extraordinary weakness of Peru's political institutions. Over the last decade, Peru has suffered two meltdowns of its political establishment. In 1990, the existing elite collapsed under the weight of hyperinflation, terrorism and its own failure to represent effectively the country's poor and non-white majority. Mr. Fujimori, a political neophyte, defeated renowned novelist Mario Vargas Llosa to win the presidency.
Two years later, Mr. Fujimori's closure of Congress delivered a coup de grace to the old guard elite, and his regime then eviscerated what remained of Peru's political institutions. The espionage and extortion network constructed by Mr. Montesinos gave him de facto control over the armed forces, the legislature, the judiciary, the electoral authorities, and much of the media.
These institutions were broadly discredited, and when the regime fell last year, the political establishment collapsed yet again. Established political parties have been replaced by an array of personality driven movements and amateur outsider candidates. Because outsiders lack political experience and a track record, they represent a shot in the dark for voters, both in terms of their ability to govern and their commitment to democracy.
It is in this context that Alan Garcia returned to become a major contender for the presidency. Mr. Garcia is a skilled politician with a real party base, but what truly permitted his rise in the polls -- his party's presidential candidate the previous year won just two percent of the vote -- was the weakness of the rest of the field. Mr. Toledo, though widely respected for his role in bringing down Mr. Fujimori, is a political amateur who has proved to be a mistake-prone candidate. He lacks clarity on major policy issues, and his clumsy efforts to dodge persistent allegations of personal misconduct -- including drug use and fathering a child out of wedlock -- have raised questions about his credibility. The third place finisher in April, Lourdes Flores, a former congresswoman with a record of honesty and support for democracy, could not free herself from the traditional political and socioeconomic elite that Peruvians rejected in 1990. Her National Unity movement never even faintly resembled the society she hoped to govern.
Mr. Garcia's return has economic roots as well. Although Mr. Fujimori's free-market reforms ended hyperinflation and initially generated growth, the economy stagnated in the latter part of the 1990s. Poverty and inequality increased, and many Peruvians now consider themselves worse off than they were 10 years ago. Yet of the leading presidential candidates, only Mr. Garcia appeared to address voters' urgent economic concerns. Although Mr. Toledo's main campaign slogan was "More Jobs," his policy proposals were generally perceived to lack content.
Mr. Garcia, while claiming to have learned from his past mistakes, vigorously challenged the economic policies of the 1990s and offered people specific changes, such as lower utility rates, public jobs programs and credit for farmers. Viable or not, these proposals struck a chord among an electorate that had grown deeply dissatisfied with the economic status quo.
 P eruvians thus confront a difficult choice: Mr. Toledo, an inexperienced leader dogged by personal credibility problems, or Mr. Garcia.
Contrary to what many observers fear, the greatest risk posed by Mr. Garcia may not be economic. He has already moved to reassure bankers and investors that, if elected, he would follow in the footsteps of the numerous other Latin American populists and leftists who pursued market-friendly policies in the 1990s. Rather, the main problem with Mr. Garcia is that he still faces credible charges of corruption and responsibility for gross human rights abuses during his first administration. If a vote for Mr. Toledo is a shot in the dark, a vote for Mr. Garcia is a vote for impunity.
Yet Peru's flawed presidential candidates do not necessarily condemn it to another cycle of instability. Although Mr. Toledo and Mr. Garcia have captured the spotlight, a more important set of developments may be taking place at the margins of the campaign.
Since assuming office last November, the transitional government led by interim President Valentin Paniagua has taken important steps to rebuild Peru's public institutions. Mr. Paniagua built a broad-based government, drawing skilled and respected people from across the political spectrum. All of these appointees voluntarily stayed out of this year's campaigns, which enabled the government to focus its attention on reforms.
The government's performance has been impressive. It has begun to restructure the armed forces, removing officers who collaborated with the past regime and eliciting a formal apology for the 1992 coup. It has restored credibility to the electoral authorities, begun to depoliticize tax administration and welfare programs, and introduced mechanisms of consultation with leading civil society organizations in such areas as education, labor and justice.
The new government has also attacked the misuse of power head on. Both the executive and the congress have launched extensive investigations into corruption and other abuses of authority under Mr. Fujimori, resulting in the arrest of top military officers, judges, previously untouchable business moguls and politicians of all stripes.
Finally, in stark contrast to his predecessors, Mr. Paniagua has governed by consensus and by the rules, seeking to strengthen rather than circumvent democratic institutions. In a society that long ago lost faith in its leaders and institutions, this represents an important change.
The international media has paid scant attention to the ongoing reconstruction in Peru. Yet this process may be critical to laying the foundation for democracy no matter who wins next month's election. Rather than wringing its hands over the return of Mr. Garcia, the international community should support this effort. If it fails, Peruvian democracy will remain vulnerable to corrupt and irresponsible leaders. If it succeeds, democracy will have a chance to survive in spite of them.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
More agencies are finding pay tied to the results of a campaign rather than the campaign itself.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
THE shift by major advertisers from compensating their agencies based on the traditional billings method to compensating them based on results has accelerated since 1997, according to a study conducted by the Association of National Advertisers in New York.
 The findings of the study are to be released today by the association, the trade organization for the country's leading marketers, at its advertising financial management conference, which is being held in Dana Point, Calif. The study is part of the 12th Trends in Agency Compensation survey, which is conducted for the association every three years. 
 The findings are indicative of the changes remaking Madison Avenue as advertiser clients rethink the way they do business as they grow larger, operate in more countries and seek to draw the attention of consumers who are becoming increasingly wary of and jaded about standard sales pitches. 
"Advertisers are asking their agencies to act differently," said John J. Sarsen Jr., president and chief executive at the association, "to proactively identify a broad cross section of solutions for profitable brand growth."
"Agencies are becoming consumer driven," Mr. Sarsen added, "and not traditional-media driven."
That was a reference to a belief that under the billings method, when agencies are compensated using fixed commissions and sliding scales, there is a bias toward spending the client's marketing budget in the mass media like television, whether or not such media make sense, because they generate the highest commissions.
"We'd like the agency to take a 'media neutral' approach to communicating the brand's essence to consumers," Mr. Sarsen said, "because sometimes something else besides TV or the mass media is an even better way to bring a brand to its target audience."
Typically under the billings method, an agency receives a commission of 15 percent of the billings. For instance, if a campaign is composed of television spots that cost $20 million for the commercial time, the client would pay the agency $3 million for its work. But if a direct mail campaign would be more effective, costing only $5 million, the agency would receive $750,000.
"The 15 percent commission, the standard for a century, has largely been supplanted," said David Beals, president and chief executive at Jones Lundin Beals in Chicago, a consulting company that specializes in agency reviews and compensation issues. He was the author of the survey with Robert H. Lundin, senior partner at Jones Lundin Beals.
"The interest in nontraditional media and marketing methods is absolutely the trend behind" the shift from the billings method, Mr. Beals said, in part because "less traditional media -- Web site design, event marketing, direct response, public relations -- are harder to compensate on a commission basis."
According to the study, which collected data from 136 corporate respondents in December and January, more than two-thirds had agreements last year centered on what is known as labor-based compensation, basing pay on performance or incentives. By comparison, according to the study released in 1998, 53 percent of respondents used labor-based compensation in 1997.
In the new study, 21 percent of respondents said they used billings-based agreements last year, compared with 35 percent three years ago.
"It's a pretty dramatic shift over a short period," Mr. Beals said.
Of those using incentives, most linked them to sales goals, so that the agency would be paid extra if, say, sales of the product advertised rose by a certain amount.
Incentives are also often linked to how the agencies perform in evaluations and to awareness goals, meaning the agency would be paid extra if consumers describe themselves as more aware of a product or its advertising than they had been previously.
Forty-nine percent of respondents said they made a change in agency compensation methods in the last three years, the study reported, while in the last survey, 38 percent said they had made a change.
"It largely has to do with a desire for greater accountability," Mr. Beals said, adding that "given tougher economic times, I can only assume the use of performance incentives is only going to increase in coming years."
"In fact, as the economy swings up and down, the 15 percent commission is a shakier approach," he added. "In boom times, it leads to inflated profits for agencies, and in down times, the agencies suffer quite a bit if compensation is based on media spending."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
Longer-Term Treasuries Fall on Inflation Fears and New Sales

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasuries were mixed yesterday, with longer-dated issues tumbling on both a wave of new supply and on worries over potential inflation later in the year, when the market expects lower interest rates to result in an economic recovery.
 Those inflation fears were exacerbated after the government said productivity in the first quarter fell more than expected. Inflation erodes the value of long-term securities over time, and investors compensate for that expected loss by driving yields higher, the opposite direction from price. 
 But short-term issues held their ground on firming hopes that the Federal Reserve would make another deep interest rate cut at its policy meeting next week, keeping yields on two-year notes pinned near their lowest levels since late 1998.
Recent signs of economic weakness, including news that the economy shed more jobs in April than in any other month in the last decade, have bolstered expectations that the Fed will respond with a fifth cut of half a percentage point in its campaign to revive economic growth.
Analysts said new government debt sales coupled with a large corporate bond sale also weighed on longer-dated Treasuries. The Treasury sold $13 billion of new five-year notes in the first leg of its quarterly refinancing, while the big long-distance phone company WorldCom Inc. sold $12.2 billion of new debt in one of the largest corporate debt sales ever.
"It is a huge amount of securities between the agencies and corporates and now Treasuries that the investment community has to digest," said John Spinello, Treasury market strategist at Merrill Lynch.
The WorldCom deal drew more than $21 billion in bids, according to people close to the sale.
The benchmark 10-year note fell 10/32, to 98 5/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed to 5.24 percent, from 5.19 percent. The 30-year bond tumbled 30/32, to 94 27/32. Its yield grew to 5.74 percent, from 5.67 percent. The selling of longer-dated Treasuries in favor of short-term issues caused the difference in yields between them to widen to new seven-year highs.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Technology Shares Gain But Dow and S.& P. Decline

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index rose yesterday as investors hoped for a positive earnings report from Cisco Systems, the networking equipment giant, after markets closed.
 The Nasdaq climbed 25.20 points, or 1.16 percent, to 2,198.77, as other makers of networking equipment rose with Cisco. A decline in Dell Computer limited the index's gains. 
 "Investors are betting on a turn in the market" for Cisco's equipment, said John Davidson, chief investment officer at Circle Trust in Stamford, Conn. 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the fourth time in five days after a report showed that workers' productivity unexpectedly dropped in the first quarter.
American Express declined, leading the Dow to a loss of 51.66 points, or 0.47 percent, to 10,883.51, after a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst said the slowing economy would hurt the credit card business.
General Electric and Citigroup drove down the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which lost 2.31 points, or 0.18 percent, to 1,261.20.
Market breadth was positive on both the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board was about 990 million shares.
In regular-session trading, Cisco rose $1.12, to $20.37, on market-leading volume of more than 160 million shares. After the bell, the company reported profit from operations of 3 cents a share, surpassing analysts' forecasts of 2 cents a share, though down sharply from 13 cents in the quarter a year earlier. Cisco stock fell after hours to $19.74.
Earlier, Christopher Stix of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said that signs of an improved outlook for Cisco's sales to large business customers persuaded him to raise his rating on the stock to outperform from neutral. He added that past performance suggested Cisco shares anticipate changes in earnings growth by about six months. Because Cisco recently won business from China Telecom and Global Crossing, Mr. Stix said, and is expected to get more at a time when cost cuts may improve profit margins, it is now "timely to buy."
Among other networking producers, Ciena surged $6.32 yesterday, to $61.60, and Juniper Networks rose $1.82, to $58.90.
Some other groups of stocks fell after the Labor Department reported that productivity last quarter dropped for the first time since 1995. Analysts had forecast a gain. Some investors interpreted the decline, and a jump in labor costs, as further evidence that the slowing economy is squeezing corporate profit.
Still, the modest declines in the Dow and the S.& P. 500, and the rise in the Nasdaq, Mr. Davidson said, were encouraging in light of the recent signs of economic weakness. Investors, he said, had "seen that the market has absorbed an awful lot of bad news and not been destroyed by it."
American Express fell $1.93, to $41.30, after Kenneth Posner of Morgan Stanley said rising unemployment and bankruptcies could cause higher-than-expected credit losses. Mr. Posner lowered his rating on the shares to neutral from outperform.
Citigroup, the largest financial services company, declined 85 cents, to $49.80. General Electric dropped 48 cents, to $49.48. J. P. Morgan Chase slid $1.45, to $47.75.
Dell fell $1.08, to $24.83. The company, one of the biggest personal computer makers worldwide, said it would eliminate 3,000 to 4,000 jobs in the next six months, or about 10 percent of its work force.
Other computer producers also fell. Compaq lost 27 cents, to $16.83; Hewlett-Packard dropped 34 cents, to $27.33, Apple slid 39 cents, to $24.57; and Gateway declined 35 cents, to $18.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing dropped $1.54, to $116.36. The chief executive, James McNerney, said at the company's annual meeting that there were "no signs" the global economy would improve anytime soon.
Shares of Cablevision Systems dropped $4.70, to $59.80, and Comcast lost $1.10, to $43.65, after the cable television companies said they would spend more to finish upgrading their systems for digital TV.
Carter-Wallace fell $2.57, to $19.99, after it agreed to split up and sell itself in pieces for $1.12 billion. Carter-Wallace's consumer division, which produces Arrid deodorant among other things, will go to a venture that includes Church & Dwight, while its health business will be sold to MedPointe Capital Partners.
Genesis Microchip, a maker of chips that process video and graphic images, rose $3.84, to $18.99. The company reported a loss of 15 cents a share in its fiscal fourth quarter, a penny narrower than forecast.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Flaws in Voucher Findings

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
WITH education high on the national agenda, some scholars have been tempted to publish sensational but premature conclusions. These can exploit policy makers' inability to distinguish simplistic analyses from those that stand up to closer examination.
 This was apparently the case with an analysis of Florida's voucher program, published in February by the conservative Manhattan Institute. The author, Jay P. Greene, a former University of Texas professor and now a Harvard researcher, concluded that Florida scores showed schools "rising to the challenge of vouchers." On the eve of Congressional debate over President Bush's plan to give students at low-performing schools federal money for private school tuition vouchers, Dr. Greene announced that Mr. Bush's proposal would work as well. 
 "That's not a theory," Dr. Greene stated, "but proven fact."
In Florida, schools are rated A, B, C, D or F. If a school gets a second F in four years, its students can get state vouchers for private school tuition. Dr. Greene concluded that this makes public schools improve.
His method was creative. He reasoned that schools in the bottom of the D category were very similar to those in the top of the F category. He showed that after failing one time, higher-scoring F schools posted greater gains than lower-scoring D schools. Because these schools were otherwise alike, Dr. Greene stated that a threat of vouchers must have made F schools improve more rapidly.
His claims garnered extensive press coverage, but his report made no mention of having been submitted, before publication, to experts expected to express caution or even doubt about the results. Such review is normal for academic studies where complex statistics or extraordinary claims are involved. 
Had Dr. Greene's report undergone this process, nonpartisan scholars might well have suggested an obvious natural experiment to test his conclusions. Other states also rate schools, but threaten nonvoucher interventions for failure. If in these states, schools labeled failures improved rapidly when vouchers were not threatened, it would suggest that vouchers did not cause Florida's more recent gains.
Indeed, before 1999, Florida itself already grouped schools by test scores, but students in the lowest category did not get vouchers. Douglas Harris, an economist at the liberal Economic Policy Institute, analyzed the earlier Florida data. Dr. Harris found that before 1999, higher-scoring schools in the failing group also gained more than lower-scoring schools in the next group. The subsequent voucher policy apparently had no added effect.
Others have tested this elsewhere. At Duke University, Prof. Helen F. Ladd and Elizabeth J. Glennie, a researcher, examined North Carolina's accountability plan. There, schools are ranked "exemplary," "meets expectations," "no recognition" or "low performing." Low-performing schools are not given vouchers; instead, state experts intervene to improve the schools.
Dr. Ladd and Dr. Glennie found that as in Florida, higher-scoring schools in the bottom group gained more than lower-scoring schools in the next group. The researchers concluded that Dr. Greene's Florida results "probably have little or nothing to do with vouchers." If vouchers explained Florida gains, "it is unlikely we would have found comparable patterns" in North Carolina.
Texas has a similar system. There, too, students in failing schools do not get vouchers, but state experts intervene.
Scholars at the Charles A. Dana Center at the University of Texas have frequently defended the state's system against partisan attacks by critics of President Bush when he was governor. So it is noteworthy that a Dana Center analyst, Amanda Brownson, challenged Dr. Greene's conclusions by applying his method to Texas scores.
As in Florida and North Carolina, Ms. Brownson found that higher performing schools in the failing category posted greater gains than lower-performing schools in the next-to-bottom group.
These studies of North Carolina, Texas and earlier Florida scores are being published by the Economic Policy Institute, together with a summary by Martin Carnoy, a Stanford University professor. Dr. Carnoy speculates that these studies, along with Dr. Greene's, may only show a "scarlet letter" effect. Being termed failing is embarrassing and motivates schools to improve, whether vouchers or other interventions follow.
As education debates get more politicized, special burdens are placed upon scholars and the public. Academics ought to resist the temptation to publish hurried findings, even though exciting results assure easy publicity. And nonscholarly audiences should be more wary of researchers who fail to discipline themselves in this way.

HEADLINE: Liberties; 
Donna, Prima Donna

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
After I saw "Town and Country," the strenuously libidinous comedy with Warren Beatty, Goldie Hawn and Diane Keaton, I was walking out behind three teenage girls.
 "Boring," said one. 
 "Cheating is so boring," agreed the second.
"Totally," yawned the third.
In a movie column in The Los Angeles Times yesterday, Patrick Goldstein said that "Town and Country" seemed dated by a quarter-century, underscoring the fact that sex farces with wife-swapping and breathless batrachian grapplings are a defunct genre in Hollywood. 
"The more commonplace sex has become in our culture, the less of a place it has in our movies," he wrote. "Sexual humor needs sexual repression to work its magic." 
Maybe because politics is one of the few spheres of life still steeped in sexual repression, it is also one of the few where the Feydeau-style sex farce still thrives, complete with angry wives storming in one door as agile mistresses scoot out another.
First we had the Bill, Hillary and Monica production of "What's New, Pussycat?" Then the Newt, Marianne and Callista version of "School for Scandal." Now we have yet another act of Rudy, Donna and Judi in "The Confounded Husband."
Donna Hanover has asked a judge to issue an order barring Judi Nathan, the mayor's "paramour," as Donna people refer to her, from Gracie Mansion.
"The paramour came into the house," one Donna ally says. "It's appalling. What kind of a woman behaves like this?" A veteran Donna watcher agrees: "She can't have this hussy chasing her out of her own house." 
It's a perfect New York saga of desire and real estate: the mayor and his wife locked in a titanic twilight struggle over a house they don't even own.
Ms. Hanover's legal maneuver against her husband is a brazen bid to control the ultimate control freak.
Her lawyers are arguing that Gracie Mansion is "the marital residence" and not a public facility. It's a tricky argument, given that Ms. Hanover is chairwoman of the Gracie Mansion Conservancy, which protects the house as a public institution.
She apparently does not want her two children -- Andrew, 15, and Caroline, 11 -- to meet Ms. Nathan until after they move out of Gracie Mansion when the mayor's term ends. 
"If the court ruled that Gracie Mansion was a private home, it would set a dangerous precedent," says Raoul Felder, the mayor's divorce lawyer. "What about all future mayors who would now have to think that they're living there at their wives' pleasure?"
The mayor and his wife are not legally separated, but they have begun divorce proceedings. They have been estranged for several years and the mayor has been dating Ms. Nathan, a sales manager for Bristol-Myers Squibb, for two years, taking her to so many parades and other public events that she now has her own police protection. He has been staying in the guest room for the last year, pals say.
"He can't invite his lady friend to the public part of the house? It's absurd," Mr. Felder says. "Judith Nathan has been at a handful of events in the public part, but she has never been in the private quarters."
Even though Rudy and Donna barely speak and have to negotiate every move -- including the mayor's trip with his son to the White House last week to hang out with President Bush and the Yankees -- she has continued to enjoy her perch as first lady, attending panels, shivas, wakes and the premiere of "The Producers." 
But as Mr. Felder dryly points out, "There is no title called First Lady of New York."
A Donna person explains that Ms. Hanover wants to stay in Gracie Mansion "for the stability of the kids, so that the kids can have their own rooms," and because she can't move back into the Giuliani apartment on East 86th Street because it is sublet until the end of the year.
"I'll happily be her rental agent," Mr. Felder says. "It's a recession. There are a lot of apartments available in New York. There comes a time we all have to get a life."
Even if her husband humiliated her, the house goes with his job. And why would you want your kids to live in the corner of a triangle? Ms. Hanover should gracefully vacate the premises.
It's time for her to say "Good night, Gracie Mansion."

HEADLINE: In Study of Nation's Worst Traffic, New York Must Yield 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 8 

 BODY:
The drivers of the South and the West, squirming ever longer in their upholstered commutes to work, can take perverse pleasure in a validation of their suffering. Just as they had always suspected, they had it worse -- much worse -- than the eight million residents of New York City.
 From Seattle to Los Angeles, and around the horn to Houston and Atlanta, drivers learned this week that they wasted much more of their time in road delays than New Yorkers did, according to a national mobility study by the Texas Transportation Institute, a research agency connected to Texas A&M University. 
 Where the average resident of those metropolitan areas loses more than 50 hours a year to traffic delays, New Yorkers lose an average of 34 hours a year, the study found. This put the nation's largest city in the unusual position of coming in 23rd in something unpleasant. (Los Angeles, of course, was the enduring emblem of vehicular immobility.) 
"They don't even know what traffic is in New York," said Gary Hudgins, a truck driver for Fulton County, taking a break at a gasoline station here this morning. "I've spent entire days of my life in traffic jams here, more times than I can count. I'd like to see a New Yorker come down here and try to deal with I-285 every day."
Of course, many New Yorkers would beg to differ, particularly the ones honking right now at the entrance to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, or the ones who don't know they are about to spend an hour on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway because of some taxi's boiling radiator. They might point out that, of course, their traffic, averaged among eight million people, would be less than that of a city like Nashville, which came in 10th on the list, up from 21 the year before. With 40 percent of the New York region using mass transit to get to work, of course, they might look better on paper than cities with barely a bus system.
And they would, in a sense, be right.
"Yeah, it's true that the benefits all those people get by taking transit aren't really factored into the study," said Tim Lomax, a transportation research engineer who was co-author of the study. "And the bigger cities wind up with lower congestion levels, because their congested cores are diluted by suburban areas."
But they would also be wrong. Residents of the post-war South and West do not need a study to tell them that they are spending more time in their cars. They do not need to be reminded that with few sidewalks in their residential developments, they have to turn on their motors just to pick up a carton of milk.
"You get off in the afternoon, you're worn out as it is, and then you have to face the traffic, sometimes for an hour -- it just adds insult to injury," said Frank Bennett, owner of a learning center in Marietta, a suburb of Atlanta. Mr. Bennett switched careers in part because of his commute. "That's time that is basically taken directly away from your family."
Bill Miller, a political consultant in Austin, Tex., which is No. 7 on the delays-per-person list, described his daily strategy this way: "Know the short-cuts, leave early and stay late -- these are your only three options and even those don't always work."
Congestion in the Sun Belt has largely been the unintended result of a conscious choice by many residents to live in low-density neighborhoods far from commercial and employment centers. Many newcomers to the region were escaping the high densities of the Northeast, but it was those densities that justified the investments in transit that New York began making more than a century ago, and which, at least in studies like this one, continue to pay dividends.
"Transit has a huge amount to do with New York's showing," said Roy Kienitz, executive director of the Surface Transportation Policy Project, a research group that put out a parallel study on Monday estimating that New York City's congestion level was actually 68th in the nation, behind even Albany's. "There are many reasons why transit does not work too well in newer cities, mostly because of the growth policies they've pursued."
But even with millions of people in New York using mass transit every day, plenty of drivers stuck in traffic were convinced that New York should be at the top of any list of congested areas.
"Impossible!" was the immediate response of Ralph Morales when he was told of the Texas transportation study. Mr. Morales navigates his worn cream-colored Plymouth all over the city every day to bring deodorizing equipment to restaurants, "We should be in the top three at least. Nothing less than that."
Jerry Oleske had a similar response as he tried to make his way from Lower Manhattan through the Holland Tunnel to his home in Madison, N.J., this evening. 
"It will take me an hour and a half to get to Morris County from here," said Mr. Oleske, a lawyer who rides a a crimson and cream Valkyrie motorcycle. Without traffic, he said, it takes a little over a half-hour. "If there are cities with traffic worse than this, I wouldn't want to live in any of them."
The Texas study is mostly car-oriented, enhancing the prominence of car-oriented cities on its list. Although it studied the effect that transit has on the roads by removing thousands of vehicles, it said nothing about the commutes of people who took rail transit every day, as Mr. Lomax acknowledged. That number is huge in New York, Boston and Chicago, but most newer cities have been reluctant to spend money on rail lines.
Thus, New York has 21 times the total hours of traffic delays of Nashville, but per-person, Nashville's delays are 23 percent greater than New York's, because almost everyone in Nashville drives. Nashville has been talking about a commuter rail system to cope with the growth of its suburban counties, two of which grew by more than 50 percent during the 1990's. But last year, one Nashville neighborhood refused to accept a rail station, saying it would increase traffic on local streets. Planners are less than amused by these paradoxes.
"There's no way we can build enough roads to take care of this problem," said Maynard Pate, executive director of the Greater Nashville Regional Council, which coordinates multicounty mass transit programs. "We need to tailor our development to reduce congestion in the future."
The economic growth that led to such congestion has itself been stymied by the traffic. Barbara Marks, a recruiter for Questalent, an executive recruiting company in Atlanta, said she frequently had to persuade executives in the Northeast that the traffic was not as bad as they had heard, and she said some just were not convinced. Business leaders and environmental groups have joined forces in several states to lobby for "smart growth" policies and transit projects, and there are signs that a traffic backlash has increased the growth of many urban cores.
But the study showed that congestion was generally getting worse in every size city and that it was unlikely that any amount of investment would ever bring a Los Angeles, a Houston or a Denver down to New York's level on the Texas survey. Which, whether they admit it or not, is just the way many people like it.
"People take this weird pride in saying they've got the worst traffic," Mr. Kienitz, the transit policy researcher, said. "They want to be able to dine out on how bad their commute is, and if the statistics don't bear them out, they just feel cheated."

HEADLINE: After 6 Years, First-Quarter Productivity Fell in U.S. 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers, which rose sharply as new technologies took hold and served as the great source of prosperity in the late 1990's, fell in the first quarter for the first time in six years.
 The decline of 0.1 percent, the Labor Department reported yesterday, reflected the sagging economy, particularly weakness in manufacturing. Output, in effect, rose more slowly than the number of hours worked, making labor less productive. 
 The surprising weakness reopened the debate among economists over how much of the heralded productivity revival of recent years will endure. 
"There seems to be a sustained rise in productivity," said Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis. "The still unanswered question is how much will last and how much will turn out to be cyclical."
Unit labor costs -- the amount of labor expense to produce, say, a pair of shoes or a computer -- rose sharply in the first quarter. Americans produced more goods and services than they had previously, but they were paid more and worked even longer hours to do so. As a result, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated, labor costs rose at a 5.2 percent annual rate. 
For now, the Federal Reserve is expected to focus on the slowing economy, continuing to cut interest rates until growth revives. But over the long run, weak productivity would put pressure on employers to raise prices, stoking inflation.
The squeeze on profits from higher costs is prompting employers everywhere to cut hours, eliminate overtime and shed workers through layoffs. That process is expected to continue for a while, increasing unemployment and making workers more fearful about the future.
But as that plays out, the productivity growth rate is likely to rise again.
"The collapse in the first quarter is 90 percent a temporary phenomenon," Mr. Varvares said.
Productivity measures the average output of the nation's work force in a period of time. If 10 factory workers, for example, produced 102.8 bathrobes an hour, on average, up from 100 the year before, then their productivity growth rate would be 2.8 percent.
That, in fact, has been the average annual improvement since 1995, when the boom got rolling. But over the last three quarters, as the economy has slowed, so has productivity -- from 3 percent in the summer quarter to 2 percent in the fall to minus 0.1 percent this winter.
Much of the collapse came in manufacturing, where the annualized productivity growth rate was a meager 0.3 percent, far below its usual vigorous performance as the economy's most efficient sector. The first-quarter downturn in manufacturing was concentrated in computer production, which had contributed mightily to the national productivity revival as the speed and power of computers has advanced.
Given its importance, productivity gets surprisingly little attention in the array of economic statistics issued each month. But when productivity rises, the extra revenue generated can be added to wages or profits or both. Or the higher quality -- the faster computers, for example -- enhance the productivity of workers who use computers, and thus the national income.
On the other hand, when productivity weakens or falls, as it did in the first quarter, then profits and wages are squeezed. Employers react by either raising prices -- difficult to do in a slowing economy -- or cutting costs, often through layoffs.
"No matter how fast businesses have tried to adjust, they just have not been able to keep up with the slowing economy," said Joel L. Naroff, an economic consultant.
Employers in fact shed an estimated 223,000 jobs in April -- the largest number since the last recession a decade ago -- and the unemployment rate rose to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent. 
For the longer term, the pace of productivity has profound consequences. Future budget surpluses, for example, may fall short of the $5.6 trillion projected by the Congressional Budget Office over the next 10 years if productivity fails to rise at the 2.7 percent annual rate the agency expects.
"Let's say productivity averages only 2 percent a year instead of 2.7 percent," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist. "That shrinks the surplus by $1.7 trillion."
The first-quarter productivity decline -- the first since an 0.8 percent decline in the first quarter of 1995 -- focused attention on a subject of endless debate among economists: whether information technology has lifted the American worker to a permanently higher level of productivity and efficiency -- and that after nearly a quarter-century of sluggish productivity growth averaging only 1.3 percent a year.
Nearly everyone's answer is yes. Computers, the Internet, advanced software and all the other trappings of the information age have made workers more efficient. But part of the revival since 1995 is cyclical -- a result, for example, of workers pushing themselves to fill the flood of new orders, and employers running factories more efficiently than they normally would.
Mr. Varvares and many others argue that the productivity growth rate will settle in at 2.5 to 3 percent a year, while Mr. Gordon says the long-term growth will be closer to 2 percent, with most of that coming from the use of computers. 
"I will not take the ultrapessimistic view that all of the productivity gains are going to disappear as the economy slows," said Mr. Gordon, who had been the chief spokesman for just that point of view until recently, "but some of it will."

HEADLINE: California Utility Accuses El Paso of Inflating Gas Prices 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and LOWELL BERGMAN 

 BODY:
One of California's struggling utility companies accused the El Paso Corporation yesterday of artificially inflating the price of natural gas in the state by $3.7 billion over the last year by using its partial control of a major pipeline to curtail the flow of gas. 
 In a filing with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the utility, Southern California Edison, said that market manipulation by El Paso had cost Edison alone at least an extra $1 billion for electricity generated by gas-fueled power plants over the 13 months ended March 31. 
 The commission is reviewing a complaint by California regulators that a chief reason for the state's soaring natural gas prices during the last year was market manipulation by El Paso, which owns the largest pipeline connecting Southern California with gas-producing regions in the Southwest. 
In a response, also filed yesterday, an El Paso subsidiary said that the high prices for gas in California came from "unexpected and unprecedented demand and an insufficient supply infrastructure," not from withholding of supply. California's energy problems, the company said, reflect "more than a decade's worth of bad public policy decisions that are now coming back to haunt the state." 
"This was a car wreck waiting to happen," said Joseph Kalt, a Harvard economics professor working on the case for El Paso. Mr. Kalt attributed the high prices to a severe shortage of pipeline capacity and resistance over the years by California officials to build more.
Southern California Edison, which is supporting the state's complaint, said its claims were based on records that it recently obtained as part of the discovery process in the federal proceeding. 
The controversy stems from a deal in February 2000 in which one El Paso subsidiary, El Paso Natural Gas, sold a sister company, El Paso Merchant Energy, the right to ship 1.2 billion cubic feet of gas a day on the pipeline. That is about 30 percent of the pipeline's total capacity and about one-sixth of California's daily demand. 
In March, the F.E.R.C. ruled that there was nothing improper in the deal between the two El Paso units but ordered further investigation into whether the company had manipulated the gas market in California. State regulators say that the price paid for gas at the California end of El Paso's pipeline plays a large role in setting the price for all gas sold in the state -- and, consequently, is a primary component in the cost of electricity and heating. 
According to sealed documents that are part of filings in the federal proceedings, El Paso Merchant executives said in internal memorandums that the unit's deal for capacity on the pipeline would give it "more control" of gas markets, including the "ability to influence the physical market" to benefit the company's financial positions. El Paso officials, citing a protective order prohibiting parties from discussing the sealed documents, have declined to comment on the documents except to say they have been taken out of context. 
In Southern California Edison's filing yesterday, the Brattle Group, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., hired by the utility, said that El Paso Merchant "withheld significant amounts of capacity from the market" between June and November of last year. 
During that period, the consultants said, El Paso Merchant used just 53 percent of the capacity it controlled on the pipeline that goes into the delivery system operated by the Southern California Gas unit of Sempra Energy, even though it would have been profitable to use more capacity. Other shippers made "significantly greater" use of the capacity they controlled through contracts with El Paso Natural Gas, the consultants said.
In its filing yesterday, Edison also attributed some blame to Southern California Gas -- a utility that provides gas service to homes and businesses across Southern California -- saying it did not store enough natural gas last year in preparation for the winter heating season. 
In its response yesterday, El Paso Merchant stated that it had "consistently made an effort to maintain high utilization" of the pipeline capacity. However, operational, service and scheduling restrictions pose an obstacle to that, while "credit, or the risk of not getting paid for the gas, is an important consideration."
On the portions of the pipeline capacity that are not hemmed in by special restrictions, Mr. Kalt said, El Paso Merchant, since June, has consistently offered more than 95 percent of its unused capacity to other shippers on terms consistent with the rest of the industry.
He said the numbers Edison cited were extremely misleading because they did not account for the restrictions imposed on El Paso Merchant's capacity. "To put out numbers like that, and not tell people that you are comparing apples and oranges, is misleading and diverts attention away from the real problems California faces," he said. 
Denise King, a spokeswoman for Southern California Gas, said that the company had met its obligation to serve its core residential and small-business customers. Some large industrial customers and power generators that hold storage capacity on the company's system did not store as much gas as they could have last year, she said, but that was their decision. 
Beginning in November, prices began to soar at the California border, and by early December the difference between the price of gas in Texas and its spot price at the California border -- known as the basis differential -- peaked at almost $50 per million British thermal units, or more than five times what gas cost in other parts of the country. (One million B.T.U.'s roughly equals 1,000 cubic feet of gas.) 
According to Edison's consultants, had El Paso Merchant fully used its capacity last year, and had Southern California Gas properly filled its core storage inventory, the gas market would have been considerably less constrained. Instead, El Paso Merchant's withholding of capacity increased the basis differential an average of $8.28 per million B.T.U.'s from December to March, according to Edison's filing. 
In all, the Brattle Group concluded that El Paso Merchant overcharged customers by at least $864.3 million on sales of gas at the California border during the 13-month period, only part of the $3.7 billion in higher costs that have affected California over all, the consultants said, because of El Paso Merchant's actions and the lack of gas storage that resulted.
El Paso Merchant denies that it has reaped large profits from the pipeline capacity, saying it has entered into hedging transactions that limited its risk but also its potential profit from rising gas prices in California. Mr. Kalt, for example, said that during December -- when the average basis differential was $17 per million B.T.U.'s -- El Paso Merchant's average differential on natural gas it sold into California was $3.04, after offsetting hedging losses.
"When the price spiked, they weren't going to capture that spike," Mr. Kalt said. "It's the most misleading part of Edison's case." 
El Paso Merchant also said prices for natural gas sold into California had not come down, even though the company decided earlier this year to relinquish the controversial pipeline capacity, which, after the end of May, will mostly be controlled by other companies. Prices actually rose after this was disclosed, the company's filing stated, and "this outcome is the opposite of what would have been expected" if the market believed El Paso Merchant had been trying to manipulate prices higher in California by restricting supply.
