HEADLINE: Sotheby's 20th-Century Art Auction Fetches $54 Million 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Despite the rocky economy, when the prices are right and the material is top notch, the art market rallies with stunning vigor. 
 Sotheby's York Avenue salesroom in Manhattan was a bidding battleground last night with record prices being made as paintings by artists like Francis Bacon, Max Beckmann and Joan Miro were seriously fought over by multiple bidders. 
 The atmosphere could not have been more different than the one at Monday evening's auction when Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg held its sale of Impressionist and modern art and, for the most part, the salesroom was dead, leaving 15 of the 41 works unsold. 
But the ingredients of last night's sale were just right. The 62 works were mostly 20th-century art collected over 50 years by Stanley J. Seeger, a reclusive American who lives in London. In the art world Mr. Seeger's name is instantly recognizable. Heir to a family fortune from lumber and petroleum, he is a quiet collector who buys millions of dollars' worth of art while keeping a low profile. Most pieces for sale last night were bought by him in the 1980's. 
As a collector Mr. Seeger does things on instinct, and in 1993 he became a celebrity of sorts. Just when the art market was in the doldrums, he decided to sell a group of 88 Picassos representing 13 years of collecting. Before the sale at Sotheby's in New York, naysayers said the auction house was taking a big risk by flooding the market with Picassos, which could drive prices down. But just the opposite happened. Every Picasso sold, many for double their estimates at a sale that totaled $32 million.
Last night's sale was another triumph. Of the works offered, only three failed to sell. The sale totaled $54 million, soaring above its $39 million high estimate. Sotheby's experts purposely kept estimates low to encourage bidding.
The evening's superstar was a triptych by Bacon, "Studies of the Human Body" (1979), in which the artist grapples with his obsession with Michelangelo. Five bidders tried hard to buy the triptych, which sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $8.5 million, a record for the artist and well above the work's $6 million high estimate. 
Miro's "Nocturne" brought another high price. One in a series of 23 gouaches called "The Constellations" painted from January 1940 to September 1941, the dream-inspired composition is an intricate field with many of the artist's signature forms. The work was bought by Robert Mnuchin, chairman of C & M Arts, a Manhattan gallery, for $5.6 million, a record price for a work on paper by the artist and way above its $3.5 million high estimate. In 1983 Mr. Seeger bought the Miro for $361,800 at Sotheby's in London.
(Final prices include Sotheby's commission: 20 percent of the first $15,000, 15 percent of the next $85,000 and 10 percent of any amount over $100,000. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
A painting of the Greek mythological heros Perseus and Hercules by Beckmann was another favorite. Martin Zimet of French & Company, a Manhattan dealer, bought it for a record $3.8 million, more than four times its high $900,000 estimate. (Tomorrow night Sotheby's is to auction a rare Beckmann self-portrait that is expected to bring between $7 million and $10 million. Judging from the appetite for works by the artist, the painting is expected to easily top last night's record price.)
In some cases prices have soared since Mr. Seeger bought many of the artworks. Two small paintings by Jasper Johns made a return on the collector's investment. "Colored Alphabet" (1959), an example of one of his Jasper Johns's signature images, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $3.7 million, nicely above its $3 million high estimate. Mr. Seeger paid $3.5 million for it at Christie's in New York in 1989, during the height of the market.
Another Johns, "Green Target" (1958), sold to a telephone buyer for $643,750, between its $500,000 to $700,000 estimate but far more than the $392,000 Mr. Seeger paid for it at Sotheby's in London in 1994. 
A Braque cubist still life circa 1913, "Glass, Pipe and Newspaper," sold for its high estimate, $2 million. At Sotheby's in London in 1986, Mr. Seeger paid $758,620 for the work, one in a series painted on oval canvases suggesting tabletops and using Braque's signature stencil-type lettering evoking a newspaper.
A Picasso "Seated Woman" saw six bidders willing to happily spend far more than $1.5 million. An abstract image from 1939, it depicts his mistress Dora Maar wearing a bright red hat and seated in an armchair. Mr. Seeger bought it in 1996, also at Sotheby's in London for $1.4 million. 
The sale included many works on paper. Among the top fliers was a three-quarter view of a man's back from 1910 by Egon Schiele. Estimated at $300,000 to $400,000, it sold for a whopping $907,750 to an unidentified bidder standing in the back of the salesroom. Mr. Seeger bought it for $165,000 at Sotheby's in 1986.
After the sale Tobias Meyer, the director of Sotheby's contemporary art department worldwide, said the secret to the auction's success was that Mr. Seeger trusted him to price the sale. "It's the glorious and rare combination of beautiful things at conservative estimates," Mr. Meyer said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Miro's "Nocturne" (1940) sold for a record $5.6 million at Sotheby's. (Sotheby's)

HEADLINE: Despite Denial, Torricelli Aided In Donor's Deal 

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN and DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
Soon after Senator Robert G. Torricelli began his relationship with David Chang, the wealthy political contributor who says he gave the senator unreported gifts and cash, Mr. Torricelli intervened in an international business deal to help Mr. Chang recover a debt of more than $70 million.
 Mr. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, has repeatedly denied helping Mr. Chang, who was seeking payment for grain he had shipped on credit to the government of North Korea. Last year, Mr. Torricelli's office said he had refused to support one of Mr. Chang's appeals on the matter because it would have violated the senator's strong belief in the need to isolate "rogue regimes." 
 But on Sept. 22, 1995, while Mr. Torricelli was still in the House of Representatives and was an influential member of its Foreign Affairs Committee, he wrote to North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations, warning that his country's failure to repay Mr. Chang could imperil any hopes it might have for better relations with the United States. 
"I hope you will join me in trying to resolve this issue so that there will be no matters standing in the path of the expanding U.S. trade and investment in North Korea," Mr. Torricelli wrote to the diplomat, Park Gil Yoon, according to a copy of the letter obtained by The New York Times.
The appeal produced no apparent results for Mr. Chang, who continued for several more years to seek help with the problem from Mr. Torricelli and other politicians. But the letter, which has also been obtained by federal prosecutors who are investigating Mr. Torricelli's activities, could be significant to any effort to charge him with taking illegal gifts.
Under federal law, gratuities to a public official are illegal only when they are given in exchange for a specific official action, whether that action is taken or merely promised. Since a 1999 Supreme Court ruling that raised the threshold of proof in such cases, legal experts have continued to debate how close a connection must be established.
Lawyers and aides to Mr. Torricelli have insisted that he never helped Mr. Chang try to recover the debt, which the businessman estimated at $71 million. They have also suggested that it would have been implausible for the senator to promise any help because his staff had quickly determined that there was nothing he could do to solve the problem.
But in statements to investigators, Mr. Chang has said Mr. Torricelli told him again and again in the three years after the letter was written that he was taking or would take further steps in the matter, people involved in the case said. At least two other witnesses in the case have told the authorities that they, too, heard Mr. Torricelli make such assurances, these people said. 
According to people involved in the case, Mr. Chang has told investigators that he gave the gifts in an effort to ingratiate himself with the senator that was motivated primarily by his North Korean debt problem. He said the gifts included an $8,100 Rolex watch, Italian suits, a large-screen television set and tens of thousands of dollars in cash. Other witnesses, including several New Jersey merchants, have corroborated at least some aspects of Mr. Chang's account, these people said.
Mr. Torricelli has not denied taking gifts from Mr. Chang, but said that he took no "illegal gifts" and that Mr. Chang was once his friend.
Senate ethics rules, which prohibit legislators or their aides from accepting expensive gifts, make a limited exception for gifts received from friends of long standing when they are publicly disclosed.
A lawyer for Mr. Torricelli, Ted Wells, declined to comment on the discrepancy between the contents of Mr. Torricelli's letter and the earlier assurances of the senator and his staff that he had done nothing to help Mr. Chang with the debt.
"This letter appears to be a routine constituent request from a local businessman and is similar to letters written for Mr. Chang by other members of Congress on the same issue," Mr. Wells said.
At least 10 other legislators -- including former Senators Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York -- wrote similar letters to senior North Korean officials between November 1995 and February 1996, according to copies of those letters.
Mr. Chang has been cooperating with the government since pleading guilty last June to obstructing justice and to campaign finance violations. His lawyer, Bradley D. Simon, said he could not comment on Mr. Torricelli's letter.
Marvin Smilon, a spokesman for the office of the United States attorney in Manhattan, which is handling the case, also declined to comment.
Mr. Chang turned to Mr. Torricelli for help in the summer of 1995, associates of both men said. At that point, court records show, Mr. Chang had been trying for more than two years to win repayment from the North Koreans for tons of corn and wheat he had shipped to the country in the early 1990's and was coming under growing pressure from creditors.
Mr. Chang had also been trying, without success, to persuade the Clinton administration to compensate him from a pool of $15 million in North Korean assets frozen by the United States. Mr. Torricelli, who had long been interested in Korean affairs, was encouraging, Mr. Chang has said.
Not long after meeting the businessman, Mr. Torricelli ordered his staff to draft the letter. According to one of his senior aides at the time, he became incensed when he found out one afternoon that it had not yet been completed. 
"Bob went ballistic," said the former aide, Georgianna Evans, who resigned a few months later. "He was screaming, 'I want this letter sent out now! This guy can be valuable to us!' "
The one-page letter, written on Congressional stationery, began: "As diplomatic and economic relations improve between our two countries, it is important that we resolve any pending financial matters. In that vein, I would like your assistance in settling a debt owed by North Korea to Nikko Enterprises."
Mr. Torricelli noted that the company, which was owned by Mr. Chang, was in his district and had been the first in the United States to win a license to trade with North Korea. "Settling any debt owed to them is of particular importance," he wrote. "Other U.S. companies seeking to trade with North Korea will naturally turn to Nikko Enterprises for advice and to hear of their experiences." 
Mr. Torricelli offered to meet with the ambassador, but Mr. Wells would not comment on whether he ever did. A spokesman for the North Korean Mission to the United Nations, Hong Je Ryong, said he had no information about the matter.
The possibility that Mr. Torricelli intervened in the debt problem was first raised in April 2000 in a document filed by prosecutors. The document stated that Mr. Chang had "received and/or solicited" the senator's help on four matters: the North Korean debt, Mr. Chang's attempt to buy a $1.5 billion life insurance company in South Korea, letters of introduction for business associates, and a college recommendation letter for a friend.
One of Mr. Torricelli's lawyers, Abbe D. Lowell, denied that the senator had assisted Mr. Chang with any of those issues, calling the prosecutors' assertion "totally inaccurate" with respect to the senator's actions. 
Interviews with South Korean and United States officials and letters written by Mr. Torricelli show that the senator lobbied extensively in 1998 and 1999 in support of Mr. Chang's attempt to buy the South Korean insurance company. Mr. Chang has told investigators that he promised Mr. Torricelli a $10 million commission if his bid for the insurer was successful, people involved in the case said.
In a statement last fall, Mr. Torricelli's office said he refused to help Mr. Chang when one of his lawyers had sought a letter endorsing the businessman's claim to part of the frozen North Korean assets. A handful of other legislators, both Republicans and Democrats, did write such letters for Mr. Chang at the request of one of his lobbyists and business associates, former Representative James A. Courter, a New Jersey Republican.
The statement by Mr. Torricelli's office referred to his ardent support for the United States embargo against Cuba: "The senator is one of the strongest voices in Congress supporting the use of economic embargoes and the freezing of assets against rogue regimes. He believed that such a letter was inconsistent with his policy and would not participate, even for a New Jersey company and contributor."
Legal experts said that if Mr. Torricelli were charged with taking illegal gratuities from Mr. Chang, it might be useful to his defense if he could show that he never acted on the businessman's behalf.
"Formally raising the issue with the North Koreans and even making a minimal effort to help Chang would probably give prosecutors enough of a nexus to charge him under the statute," William B. Canfield, a Republican lawyer and former counsel to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics, said of Mr. Torricelli.
According to documents from Mr. Torricelli's 1996 Senate campaign, he did not wait long to test Mr. Chang's potential value to his cause. On Sept. 26, four days after the letter was written, his staff contacted Mr. Chang to see if he would be host to a gathering to raise funds for the campaign. The event was held that December at the Fort Lee Hilton hotel, which Mr. Chang had owned.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
FAB INDUSTRIES, MAKEROF TEXTILES, WILL SHUT 2 FACTORIES

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Fab Industries Inc., whose textiles are used to make sleepwear, sportswear and intimate apparel, will close two factories and eliminate about 150 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, to cut costs. 
The company will close the Travis Knits plant in Cherryville, N.C., and the Adirondack Knitting factory in Amsterdam, N.Y., by the end of the year. The knitting, dyeing and finishing done at the two plants will be moved to the company's Mohican Mills plant in Lincolnton, N.C., the chief financial officer, David Miller, said. Fab Industries, based in New York, said the weak economy and competition from imports had reduced demand for its products.

HEADLINE: National Briefing South: South Carolina: State Budget Cuts Ordered 

BYLINE:  NYT 

 BODY:
 South Carolina's Budget and Control Board ordered a spending cut of 1 percent for most state services, including public schools, for the fiscal year that ends June 30. 
State economists blamed a stagnant first quarter, high tax refunds, and open-ended legislative commitments to property tax cuts and college scholarships. State law requires the board, whose chairman is Gov. Jim Hodges, to make cuts when revenue lags. The $48 million in cuts came as lawmakers debated how to cut $500 million from the budget for the year that begins July 1.

HEADLINE: Surging Prices Of Natural Gas Aid BP's Profit 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 8 

 BODY:
BP P.L.C., the world's third-largest oil company, said today that high natural gas prices in the United States along with BP's American acquisitions pushed its first-quarter profit to $4.12 billion, up about 52 percent from the period a year earlier.
 The figure was at the high end of forecasts, but it fell short of the $4.23 billion that some analysts had expected. The company's shares, which ended the day down 1.8 percent, slipped as much as 2.7 percent in an otherwise flat market for energy companies as analysts weighed whether increased oil supplies in America would push down prices. 
 "The place to be has been the U.S. because of natural gas and refining margins," said Steve Turner, an analyst with Commerzbank in London. "BP has been a big beneficiary of that." Now, Mr. Turner said, natural gas prices have "seen their winter peak and they will get a seasonal effect, dragging down gas prices."
Additionally, he said, many oil industry experts "are assuming a fallback in oil prices." Every dollar decline in the price of crude oil costs BP some $400 million a year in net profits, Mr. Turner said.
Sir John Browne, BP's chief executive, sought to play down the impact of falling prices.
"The trading environment remains broadly positive in spite of the slowdown in the world economy," Sir John said in a statement. "Oil and gas prices have fallen back from peak levels, but both are expected to remain firm."
For much of this year, investors favored BP stock because of its high exposure to the United States gas market, particularly after its purchase of Atlantic Richfield a year ago and its earlier acquisition of Amoco. Last year, almost half of BP's earnings came from the United States. BP, formerly BP Amoco, is the leading natural gas producer in North America.
The company's overall first-quarter results were adjusted to exclude one-time-only costs from acquisitions, and they assume that the oil reserves can be replaced at current prices.
Profits were buoyed by high gas prices, particularly in the United States, where, BP said, the benchmark price of $7.08 per million B.T.U. was almost three times the level of a year earlier. Globally, BP said, prices more than doubled in that time, averaging $4.96 per million B.T.U.
Among the challenges BP faces is to expand production, which the company has said will grow 5.5 percent to 7 percent annually. Excluding its acquisitions over the last year, however, BP's oil and gas production was virtually unchanged, growing around 2 percent from the fourth quarter of last year.
Doubts about BP's production growth, said Mr Turner at Commerzbank, stem from BP's heavy reliance on developing new oil fields in deep water in the Gulf of Mexico and off war-torn Angola.
Sir John insisted, however, that the company was "on track to achieve our announced targets, with higher reported production being a particular feature."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sir John Browne, the chief executive of BP, shown last August, said yesterday that he expected prices of oil and natural gas to remain firm. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
The Unrefined Truth

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices are rising again, and the administration is rushing to turn this into another argument for its drill-and-burn energy strategy. But a look at the causes of the current gasoline shortage actually suggests a quite different moral: namely, that conservation ought to be a major element in our energy strategy, and that lack of conservation is a large part of what we've been doing wrong. 
 First things first: This year's gasoline price spike has nothing to do with a shortage of crude oil. Even if we had already punched the Alaskan tundra and the ocean floor off Florida full of holes, we'd still be in the same fix. The binding constraint right now is the nation's limited capacity to refine crude oil into gasoline. 
 Why is refining capacity inadequate? No new refineries have been built in this country for 20 years, a point emphasized with obvious relish by Dick Cheney. His implicit subtext, of course, is that it's the fault of environmentalist types who stood in the oil industry's way. That must be the story, right? 
 Wrong. It's true that environmental rules have somewhat crimped the production of our existing refineries. The problem is not so much the strictness of the regulations as their lack of consistency: each region has its own rules -- like the insistence of Midwestern states that gasoline include corn-derived ethanol -- fragmenting the nation's production. But the reason the oil industry didn't build any new refineries for two decades was that they weren't needed. In fact, right up until last year oil refining was a persistently depressed business, plagued by overcapacity. 
 Here's what happened: In the wake of the energy crisis in the 1970's, ordinary people in the United States began conserving energy -- not as a "sign of personal virtue," as Mr. Cheney sneeringly puts it, but because they wanted to save money. Cars, in particular, became much more fuel-efficient. Meanwhile the oil industry was subject to "refinery creep," the tendency of refining capacity to grow through incremental improvements even when no new refineries are built. The result was excess capacity and squeezed margins, right up to the late 1990's. 
 What finally brought us up against capacity constraints was a surge in demand that was partly due to the economic boom of the later Clinton years, but mainly due to the renewed enthusiasm of Americans for huge, gas-guzzling vehicles -- an enthusiasm, er, fueled by cheap gas. In 1998 gasoline was cheaper compared with overall consumer prices than ever before in U.S. history -- 60 percent cheaper than it was in 1981. The nation rushed out to buy ever-bigger S.U.V.'s -- and then suddenly discovered that we had run out of refining capacity. Refiners weren't frustrated by rules that prevented them from building new facilities; they were simply caught by surprise.
 You have to bear this history in mind when parsing Mr. Cheney's recent speeches. To listen to him, you would imagine that we live in a country in which powerful political forces oppose energy production and preach a return to the dark ages. "To speak exclusively of conservation," Mr. Cheney declared in one speech, "is to duck the tough issues . . . it is not a sufficient basis -- all by itself -- for a sound, comprehensive energy policy." In another speech he ridiculed unspecified types for "saying to the American people that you have to live in the dark, turn out all of the lights." The story according to Mr. Cheney, in other words, is that we have an energy shortage because extreme conservationists prevented us from developing the supply capacity that serious people knew we needed.
 Need I point out that this, like so much of what one hears from this administration, is a cynical misrepresentation? I defy Mr. Cheney to come up with examples of influential people who "speak exclusively of conservation," let alone anyone who says to the American people that they have to live in the dark. In fact, hardly any important politicians have spoken about conservation at all -- never mind exclusively -- this past decade. 
 We will need to build more refineries -- and more power plants, and pipelines, and so on. But it is ludicrous to suggest that our current energy woes are the result of too much emphasis on conservation. It would be closer to the truth to say that we are in trouble now because our politicians haven't dared even use the word.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Telecommuting's Big Experiment

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
There is something quixotic about the quest of Representative Frank R. Wolf to encourage federal workers to stay out of the office more often.
 Mr. Wolf, a Virginia Republican and a vocal champion of telecommuting, conducts what he calls a field hearing on the subject twice every day, first on the drive to the Capitol from his home in Vienna, Va., in the morning, and then on the way home in the evening. And all too often, he does not like the results. 
 Last month, for example, he started at 8 a.m. to allow time to review his notes in his office before running a 10 a.m. hearing at which Secretary of State Colin L. Powell testified. Caught in heavy traffic, he arrived with 15 minutes to spare -- barely enough time to straighten his tie. 
"You've got federal employees driving 35 to 40 miles when they could be sitting in front of a laptop," he said. And his suburban Washington constituents, complain often about their commute. "It's a big issue for us here," he said.
So Mr. Wolf inserted a provision in the 2001 fiscal year appropriations bill for the Transportation Department, enacted last October, that requires every federal agency to give at least 25 percent of its eligible workers the option of working outside the office by this fall.
But reports from the alphabet soup of executive branch agencies on the status of their telecommuting programs, which had to be provided to the Office of Personnel Management last month, suggest that Mr. Wolf and several of his colleagues may be tilting at windmills.
It has been tough enough for companies in the private sector, where managers generally have more flexibility than government bureaucrats do to institute the practice. The number of telecommuters -- most on a sporadic basis -- has risen steadily over the last decade, to 23.6 million last year from 4 million in 1990, according to data collected by Joanne H. Pratt Associates, a Dallas firm that has studied telecommuting trends.
But the federal government is something else again. The figures speak for themselves. At the Justice Department, according to the agency's report to Office of Personnel Management on its telecommuting practices, only 581 employees regularly telecommute and 479 telecommute sporadically, out of 125,019 employees.
At the Interior Department, 1,450 out of 68,858 employees telecommute. Only 653 of the Energy Department's 14,461 employees telecommute. And at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, 385 out of about 9,000 employees telecommute weekly.
"They have a long way to go," said Trina L. Hoefling, owner of the Consult One Group, a Denver telecommuting consultant.
Why the slowness in adapting to the new economy? In part, recalcitrant managers and the initial cost of installing computers in employees' homes are at fault. But officials at various agencies have another excuse: the very nature of their mission often makes working at home anywhere from difficult to impossible.
Some agencies handle top-secret documents, like intelligence reports on foreign powers, for example, that cannot be taken home on a laptop that might be stolen. Lawyers for the Justice Department are frequently involved in highly sensitive litigation, drawing on documents that while not classified, would typically be kept confidential. Justice employees who work at prisons generally need to do their work on the premises. And Treasury Department employees who work for the Secret Service; the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms; or other law enforcement agencies, might be hard-pressed to capture many violent criminals while working from home.
"We have a number of employees who do national security work who work daily with classified material," said Lisa Cutler, a spokeswoman for the Energy Department. "Those are things we are continuing to work through, trying to figure ways to get around."
Representative Wolf acknowledged the problem. "It depends on where you are and what your job is," he said. "The postman can't."
Despite the obstacles, Mr. Wolf is determined to ensure that all federal employees whose jobs make them eligible -- that is, whose jobs do not require their physical presence -- have the option to telecommute to some degree by 2004. By his estimate, 45 percent to 60 percent of the 1.8 million people who work for executive agencies are eligible.
Ms. Hoefling, the Denver consultant, says that is a lofty, though not impossible, goal. "I don't think the initiative is overly zealous," she said. "I think having it 100 percent in place by the fall may be overly zealous."
There are signs, though, that telecommuting may spread through the federal government. The experience of Martin Gertel, who has telecommuted in various ways for about five years, or as long as the option to do so has existed, is one.
Before he began to telecommute, Mr. Gertel, who is audit liaison for the Transportation Department and who has worked for the agency for about 10 years, spent three hours getting to and from his office in Washington every day: half an hour to the train station near Warrenton, Va., and then an hour to the city.
Then he cut his commute to half an hour by using a telework center closer to home. These centers are offices set up in the suburbs to allow federal workers to have access to computers and other office equipment, without having to travel all the way to their desks downtown.
Now, the declining cost of the technology needed to set up a home office may have made the centers passe. Mr. Gertel currently works from home, where he has his own computer, a separate phone line and a fax machine. Practical considerations, like meetings, require him to go to the office on many days, but he generally works at home on Mondays and Fridays.
"I can do just about anything from my study that I can do here," said Mr. Gertel, in his office to go through his in-box -- one thing he must do in person. "I can move documents, I can work cooperatively with people on drafting and redrafting responses to reports." And, said the father of two, "I get to be home for dinner."
Despite the low number of telecommuters, government agencies have recently voiced strong support for the practice, perhaps in part because Representative Wolf sits on the House Appropriations Committee and could hit laggards where it hurts -- in their budgets.
"The environment to me seems right to make this work," said Teresa M. Jenkins, director of the office of work force relations at the Office of Personnel Management, whose report on agencies' telecommuting policies and practices will be sent to Congress sometime in the next few weeks. "It's just good government if you want to stay competitive," Ms. Jenkins said, "and you want to recruit the best and the brightest."
To increase the number of people working from home, the Office of Personnel Management plans to hold a series of workshops and seminars on successful telecommuting arrangements for managers of different agencies and will help them set targets, Ms. Jenkins says. 
Another big obstacle to increased federal telecommuting, which workplace consultants say used to be the cost of setting up home offices, is probably management.
"A lot of us who learned our management techniques or styles in the 60's or 70's have sort of a bias that we have to see our employees at work," said Paul Chistolini, acting commissioner of the public buildings service of the General Services Administration. Of the roughly 7,300 people who work for him, 10 percent to 15 percent telecommute, he said. "It's quite a culture change to have to let people go and simply trust them to do the work," he said.
But if telecommuting poses obvious risks for managers by diminishing their control over subordinates, it also holds potential benefits for them. For one thing, it is a perk that can be a great recruiting tool. Surveys of federal workers show that telecommuting and flexible hours appeal to them and may reduce employee turnover, Ms. Jenkins said.
Whatever the actual advantages of telecommuting, Representative Wolf and some of his colleagues have undertaken a monumental task. The federal employees affected by the new law make up the largest work force in the country, and their employer is notoriously slow moving.
"If the federal government decided to change the style of paper clips that they wanted to use, it would probably take 18 months," said Gil Gordon, a telecommuting consultant in Monmouth Junction, N.J.
But the effort to change federal managers' thinking about telecommuting is worthwhile for reasons beyond improving the quality of life of government workers. The government often functions as a role model for private businesses, consultants say.
"They set the standard for the rest of American industry," said Ms. Hoefling, the consultant. Representative Wolf's goals may be ambitious, she said, but are probably necessary -- even though it may take a while to achieve them.
"The federal government is probably in the first stage" of adopting telecommuting, said Mr. Wolf, who remains a stalwart optimist. "It's beginning to take off."

HEADLINE: Cheney Is Backing Plan to Expand Cleaner Sources of Energy 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
The Bush administration will encourage the widespread use of agricultural, animal and human waste to produce energy as part of an effort to expand environmentally friendly energy supplies along with fossil fuels, administration officials said today.
 The so-called biomass refining effort would be modeled on a government-industry partnership that produces ethanol from corn, a program that is popular in farm communities and is seen by some as a relatively clean source of energy that reduces reliance on imported oil. 
 The effort would seek to refine organic waste, like corn fiber, manure, even saw dust, into a new kind of ethanol. It would require hundreds of millions of dollars in government tax incentives and research spending but could rival corn-based ethanol as a source of energy within a decade, industry lobbyists said. 
Vice President Dick Cheney has backed the plan as one of the most promising renewable sources of energy, and it is expected to feature prominently in the final report the administration's task force issues this month, officials confirmed.
Mr. Cheney, speaking on television today, also sought to show that his task force had put a balanced emphasis on increasing energy efficiency as well as expanding supplies of oil, coal and natural gas.
In a surprise, Mr. Cheney said the administration had not ruled out raising government-mandated fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks. But he said the administration would not make a final decision until a scientific study on the matter was completed this summer.
Some Democrats and environmentalists have urged the administration to raise the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards. They have not been increased since the 1980's, and the average fuel economy of cars and light trucks has declined in recent years with the rise of minivans and sport utility vehicles.
The automobile industry has tended to oppose any change in government mandates for fuel economy, arguing that tax incentives for highly fuel efficient vehicles work better.
"We think they have made a significant contribution over the years, improve the efficiency, if you will, the mileage of our automobiles," Mr. Cheney said of the standards in an interview with CNN. He said that when the National Academy of Sciences completed a study of the subject, the administration would decide "whether or not to go forward" with a change in standards.
Mr. Cheney also suggested that the administration would seek powers of eminent domain for electrical transmission lines, and President Bush, speaking to an electronics group tonight, indicated that was a priority.
"We need more electricity wires carrying product across the country," Mr. Bush said, warning that the nation "can't conserve our way to energy independence."
Mr. Cheney also said his energy report would recommend financial incentives for energy conservation, renewable energy and efficiency programs. Environmentalists and some scientists have criticized the administration as for playing down the potential of energy efficiency and renewable energy.
The vice president said, however, that renewable sources like solar, wind, biomass and geothermal were unlikely to account for more than 6 percent of total energy supplies by 2020, meaning that it was still necessary to drill for more oil and gas and ease regulatory barriers for the coal and nuclear power industries.
The energy report, Mr. Cheney said, would instruct Christie Whitman, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, to review regulatory requirements on coal-fired power plant companies. 
Many coal-using utilities have complained that the agency's regulations, which were designed to make sure that old coal-fired power plants adopt pollution controls, made it difficult for them to upgrade old plants.
In biomass production, enzymes break down organic waste into sugars that can be fermented into ethanol. But while the process of turning corn into ethanol is well established, development of a refinery system that can use waste products is considered less advanced. 
Administration officials have indicated that they plan to increase Department of Energy spending on biomass greatly in the 2003 fiscal year. In the 2002 fiscal year, President Bush's first budget, the administration sharply cut spending for renewable energy.

HEADLINE: No. 2 Official Of the I.M.F. To Step Down By Year's End 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
Stanley Fischer, who engineered record bailouts for several of the largest developing countries as the day-to-day manager of the International Monetary Fund, announced that he would leave his post by the year's end.
 His resignation clears a path for Bush administration officials, several of whom have been vocal critics of the fund's lending to Russia and several Asian countries in recent years, to help select a person to fill the No. 2 post, which by tradition is held by an American. 
 Mr. Fischer, 57, a former economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today that he had resigned the post voluntarily. Other fund officials and a spokesman for the United States Treasury Department were quick to agree, with several people saying that Mr. Fischer had been urged to stay on longer. 
Mr. Fischer briefly served as the fund's top official last year while the United States, Germany and several other European nations waged a protracted and sometimes bitter diplomatic contest over who would serve in the top post. The post eventually went to Horst Kohler, a former German government official, following the tradition of naming a European to the job but disappointing some developing nations that had nominated Mr. Fischer for the job.
Mr. Fischer said at the time that he would stay on under Mr. Kohler. But fund officials said they were not surprised that Mr. Fischer chose to resign after slightly less than a year under Mr. Kohler. Mr. Fischer said today he would continue in his post until later this year, when a successor is found.
"I will leave the fund with the highest respect for this institution and the deepest regard and affection for its dedicated and outstanding staff," Mr. Fischer said today.
Mr. Kohler and Mr. Fischer did not always work well together, several fund officials said. Mr. Kohler came into office vowing to rectify what some critics had identified as weaknesses, including the number of conditions attached to its loans, these people said. They added that Mr. Fischer did not always agree with Mr. Kohler about how, and how quickly, to enact changes.
Mr. Kohler issued a statement that was highly supportive of Mr. Fischer and expressed regret for his departure.
Since joining the fund in 1994, Mr. Fischer has overseen the details of its most economically challenging and politically delicate rescue operations.
He helped infuse money into Mexico after the crash of the peso in 1995. That effort, judged by many economists as successful, was quickly followed by the Asian financial contagion beginning in 1997. Mr. Fischer flew among South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia, arranging giant loan packages in exchange for commitments to open markets and streamline regulations. Those bailouts are still a much debated topic in economic circles.
The I.M.F.'s repeated loans to Russia in the 1990's are almost universally seen as failures. But Mr. Fischer and his supporters in the Clinton administration defended them as necessary gambles, given Russia's strategic importance. 
A technocrat who espoused classical views of economic management, Mr. Fischer defended the fund's efforts to force nations to tighten their fiscal belts and restrain spending even as they grappled with economic slowdowns.
Critics of the fund, including street protesters, members of Congress and both liberals and conservatives in academia, have often argued that it interferes too much in the financial affairs of the developing world and achieves poor results. But the critics have rarely aimed at Mr. Fischer himself, whose mastery of details, dry wit and easy diplomacy leaven his otherwise orthodox style.

HEADLINE: Panel Reaches Deal on Budget Framework 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
Republicans in the Senate and a handful of moderate Democrats reached a final deal tonight on how much money to allocate to tax cuts and spending, and Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee intensified their talks over how to apportion the tax reductions.
 The committee's Republican chairman, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, met twice today with the senior Democrat on the panel, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, and said they were making progress toward a tax bill that could attract bipartisan support. 
 Mr. Grassley said the bill would include all four of the main elements sought by President Bush in his proposal to cut taxes by more than $1.6 trillion over the next decade. They are a reduction in all income tax rates, an increase in the child credit, a tax break for married couples and repeal of the federal estate tax. 
But in part because the budget plan will provide less for tax cuts than the $1.6 trillion sought by Mr. Bush -- $1.25 trillion over the next decade, plus $100 billion for tax cuts this year and next year to boost the flagging economy -- Mr. Grassley said the committee would scale back and modify each component of the Bush proposal.
Mr. Grassley said the bill would not cut the top personal income tax rate to 33 percent from 39.6 percent, as Mr. Bush wants. Congressional aides and senators from both parties said they expected a compromise that would reduce the top rate to around 36 percent and the current 36 percent rate to about 33 percent.
"We're going to have a reasonable compromise on the top rate," Mr. Grassley said.
Mr. Grassley said the committee would take up the tax bill soon, following a vote in the House on Wednesday and in the Senate on Thursday on the final budget framework setting overall tax and spending levels. Republican aides said tonight that they had completed negotiations on the budget with moderate Democrats whose votes they need to adopt it in the Senate, trying to resolve differences over how much money Congress would make available for spending on education as well as agreeing on the final details of the scale of the tax cut.
The Senate Finance Committee is one of the most critical stops for the tax bill. Unlike the Republican-controlled House, which has passed a series of bills that would enact President Bush's plan in more or less the form he proposed, the Senate, where each party has 50 seats and the committees are evenly divided, is going to substantially rewrite his plan.
Mr. Grassley and Mr. Baucus have been trying to develop a compromise that could win support from at least 8 or 9 of the 10 Republicans on the Finance Committee and as many as 4 of the 10 Democrats. 
The committee's work could be amended on the Senate floor, and the bill that comes out of the Senate is sure to be modified again when negotiators from the House, the Senate and the White House sit down to agree on a version.
The Finance Committee is the best venue available to Democrats to reshape the tax bill to direct more of its benefits to lower- and middle-income taxpayers than the Bush plan would. 
Republicans cannot report a bill out of the committee without at least one Democratic vote -- and possibly more, since one moderate Republican on the panel, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, has indicated he might vote against it, and another, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, has expressed reservations.
"It's going to be hard to accommodate everybody," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, a Democrat who might back the bill. "The basic choice the Bush administration has is to attempt to win by a single vote and produce very conservative tax legislation, or build a broader coalition with more philosophically moderate legislation."
There is general agreement on a few points. Members of both parties want to create a new tax bracket below the current 15 percent bracket to give all taxpayers an immediate cut this year. And Mr. Grassley has said he intends to take some steps to deal with the alternative minimum tax, which was created to reduce tax avoidance by upper-income people but now subjects increasing numbers of middle-income taxpayers to higher tax bills.
The debate over how much to limit the reduction in the top income tax rate of 39.6 percent is one of the most ideologically contentious, but members of both parties said arithmetic is likely to drive the outcome.
Mr. Bush's proposal to reduce all income tax rates would reduce tax revenues by $877 billion over the next 10 years, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Of that, about a quarter, or more than $200 billion, would come from the reduction of the top rate to 33 percent. With the size of the overall tax cut shrinking, reducing the top rate by less than Mr. Bush wants is an obvious way to help fit all the pieces into the money available.
At the same time, centrists from both parties on the panel are pushing for ways to expand the 15 percent tax bracket to help middle-income families. One proposal is to increase the bracket's income ceiling for married couples to twice the level for single people; now, the bracket is about 1.7 times higher for married couples than for single people.
Several members of the committee, including Senators Snowe and Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, a Democrat, are pushing for a change in Mr. Bush's proposal to double the child credit to $1,000. 
They want low- to moderate-income families who do not pay any federal income tax to be able to benefit from the increase in the child credit. They would accomplish that by letting them use the child credit to offset part of the payroll taxes they pay to help finance Social Security and Medicare. For many low-income working families, payroll taxes are the biggest tax liability.
The estate tax could prove to be the most difficult issue for the committee. Mr. Bush's plan calls for gradual repeal of the tax, which would reduce revenues by $306 billion over 10 years. 
Its cost, and criticism from Democrats who say it would provide a disproportionate benefit to relatively few wealthy families, have made it an obvious target. But conservative Republicans on the committee, including Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, have made clear that they will fight hard for full repeal, and Mr. Bush said today he would back them up.

HEADLINE: TURF; 
The Price Is Right; So What if It Isn't Perfect?

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
LISTEN to real estate agents and cocktail party pundits, and you might think there's no point in even looking for a decent one- or two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan south of 96th Street for less than $450,000.
 So $300,000 is out of the question, right? 
"It's embarrassing to admit it, but there's almost nothing," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate. "It's embarrassing because for $300,000 -- an amount way above the median home price in the United States -- you can find barely more than a coal chute in Manhattan." (A coal chute, for those too young to remember, was a hole under the sidewalk with a dim-glass-and-iron lid.) 
Other brokers agree. "How about a nice studio?" suggested Diane Ramirez of the Halstead Property Company. 
Dexter Guerrieri, president of Vandenberg Real Estate, just laughed -- and laughed.
But would-be buyers who persist -- either out of economic necessity or sheer stubbornness -- will be rewarded. A search this week of the shared listings of Manhattan agents uncovered 156 candidates for under $300,000.
While some were quickly eliminated because of monthly maintenance fees way beyond the standard $1 a square foot, there still remained dozens offered in the $200,000's. Six had two bedrooms.
Catch them while you can: a one-bedroom at 417 East 90th Street with a terrace -- and glimpses of the East River -- came on the market last Thursday for $197,000. (It's still available, but offers are pending.) And don't overlook the petite second-floor flat at 337 West 20th Street in Chelsea, complete with a shared courtyard garden and birdbath.
There were (relatively) cheap apartments on West 87th Street and Riverside Drive, on Minetta Lane and Sheridan Square, on Grand Street and East 35th Street, and even on Park Avenue. This reporter went to inspect the ones that sounded the most promising.
An apartment at 227 East 87th Street has two real bedrooms (not just one plus a dining L, like some on the list) and, even more unusual, two bathrooms. And the layout is desirable, too, with a bed and bath at each end of the apartment -- perfect for college students, hosts and house guests, or parents and children. The ceilings are high (12 feet), there is a nonworking fireplace in one bedroom and, for those who like them, exposed brick walls throughout. 
So far, so good. So what's the drawback?
While avoiding the bedroom-through-bedroom arrangement of a classic railroad flat, this apartment is nevertheless shaped like a bowling alley -- 83 feet long and 11 feet wide at its widest point. And it is dark, partly because it is on the first floor. The 1930 building, not exactly a tenement, is one of those double-width, non-doorman rental buildings that were converted to co-ops in the 1980's. The small kitchen is done in mundane Formica, and one bathroom looks dated with its bright turquoise tile. 
Despite its problems, the $275,000 apartment has a handful of prospective takers, said Cynthia Keskinkaya, a Corcoran Group agent, who started showing it three weeks ago. But the would-be buyers may not make the grade because they are first-time buyers -- and may want to bring in roommates. "It's a co-op; they have to satisfy the board," Ms. Keskinkaya explained, echoing other agents who encounter similar troubles with youthful buyers.
Next, it was on to a corner one-bedroom at 16 Park Avenue (35th Street), where it quickly became clear why the owners were eager to sell: two tiny cribs crowded the bedroom.
It also became obvious why the apartment, 725 square feet and with a view of the Empire State Building from the kitchen, had not sold. Laura McGinn and David Leichtman, the owners, did what many sellers do in a real estate market not even the brokers fully understand: they overpriced their apartment. The price has slid from $375,000 in January to $345,000, then $315,000. This week, it was $295,000.
Other inexpensive apartments are in so-called off-neighborhoods (as in "off the beaten path"). The largest apartment spotted for under $300,000 was on Suffolk Street on the Lower East Side, near Delancey and Orchard Streets. This is hardly blue-chip or blue-stocking territory, but it may be white-hot -- at least for the youngest, hippest apartment hunters.
The loft-style 974-square-foot apartment has space for two bedrooms, though one is separated from the living area by orange curtains instead of a wall. Priced at $238,000, it would be closer to $500,000 in Greenwich Village or TriBeCa, judging from comparable listings.
Like many lofts, it is a walk-up, in this case two flights in a clean, newly painted brick building across from a parking lot and catty-corner from a gothic-style school building. Unlike many lofts, which can be dark and narrow, this one is bright and square, with four windows on the street facing west. The second bedroom has real walls but is small and close to the entrance.
The open kitchen is plain but well designed, and the exposed brick contributes to a gritty, airy ambience. The loft benefited from a co-op conversion in the 1980's that turned 20 apartments into 10.
The one real drawback (assuming the neighborhood isn't an issue) is the parking lot across the street. "They all want to know what kind of building will be built there -- you know, will it block their light," said the broker, Henry Davis of Ashforth Warburg.
But that hasn't stopped people from bidding. One offer, which is close to the asking price, has already been accepted, and two others are in line.
In this uncertain market, brokers say the asking price is all important. It is well known that $2.99 sounds like a lot less than $3, and the same thing applies to $299,000.
One thing many apartments under $300,000 have in common is that they started out over $300,000 and gradually or not so gradually worked their way down, agents say, growing a little stale in the process. If Ms. McGinn and Mr. Leichtman had asked $295,000 for their prewar one-bedroom in January, they think they would have sold it right away.
"What I've learned," Ms. McGinn said, "is not to go for what the apartments are listed for in the newspapers, to try and find out what they actually sold for." 
The brokers handling many of the properties for less than $300,000 say the market is at least 10 percent lower than it was a year ago.
On Tuesday, Elaine Tross, an agent with Douglas Elliman, was showing a large one-bedroom in a 1969 "plain vanilla" -- white-brick -- postwar co-op at 400 East 77th Street. It has open southern views of the city, central air-conditioning and a 24-hour doorman. The maintenance is $787, and the price is $299,000.
"A year ago, they would have been asking $330,000," Ms. Tross said. "I sold a similar apartment here in the same building a year ago. It was two floors higher and in triple-mint condition. It sold for $349,000."
The apartment Ms. Tross is selling now is in good condition, too -- partly because she helped to make it that way. This is a common gesture among brokers in a market where fixer-uppers are not the hot commodity they were a year ago. Back then, they were going for almost as much as the fixed-up ones. But as buyers become nervous, they are less willing to gamble on construction spending. So today, agents are advising sellers to paint walls, refinish floors and put away the dishes.
"When I first walked in, the apartment looked a little cluttered," Ms. Tross said. Some of the chairs disappeared ("they're in the front closet," she whispered) and bric-a-brac was removed from the windowsills. "Buyers like a sparser look, so you can see the view," the agent said.
A year ago, when the market was at its peak, buyers often overlooked not only cluttered sills but also what agents used to call the fatal flaw. It might have been the apartment's location, like a funky block off Avenue C. Or an air-shaft overlook. Or an astronomical monthly maintenance fee.
Or an apartment in want of $150,000 worth of renovations. But nowadays, there appear to be fewer wrecks. 
Haruno Arai, an agent with the Corcoran Group, who is showing the one-bedroom Chelsea flat with the shared backyard garden ($285,000), says that young sellers have the resources to fix their apartments up. "I see so much stuff from Ikea now," she said.
And there are fewer bad neighborhoods. While not everyone might want to live on the Lower East Side or in the meatpacking district, there are lots of people who do -- and not only 23-year-olds.
It all depends on the buyer.
"There are some adorable apartments, charm with a working fireplace," said Hall Willkie, director of sales at Brown Harris Stevens. "They're great for people who are young or want exercise." Those apartments, he added, are fourth-floor walk-ups.
About those and the other less-than-perfect apartments, Mr. Willkie was blunt.
"They only can be considered fatal flaws if you pay too much," he said.

HEADLINE: Digital Storage: Computer Age Gets a Valhalla 

BYLINE:  By KATIE HAFNER 

DATELINE: MOFFETT FIELD, Calif. 

 BODY:
TWELVE years ago, Keith Uncapher, a computer scientist at the RAND Corporation, was shocked to discover that the Johnniac, a behemoth of a computer he had helped develop in the 1950's, had been left out to rust in a parking lot behind the Museum of Science and Industry in Los Angeles.
 After some hasty negotiations, Mr. Uncapher managed to rescue the computer before it was trucked off to a junkyard. Now the one-of-a-kind Johnniac, named for the computer pioneer John von Neumann, is safely ensconced 350 miles north, at the Computer Museum History Center here. 
 So goes the practice of saving the machines that both ignited and sustained the computer revolution.
The Johnniac is part of a vast collection of computer and electronic equipment assembled over the last two decades by a dedicated cadre of computer pioneers who are determined to prevent the industry's tangible roots from slipping away. 
Part of the collection is displayed in what the museum calls "visible storage" in a large warehouse at the eastern edge of Moffett Field, a former naval air station that is home to NASA's Ames Research Center. It looks almost, but not quite, like a proper museum exhibition. Next to the Johnniac is a large chunk of an I.B.M. SAGE computer, one of about two dozen built in the 1950's as part of an early warning air-defense system. A few feet from the SAGE is the Cray-1, an early supercomputer introduced in 1976.
The rest -- several thousand computers, pieces of peripheral equipment and gigabytes of software -- is stacked to the rafters in an adjacent warehouse.
Behind the confusion of metal and vacuum tubes lies an ambitious plan: to raise $100 million and build a 114,000-square-foot museum to house the collection. The museum, scheduled to open in 2005, will be built on a three-acre parcel at Moffett Field, near the city of Mountain View in the midst of Silicon Valley.
For now, the 10 staff members sit in a trailer next to a decommissioned Titan missile, and the collection is open to the public only by appointment. "The long-term plan is to put it on every Silicon Valley tourist's must-see list," said John Toole, the museum's executive director.
The idea of amassing historical artifacts has wide appeal in Silicon Valley. 
"This is the information age, after all," said Eric Hahn, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur and investor who is a museum trustee and donor, "and the textured stories behind all these artifacts are very, very important for this century. They deserve to be treated with reverence."
One of the most conspicuously impressive pieces in the collection is a fully functioning Enigma machine, a portable typing device used by the German military during World War II to created encoded messages. The machine is on loan to the museum from Dr. C. Gordon Bell, a computer scientist who helped design the first minicomputers in the 1950's and 1960's and is one of the museum's biggest supporters. Dr. Bell, who bought the machine in 1991, estimates that no more than 20 Enigma devices still exist.
The museum is also the repository for unique machines like the Johnniac and the WISC, or Wisconsin Integrally Synchronized Computer, a mainframe computer built by Gene Amdahl for his doctoral dissertation at the University of Wisconsin in 1953. (Mr. Amdahl designed early mainframes at I.B.M. and later founded the Amdahl Corporation, which was a major computer manufacturer.) The WISC was discovered in Wisconsin in an engineer's basement, where it had apparently been used on occasion for target practice. And Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, has donated the paper tape of a computer program he wrote as a Harvard student.
Beyond the curiosities and collector's items in the collection, the museum also takes a Library of Congress approach, acting as a repository for most products of the computer era, including more recent ones, like the original Palm Pilot. 
"If you've been a computer user for more than two years," said Dr. Leonard Shustek, chairman of the museum board of trustees, "your computer is obsolete and we have it in the collection." 
The museum's holdings are drawn partly from the former Computer Museum in Boston, which sent more than 100,000 pounds of old computers in 1996 and 1999. 
The main driving force behind the museum project is Dr. Shustek, a successful Silicon Valley engineer who joined the trustee board of the Boston museum in 1995 with an eye toward starting the West Coast outpost. "It really bothered me that no one except the museum in Boston was doing anything like this," he said. 
With his wife, Donna Dubinsky, who is a founder of Handspring, the hand-held computer manufacturer, Dr. Shustek has carried out an ambitious fund-raising campaign. To date, the museum has secured pledges of nearly $50 million, the projected cost of the new building, and the board hopes to raise another $50 million by the time ground is broken in 2003.
Dr. Shustek is especially proud of the pieces in the collection that were rescued from junk heaps, like the Johnniac. In another instance of disaster aversion, Ken Olsen, who founded the Digital Equipment Corporation, saved the Whirlwind computer, a ground-breaking machine built at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and completed in 1951, by keeping a truck from hauling the machine to a landfill. 
"The museum prides itself in just-in-time collecting," Dr. Shustek said. "We get to things just before it's too late."
Very few of the older machines in the collection are still functioning. One that is, a 40-year-old I.B.M. computer called the 1620, was painstakingly pieced back together by a group of volunteers, who worked on weekends for 18 months to bring it back to life. An emulation of the machine is on the museum's Web site.
The museum also showcases products that did not succeed. A notable example is the $10,000 Honeywell Kitchen Computer, a recipe-generating machine marketed in the 1960's that required of its users more than a passing acquaintance with computer programming. Mr. Toole said he doubted that any were actually sold. 
Successful or not, all legacies of the computing era deserve recognition, Dr. Shustek said. "If we don't preserve these things," he said, "future generations will be annoyed at us for not having told the story of how it all happened."

HEADLINE: Sham Election In Kyrgyzstan Erodes Image Of President 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan 

 BODY:
For years, Western diplomats held up President Askar Akayev of Kyrgyzstan as a champion of democracy among a gang of authoritarian leaders who control the other former Soviet republics of Central Asia. 
 But the image of Mr. Akayev and his tiny country have been tarnished in recent months. Political rivals have been jailed, opposition newspapers and independent television stations have been intimidated and silenced and, most damaging, international observers condemned Mr. Akayev's re-election last October as a sham. 
 The former university professor says he is determined to restore the prestige that he acknowledges he and his country have lost. Regaining the attention and respect of foreign leaders and international lenders is essential for any hope of prosperity in this nation, which lacks the energy resources of its neighbors. 
"We admit that we made mistakes and we are fully committed to correct them and stay on the track of democracy," Mr. Akayev said in a 90-minute interview at his residence in an orchard-filled park on the outskirts of Bishkek, the capital. 
Mr. Akayev then outlined what he knows foreign lenders would like to hear. His top priority, he said, is a new national plan for micro-credit loans to alleviate the extreme poverty that grips much of the country. He described the importance of the ombudsman post being created to monitor human rights. And he promised to work with opposition politicians and independent journalists. 
"As Victor Hugo said, the real mistake is the one that cannot be corrected," said Mr. Akayev, 56, sounding more like a penitent than the autocrat his critics say he has become after nearly a decade in office as Kyrgyzstan's first president after its independence. 
"I'm glad to hear that he acknowledges the mistakes because they are obvious and bad," said Christoph Schuepp, country director of Internews, an American-based foundation that promotes press freedom. "But the media is still under enormous pressure." 
A Western diplomat gave Mr. Akayev credit for some positive steps, like authorizing elections of local officials and adopting a progressive needle-exchange program to combat drug-related diseases. But he said each step forward seems to be matched by at least one step back. 
One of Mr. Akayev's earliest supporters, Feliks Kulov, is serving a seven-year prison sentence on charges supporters say were trumped up to keep him from opposing Mr. Akayev in last year's presidential race. 
Mr. Kulov was acquitted last August by a military court of charges he abused his office while he was vice president, but an appeals court found him guilty of the same charges and sentenced him to prison. 
After the presidential election, Mr. Akayev appointed a former Communist Party boss known for his hard-line attitude as his new chief of staff.
Mr. Akayev knows democracy is one of the few products Kyrgyzstan has to market, particularly if he wants to keep international aid flowing and tourists arriving to trek in the rugged Tien Shan and Pamir Mountains, whose soaring peaksare called the Roof of the World. 
Kyrgyzstan's only other major resource is the network of rivers and dams that regulate the flow of water essential to the farmlands and cotton fields of the Ferghana Valley and the production of electricity. 
The limited resources have left the country with an anemic economy. Per capita income is about $300 a year, less than $1 a day, and declining. 
The poverty and outbreaks of violence by Islamic insurgents in southern Kyrgyzstan during the past two summers have raised tensions, particularly in southern Kyrgyzstan where ethnic Kyrgyz, Uzbeks and Tajiks live in sometimes uneasy proximity. 
President Islam Karimov of neighboring Uzbekistan has responded to the Islamic radicals with mass arrests, something Mr. Akayev has avoided so far. The way to counter the appeal of the militants, he said, is by alleviating poverty. 
"In some cases these people live in extreme poverty and for that reason the ideas of the Islamic fundamentalists are appealing to them," he said. "Only economic well being and education will help us in defeating extremism."

PERSON: Marie Jahoda 

HEADLINE: Marie Jahoda, 94; Studied Work and Women 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Marie Jahoda, one of the world's foremost social psychologists and an emeritus professor at the University of Sussex, died on April 28 at her home in Keymer, in southeast England. Dr. Jahoda, who taught at New York University in the 1950's, was 94.
 In a long career as a researcher, teacher and writer, Dr. Jahoda, known as Mitzi, examined social issues in the field well beyond the realm of dry statistics, and in her classes emphasized a humanistic approach and adherence to scientific rigor in social research. 
 In New York from 1949 to 1958, she was a professor of social psychology at N.Y.U. and was a founding director of its Research Center for Human Relations. She was the source of a steady stream of surveys and reports on the social fabric of the city and the country.
Her topics included anti-Semitism and ethnic and religious prejudice in the work place and in intergroup relations. In one report she found that opinion researchers must sometimes resort to biased questions to detect bias on the respondent's part.
"People with prejudices," she concluded, "seldom like to admit it."
On behalf of the federal Public Health Service, she investigated the effect of conditions in a wartime boom town on the mental health of workers. For this, she documented overcrowded living quarters and a dearth of education, health and recreation centers.
She tackled the delicate issue of loyalty in the political atmosphere of the 1950's by studying the impact of federal security measures on government employees.
In 1954 she assessed the role of women in America and wrote that women seeking to combine marriage with a career need strong mental health and an ability to solve problems.
Her investigation of conformity in America in the 1950's found the issue to be oversimplified. There were several basic types of conformers, she said. The most common type she called drifters, people who willingly changed their beliefs because they lacked adequate knowledge of the arguments pro or con. Another category she characterized as people who had definite and unpopular beliefs that they kept to themselves for fear of the consequences of speaking out.
Born in Vienna, Marie Jahoda absorbed the teachings of Freud and Jung and received her doctorate at the University of Vienna. She gained early recognition with a sociological study conducted in Marienthal, near Vienna, with Hans Zeisel and her first husband, Paul Lazarsfeld.
Marienthal, an industrial district, was racked by unemployment in the 1920's and 1930's. Working unobtrusively, the researchers measured the psychological consequences. For Dr. Jahoda the project demonstrated that work met a basic need for most people, giving them personal worth, social coherence and structured time.
As a Social Democrat opposed to the Austrian government even before Hitler annexed the country, she was imprisoned in 1936 but managed to reach England. There her research took on topics like unemployment in the coal mines and the transition from the classroom to the work place.
She came to the United States after World War II and worked as a researcher for the American Jewish Committee and at Columbia University before moving to N.Y.U.
She returned to Britain in 1958 to marry Austen Albu, a Labor member of Parliament. She worked as a researcher and teacher at the University of Sussex from 1965.
Mr. Albu died in 1994. Dr. Jahoda is survived by a daughter from her first marriage, Lotte Bailyn of Belmont, Mass., a professor of management at M.I.T.; and two grandsons. Dr. Jahoda and Dr. Lazarsfeld divorced in the 1930's. He became a professor of sociology at Columbia University and died in 1976.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 18, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on May 10 about Dr. Marie Jahoda, a social psychologist, omitted two survivors. They are a sister, Rosi Kuerti of Cleveland, and a brother, Fritz Jahoda of Concord, Mass.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
Treasuries Climb as Traders Hedge Giant Corporate Issue

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as dealers snapped up longer-dated issues after the biggest debt sale ever by an American company and an auction of new benchmark 10-year notes.
 Both 30-year bonds and 10-year notes jumped higher as dealers abandoned hedged positions related to WorldCom's record sale of $11.9 billion in bonds. 
 Much of the WorldCom deal was concentrated in 10-year notes and 30-year bonds, and traders said the unwinding of those positions lifted long-term Treasury issues. 
The Treasury sold $9 billion in a reopened issue of 10-year notes, the second sale in its two-part quarterly refunding. 
"It's a combination of very good reception to the WorldCom deal and a fairly good Treasury 10-year note auction that's helping the market do better," said Gemma Wright, senior market strategist at the Barclays Capital Group.
The current-issue benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 19/32 , to 98 24/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 5.16 percent from 5.24 percent on Tuesday. The yield on the newly auctioned notes, which were sold at a price to yield 5.189 percent, improved to 5.185 percent by late in the day.
The 30-year Treasury bond jumped 1, to 95 28/32 . Its yield fell to 5.66 percent from 5.74 percent on Tuesday.
There were no economic reports yesterday. Bond traders are awaiting reports tomorrow, which include a preliminary reading on consumer sentiment in May and retail sales nationwide in April, for further direction on Federal Reserve policy.
The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee meets on Tuesday and is widely expected to cut overnight lending rates another half a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Economists Say Recession Is Unlikely 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9 

 BODY:
Business economists still say they believe that the United States will probably avoid recession this year, a quarterly survey released today found.
 The survey by the National Association for Business Economics did find an increased chance of recession this year, up to 35 percent from 33 percent in February and 20 percent in November. 
Still, the panelists did not consider the change alarming. 
 "While the business outlook remains cloudy and profits are under severe pressure, panelists have remained steadfast in their belief that a recession is unlikely," said Richard Berner, president of the association and chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
The 27-member panel lowered expectations for growth next year, meanwhile, to 3.1 percent, from the 3.5 percent forecast in February. The forecast for 2 percent growth this year was unchanged. The economy grew 5 percent in 2000.
Slowing growth has prompted Federal Reserve policy makers to reduce their benchmark interest rate four times since the beginning of the year and most of the 25 banks and securities firms that trade directly with the Fed expect a further rate cut next week and additional reductions later in the year to preserve the record expansion.
The economists surveyed said the Consumer Price Index would probably rise 3 percent in 2001, up from a 2.6 percent forecast in the previous survey, mainly because of higher energy costs, and 2.5 percent in 2002, unchanged from the last survey. Prices rose 3.4 percent last year.
There is a 25 percent probability of recession in 2002, the group found. That compares with 20 percent and 25 percent in the prior two surveys.
