HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Lest we forget: each generation has its own 'new economy.'

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a fellow at the Shorenstein Center at Harvard University.

 BODY:
EVER since high-technology stocks began to plummet last spring, the press has become increasingly disillusioned with the "new economy." But this was always a loosely defined concept. As The Economist wrote in 1999, the stunning economic boom of the late 1990's needed a "very big idea" to explain it. The press, Wall Street and a handful of influential authors rushed to fill the void. 
 Such a big idea is rarely right, and some might argue it is disingenuous to criticize it in retrospect. But America took the new economy seriously, causing a lot of damage. The enthusiasm the term fostered, the sense of authority it conveyed, convinced Americans that they might at last have solved their central economic problems. Yet a recession may arrive long before family income is back on a firm growth track and enough people have been lifted out of poverty. 
 Claims that there was a new economy helped justify soaring stock prices that could not possibly be maintained and enormous commitments of capital to new ventures that inevitably went bad. While economists wrung their hands over America's lack of savings, tens of billions of dollars that could have been spent more wisely were dissipated.
What was the genesis of the idea? Research I recently completed at the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard shows that the press, business economists and economics authors have been using the term "new economy" since the 1970's to describe many different and often unrelated things. Sometimes it was about computer technology. But it has also been used to describe a service economy, globalization, the two-worker family, stagnating wages, the rise of small companies, deindustrialization and corporate restructuring.
In the 70's, there were references to a new economy as the nation tried to adjust to high inflation and expensive oil. Fuel-efficient cars were called new-economy cars. By 1981, some made the familiar claim that a new economy would no longer be subject to harsh recessions; the worst recession since World War II began the next year. 
In the mid-1980's, the idea of a new economy gained wide acceptance. There were books with titles like "Doing Business in the New Economy" and "Understanding a New Economy." In 1986, Fortune hailed "America's New Economy" on its cover, as did U.S. News & World Report. Business Week asserted that the nation was undergoing "the most revolutionary economic change in a century -- the emergence of a 'new economy' of services and high technology."
The reason for the mid-1980's exuberance was not hard to trace. By the end of 1985, the economy had strung together three strong years. But in 1987 the stock market crashed and economic growth ultimately sputtered. It was time for another new economy, but this time an economy of strain. "Sacrifice and industriousness will be the features of the new economy," Business Week wrote.
There have always been "new eras" and "new ages," but such phrases never before gushed forth as frequently as they did in the last two decades. Partly, the repeated claims of epochal changes reflected increasing competition in the business media and on Wall Street; big ideas, after all, attract attention. 
But the modern era was also both confusing and disappointing. The 1970's began with virulent inflation and were followed by high unemployment rates, insecure jobs, falling wages and historically slow productivity growth. Americans seemed to hope that a new economy would come along to sweep their problems away, and many were willing to oblige them.
By the late 1990's, claims about a new economy at last had staying power. The surprisingly strong economy of 1996 and 1997 did not peter out. Capital investment in new technologies continued to grow rapidly, the unemployment rate fell, and, most important, productivity grew rapidly again.
From 1985 to 1995, the business press had about 775 references to a new economy. In 1998 alone, there were more than 1,000.
Even in the late 1990's, however, it was hard to tie the new economy down to a precise definition. Most analysts and the press attributed the strong economy to the spread of the computer. But just how information technology produced these gains was far from clear.
Some economists, like Robert Gordon of Northwestern University, argued that much of the increase in productivity had to do with the cyclical strength of the economy, and that any additional gains were being made by the producers of computers, not their customers.
Ironically, even the proponents of the new economy seemed insecure. The Economist wrote that most experts believed it would require the Internet to solidify the new economy's gains. But sales on the Internet were too minuscule even by 2001 to have accounted for rapid economic growth. 
It was the rising stock market, not economic analysis, that pressed the new economy indelibly into the nation's consciousness. High-tech stocks soared in 1999, and references to the new economy in the business press tripled, to more than 3,000. 
In 2000, such references totaled more than 20,000, and hyperbole was rampant. "Thanks to wondrous new technology," The Economist wrote, "the business cycle was supposedly consigned to the history books, and productivity would grow forever at a miraculous rate."
Now, the economy is slowing, dot-coms are failing, venture capital has dried up, fortunes are lost, as is a goodly portion of retirement savings, and doubters are rising from the woodwork. Is a more clear-headed age upon us? 
It is not likely. We economics writers cannot seem to get out of the way. The Wall Street Journal recently wondered, for example, whether there would be a "New Economy growth recession."
There is little doubt that information technology is having a constructive impact on the nation's capacity to produce goods and services. But claims that America had a new economy rested more on the need for simple answers and promises of deliverance from difficult times than it did on solid economic analysis. Reasonable people will make mistakes, but such cynicism exacts a price.

HEADLINE: Kingman Journal; 
Famous by Association And Not Happy About It

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: KINGMAN, Ariz., May 8 

 BODY:
Sitting just beyond the blazing desert sun in the shade of his carport, a handgun strapped, as always, to his hip, Walter McCarty welcomed the opportunity to talk of his anger.
 Mr. McCarty, a 78-year-old former marine, described his contempt for what he called the federal government's abuses of power and how his views and a handgun course he taught brought him together with another angry man, Timothy J. McVeigh. 
 Mr. McCarty said he was even mad at Mr. McVeigh, who spent nearly two years here before blowing up the Federal Building in Oklahoma City in 1995. That senseless loss of 168 lives left him furious, Mr. McCarty said, as well as the way the F.B.I. swooped into Kingman after the attack in search of a conspiracy. 
What upsets him now, said Mr. McCarty, whose modest home is decorated with Marine insignia and a Marine flag, is the way Mr. McVeigh's scheduled execution next week has dragged Kingman again under an unflattering spotlight that he and other residents say the town does not deserve.
Mr. McCarty and others admit that the desolate, sun-baked flats and canyons along the old Route 66 here have long been a magnet for malcontents and that some extremist groups have found recruits in the area. But they insist that Kingman itself, a former mining and railroad town transformed by a burst of growth in recent years, has been branded wrongly as a militia haven.
"There never was at any time a really organized militia or group like that around Kingman, and I would know," said Mr. McCarty, who works as a bailiff in the Mohave County Courthouse here. "There are some people around here who think that way, I can tell you that. But it's not organized like they say."
This is a sore point in Kingman. But most concede that the evidence is mixed. There were some active militias in Arizona a decade ago, and a few terrorist attacks, including the derailing of an Amtrak train several years ago. Larry J. Butler, Kingman's chief of police, said that in the heyday of antigovernment movements in the mid-1990's, he would occasionally hear of hunters stumbling on makeshift survivalist camps in the desert.
Chief Butler also said his officers would sometimes confront zealots who claimed the government had no right to force them to register their cars or obtain driver's licenses. But he said those confrontations were never violent and had all but stopped.
"To the extent there were any, Tim McVeigh killed the feelings for militias around here," the chief said. "I can tell you, there's no sympathy for them."
Steve Johnson, a spokesman for the Mohave County Sheriff's Department, agreed, saying of the militias: "I can't say that they are here and I can't say that they aren't here. We just don't see them."
Mohave County had been inviting for antigovernment protesters at least in part because it is so vast and empty. It stretches across Arizona's broad northwest corner, covering 13,260 square miles of dun-hued desert. Arizona's liberal gun laws had also been attractive, making it easy to buy and carry weapons.
But groups that track the militant antigovernment movements say they have nearly disappeared. According to the Southern Poverty Law Center, which monitors extremist groups, the number nationwide plummeted to 194 last year, from a peak of 858 in 1996. Just three are reported in Arizona.
Sean McMahon, the editor of The Kingman Daily Miner, said his paper used to publish articles regularly tracking the groups, but had not done so for more than a year because there was little to report.
Kingman has been changed by a more powerful force than anger: opportunity. The city has been caught up in the Sun Belt boom. Its population soared in the past decade by 60 percent to 20,069, according to the 2000 census. In Mohave County, population grew to 155,032 in 2000 from 93,000 in 1990.
Lou Sorensen, Kingman's city manager, said many of those new residents had been attracted by jobs in the casino-fueled economy of nearby Nevada, not right-wing ideologies.
Mr. McCarty said local residents still loved their guns and feared that the government might take them away -- a concern he shared with Mr. McVeigh. But, he added, people are no longer as naive as they once were. In his neighborhood, he said, they are delighted that things have calmed down. 
Elsie Starkey agreed. She had been a neighbor of Michael Fortier -- a friend of Mr. McVeigh who pleaded guilty to knowing about the bomb plot but failing to alert the authorities -- just a couple of blocks from Mr. McCarty's home. Despite the talk of illegal activity at Mr. Fortier's house, where Mr. McVeigh often visited, she said she had seen none of it. 
"He seemed like a nice guy," Ms. Starkey said of Mr. Fortier, who is serving a federal prison sentence. "I just never saw any of that stuff. I never expected any of that to happen and I'm glad it's back to normal."

HEADLINE: Excesses of Hoboken's Success Helped Defeat Mayor 

BYLINE:  By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., May 9 

 BODY:
For some voters, it may have been Mayor Anthony Russo's strong-handed style. Others may have had concerns about his health, after his bouts with a brain tumor and lung cancer. And nearly everyone seemed to have an opinion about the mayor's aborted plan last month to keep out-of-towners from driving through the city on their way elsewhere.
 But hours after Mr. Russo lost his race for a third four-year term as Hoboken's colorful power broker, the feeling here today among many residents -- including Mr. Russo -- was that he had fallen victim to one of the proudest boasts of his administration: the headlong growth of this waterfront city. 
 In an upset, Mr. Russo lost to City Councilman David Roberts Tuesday by 53 percent to 42 percent in a nonpartisan election.
Mr. Russo, 54, said today that he had lost in part because he had not run a spirited campaign. "I did not have the fire in the belly that I did in 1993," he said, referring to his first mayoral race. "I think I really didn't have my heart in this campaign."
But he also said voters had blamed him for problems caused by the city's rapid growth. Since Mr. Russo was elected mayor, Hoboken's business district has thrived, and it has added 5,000 housing units. But there is also more traffic, noise and complaints about lack of parking.
"What were once garbage-strewn lots became taxable property," Mr. Russo said in a telephone interview. "But the spin on the economic development of the city became overdevelopment."
This afternoon, Mr. Roberts, who will take office on July 1, said that voters felt the mayor was insensitive to their complaints.
"In one year, five different citizens' groups had to hire private lawyers just to get their issues heard by city government," he said, sitting at a sidewalk table at the Hoboken Gourmet Company on Washington Street. "What we will bring to city government is more respect."
Mr. Roberts, 44, a Democrat who has been on the City Council for 16 years, ran on a slate with three Council candidates: current Councilmen Ruben Ramos Jr. and Anthony Soares, and Carol Marsh, a community activist.
"We had a diversity of support in Hoboken," Mr. Roberts said. "That included young professionals, people who had moved to Hoboken recently, the more traditional Hoboken residents and people of all economic levels. Our campaign headquarters looks like a mini-United Nations."
Mr. Roberts said that he and his running mates want to draw up a new master plan for the city that would call for controlled growth, and that might restrict most parking to the perimeter of the city, an issue of great concern here. 
Last month, Mr. Russo tried a radical solution to the traffic problem: he announced that at certain hours, he was closing off the city to traffic by people who did not live or work there. But before the police could turn away drivers, Frederick J. Theemling Jr., the Hudson County prosecutor, halted the plan, saying it was probably unconstitutional.
Many on the streets of Hoboken said today that growth and traffic were big reasons they voted against Mr. Russo. Cheryl Villone, 44, who has lived here all her life, supported him four years ago, but not this time. "He overdeveloped the town and broke a lot of promises," she said. "He lost touch with the town, and everything went out of control."
Ms. Villone also said that Mayor Russo's proposal to close the town to outside traffic was a last-minute effort to win votes. "He only visited the important topics when it was time for people to vote. Other than that, no one in town knew what he was up to."
At Mr. Russo's storefront campaign headquarters on Washington Street, the door was locked and the lights were out. Joe Wainright, 59, peered into the office and conceded that as a Russo supporter, "I'm part of the minority now."
"I thought Russo did a decent job and I voted for him," he said. "The town flourished and it's a nicer place now, but I guess some of the lesser things he did caught up with him."
Mr. Russo had also lost the support of crucial political players in Hudson County, including members of his own Democratic Party.
Then there was the issue of his health. In the last year, a tumor was removed from his brain and he was found to have lung cancer. "Some people were concerned that I wouldn't make it through a third term," he said. "But that's baloney."
Still, he said the city's development became an emotional issue. "A person rides around the neighborhood looking for parking that he can't find, and he gets angry and he votes against the incumbent," Mr. Russo said. "Most votes for my opponent were really votes against me."

Mayor Russo, who has served for two terms, said, "I think I really didn't have my heart in this campaign." (Jill C. Becker); (Jeff Zelevansky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Yellow Taxis Battle to Keep Livery Cabs Off Their Turf 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A former New York City police detective stood on the corner of 67th Street and Central Park West the other morning trying to hail a taxi. What made this unusual was that he was not going anywhere.
 Instead, the former detective was working as a foot soldier in a war being waged on the streets of Manhattan, one whose battle lines became apparent the minute he raised his hand: the cabs that raced to his side were not yellow. They were livery cabs, from sleek corporate sedans to battered gypsies, and they arrived in a virtual procession, rushing over and stopping illegally to haggle over a price. 
 "It's like rapid machine-gun fire," said the man, appropriately named Harry Hard, a flinty private investigator employed over the last month by the yellow taxi industry to document livery pickups and report the findings to the city. 
Turf wars are nothing new between the medallion and livery cab industries -- the complex two-class taxi system that has evolved in New York since the 1930's. Medallion taxis were always supposed to be restricted to picking up street hails. Liveries were to be restricted to prearranged calls -- though they have always picked up street hails on the sly, usually in neighborhoods where yellow cabs have no interest in going.
But over the last two years, according to yellow cab owners, livery owners and even the Taxi and Limousine Commission, liveries have increasingly invaded the yellow cab's traditional stronghold, south of 96th Street in Manhattan, cruising around business areas, hotels and restaurants and illegally taking hails.
The reasons they say this is happening now more than ever -- even in Midtown -- include a dearth of yellow cabs, especially during the day; more people in Manhattan trying to hail them; and what yellow cab owners see as a lack of enforcement by the taxi commission against liveries.
"Clearly, we are seeing it happen," said Diane McGrath-McKechnie, the chairwoman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission. "It's illegal and we have to stop it."
The livery invasion has done more than raise the hackles of yellow taxi drivers and owners, who sometimes pay more than $200,000 for the metal medallions riveted to their hoods, medallions that are supposed to give them the sole right to street hails. In effect, it threatens to turn the whole taxi system on its ear, challenging the logic of the way the medallion industry is regulated.
The regulations have always been much stricter for medallion cabs on the theory that New Yorkers and tourists need more protection when hopping into a cab than when calling ahead for one. For example, livery cabs have no limits on what they can charge, while taxis do. Their drivers do not have to attend an 80-hour preparation course, get a physical examination or prove they are proficient in English. They do not have to retire their cars when they are three years old, install air-conditioning or post any information in the cars to let passengers know who they are or whether they are licensed.
The yellow cab industry says that the breakdown in the taxi system not only makes the stricter rules against them unfair, but also undermines the economic balance in the industry. Because it is less complicated and costly to drive a livery car than a taxi, and because it is now easier for livery drivers to supplement their incomes by picking up street hails with relative impunity, more new drivers are gravitating to the livery industry than to the yellow industry.
Yellow taxi owners say this exacerbates a longstanding driver shortage. That translates into a cab shortage that they consider to be, in part, responsible for the greater number of liveries cruising for street hails in Manhattan.
"It's a vicious cycle," said Ronald Sherman, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents owners of big yellow cab fleets. "My drivers that are legal and go out and spend more than $600 for a license and do everything properly, they go out on the street and see people in their own cars picking up people left and right. The law-abiding drivers are saying, 'Why should I go through all these hassles when I can just go out and make a lot of money doing it on my own?' "
The situation has become so bad that a group of yellow taxi fleets, whose members have long cried poverty, recently came up with money of its own to produce a series of radio ads intended to protect its turf, essentially by trying to scare people who hail livery cabs.
"Think about it," says the voice-over on the ads, which ran last month on three radio stations. "The driver's already broken the law once -- just by picking you up. What's stopping him from breaking the law once you're inside the car? And who do you call when you have a complaint?"
The industry also hired Mr. Hard, the private investigator, to spend a month on the streets quietly gathering information about the incursion of liveries. During the recent morning on Central Park West, for example, 20 livery cabs responded in 30 minutes to his outstretched hand -- an average of one every minute and half -- some of them so aggressively that they cut off the few available yellow cabs, whose drivers honked and pounded their steering wheels as they saw their next fare being snatched away.
Mr. Hard is focusing mostly on hotels, where yellow taxi owners say they are losing a substantial amount of business to liveries that line up to snag passengers headed to the airports. Industry leaders say they plan to present his findings -- including tales of $65 rides to Kennedy Airport and payoffs to hotel doormen -- to the taxi commission, the hotel industry and to tourism officials.
In an odd twist, one that also speaks to the shifting dynamics in the taxi industry, many livery fleet owners have found themselves on the same page as their yellow fleet counterparts when confronting the issue.
They both vehemently oppose a proposal by Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, for the city to create zones in which it would be legal for liveries to pick up street hails. They point out that many of the murders of livery-cab drivers have occurred when they picked up street hails.
And the livery owners say that as illegal livery street hails become more commonplace, radio bases -- which dispatch cars to pick up passengers -- are also having a harder time fielding cars to fill all of their calls. And so they, too, would like to see the taxi commission crack down on liveries that break the pickup law.
Ms. McGrath-McKechnie, the taxi commission chairwoman, said the agency was aware that illegal livery activity had become more pervasive and was threatening the livelihood of the yellow taxi fleets. And she said that the agency had recently stepped up enforcement, particularly in conjunction with hotel managers.
The agency's lawyers are also exploring with the city's corporation counsel whether taxi enforcement officers can seize the cars of licensed liveries who are caught too many times picking up street hails, she said. Under the law, the agency can now seize only gypsy cabs -- essentially private, unlicensed cars -- when they are caught carrying passengers or making pickups.
But both yellow taxi fleet owners and livery owners say that they think the problem will persist, no matter how hard a line the taxi commission takes against it, because the agency has only about 200 taxi officers to cover all five boroughs and those officers usually must concentrate on more pressing public safety problems. And the Police Department, though able to respond to illegal pickups, almost never does.
"If it keeps up, then eventually what you're seeing is that the whole structure that the industry is based on begins to deteriorate," said Bruce Schaller, who was a policy expert for the taxi commission before starting his own taxi consulting company.
The other day on Central Park West, it was not easy to find anyone who really cared one way or the other about structures deteriorating or industries suffering, so long as he could find a cab. And if a yellow one wasn't around, he did not hesitate long to hop into a livery.
"There just aren't enough cabs out there," said Stewart Unger, a vintage-watch salesman, who was haggling with a livery driver. "Water seeks its own level, and guys look for jobs where they can find them. That's what's going on."

HEADLINE: City Clothing Bank Manager Charged in Fraud 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
A top official at the city Clothing Bank, which distributes apparel to the needy and homeless, was arrested yesterday for taking cash payoffs from an undercover investigator who said he wanted to divert $9,000 worth of donated clothes and merchandise to bogus charities, officials said.
 An inquiry began last July when the city's Department of Investigation received a tip that Philip E. Sheil, 44, the distribution manager at the Clothing Bank's warehouse at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, was selling garments to noncharities for resale and keeping the money. 
 Mr. Sheil allegedly solicited a total of $300 from an agent over several occasions, and helped the agent fill out paperwork and create fake charities. 
"This defendant was supposed to help clothe New York City's poor and homeless," said Edward J. Kuriansky, the commissioner of the Department of Investigation. "Instead he took the clothes off their backs and put money in his own pocket."
Mr. Sheil, of Dean Street in Brooklyn, was a full-time employee at the Clothing Bank since 1998, earning $25,000 a year. He was charged with mail and wire fraud, officials said, and, if found guilty, could spend up to 10 years in federal prison.
The Clothing Bank, a unit of the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center, was established in 1986 and stocks irregular and out-of-season clothes, as well as counterfeit designer garments seized by the police and no longer needed as evidence. More than 800 retailers nationwide also donate surplus or overstocked goods. The bank's citywide distribution network includes more than 400 charities that pay an annual membership fee to make warehouse pickups. 
To get the clothing, Mr. Sheil allowed the agent to claim to represent Bronx Educational and Charitable Organization, which did not exist, according to the charges. The two men also created a second fake charity, the Tyler Youth Education Foundation.

HEADLINE: U. of Virginia Hit by Scandal Over Cheating 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 9 

 BODY:
As they have for 160 years, students at the University of Virginia took their final exams unsupervised today, despite a cheating scandal that has shaken the campus. 
 Under trees and on benches, on a beautiful spring day, lone figures scrawled their answers in blue books, with teachers trusting that students would not peek into textbooks, steal solutions from the Internet or seek help from friends. 
 But the University of Virginia's code of student honor, a proud tradition that relies on students signing pledges not to cheat, steal or lie, is facing what may be its most severe test. Some 122 students stand accused of cheating on term papers in a popular introductory physics class, with as many as half of them expected to face the only penalty available for cheating here: expulsion or loss of degrees awarded in earlier years. 
The scandal at this campus of 18,000 as the academic year ends has prompted new questions about the university's widely admired code of honor and its single sanction system, rare among American universities. 
Cheating was discovered after a student from last semester told Louis A. Bloomfield, the physics professor, that the grade he had given her paper was low and that others with higher marks had cheated. The class has 300 to 500 students each semester. 
Professor Bloomfield set up a computer program to detect similarities of six consecutive words or more between term papers submitted to him over the last five semesters. It took the program 50 hours to run through more than 1,800 papers, but it was not long before the first matches appeared, he said, and they showed the papers to be virtual replicas. 
"In this universe, it's not 6 or 12 identical words in a phrase," Professor Bloomfield said, "it's 1,500."
"I expected to see a couple of matches," he said. "I was a bit shocked to find 60."
Professor Bloomfield's discovery was first reported in The Richmond Times-Dispatch.
He suggested that in an era when people swap music over the Internet, forward e-mail messages and send texts to each other with a single keystroke, the lines between collaboration and theft have blurred. 
While some educators have raised concerns that the Internet has made cheating on exams and term papers easier, Professor Bloomfield's program raises the potential of electronic sleuthing to match it.
Some university officials say they suspect the Internet has increased cheating. But Linda K. Trevino, chairman of the department of management and organization at Pennsylvania State University's business school, said she found little evidence that cheating on term papers had increased when she compared a 1963 survey of students with one she wrote in 1993 with Donald McCabe, a Rutgers University professor who founded the Center for Academic Integrity. 
But Dr. McCabe said he believed that cheating on exams had increased sharply. In the 1960's, he said, one in four students admitted to cheating once or more on a test in the previous year. By 1993, that figure had doubled. 
Both researchers said that colleges that relied on an honor code appeared to have less cheating.
In 1993, 53 percent of students at schools without honor systems admitted to cheating once or more on a test in the previous year, while 29 percent of students at schools with honor codes admitted cheating. Two out of three students surveyed at colleges and universities without an honor code admitted to copying another student's papers, while 42 percent of students on honor codes said they had done so.
Thomas Hall, a student who heads the University of Virginia's Honor Committee, said that an investigative panel was going through the 122 cases Professor Bloomfield had referred, and that some students were found to have cheated and been told they would be expelled. Often, he said, the students whose papers were copied said they had shared their work to help a fellow student, but did not know it would be plagiarized. In those cases, the students have not been thrown out.
Several students under investigation had graduated, Mr. Hall said, and so could see their degrees revoked.
"The majority of students who don't cheat don't want to put up with those that do," said David Gies, a Spanish professor and former head of the faculty senate.
Professor Gies said that he welcomed Professor Bloomfield's discovery of cheating, and that the expulsions would force students to think twice about cheating.
At the Alderman Library, undergraduates facing final exams said the plagiarists should be punished, but some raised questions about the fairness of scrutinizing just one class. 
"I would agree to it if they could apply it to everyone," Chris Reams, a sophomore from Richmond, said.
He said he knew of students who cheated in advanced economics courses that were essential for admission to business school, driving up the grading curve. Though he considers them more serious offenders, he never reported them.
"The honor system is like a death penalty," Mr. Reams said. "Because it's so severe, if you see cheating, and I have, you're reluctant to report it, so we end up resorting to these spy systems. We've created an atmosphere that makes cheating more seductive."
Sean Turner and Jason Bakelar studied for a calculus test just hours away.
"I'm having a hard time finding a gray area when you say, What's cheating and what's not?" Mr. Bakelar, a senior majoring in politics, said.
Mr. Turner, a junior majoring in economics, agreed, saying students caught cheating should be expelled. "It's not fair to students like us," he said, "who study and do our work." 
But Kristen Edington, a freshman about to take a final in a class on religion and ethics said, "I think the honor system's an ideal." By giving students so much freedom, she said, "it sets up for people to cheat and steal and lie."

HEADLINE: Bit by Bit, Tiny Morland, Kan., Fades Away 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MORLAND, Kan. 

 BODY:
As a lawyer in this little town, Jerry Helberg does just about everything. He settles estates, writes contracts and wills, prepares tax returns and handles the rare small crime. Mr. Helberg is Morland's only lawyer. At 63, he is also probably its last, for this town is getting smaller by the year.
 Mr. Helberg's three grown children, all graduates of Morland High School, have moved away. 
 "There was no place here for them to take a job and make a living," he said. "Every one of them would come back if there was a job here." 
Morland, population 164, down from 234 in the 1990 census, sits squarely in the path of a decline that the 2000 census found sweeping through the small towns of the Great Plains. While the nation's population grew 13 percent in the 1990's, the Census Bureau found that 676 of the nation's 3,141 counties lost people. 
Most of the decline was in wheat, ranching and oil country in Texas, Oklahoma, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Minnesota and the Dakotas. In Kansas, for example, there are now more "frontier counties" -- defined by the census as having from two to six people per square mile -- than there were in 1890.
Graham County, which includes Morland, lost 17 percent of its population, which fell to 2,946 in the last decade. Within 50 miles of Morland, fading towns settled more than a century ago -- like Zurich, Palco, Jennings, Clayton and Dresden -- lost 15 percent to 30 percent of their inhabitants. In many places, headstones outnumber mailboxes 10 and 20 to 1.
The population of the Great Plains peaked in the 1930's, but many communities throughout the Plains had been losing people for nearly a century. Demographers spotted some recovery at the start of the 90's.
"In the early 90's there was some hope for what demographers call a population rebound," said Leonard Bloomquist, director of the Population Research Laboratory at Kansas State University in Manhattan. But those hopes quickly sank as water shortages impeded growth and as chain stores like Kmart and Wal-Mart opened in towns, helping them grow but draining business from smaller communities with stores that could not compete.
A town does not vanish in a single moment. Nor does it vanish for a single reason. In Morland's case, the decline was brought on by the mechanization of agriculture and nearly two decades of low wheat prices and shrinking oil fields.
The staples of the community fell away one by one. The Union Pacific Railroad pulled out in the mid-1990's; the tracks were pulled up a couple of years ago. The Methodist church lost its full-time pastor, so the parsonage, built in the 1970's, is rented out. Over the years, Morland has lost its opera house, one of two banks, its two-story hotel, the pool hall, its weekly newspaper, its lumber yard, its three gasoline stations, its automobile dealership, three clothing stores, the shoe store and two of three grocery stores.
In 1973, the town lost its furniture, hardware and mortuary businesses at once when Joe and Jane Nichols, who ran all three, died. The hardest loss will come on Saturday, when Morland High will graduate its last class and close its doors.
What is left is on increasingly unstable ground. Houses that remain sturdy are often close to worthless.
"How do you sell houses to people that aren't here?" asked Fred Pratt, Graham County's main real estate agent. In the county seat, Hill City, he said, "Most of my houses are in the $20,000 to $30,000 range."
Mark E. Niehaus, the county appraiser, said the assessed value of property dropped to $25.5 million last year, from $36.6 million in 1989.
Lana Barton, 32, a divorced mother of two, moved to Morland two years ago to be closer to her parents. She bought a four-bedroom house on Main Street.
"I paid $13,000 for it," Ms. Barton said. "It's a nice house, too."
But her plans exclude Morland. She is studying in Hays, an hour away, to be a teacher and expects to work away from Graham County. 
"I send my children to school in Hill City," she said. "It's a bigger school, with more going on."
The rolling prairie and pasture around Morland are bound by telephone lines and barbed wire, with outcroppings of sandy yellowish shale. Every two or three miles along Graham County's packed dirt roads, stands an empty farmhouse, its clapboard walls scraped of paint, its land rented or sold to big farmers. Occasionally the vista is broken by a rusty oil tank and drilling gear or the bones of a half-century-old tractor and other farm equipment. The roads, some paved, wear shifting layers of shale dust, which April storms whip into blistering fogs.
People do their best to get by. Fred Pratt runs farm auctions and sells real estate and used cars.
"We like living here," Mr. Pratt said. "It's a beautiful place. The only thing we don't like, you can't make any money to survive. My son is getting straight A's. He's not going to be around here."
Patty Minium Bean's father settled here in 1901 and became mayor. Her mother opened the Minium Dry Goods store on Main Street in 1958. Although it loses money, Mrs. Bean keeps it open, selling boots, overalls, zippers, thread and fabric.
"I should close it, but I just don't," Mrs. Bean said.
Her husband, Robert, 70, owns Bean's Country Store at Main and Tiger Streets, the latter named for the school's mascot, a fighting tiger. After school, until a couple of years ago, "the store would fill up with kids," said Faye E. Minium, president of Citizens State Bank on Main Street. "It doesn't anymore."
With the shuttering of Morland High, it is not likely to fill up again. The beginning of the end for Morland's combined high school and junior high came last July. Shelly Swayne, 27, the principal, waited for students to come in to talk about courses and sports for the next year.
"We kept waiting for people to walk in the door, and they never came," Ms. Swayne said. Days later, she said, "other schools started requesting our students' academic and health records."
A school that had graduated 20 to 30 students a decade ago opened this school year with just 19 high school students, an eighth grader and a seventh grader. Sports had to be discontinued, and students were sent to join Hill City High School's teams.
After some parents made clear that they would not enroll their children next fall, Morland's school board surveyed the remaining parents and found even more had decided to send their children to other schools, so the board voted in April to close the school. The elementary school with 30 pupils, an average of about four in each class, has been spared for a year.
"You shut your school and you take some of your identity away," said Todd Toll, 43, a home remodeler and chairman of the school board.
Terry Allison, 40, associate director of the Graham County United Methodist Parish who preaches here on alternate Sundays, said losing the school shook his few parishioners.
"They're proud to live where they are," Mr. Allison said. "But they feel they can't do anything to replenish what they had."
The school's closing is also shaking the economy. Last year, before the latest plunge in enrollment, Mr. Bean sold the school district $1,000 a week in food. This year he is selling it $500. Next year, he might get $350 from the grade school, then nothing.
For all that, the pioneer spirit still glows. Morland's residents take pride in their smart children and imperceptible crime rate. They relish their customs, like ham and eggs on Sunday night at Hill City's Western Hills Restaurant, their traffic-free roads and hunting wild turkeys and ringneck pheasants and fishing in Antelope Lake.
People are also doing their best to survive. Faye Minium's bank has opened branches in Hill City and WaKeeney, 25 miles south of Morland. With 800 checking accounts, almost five times the population of Morland, the bank has been growing about 15 percent a year, Ms. Minium said. She is also organizing a museum in a renovated bank building to draw tourists to Morland.
"You have to be somewhat of a pioneer to live here," she said.
Mr. Bean is reaching out, too. He persuaded small grocers in the region to combine their orders so they can get the volume discounts that wholesalers offer supermarkets, and he delivers the groceries to them.
Still, with downtowns boarded up and shopping strips struggling, the tide of flight from Graham County may be impossible to turn.
But interviews with six of Morland High's eight juniors and seniors revealed fiercely loyal Morland Tigers. Kyle Lemon, a junior who was sent last year to play for Hill City High's teams, said, "I still felt like a Tiger, even if I had to wear the red shirt" of the Hill City Ringnecks.
Georgann Meier, a cheerleader and hurdler whose mother owns the town's beauty salon and whose father works at the grain elevator, said of the school's closing: "I didn't want this to happen. You learn more at a small school. You can't hide."
But in their own aspirations, the school's final classes may be writing Morland's epitaph. Seven of the eight are children of farming families, but not one plans to become a farmer or to live in Morland.
Ms. Meier is going to a junior college across the state in Kansas City and then perhaps to a university.
"I will probably live in a small town, but not in Morland, Kan.," she said. "I'll probably come back when I retire, maybe."
Becky Ellis, 47, the music and special education teacher, is the third generation of her family to graduate from Morland High. She is the wife of a Morland farmer, and they sent their three children to Morland schools. The two older children have gone on to the University of Kansas. 
"Kids here are able to go as far as they can go," Mrs. Ellis said. But, she added, "I think the loss of the school is the beginning of the end of this community."

HEADLINE: Utility Seeks 2 Power Plants To Meet Long Island Demand 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., May 9 

 BODY:
The chairman of the Long Island Power Authority said today that the utility would propose two new power plants on Long Island to meet a demand for electricity that is growing at twice the state average and to avoid the kind of blackouts that have recently afflicted Californians.
 The chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said details about the location of the first plant would be announced Thursday, while information about the second would be announced this summer. The plants would be away from houses, in commercial or industrial areas or at sites where power plants already exist, said Mr. Kessel, who would not provide more details. 
 "While we're going to be O.K. this summer, and we're going to be nothing like California, we will be exactly like California in a couple of years if we don't start" the process for getting permits for at least two new power plants, Mr. Kessel said today at a news conference at a KeySpan Energy electric substation here. "Without some new on-Island power plants, we can't survive here." 
But even if the approval process begins by fall, as Mr. Kessel expects, the earliest the plants could be operating is in 2004. Then, they would add a combined 600 to 700 megawatts of power to LIPA's current available electricity capacity of 5,293 megawatts. LIPA estimates that in an extended heat wave, demand might rise to 5,023 megawatts. Demand is growing at a rate of 100 megawatts a year.
Mr. Kessel said a new plan for an electrical cable traversing the Long Island Sound, to Connecticut, would be proposed within 30 days in hopes of providing an additional 330 megawatts of power by summer 2002. An earlier LIPA plan for such a cable was rejected in March by Connecticut officials.
The first new power plant would be built and operated by KeySpan, and LIPA would buy a portion of the power for Long Island's 1.1 million electricity customers. But Mr. Kessel would not rule out LIPA's owning and operating future plants. LIPA is already considering buying 5 major power plants and more than 40 gas-powered turbine units from KeySpan, Mr. Kessel said.
Applications for the two new plants must be filed with the New York State Board on Electric Generation Siting and the Environment.
David Flanagan, a spokesman for the State Public Service Commission, said nine projects around the state -- for new plants and for work on existing plants -- have applications under review. Ten others are in the preapplication stage, including two in Brookhaven and one in Smithtown, which together would generate 1,630 megawatts.
Gerald A. Norlander, executive director of the Public Utility Law Project of New York, which represents low-income power users, said LIPA's plans for two new plants "is a common-sense and realistic" approach to the anticipated growth in demand for power. 
Long Island is unique in its transmission constraints, he said, so utilities have to strive for self-sufficiency "whether they build or enter into a contract to buy the power."
"Both of those are reasonable alternatives to either running short and having blackouts or having to pay exorbitant prices in the short-term wholesale market," Mr. Norlander said.
But Ashok Gupta, the senior energy economist with the nonprofit Natural Resources Defense Council in Manhattan, was skeptical.
"The public is still not convinced that either Long Island or the state knows what it is doing to solve the energy problems and is not, therefore, ready to support new power plants, whether built by private companies or built by the state," he said. "What the public perceives is a lot of confusion and no strategy."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Ad Revenue Drops At Magazines

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
 In another sign of the effect of the weakening economy on advertising and the media, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported yesterday that ad revenue in magazines declined in April compared with figures in the month a year earlier. 
 Ad revenue last month totaled almost $1.6 billion, down 1.2 percent from $1.62 billion in the month a year earlier. 
That decline was somewhat less than expected given the cutbacks many advertisers have made in print ad budgets. Ad pages for April fell off more sharply, down 9.5 percent from April 2000 to 23,330 from 25,791. For the first four months of 2001, revenue totaled $5.18 billion, up 0.3 percent from last year, and ad pages totaled 79,109, down 7.5 percent.

HEADLINE: M.I.T. Official Is Chosen to Be the President of Tufts 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Lawrence S. Bacow, chancellor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an architect of its research partnership with the University of Cambridge in England, was appointed president of Tufts University yesterday.
 In August, Dr. Bacow, 49, will succeed John DiBiaggio, who became president of Tufts in 1992 and who announced last fall that he intended to step down. Dr. Bacow, who received a Ph.D. in public policy from Harvard in 1978, will become the 12th president of Tufts since it was founded in Medford, Mass., in 1852. 
 A professor of environmental studies who specializes in resolving disputes over environmental policy, Dr. Bacow has served as one of two deputies to the president of M.I.T. since 1998. 
While his responsibilities at M.I.T. include overseeing graduate and undergraduate education, and strategic planning, his highest-profile assignment was the creation of the Cambridge-M.I.T. Institute in 1999. The institute, founded with an initial $108 million investment from the British government, is seeking to develop technologies and products to sharpen the competitiveness of British manufacturing industries.
Dr. Bacow, who earned his bachelor's degree at M.I.T. in 1972, said he hoped to build on a similar spirit of innovation and entrepreneurship at Tufts, where experts on nutrition and international diplomacy have already collaborated on efforts to ease world hunger, and where engineers have sought to improve the practice of dentistry.
"This is an institution that gained enormous stature in the last 10 to 20 years," said Dr. Bacow, who cited the 14,000 applications that Tufts received last fall for the 1,100 seats in its freshman class. "It's gone from being a regional institution to one that has national and international stature."
Dr. Bacow received a law degree from Harvard in 1976, but never practiced. The following year, he joined the department of urban studies and planning at M.I.T. He has since specialized in finding ways to forge consensus, outside the courts, on thorny environmental disputes like those over the location of hazardous waste facilities. He is the author or co-author of four books and is writing a fifth, "The New Protectionism: Environmental Policy in a Global Economy," for M.I.T. Press.
Dr. Bacow's wife, Adele Fleet Bacow, is a community planning consultant. They have two sons, one an undergraduate at M.I.T., the other at the University of Pennsylvania.
During Dr. DiBiaggio's nine-year tenure, the Tufts endowment has tripled, to nearly $600 million. Dr. DiBiaggio, 68, says he plans to continue his work "promoting issues of active citizenship."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence S. Bacow at a Boston news conference yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Competition Is Feverish As 3 Cities Woo Boeing 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 9 

 BODY:
Some cities will do just about anything to lure the Boeing Company.
 Denver trotted out John Elway, the football great, to greet Boeing executives when they scouted the city for their new headquarters; in Dallas, top executives were met by a mariachi band and a letter from Alex Rodriguez, the baseball superstar who recently left Seattle for Texas, encouraging Boeing to do the same. And Chicago played the culture card by uncorking a string quartet at a dinner with the city's elite at the Art Institute. 
 Now, just seven weeks after Boeing, the world's largest aerospace company, said that it would leave Seattle and move its corporate headquarters to either Chicago, Dallas or Denver, the competition is largely over and the three contestant cities are nervously awaiting a decision that could be announced as early as Thursday. 
News reports, which were unconfirmed, have put Chicago ahead in the horse race, though some accounts have Dallas way out front; most reports place Denver, whose economic incentives were perhaps least generous, as the underdog.
"We pretty much feel like everyone else does," said Andrew Hudson, a spokesman for Denver's mayor, Wellington Webb. "We just tried out for the high school play and we're waiting for them to post the results. We're the underdog, but we kind of like it that way."
Though the new Boeing headquarters would house only about 500 employees -- more than 70,000 manufacturing jobs will remain in the Seattle area -- each city hopes to gain in prestige and bragging rights what it cannot gain in head count.
Indeed, the high-stakes contest for Boeing has stirred not only the pride of the competitor cities, it has also created a sideshow to the effort to find a suitable home for Boeing and wrest tax breaks, subsidies and other concessions out of the process.
Newspaper columnists have weighed in on the advantages and disadvantages of luring Boeing. Television choppers have chased Boeing helicopters as top executives tried to scout locations in privacy; and Ron Kirk, the mayor of Dallas, has thrown in what could tip the balance in the Boeing sweepstakes.
"We've got chalupas; we've got tacos," he reportedly told Boeing executives.
Landing Boeing's headquarters would be more of a symbolic victory than an economic boom. With just 500 employees, Boeing would not even rank among the largest employers in the Chicago area. Sears, Roebuck; Sara Lee; and others have tens of thousands of employees here.
But the move would add cachet to an already big lineup and help Chicago send a message to a global audience. After losing some giant corporations, like Quaker Oats and Amoco, to mergers or acquisitions in recent years, Chicago is looking to snare another Fortune 500 company and prove that it is still the City of Big Shoulders.
'It would be a great shot in the arm for us," said Paul O'Connor, executive director of World Business Chicago, a nonprofit economic development association. "To be the place that sends a dramatic global message would be great.'
Critics have long debated the economic benefits of offering tax breaks, subsidies and other financial incentives to wealthy corporations. Now it is clear that Chicago, Denver and Dallas are willing to offer millions of dollars in incentives because they want more than 500 jobs; they believe attracting Boeing could give them enormous marketing influence and help persuade other corporations to follow suit.
"This says to the rest of the business world, 'This is a strong business environment,' " said Patty Silverstein, chief economist at the Metro Denver Network, an arm of the Denver Chamber of Commerce.
Though Boeing said it wanted to conduct a quick and low-key search for a new home, the company's announcement in March that it wanted to have a "leaner corporate center," touched off a media blitz and a frenzied triangular courtship.
Denver played host to Boeing executives by treating executives to buffalo meat and eggs at the Governor's Mansion, where Mr. Elway, the former Broncos quarterback, played top booster among a Who's Who in the business elite.
The news media in Denver were less cordial, though, openly questioning whether the city could handle any more growth. "Boeing executives are thinking about moving their luxurious suites to Colorado because of our quality of life in this little part of the world we call paradise," wrote Chuck Green, a columnist at The Denver Post. "Nearly 1.5 million people came here during the last 20 years for the same reason. So when is paradise lost?"
In Texas, where saying something is overgrown is a compliment, Boeing executives were showered with gifts. There were autographed pictures; a bobble-head doll in the likeness of Dirk Nowitzki, the German-born Dallas Mavericks basketball player known as the Flying Dutchman; and a letter from Alex Rodriguez, formerly of the Seattle Mariners and now the Texas Rangers' $252 million man.
Chicago chose to emphasize culture. A glossy brochure promoted the city's diversity, parks and neighborhoods. Top executives had dinner at the Art Institute, the museum that holds treasures like works by Cezanne and Edward Hopper. 
Chicago officials called it the soft sell, but when the executives tried to tour the city and its suburbs, their corporate jet was tailed by a local television station helicopter, and vans with other employees were pursued by car-bound journalists; the same thing happened in Dallas.
The press also printed daily rumors about where Boeing might move, what incentives it was offered and even who was believed to be the front-runner. They also offered subtle knocks of the competitor cities. In Texas, Boeing was greeted by great weather and blue skies. The Dallas Morning News contrasted that with the Chicago visit.
"Chicago didn't do as well when Boeing came to visit last week," The Morning News said. "The Windy City lived up to its name, welcoming Boeing with gusty days, rain and some snow flurries."
The relief from the corporate storm over the Boeing headquarters could come as early as Thursday. If news accounts are to be believed, Boeing's chief executive, Philip M. Condit, will not make the announcement until he is aboard the corporate jet. He will place a call to the three governors just before he touches down in the winning city. State and local officials confirmed today that they gave Boeing officials telephone numbers and their whereabouts over the next few days in case of the sudden announcement.
Boeing was typically mum on reports: "I can't talk about the process or the logistics of making an announcement," said Ken Mercer, a spokesman at Boeing.

HEADLINE: Labor Abuses In El Salvador Are Detailed In Document 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A long-suppressed report by the Salvadoran government, made public yesterday by an American labor rights group, spelled out serious problems in the country's apparel factories, including unhealthy air and water, large amounts of forced overtime and the frequent dismissal of workers who supported labor unions.
 The National Labor Committee made the copy available as part of a campaign by labor unions and their Democratic allies to pressure the Bush administration and Congress to include strong worker protections in any new trade agreements. 
 El Salvador's government originally issued the unusually critical report last August, but withdrew it from circulation the next day, saying it was technically flawed. On the day the report was issued, managers of the country's duty-free, export-oriented factories, known as the maquiladoras, denounced it. 
Last year, El Salvador exported $1.6 billion worth of apparel to the United States, making it the eighth-largest apparel exporter to this country.
The report found that many of the country's 229 apparel factories did not provide basic safety equipment and threatened to fire workers unless they agreed to work long hours of overtime. The report also faulted many factories for setting unrealistic production quotas and for requiring many workers to put in extra hours with no pay when they fell short of those quotas.
The report's harshest conclusion involved what it described as the systematic violation of workers' efforts to form unions.
"It was found that there exists an anti-union policy in the maquilas, by which any attempt at organization is repressed," said the report, prepared by the El Salvador Labor Ministry and financed in part by the United States Agency for International Development. "According to union leaders interviewed, it is very common for supervisors and chiefs of personnel to threaten workers with firings if they belong to a union or attempt to form one," it said.
The report noted that not one of the 229 maquiladora factories had a union contract. Many workers interviewed told Labor Ministry officials that there was a blacklist that factory managers used to make sure that known union supporters were not given jobs.
The report was made available just days after President Bush announced plans to seek expedited negotiating authority in the hope of establishing the Free Trade Area of the Americas, a duty-free trade zone from Canada to Chile. In a speech on Monday, Mr. Bush said such a free trade area was essential to improving living standards throughout the Western Hemisphere.
But union leaders assert that unless the treaty establishing the free trade area includes strong labor protections, it will encourage companies to move operations to countries with the worst wages and working conditions, thus undermining efforts to upgrade living standards.
The El Salvador report criticized the country's factory inspectors, saying that many workers interviewed were emphatic in declaring that there was a great deal of corruption among inspectors.
Jorge Nieto Menendez, El Salvador's minister of labor, said the government was seeking to train inspectors better. "We want investment, but only with respect and fairness," he said. "Only when workers' rights are respected can we generate more contracts with American companies."
The report describes how important the export apparel industry is for El Salvador, growing at a 13 percent annual rate and accounting for 79,000 jobs.
Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Commission, and several members of Congress are planning to hold a news conference today in Washington where they will issue a report detailing problems at El Salvador factories that make goods for many well-known companies, including Kohl's, the Gap, Liz Claiborne and Nike. That report found that many apparel workers face mandatory pregnancny tests, work 80-hour weeks and have to work in temperatures of more than 90 degrees.
The Labor Ministry report found that many workers complained about inadequate wages. According to the report, many workers said that despite the many hours of overtime they worked, "the wage was insufficient to satisfy their family needs with dignity."
Factory managers told the labor ministry that an important reason that employees have to work so much overtime is that, in their view, the workers deliberately delay production to force the company to continue operations beyond the normal shift, thus allowing the workers to receive overtime pay.

HEADLINE: Annan in Washington to Seek AIDS Funds 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 9 

 BODY:
Against a background of rising anger in Congress over the loss of American seats on two United Nations panels, Secretary General Kofi Annan went to Washington today to ask the Bush administration for more money to fight AIDS in Africa.
 Mr. Annan has proposed a global fund to provide $7 billion to $10 billion annually on top of money already being spent to battle AIDS and other infectious diseases. He met this afternoon with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the secretary of health and human services, Tommy Thompson. 
 General Powell told reporters after the meeting that the talks had been "excellent."
Mr. Annan has been invited to the White House on Friday, when President Bush is expected to announce an initial pledge to the AIDS fund, probably about $200 million. 
But an administration official said the United States would have certain criteria for establishing the fund and would expect other leading industrial nations to contribute.
On Friday Mr. Annan will take part in talks with President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, who recently convened a summit-level meeting of African leaders to discuss the AIDS crisis. 
Africa has about 70 percent of the world's 36 million people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and 17 million Africans have died of the disease. Epidemics -- tuberculosis and malaria as well as AIDS -- are not only shortening African lives but also creating havoc in already weak economies.
Secretary General Annan's trip to Washington today, in advance of a special General Assembly session on AIDS next month, was planned to focus strictly on his proposed global fund. 
The deputy United Nations spokesman, Manoel de Almeida e Silva, said after the meeting that no other topics had been discussed. Some officials had expected that broader questions about United States relations with the United Nations would arise, but they did not.
As Mr. Annan made the rounds in Washington today, the Bush administration sought to halt Congressional efforts to put pressure on the United Nations to reinstate the United States to the two committees -- the Human Rights Commission and the International Narcotics Control Board.
On Tuesday leaders of the House International Relations Committee agreed to a plan agreeing to pay $582 million in back dues owed to the United Nations but withholding $244 million unless the United States was voted back onto the rights commission.
"We don't think that linking our obligations and payments to the United Nations to the outcome of that particular vote is a good idea," said Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman. "We think that that would be extremely damaging to our ability to cooperate in multilateral organizations and with a sense that we are a reliable participant in these organizations and that we'll pay our way."
Mr. Annan met today with Senator William H. Frist, Republican of Tennessee. Mr. Frist, a well-known surgeon before turning to politics, was among a group of senators that introduced a bill in early April committing the United States to a contribution of $1 billion to fight AIDS over the next two years. 
Various programs taken together now total less that half of that, though the United States remains the largest single contributor to anti-AIDS campaigns globally.
In March Senator Frist, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Africa, asked the General Accounting Office to study how effectively American money was spent in Africa to combat AIDS through the United States Agency for International Development, which handles a large part of the budget. 
That study found that while the agency had been allocated a 53 percent increase in its budget for Africa this year -- to $174 million from $114 million -- there still were problems in distributing the assistance.
The study found, for example, that Congressional restrictions on assistance to foreign military forces got in the way of programs aimed at troops and police officers. 
The General Accounting Office referred to a National Intelligence Council report that between 10 percent and 60 percent of soldiers in sub-Saharan Africa were infected with H.I.V. For example, in Tanzania, the report said, the infection rate in the armed forces is between 15 percent and 30 percent, compared with 8 percent in the general population. Similar patterns were found in other countries.
The G.A.O. report said that laws limiting American aid to foreign troops were a "disincentive" to pursuing prevention campaigns where they might be most needed.
Members of Congress have also restricted family planning assistance in efforts to prevent money from going to organizations that advocate abortions. Family planning experts say that contraceptives, particularly condoms, are the most effective weapon in preventing AIDS, and that there is not enough money to meet international needs.
Diplomats and members of Congress say it is hard to judge what effect if any the confrontation between Washington and the United Nations will have on Mr. Annan's efforts to involve the United States in his global campaign against the AIDS epidemic. Officials here say Mr. Annan regrets the unexpected votes that dropped American representatives from international panels.
In an interview on Tuesday, General Powell said of the American setbacks at the United Nations, "Kofi Annan is as distressed as we are."
For much of last year, Richard C. Holbrooke, the Clinton administration's United Nations envoy, had to drop most other issues to campaign for reduced American dues in return for a promise to pay arrears totaling more than $1 billion. 
Today, Fred Eckhard, spokesman for Mr. Annan, said the secretary general had told a meeting of senior United Nations officials this morning before leaving for Washington that he was concerned about calls in Congress to punish the organization for votes cats by fewer than one-third of its member nations.
"Punishing all 189 member states would be counterproductive, and punishing the bureaucracy would be unfair," Mr. Eckhard quoted Mr. Annan as saying. The secretary general also recognized the significant contributions the United States had made to the commission since its inception in 1947 and hoped that the United States would be voted back onto the rights commission next year, Mr. Eckhard said. The next election takes place next spring.
Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, who was here for the senior officials' meeting, said there was "shock and dismay" in Geneva last week when the results of the voting became known.

HEADLINE: IN SHOW OF UNITY, HOUSE REPUBLICANS PASS BUDGET BILL 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER with DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9 

 BODY:
Again displaying a solid wall of support for President Bush, House Republicans voted nearly unanimously today to pass a budget resolution that was favored by the president and opposed by nearly all the Democrats. 
 The vote was the latest in a string of House victories for Mr. Bush on issues like ergonomics, bankruptcy rules and tax cuts, and it illustrated how House Republicans were defying expectations that their narrow majority would leave them hamstrung by infighting. 
 Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, the Budget Committee chairman, said the votes of all but 3 of the 220 House Republicans reflected the wide support the measure had from conservatives, who were "satisfied that we have held the line on spending," and moderates, who were pleased that the tax cut contained in the measure was a bit smaller than the original March version.
But the legislative details are less striking than the unity, which has set off complaints from Democrats, who say that Republican partisanship exceeds all decent bounds, and celebration among Republican leaders, who hope that the cohesiveness will help them increase their 10-vote majority. 
The vote approving the budget resolution, 221 to 207, included support from six Democrats. The final vote in the Senate is scheduled for Thursday. Congressional leaders said they would not allow the measure to come to final votes unless they were certain it would be passed by the Senate. The measure, which White House and Congressional negotiators agreed to last week, would allow $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years and nearly $2 trillion in spending in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.
Republicans argued that they had set aside sufficient money for Social Security, Medicare, debt reduction and other needs and had plenty left for a tax cut.
"Who does the money belong to?" Mr. Nussle asked. "The American people."
Democrats said the measure would allow too much tax reduction for the wealthy and was dishonest in that the spending limits for the military and other programs were sure to be exceeded.
"This is the day Republicans return to high deficits and high interest rates that could stall our wonderful engine of economic growth,"said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader.
There are at least four major reasons the Republicans' thin margin has been enough to help pass the Bush agenda.
First, that agenda has been kept simple, focused on the most unifying issue to Republicans -- tax cuts and their cousins, budget resolutions. As Representative Phil English of Pennsylvania said: "We've been hitting on the easier stuff. There hasn't been much to set off any ideological war."
Even a potential split over education has been papered over, at least for now, with approval today by a House committee of an education bill backed by Mr. Bush that would require annual testing in grades three through eight. Conservative Republicans complained that the bill no longer contained a measure backed by Mr. Bush to give parents of students from failing schools vouchers to use for private school tuitions. But enough conservatives set aside their opposition, and the committee passed the bill 41 to 7. 
But they have also succeeded because of effective party leadership, from a patient Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to a hard-driving, persistent majority whip in Tom DeLay; pride in President Bush and a desire to see him succeed; and the narrow majority itself, which reminds Republicans that if they do not hang together, they will not really be running the House.
As Mr. DeLay said last week, "The closer the majority, the easier it is to hold people together."
That maxim plainly does not work in the Senate, where the Republican majority is only one vote -- when Vice President Dick Cheney is there -- and Republican senators desert their leaders on issues like taxes and campaign finance. But the Senate is a different place, where members have larger and more diverse constituencies, where independence and individualism are exalted. 
Of course, issues like family planning abroad, support for the United Nations, and other ideologically charged matters can still create deep divisions among Republicans. And the education bill will test the Republicans' winning streak in the House, where it will be considered as early as next week. Because enough conservatives are likely to oppose this legislation, a strong Democratic vote will be needed. And everything done to please the Democrats risks displeasing more Republicans.
But thus far, Republicans' unity has been astounding. Of eight important measures adopted through last week, Republican dissent reached double digits only twice. The Republicans who voted against the budget resolution today were Representatives Charles Bass of New Hampshire, Joel Hefley of Colorado and Ron Paul of Texas. Democrats voting for the measure were Representatives Gary A. Condit of California, Ralph M. Hall of Texas, Earl F. Hilliard of Alabama, Chris John of Louisiana, Ken Lucas of Kentucky and James A. Traficant Jr. of Ohio. 
Democrats grumble over the Republican unity. Representative Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota accuses Republican moderates of "abject surrender" to the "hard right wing." Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, known for seeking accommodation across party lines, said that the Republicans' excluding Democrats from budget discussions "is about as bad as it can get."
Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts said, "They believe that the Democratic minority is a nuisance to be tolerated, rather than elected representatives." (When Democrats ran the House until 1994, Republicans said much the same things about them.)
Mr. DeLay replies that "Democrats have devoted themselves to one thing only: total and complete obstruction."
But much as they would like to, House Democrats have not managed to obstruct anything important.
The biggest difference for House Republicans is the Bush presidency. Only 69 of the 220 Republicans ever served under a Republican president, and then they were in a minority; they delight in the change. Representative Jennifer Dunn of Washington, said, "It's very important to us to make him succeed." 
Representative Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, credits Mr. Bush's leadership with making "the fractured nature of the Republican conference almost nonexistent."
Party leadership shows in those lopsided votes. Mr. DeLay says he talks weekly to almost every Republican. Representative Peter Hoekstra of Michigan said, "This guy intuitively knows how far the leadership can push."
Even some Republicans who think Mr. DeLay's views are too far to the right credit him with diligent, determined leadership.
But while Democrats, seizing on those views and his hard-edged partisanship, would like to portray Mr. DeLay as running the House, most Republicans insist that their low-key speaker, Mr. Hastert, is in charge. Representative David Dreier of California, chairman of the Rules Committee, said, "Here's a guy who has incredible patience, he has large groups of members who come in and, for lack of a better term, beat him up on things. And he takes it, and then gets them to go along."
Ms. Dunn identified another reason for the successes: dealing with tax legislation they had worked on in previous years: "We knew the strengths and the weaknesses -- what would come up. We already had our act together." 
The education bill is a different matter. As Mr. DeLay said last week, "Many on our right don't see education as a responsibility of the federal government."
He should know. Opposing a Clinton measure to pay for increased testing -- the cornerstone of Mr. Bush's plan -- Mr. DeLay said in 1998, "We don't need the federal government and national organizations getting involved in our local school districts." 
Mr. DeLay may see things differently now, since it is Mr. Bush making the proposal.

HEADLINE: The Next Mayor's Education Agenda 

 BODY:
Polls show that New York City voters rank education at the top of their issues list this year. It should therefore come as no surprise that so do the candidates who hope to succeed Rudolph Giuliani as mayor. The city has 1.1 million public-school students, many with parents who vote. But plenty of people who do not have children in the public schools are no less concerned about the sad state of those schools. This broad interest in better schools offers the mayoral candidates an unusual opportunity to wrestle with a problem that looks as intractable today as the city's crime rate appeared to be a few years ago. 
 The basics clearly come first. A State Supreme Court justice framed the city's problem in stark terms in January. The state, he said, has failed in its obligation to provide New York City's students with a "sound, basic education" as required by the State Constitution. The two worst problems the next mayor will confront are acute shortages of both space and certified teachers, which in turn create overcrowded classrooms. Solving both problems will require the political will to commit extra state and city money to New York City's schools. 
 City officials estimate that they will need almost 70,000 new seats by 2004. Even now, thousands of high school students attend in shifts and are robbed of a full day of class just when they need it most. At the same time an entire generation of teachers, including some of the best in the system, is preparing to retire, greatly complicating the chancellor's job of finding enough certified replacements. Meanwhile recruitment is hobbled by the fact that the city offers less pay than the suburbs, even though city jobs make demands that suburban teachers rarely face -- including the hassle of ensuring order in large and unwieldy classes and introducing students who speak 140 different languages to a new educational and civic environment.
There are other factors over which the candidates now have little control. If Mayor Giuliani negotiates a short-term contract with teachers, or fails to negotiate any contract at all, the next mayor will face a labor problem. If the State Legislature fails to abolish the Board of Education, the next mayor will have less authority over city schools than he requires. If Albany shies away from extra funding in its new education formula, or the City Council fails to restore Mr. Giuliani's cuts in education money, the next mayor could have his educational agenda clipped from the outset.
Such an accounting of the city's education needs can make New York's school problems seem insurmountable. But if a city of eight million can be made to work better, as Mr. Giuliani has demonstrated it can be, then surely the nation's largest public school system can work better as well. 
Historically, New York's public schools have brought millions of immigrants into the American mainstream and have helped fill this vibrant city with productive citizens. Good schools are central to New York City's quality of life and to its economic base, both of which decline when the middle class flees to suburban schools. The city and the country lose ground, both educationally and in terms of social justice, when poor children find themselves trapped in a crumbling system that serves only to reinforce their poverty.
