HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Microsoft shakes up beleaguered San Francisco agencies by shifting its account for Ultimate TV.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THERE may be a shortage of jobs and clients in the San Francisco advertising market as a result of the dot-com meltdown. But there is no shortage of drama as evidenced by big changes that involve Microsoft and several local agencies.
 Microsoft is dismissing FCB Worldwide in San Francisco, which had served as the creative agency for Ultimate TV, the digital video recorder being introduced to compete against brands like TiVo and ReplayTV. Microsoft is hiring a San Francisco start-up shop, Venables/ Bell & Partners, to create campaigns for Ultimate TV with an annual budget estimated at $50 million. 
 Venables/Bell is being formed by three executives, two of whom worked until this week at another San Francisco agency, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners. But Goodby, Silverstein's top managers say they have no problem with the departures, though one of the executives had been designated part of the next generation of agency leaders.
Why the calm reaction? The executives could not have handled the Ultimate TV assignment and remained at Goodby, Silverstein because that agency works for TiVo. So the top managers at Goodby, Silverstein, owned by the Omnicom Group, are bidding a fond farewell to the departing executives, helping them by providing the start-up shop with office space and equipment.
The shifts are indicative of the rapid-fire series of changes that can take place when economic uncertainty clouds the advertising outlook. Nowhere is that more the case right now than San Francisco, where the dot-com boom of 1999 and 2000 has spiraled downward into a bust that has resulted in abrupt cutbacks, layoffs and closings.
"There is nothing ever in stone in advertising," said Rich Silverstein, co-chairman at Goodby, Silverstein. "Everything is constantly in flux in this nutty business. You just have to manage the flux."
Jeff Goodby, the other co-chairman, said that the departures of the executives -- Paul Venables, promoted in June 2000 to creative director and associate partner, and Greg Bell, group creative director -- were "disappointing."
"But it would be hypocritical for us to say a good creative team ought not to leave an agency to start another agency," he added, because he and Mr. Silverstein left Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco in 1983 to start Goodby, Silverstein with a third partner, Andy Berlin.
"They have our blessing," Mr. Silverstein said. "Hal Riney gave it to us, and we give it to them."
Mr. Venables, 35, a copywriter, and Mr. Bell, 31, an art director, have a third partner, too. He is Bob Molineaux, 41, a management executive with whom they worked on various accounts at Goodby, Silverstein before Mr. Molineaux left to join another San Francisco agency, Citron Haligman Bedecarre, now part of AKQA. Mr. Venables and Mr. Bell will be co-creative directors at Venables/Bell and Mr. Molineaux will be president.
"The smart, savvy marketers scrutinize their advertising at a time like this and ask, 'Am I getting a return on my investment, or is what's on the air a financial drain?' " Mr. Venables said.
"We have a pretty good track record of making sure what's on the air is not a financial drain," he added. He and Mr. Bell are leaving Goodby, Silverstein after working together there on accounts like Discover Card, Netflix, SBC Communications and Sutter Home wine. Mr. Molineaux worked with them on SBC and Sutter Home.
"What we discovered working together, the three of us," said Mr. Molineaux, who since January has served as the managing director of the New York office of AKQA, "is that we were able to take difficult client situations and manage them where the outcome was better creative."
"In a bad economy, clients are very often looking to switch agencies," he added, "and they're looking for someone who thinks a little out of the box." Goodby, Silverstein is known for irreverent ads featuring characters like the Budweiser lizards and the E*Trade Group chimp as well as "Got milk?" and a new Hewlett-Packard campaign centered on employees.
Mr. Venables's promotion at Goodby, Silverstein elevated him into the ranks of the next generation along with Steve Simpson, creative director and partner. Other creative executives will now assume Mr. Venables's duties and work with Mr. Simpson, Mr. Goodby and Mr. Silverstein said.
The SBC connection is not only bringing together Mr. Venables, Mr. Bell and Mr. Molineaux, it is also bringing them their first client. The three worked with Bill Morgan, vice president for marketing at Ultimate TV, and Beth Kachellek, director for advertising and brand management at Ultimate TV, who are based in Mountain View, Calif., when those two executives were at SBC.
While the fact that Ultimate TV is leaving FCB San Francisco for a start-up shop is surprising, the leaving itself is less so. Trade publications have reported a rocky relationship between the two. That was demonstrated in March, when a television campaign for Ultimate TV was created not by FCB San Francisco but by Rodgers Townsend in St. Louis, which had originally been hired to handle brand identity work, not advertising.
The loss of the Ultimate TV creative account is another blow for FCB San Francisco, owned by True North Communications. It has lost other high-profile clients like Amazon.com and suffered layoffs after the Compaq Computer account was shifted to the FCB New York office.
Venables/Bell will handle creative and media planning for Ultimate TV. Media buying is handled by the Universal McCann division of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
In exchange for accepting Mr. Goodby and Mr. Silverstein's help, Mr. Venables and Mr. Molineaux said they promised not to hire staff members from Goodby, Silverstein. That's a sore point with Mr. Goodby and Mr. Silverstein, who often complain they have been raided too many times by former employees opening their own shops.
"They can pick from many trees, not one," Mr. Silverstein said, laughing.
Besides, Mr. Venables said, with all the laid-off advertising employees in San Francisco right now, "there's lots of good talent on the street."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
To the Thinnest Of Applause, Europeans Cut Interest Rates

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: LEIPZIG, Germany, May 10 

 BODY:
Having insisted for months that Europe had no need to join the rest of the world in easing monetary policy, the European Central Bank unexpectedly shifted ground today and reduced its benchmark interest rate.
 The modest rate cut -- of one-quarter of a percentage point, to 4.5 percent -- appeared to reflect increasing concern that the American economic slowdown might indeed hurt the European economy more than originally thought. 
 But the move evoked criticism by economists, who accused the central bank of being contradictory and slow to respond. Far from comforting markets by providing easier money, they said, the bank had undermined its own credibility and provided new evidence of its shakiness in making decisions. 
The lack of steady leadership, and the increasing difficulty that central bankers from the 12-nation euro zone have had in reaching agreement, makes it less likely than before that Europe can step in as the engine of world economic growth if the American economic slowdown becomes protracted.
A month ago, the European Central Bank resisted pleas to emulate the Federal Reserve by reducing interest rates and giving European economies a boost. "I hear, but I do not listen," remarked Wim Duisenberg, the central bank's president, in his most concise articulation of such go-it-alone sentiment.
Today, Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged that little had changed since last month on either the prospects for economic growth or for inflation. The main piece of additional news, he said, had been that the money supply grew somewhat more slowly than previously thought.
To which, Adolf Rosenstock, an economist with Nomura International in London, remarked: "How much more contradictory can you be? What kind of monetary policy is it? You can't pin them down."
Thomas Mayer, a senior economist with the Goldman Sachs Group in Frankfurt, said the move vividly demonstrated the difficulty of the European Central Bank's governors in reaching agreement.
"The Federal Reserve surprises by making decisions earlier than people expect," Mr. Mayer said. "The E.C.B. surprises by making decisions later than people expect."
None of this was particularly good news for the common currency, the euro, which has lost nearly a quarter of its value against the dollar since 11 European nations adopted it in 1999. (The 12th euro zone member, Greece, joined in January.) After jumping briefly in European trading today when the interest rate cut was announced, the euro declined, settling in New York late in the day at 88.16 cents, down from 88.42 cents on Wednesday.
The European Central Bank's troubles stood in contrast to a smoother course at the Bank of England, which also lowered its key interest rate by a quarter-point today, to 5.25 percent. The British had signaled their intention well in advance.
Britain -- which has not adopted the euro and conducts its own monetary policy -- has had relative stability in the exchange value of the pound, which settled at $1.4233 today, as well as a rise in value against the euro. Still, the British economy may be more vulnerable to American economic weakness than Continental Europe's because American investment is higher there. British interest rates are now at their lowest since November 1999, but are the highest among the Group of Seven industrial nations.
In many ways, the European bank's timing could not have been worse. The bank disappointed the markets last month by refusing to reduce rates, maintaining that the dangers of inflation were too serious to be ignored. Since then, new data have heightened inflation worries and seemed to validate the bank's hawkish views. In Germany, which accounts for about a third of the euro zone's economic output, inflation reports from individual states last week suggested that prices were climbing at nearly 3 percent a year, higher than the central bank's target of 2 percent or less. 
Yet the most recent data on industrial production and factory orders, which dropped sharply in Germany, have confirmed widespread expectations of a modest slowdown. 
Most private economists, as well as those at the European Central Bank, still say that economic growth will be about 2.5 percent this year -- slower than in 2000, but not as slow as they expect in the United States.
So what has changed? At a news conference in Frankfurt today, Mr. Duisenberg said the money supply had climbed more slowly than thought as a result of statistical distortions. On top of that, he said, wage increases had continued to be moderate. 
Mr. Duisenberg sounded downright optimistic about inflation risks even though senior European Central Bank officials have been issuing a steady stream of warnings for the last several weeks. "It can now be concluded that there is no threat to price stability over the medium term," he said. "Wage moderation has so far been maintained for the euro area as a whole. This has been a very positive factor."
But economists' reactions to such explanations ranged from skepticism to scorn. "The forecasts for the next year did not change," said Norbert Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Research. "This was not news. This was something that everybody had known and that the E.C.B. could have known. I don't see any reason why they had to pick today to change policy."
Mr. Mayer of Goldman Sachs said that today's move demonstrated that the European Central Bank ultimately followed conventional wisdom, but took a long time to reach each new agreement.
In the last several weeks, the bank has come under strong pressure to relax monetary policy. Finance ministers from countries including Belgium and Austria have publicly called for rate cuts. The International Monetary Fund as well as the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have also argued for an interest rate reduction.
But in cutting rates, after repeatedly saying that it would wait and see, the central bank seemed to be capitulating to pressure. That is not the kind of image that central banks want to cultivate, and it did nothing today to bolster confidence in the euro.
"The E.C.B. has always had a problem getting people to understand what it is doing," Mr. Mayer said "This is not going to help."
Mr. Duisenberg rejected such views. "New facts lead to new assessments," he said. "It has nothing to do with pressure."
Mr. Walter of Deutsche Bank argued that today's rate cut could in fact help slow economic growth because it was so modest that investors would almost certainly be betting on additional rate cuts in the months ahead.
"If there has been a new assessment," he said, "consumers may well delay their spending and businesses may delay investments because they are expecting rates to become even lower in the future."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Substantial Cutbacks For 2 Big Agencies

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Two large agencies -- the United States division of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York and Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex. -- are making significant cutbacks and staff reductions.
 Lowe Lintas, based in London and part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is closing its San Francisco office, leaving the agency with only one office in the United States. 
 "The factors in this decision are twofold," said Gary Goldsmith, United States chairman and chief creative officer at Lowe Lintas, "the dramatically softening San Francisco-region advertising market and a radical reduction of advertising-related spending and viable new-business opportunities in that marketplace."
At its height, the Lowe Lintas San Francisco office, which opened in April 1997, had 60 employees and billings estimated at $150 million from clients like Eddie Bauer, InterNAP Network Services, Sun Microsystems and ZDNet. The agency closes with 27 employees and billings estimated at $15 million from clients like Disney Quest and Virgin Mobile USA.
Efforts are being made to find jobs for the remaining employees at other San Francisco agencies or other Interpublic agencies, said Michael Draznin, a spokesman for Lowe Lintas. He added that Buz Sawyer, president and general manager at the office, is looking at options inside and outside the Lowe Group and Interpublic.
Lowe Lintas closed its Chicago office 14 months ago after the largest account there, Ameritech, departed because of a merger. Last week, the New York office laid off 18 employees, or about 2.4 percent of the staff.
Temerlin McClain is laying off about 20 percent of its staff of 550 employees, said Dennis McClain, chief executive, because of the economic slowdown, a loss of accounts and the coming acquisition of its parent, True North Communications, by Interpublic. 
The estimated 102 employees who are being dismissed come from across the agency.

HEADLINE: Judge Blocks New Forest Protection Rules 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10 

 BODY:
A federal judge in Idaho blocked the Clinton administration's forest-protection plan today, saying that if the rules went into effect as scheduled on Saturday, they could cause "irreparable long-term harm" to local communities.
 The ruling by the judge, Edward J. Lodge of Federal District Court in Boise, abruptly halted a plan that would have put about a third of the national forests off limits to road building and most logging. After an internal review, the Bush administration said last week that it would carry out the rules but with major amendments, a plan that Judge Lodge rejected today as "a Band-Aid approach." 
 In ruling in favor of a challenge by the State of Idaho and Boise Cascade, the giant timber company, Judge Lodge recalled his own earlier scorching opinions in which he had accused the Clinton administration of drafting the rule without adequate attention to local concerns. 
In issuing a preliminary injunction, the judge sided with arguments by Idaho, Boise Cascade and other opponents, who say the restrictions could cause economic harm to the state and to the timber and mining industries. The plaintiffs argued that the administration had failed to meet its obligation under federal law to take those concerns into account. 
A Justice Department official said tonight that the administration had not decided whether to appeal the ruling. But environmental groups granted status as intervenors in the case said they would challenge the decision in the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. 
They said that the Bush administration's defense of the Clinton plan had been only lukewarm and that its proposal to give local officials considerable power over road building restrictions could leave the plan essentially hollow.
The environmental lawyers said they saw no basis for the judge's finding that letting the rule take effect would cause harm.
But in his decision, Judge Lodge said, "Once something of this magnitude is set in motion, momentum is irresistible, options are closed and agency commitments, if not set in concrete, will be the subject of litigation for years to come."
In Idaho, Gov. Dirk Kempthorne said the decision had "affirmed what the State of Idaho has contended all along," that the decision-making process was flawed and that the policy could deny the state vital revenue from logging and crucial access to state lands. The governor said the decision would now allow local decision making "to be at the front end of any future planning process for our nation's forests."
The Bush administration has made clear that it shares Western concerns that the process used to shape the rules had trampled on local interests, but it also recognizes the broad public support for protecting forest areas. 
The environmentalists said that a failure by the Bush administration to offer a stronger defense of the Clinton rule before the Boise court appeared to have cleared the way for the injunction, perhaps intentionally. They said they feared that the administration would now use the ruling to justify its plan to put in rules that would allow local forest managers to amend or ignore broad forest protection regulations case by case.
In announcing that plan last week, Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said the administration was trying to address concerns raised by Judge Lodge in earlier rulings.
Environmental groups have been skeptical of the idea that the administration's hands were tied.
"The Bush administration has made it clear that it's using this judge's opinion as a rationale for reopening and potentially gutting a hugely popular conservation measure," said Niel Lawrence, a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "And until we can get the Ninth Circuit to rule on this, this will only add fuel to the fire for them." 
In a brief filed last Friday, Justice Department lawyers said the government opposed the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction. But it was unclear whether the administration would decide to join the environmentalists in any appeal.
Administration officials said high-level meetings on that subject were scheduled for Friday.
To support his order, Judge Lodge cited what he called the Bush administration's "own admission" that its officials "share plaintiffs' concerns about the potential for irreparable harm in the long-term under the current rule."
He did not spell out what potential harm he believed might occur, but he cited warnings by the state and timber industry that the rule would restrict logging, energy development and other activities already planned for parts of the forest.
He also mentioned the plaintiffs' argument that if the rule remained in place, it would "cause a chilling effect that will preclude local Forest Service officials from planning future management activities." 
The rule, issued by the Clinton administration on Jan. 5, was developed over three years in which there were scores of public meetings and more than a million people commented on the plan to the Forest Service. Critics, led by Western states and the timber companies, argued all along that the outcome was preordained and noted that states and communities in the West were given no role in the decisionmaking.
Environmentalists have praised the Clinton rule as the most extensive land-conservation act in decades.
"Today's decision means the chainsaws can roar while the timber industry tries to dismantle a popular effort to protect our last wild forests," said Carl Pope, the executive director of the Sierra Club. 
Among those who have long criticized the Clinton rule, Senator Larry E. Craig, the Idaho Republican who heads the Senate forest subcommittee, had confidently predicted the ruling even before the judge issued his decision this afternoon.
"I do believe that President Clinton and his people intentionally attempted to step around the National Environmental Policy Act, and I believe the judge and I and others caught them in that," Mr. Craig said in a telephone interview. "And I don't believe that a flawed document that was designed in an illegal way should stand." 
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who heads the Senate Energy Committee, said: "It is fully appropriate given the legal infirmities that the judge stopped this rule dead in its tracks. The ruling allows the Bush Administration to start with a clean slate and to make forest policy in a proper manner." 
Despite the injunction, environmentalists said the only place timber projects that would have been blocked under the Clinton plan are in a position to go forward in the near future would be in the Tongass National Forest of Alaska, the country's largest. But there, they noted, the proposed timber sales that may be affected have been blocked for now by a separate court injunction.
They said they would watch closely for signs that the administration is using the ruling to put in place policies very different from those envisioned by the Clinton administration. One decision could come later this month, when the White House will issue a report on energy that may call for new oil and gas exploration on public lands that the Clinton administration had been trying to put off limits.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "BEAUTY, HONOR AND TRADITION: THE LEGACY OF PLAINS INDIAN SHIRTS," Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through Nov. 4). To Plains Indians of the 18th and 19th centuries, magnificently decorated hide shirts were symbols of bravery earned only by the most courageous in battle. Obsessively fringed and embellished with porcupine quills, paint, ribbon, hair and, later, tight patterns of colored glass beads, the shirts took on the spirits of their owners and even today are made for wearing at powwows and in recognition of other accomplishments. Celebrating the power of this glory gear, almost 50 dazzlers in the museum's collection are on view, dating from about 1820 to the 1990's. Among the more fascinating examples are a brilliantly painted Crow shirt (1890) with beadwork in geometric patterns and frizzy fringes of dyed magenta and yellow hair and a Lakota shirt, circa 1890, that carries United States Army insignia, the American flag and stepped tepees topped by crosses, all worked in porcupine quills and metal beads. Hours: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Free. (Grace Glueck).

* "BITSTREAMS" AND "DATA DYNAMICS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through June 10). Companion digital shows with a well-mannered, slightly dull air of decorous efficiency and cheerful modernity that encapsulates what you may regard as an ethos at large. Both affairs survey the new technological age in art, and there is no denying the inevitability of the big message here, which we discount at the risk of sheer stupidity: technology is changing how artists, especially young ones, make all types of art and, in turn, how we experience it. Still, the work produced needs to answer the old question: Does it move us? And there's the rub. A few artists, like Paul Pfeiffer and Jeremy Blake, stand out in "BitStreams." In "Data Dynamics," works like "Apartment" and "Netomat," metaphors for the Web as global unconscious, suggest that Internet art is at least becoming more like traditional media, whereby most but no longer all of what you see is unremarkable. Don't skip the sound section in "BitStreams," 25 audio artists working squarely in the tradition of musique concrete, a half-century-old movement but with new digital means replacing tape recorders. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays; Saturdays, Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "WILLIAM BLAKE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 24). A touching and beautiful show if you have a taste for Blake's art, which strives for ecstatic revelation on the level of his famous visions and rises to the heights of his verse, sometimes. From the Age of Aquarius to New Age, he has come to serve as the patron saint of flower children, Jungians, Freudians, occultists, spiritualists, nudists, unpublished authors, animal lovers, socialists and teenagers of the sort who read Hermann Hesse. By turning our attention to his laborious illustrations and watercolors, the exhibition compels us to think about him as a serious and original visual artist, which is to say as a more idiosyncratic and substantial figure than the cliches suggest. He truly believed that the world was ending and that he had been sent to set things right at the last minute. Whatever else he may or may not have been, Blake was the most genuine and uncompromising artist you can think of. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"MARC CHAGALL: EARLY WORKS FROM RUSSIAN COLLECTIONS," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Oct. 14). When Chagall returned to Russia in 1914 after four years in Paris, he intended to marry his beloved fiancee Bella Rosenfeld and then hurry back to the French capital. Instead World War I and the Russian Revolution kept him in his homeland for eight years, during which he did some of his greatest works. The 60 here, most being exhibited in the West for the first time, form a series of intense Chagallian doses rather than a comprehensive overview. They are accompanied by nine paintings by Chagall's first teacher, the sensitive realist Yehuda Pen. The show culminates in the seven large, deliriously inventive murals Chagall made for the Jewish State Chamber Theater in Moscow during three feverish months in 1920. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $4, students and 60+ (Roberta Smith)

* "KENNETH JOSEPHSON: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through May 27). The first full-scale career assessment for one of the earliest and most inventive explorers of photography's character and the issues of perception and representation that it raises. In the 1960's, when Mr. Josephson began commenting on it, the truthfulness of photography was still a myth with a powerful hold on the imagination. Best of all, his philosophizing is often served up with a generous portion of wit. Much of his work has never been exhibited, and he is not nearly as well known as he deserves to be. Hours and admission: See above (Vicki Goldberg).

* "VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through May 27). Genius does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by this alternately tousled and crystalline exhibition. With 15 Vermeers -- nearly half his known paintings -- serving as ballast, this exhibition almost giddily spotlights a succession of artists, tracking the emergence of an increasingly effortless illusionism in Delft in the 1650's and 60's. Flower still lifes, whitewashed church interiors, townscapes and genre scenes by Pieter de Hooch, Carel Fabritius and Gerard Houckgeest are part of the mix, along with drawings and a breathtaking selection of small landscapes by artists you've never heard of. All this contextualizing sharpens one's sense of Vermeer's achievement, but it also spells out the milieu without which he would not have been Vermeer. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

BERND AND HILLA BECHER, "Photographs From the 1960's and 70's," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677. (through May 25). This exhibition samples the early efforts of the German team that helped establish the camera's art-world credentials with rigorous black-and-white photographs of lime kilns, blast furnaces and water towers that capture the body industrial (Smith).

* LOUISE BOURGEOIS, "The Personages," C & M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020 (through June 9). Bone-skinny, striking and each an individual, Ms. Bourgeois's 19 bronze "Personages" are enigmatic, people-size totems that stand in amiable camaraderie, like well-behaved guests at a cultural soiree. But their presence is insistent. Made from 1947 to 1953, and Surrealistic in origin, they greet the viewer at eye level, dispensing with the built-up bases that afflicted most earlier sculpture. Revisiting this powerful body of work strengthens awareness of the inspired personal vision with which Ms. Bourgeoise has enriched the universe of sculpture (Glueck).

KARA HAMMOND, Joseph Rickards, 1045 Madison Avenue, at 79th Street, (212) 924-0858 (through Wednesday). Five sweet, delicately made pencil drawings represent an assortment of technological yet oddly poetic objects: a blimp, an old radio tube, an oil-rig escape pod, a safe hanging by a rope and the strangely blossoming sphere of a nuclear bomb mushroom cloud. A four-foot-square painting of a space station interior suggests Ms. Hammond works best closer to miniature scale (Ken Johnson).

JIM PETERS, CDS, 76 East 79th Street, (212) 772-9555 (through May 19). Carnal desire animates deliberately grungy assemblages and collages in a show by an artist with a master's degree in nuclear engineering. The contrast between roughly built, crustily painted structural elements and the photographs of attractive naked women that they frame suggests a tension between raw actuality and idealizing fantasy. One senses an underlying anxiety, which might be worth making more visible (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through June 30). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop art by the movement's star names. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit into an art of their own (Glueck).

REEVA POTOFF, "Zero Gravity," Kouros, 23 East 73rd Street, (212) 288-5888 (through May 31). A veteran installation artist here shows a series of analytic yet evocative, grid-based photographic collages. In each, the image of a female swimmer shot from behind and below water is mediated by a field of darkly translucent photographic squares. The effect is like a modern stained-glass window and almost mystically haunting (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

* JOAN BROWN: "CATS AND DOGS," George Adams, 41 West 57th Street, (212) 644-5665 (through May 19). Anyone unfamiliar with Joan Brown (1938-1990) will find this selection of pictures with dogs or cats in them an excellent introduction to an exuberantly original painter. Not to be missed is the large 1969 diptych in which Rufus the dog observes the artist and her husband posed in formal evening wear under an arcade of trees with valentine-shaped clouds tumbling in the sky (Johnson).

CHARLES HARBUTT, "Dreams and Memories . . . ," Laurence Miller, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through May 19). This small retrospective looks back on an admirable 40-year career in photojournalism. With affectionate warmth and great framing instincts, Mr. Harbutt captures moments of riveting narrative pregnancy. In a shot in Milan in 1970, for example, five businessmen gather on an astonishingly long modern stairway against a high wall splashed by sunlight; you feel an almost divine immanence (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* GENE BEERY, Mitchell Algus, 25 Thompson Street, (212) 966-1758 (through May 19). The wordy sign paintings by this pioneering Conceptualist mischief-maker are funny and philosophically knotty. A recent work, "Essences Only," consists of a comically self-referential message hastily brushed in black paint on white canvas: "My life is too short to spend much time on formal painting art concerns. I am simply recording essences." Just so (Johnson).

"DANGER," Exit Art/The First World, 548 Broadway, between Prince and Spring Streets, (212) 966-7745 (through May 19). Little in this disappointing theme show seems truly dangerous and no clear thesis about danger in art emerges. A noisy machine by Robert Chambers shoots air in your face; amusing junk robots by Chico MacMurtrie dance and masturbate; Gregory Green has set up a consulate for a real nation he is trying to create on an unclaimed island; and elegant, emblematic photographs by Susan Seubert symbolize various phobias (Johnson).

ANTONIO FRASCONI, Sragow, 73 Spring Street, (212) 219-1793 (through May 19) and El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through May 20). This eminent, socially engaged printmaker is showing rough expressionistic, politically charged woodcuts from the 1940's at Sragow. At El Museo del Barrio is a recent series of richly colored, textured and abstracted prints that illustrate Langston Hughes's poem "Let America Be America Again" (Johnson).

ROBERT RYMAN AND IAN WILSON, Peter Blum Gallery, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through June 2). Bringing together examples of Mr. Ryman's stripped-down paintings and evidence from Mr. Wilson's various Conceptual Art activities, this exhibition tellingly contrasts different kinds of aesthetic purism (Smith).

VALTON TYLER, Phyllis Kind, 136 Greene Street, (212) 925-1200 (through June 30). The paintings by this self-taught Texan verge on a kind of surrealistic kitsch, but they are persuasively strange. At his best, in large, weirdly stylized landscapes Mr. Tyler accumulates simplified tubular and spiky forms into dense jungle scenes that have the Cubist palpability and otherworldly dreaminess of Henri Rousseau (Johnson).

STEPHEN WESTFALL, Lennon Weinberg Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through June 2). In this quiet knockout of a show, Mondrianist grids and color blocks are once more infused with worldly reference and postmodern play while being extended on their own adamantly visual terms. Intimations of domestic interiors are among the new additions, along with doubled or widened grids that ante up to the usual jittery spatial contradictions. In all, the subtle yet marvelously optical jostling, something of a Westfall trademark, is increased almost to the point of breaking into dance (Smith).

Galleries: Chelsea

* ROBERT BARRY, "Early Works, 1966-73," Gasser & Grunert, 524 West 19th Street, (212) 807-9494 (through May 19). This beautifully installed exhibition presents classic works by a pioneer of dematerialized art. Mr. Barry's visually minimal, verbally paradoxical works operate like Zen koans to heighten awareness of the mystery of consciousness. One, penciled in fine block letters on the wall, reads, "All the things I know but of which I am not at the moment thinking -- 1:36 PM; June 15, 1969" (Johnson).

"HOME AND THE WORLD: AN EXPLORATION OF IDENTITY AT CROSSROADS," India Center of Art and Culture, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 462-4221 (through May 31). The center is a recently opened nonprofit space devoted equally to art, literature, music and film, and most of those media play some role in this group exhibition of contemporary artists of Indian descent (Holland Cotter).

MELISSA MEYER; ALEX STOLYAROV, Elizabeth Harris, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 463-9666 (through May 19). Ms. Meyer's loosely gridded, confidently improvised paintings exude a fine summery light. With wide brushes she layers loopy squiggles of color over radiant patchwork fields; the effect is rigorously economical yet hedonistically sumptuous. Mr. Stolyarov's compact, extremely thick, lusciously colored monochrome abstractions are like giant Chiclets (Johnson).

ESTER PARTEGAS, De Chiara/Stewart, 521 West 26th Street, (212) 967-6007 (through May 26). For her second New York solo, Ms. Partegas has installed rows of diminutive modern seats made of cardboard and other lightweight materials. Along with planters holding ferns made of silver cardboard, framed blank signboards on the wall and color-coordinated floor and wall paint, it all adds up to a toddler-scale airport waiting room. The spell is undermined by real stuff like luggage, fast food and magazines scattered around, but the magical miniaturism still prevails (Johnson).

FRAN SIEGEL: "INTERFERENCE," Margaret Thatcher Projects, 529 West 20th Street (212) 675-0222 (through May 26). Shimmering wall works of steel mesh backed by painted Plexiglas radiate pale, offbeat shades that resonate in the small space of this gallery. Ms. Siegel achieves her effects by painting on a Plexiglas panel, then covering the panel and its frame with a cover sheet of thin steel, punctuated by dots in random patterns. The color streams through the holes, shifting and changing with the angle at which the works are viewed. An extension of the painting is a row of light papier-mache balls suspended from the ceiling on nylon string, hovering just above the floor. The balls, each with a mirror under it, move and bobble in response to ambient air currents, again creating a shifting space and adding to the show's appeal (Glueck).

DOUG WADA, Dee/Glasoe, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 924-7545 (through May 26). This canny painter updates Jasper Johns with his deadpan fusion of Pop, trompe l'oeil realism and grid-based formalism. You might mistake a 6-by-10-foot canvas for a wall of green high school lockers; in two other works, plastic subway seats fitted perfectly into the rectangle of the picture have a startling palpability. Other subjects include a wire-mesh trash receptacle, stacks of rounded suitcases and an air-conditioner (Johnson).

Other Galleries

GLORIA KLEIN, "Paradise Found," Gallery Onetwentyeight, 128 Rivington Street, between Essex and Norfolk Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 674-0244 (through May 19). Ms. Klein's new drawings, displayed in a small back gallery, consist of odd-shaped interlocked geometric forms in colored pencil on paper. They suggest both exuberant jigsaw puzzles, every piece in place, and abstract woodland landscapes of lush green foliage, purple shadows and bursts of radiant light. Tabletop size, they were clearly created up-close and are meant for up-close viewing (Cotter).

LIZZIE SCOTT AND JOSH BLACKWELL, P.S. 122, 150 First Avenue, entrance on East Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 228-4249 (through May 20). These two artists use fabric as a metaphor for ephemerality and as a source of unsuspected beauty. Using gouache, Mr. Blackwell replicates found patterns -- flowered furniture covering, the stripes in an American flag -- on paper and pins his versions to the original material. Ms. Scott, who stands out here, makes rubbings of tiled bathroom floors on pieces of fine silk, then trims the results with mother-of-pearl buttons and satin roses, creating what appear to be elegantly off-center cloaks. Lovely (Cotter).

"SCULPTURE," Flipside, 84 Withers Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 389-7108 (through May 27). Sculpture as intimate as drawing is the unstated theme. Mary Carlson's stoneware serpents and Julia Kunin's crystal octopuses hang on the wall, as do Janet Pihlblad's fragrant moss-covered window frames. Elana Herzog transforms the wall itself with stapled and torn cloth. Drew Shiflett's free-standing structures of paper and glue are like furniture made splinter by splinter. Matt Freedman offers a small panoramic view of the gallery within the gallery; at Five Myles, 558 St. John's Place in Crown Heights, (718) 783-4438, he has collaborated with neighborhood children on a wraparound mural of Prospect Park, up through May 19 (Cotter).

QIU ZHIJIE, Ethan Cohen Fine Arts, 37 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 625-1250 (through May 19). This young Beijing-based artist makes his New York debut with a show that plays with and extends classical forms. Calligraphic scrolls carry outtakes from the dictionary. On other scrolls, elements of ink-and-brush landscapes -- trees, figures, pavilions -- are cut loose from their original contexts. In a video the artist writes out Tang dynasty poems, but the tape is played backward so that he seems to be erasing them. He's moving in several directions at this point, but certain themes (cultural fragmentation, transience) and attitudes (brash Zen-style wit, nostalgia) are constants (Cotter).

Last Chance

* "ANOTHER, ONCE AGAIN, MANY TIMES MORE," Feature, 530 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 675-7772 (through tomorrow). This show of serial work has something for everybody, and possibly a little too much for some viewers. John Torreano covers the wall with bejeweled half-spheres, Lisa Beck with painted tondos, Nancy Shaver with stacked architectural outtakes and David Morreno with a suave pattern-painting titled "Door Knob Head: The Movie Sequence." Michael St. John edges into fraught terrain with a sculptural lineup of serial killers from horror films. Daniel Hesidence follows up with alarming paintings of bullet-strafed heads, all women. Howard Johnson is an island unto himself with thick collages made of ink drawings, reflective stickers, floor plans and G-strings, forming a grimy looking Insider-Outsider Art melange with lots of promise (Cotter).

"THE COS COB ART COLONY: IMPRESSIONISTS ON THE CONNECTICUT SHORE," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). From 1890 to 1920, Cos Cob, Conn., was a hangout for American Impressionist painters, led by John H. Twachtman, J. Alden Weir, Childe Hassam and Theodore Robinson. Writers and journalists added to the scene's buzz. Though art talk and theorizing ran at fever pitch, in practice the Cos Cobbers put out a quiet, conservative brand of Impressionism that emphasized a bright palette, pastoral subjects and a concentration on what the novelist and critic William Dean Howells once called "the smiling aspects of life." Still, as a footnote to American art history, Cos Cob deserves recognition. Even though this is not the most urgent exhibition in town, it includes some lovely paintings, produced by the group's minor artists as well as its stars. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5 (Glueck).

* "ANDREAS GURSKY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Tuesday). The giant pictures in this midcareer retrospective of Mr. Gursky, the 46-year-old German photographer, are so eye-poppingly, drop-dead gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, you may feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. But knee-jerk resistance at the sight of the nondescript global emblems of new capitalist sprawl that he photographs is short-circuited by sheer awe at the incredible, sublimely weird, almost erotic glamour he imparts to them. The work is instantly attractive to the point of alarm, which is the feeling of falling in love. You might as well give yourself over to it and worry about the consequences later. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; until 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

FARIBA HAJAMADI, Christine Burgin, 243 West 18th Street, Chelsea, (212) 462-2668 (through tomorrow). This brainy, Iranian-born conceptualist uses photography to explore unspoken ideologies that drive Western museum practices. In six large, handsome, digitally manipulated views of museum exhibition spaces, Ms. Hajamadi gives her project an obliquely autobiographical spin by including obscure reflections of her own image and composing her own fictive installations of art and artifacts (Johnson).

* SIMON LEE AND CLAIRE LESTEVEN, Smack Mellon Studios, 56 Water Street, Brooklyn, (718) 834-8761 (through Sunday). In Mr. Lee's cinematic installation, a screen stretching across the darkened gallery is filled with luminous drifting images of animals, trees, houses and figures that appear to be under a microscope lens. They are all "live" projections of tiny plastic forms floating in a tank of eddying water. The results are a metaphor for the random flow of history, and a low-tech formal tour de force. In a separate solo show, Ms. Lesteven shows photographs and videos made with multi-aperture cyclindrical versions of a pinpoint camera, producing eerily distorted pictures of public spaces. Here, too, the means are straightforward, the ends evocative (Cotter).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sunday). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective subconscious, well beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. He has been a cultish presence in Los Angeles for years, and his moment has finally come in New York. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascoes -- the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive secondhand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"WILLIAM TROST RICHARDS IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879 5500 (through Sunday). A 19th-century landscapist who worked in the tradition of the Hudson River School, Richards (1833-1905) made his mark as a painter of coastal scenes and as a watercolorist. The Met acquired a large trove of his watercolors in 1880 from the Rev. Elias Magoon, but let many of them go in 1929 when the Hudson River School was in disfavor. It has gradually been recouping, and although this show of oils, watercolors and drawings by no means provides a comprehensive view of Richards's career, it is a useful sketch of it from youth until shortly before his death. The White Mountains, the environs of Newport and scenes of the English coast were among his prime subjects, and one of the loveliest of the mountain scenes here is "Moonlight on Mount Lafayette" (1873), a poetic nighttime view of a lush, brook-crossed terrain. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

HOUGHTON CRANFORD SMITH, "The Purist Landscapes," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through tomorrow). In Paris in the early 1930's, this American painter learned Purism, a variation on Cubism, from Amedee Ozenfant. Returning to New York, Smith combined idealizing simplification and finely textured paint in pastoral landscapes, producing images of New England hills or harbors or South American mountains that call to mind Grant Wood, Rockwell Kent and Charles Sheeler. But they also have their own slightly comical, slightly melancholy serenity (Johnson).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Tuesday). This revelatory micro exhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met in Arles. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

HEADLINE: Productivity: An Exaggerated Boom May Soon Be a Bust 

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
PRODUCTIVITY is not what it was cracked up to be. And therein lies one of the great fallacies of the recent boom and bubble.
 Productivity -- at least as measured by the government -- zoomed in recent years, rising at a faster rate than at any time since the 1960's. That increase helped to persuade many economists that it was a new era, one in which old economic verities might not apply. 
 Rising productivity meant that the economy could grow rapidly without fear of inflation while the information technology revolution, in the year-old words of John T. Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco Systems, enabled companies to "reduce costs, generate revenue in new ways, empower employees and citizens and provide the agility needed for the Internet economy's rapid pace."
Now productivity is falling, and Mr. Chambers is coping with a collapse in demand that he did not see coming and still cannot quite believe. This week he was still talking of Cisco returning to a 30 percent to 50 percent annual growth rate when the economy recovers. 
The reality of the productivity explosion was that it was concentrated in the information technology industry. Some of that rise was not real anyway, since the government's statistical adjustments probably exaggerated the improvements in computers. But the failure of the productivity measures to show big gains in other areas should have been telling. "If it was a real productivity miracle, how come we didn't see it in other places?" asked Greg Jensen, an analyst at Bridgewater Associates.
Nonetheless, it was believed to be real by the people that counted. It was that belief, says Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, that led the Federal Reserve to back away from a pre-emptive tightening framework, in which rates were raised when the economy began to grow too fast.
There is no way to know just how much a tighter Fed would have been able to slow the expansion of the bubble, but it would have had some effect. Less money would have been wasted on unproductive investments, of which Cisco's $2.2 billion inventory write-down is but a small part. Think of the money invested in absurd dot-coms, as well as fiber optic lines that are installed but may never be used.
"Now we see a contraction of the ability of good companies to get money, because of all the money the bad companies sucked in," Mr. Jensen said. 
Instead, we must deal with the effects of a bust in capital investment, one that is likely to continue for some time. We will learn that productivity was probably really growing at a slower rate than we thought, and will continue to do so. That implies slower economic growth and lower multiples for earnings in the stock market.
There are historical precedents. In the 1920's and again in the 1950's and 1960's, productivity surged along with the stock market. "Productivity growth does not necessarily presage heaven on earth," James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, said. 
The last productivity boom came to an abrupt halt with the horrors of the 1970's, when high oil prices helped to choke off economic growth and slow investment. In the five years that ended with 1972, productivity rose 2.9 percent, very close to the level of the last five years. But by 1980, the five-year average was below 1 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average was below where it had been in 1966.
Productivity booms are not permanent things.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Cautions on F.D.I.C. 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that policy makers should proceed with caution as they explore overhauling a Depression-era system that insures deposits in banks and savings and loan associations.
 The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has proposed some changes to the system, which was established in 1933. 
 Last month, the F.D.I.C. recommended to Congress that all banks pay for deposit insurance according to their risk of failure, and it proposed that the $100,000 limit on account coverage be pegged to inflation.
The insurance system and other federal programs that are intended to keep banks safe are often referred to as the safety net. Any changes to this safety net, Mr. Greenspan said, must be balanced against potential costs.
"I believe this means being very cautious about purposefully or inadvertently extending the scope and reach of the safety net," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to a banking conference in Chicago.
Copies of his speech, which did not touch on interest rate policy or the state of the economy, were distributed in Washington.
The F.D.I.C. wants to end what it sees as a free ride for more than 900 banks and savings and loans that have the benefit of the insurance without paying premiums.
Current law prohibits the F.D.I.C. from collecting premiums from most institutions that have adequate capital and receive strong ratings from examiners. The F.D.I.C. wants a system in which every bank and savings and loan would contribute, with insurance premiums based on risk. If funds fell below a certain level, premiums would gradually be increased.

HEADLINE: Everyone Wants to Fix Rent Regulations. No One Knows How. 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Tenant groups seldom agree with landlord groups, but after the latest contortions on the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, the two sides have found common ground.
 Both sides complain that the rent regulation system is broken, and say it needs to be fixed. Some critics are even looking at the rent rules in neighboring suburbs and in New Jersey for pointers. 
 What has them so exercised is the drama that culminated at the board's session on Wednesday night. As the police barred news cameras and some citizens, the board convened with a new chairman and two other new members, all freshly minted appointees of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
Taking their seats for the first time, the newcomers promptly voted on increases for one million rent-stabilized apartments. The increases were 4 percent for one-year leases and 6 percent for two-year renewals, which were higher than the mayor had wanted. But that vote turned out to be a mistake. After a hasty recess, the board reversed itself and adopted 3 percent and 5 percent instead, as the mayor had urged. The majority did not debate or explain why it had approved those numbers.
"I'm glad Giuliani exercised the heavy hand he did and made the stumbles he did, with the comedy of three new people who didn't know what they were doing," said Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "The mayor has done us a big favor by turning a spotlight on this obscure board, which nobody understands, and the need to reform the process."
The landlords' chief spokesman, Joseph Strasburg, is equally vocal. "There used to be at least an attempt to come to a compromise that was somewhat fair, but the system is tainted now," said Mr. Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, representing 25,000 owners.
They are not the only ones who have been complaining.
The mayor himself had criticized the board's decision last year to adopt increases of 4 and 6 percent, 1 percentage point more than he wanted. So he replaced the board chairman, Edward S. Hochman, with a former mayoral aide, Steven Sinacori, and filled two other vacancies on the nine-member board with loyalists, including David Rubenstein, a deputy director in the budget office.
If nothing else, the board's vote on Wednesday showed how rent increases for regulated apartments are often governed by politics, and not necessarily by the cost of providing housing. But landlord and tenant groups disagree on what should be done to improve the process.
"I'd be the first to advocate the abolition of the board," Mr. Strasburg said. "Let's create a price index of landlord costs, and whatever the number is, they automatically get it."
Variations of that system are used in many of the 120 New Jersey municipalities that regulate rents for an estimated 1.3 million residents. Local councils and mayors usually decide the increases.
"Most use the Consumer Price Index or some formula using the C.P.I." said Nathan Slovin, executive vice president of the New Jersey Apartment Association, representing owners. Recent increases have been in the 3 percent range, he said. Few landlords apply for hardship increases, said Mitchell Kahn, vice president of the New Jersey Tenants Organization.
But New York tenant leaders are wary. "I'd be skeptical of going with a formula based solely on the landlord end, instead of an appointed board to protect people from unreasonable rents," said Kenneth Schaeffer, vice president of the Metropolitan Council on Housing.
In New York City, the board consults a landlord price index that tenant leaders argue is irrelevant. Rising oil prices, for example, can be partly offset by bulk purchases, by cutting back on heat or by adding insulation and taking other conservation steps.
Instead of focusing on prices, tenants say, regulators need to look at actual expenses and income. The board's own reports show that landlord profitability has risen to record levels as fewer and fewer apartments are governed by rent regulation. The advocates also say that regulators need to balance factors like limited tenant incomes and the housing shortage.
A different system applies in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties, where nearly 70,000 apartments are regulated. To raise rents, landlords must submit income and expense declarations to the state, which computes averages to guide local rent boards.
As a result, the suburbs have had a slower rise in rents, Mr. McKee said. Last year, when the city's regulated rents rose 4 and 6 percent, the suburban increases ranged from 1.25 to 3 percent for one-year leases and from 2 to 3.75 percent for two-year renewals. Tenant groups are pushing for the city to follow that procedure.
But in other parts of the country, the trend has been toward having the free market govern rents. In California, a stronghold of rent regulation, a Republican-sponsored change in 1999 imposed a "decontrol-recontrol" policy that is also followed in much of New Jersey. Under that rule, a landlord may charge any rent when an apartment becomes vacant, but then regulation covers the new tenant for subsequent increases.
Some experts side with landlords in urging that rent regulations simply be eliminated, which, they argue, might actually benefit tenants. Eliminating rent regulation, they say, would spur the creation of new housing units, thereby increasing the supply of homes and putting downward pressure on rents.
A state referendum in Massachusetts a few years ago ended controls in Boston, Cambridge and Brookline. Arthur Zabarkes, former dean of the New York University Real Estate Institute, said: "As a market economist, I think regulation is a profoundly bad idea."
But tenant advocates say that past attempts to decrease rent protections have been disastrous for residents.
An author on rent controls, W. Dennis Keating, associate dean of urban affairs at Cleveland State University, said that whatever rules are devised, the factors are so complex that the best to be hoped for is only a "rough justice."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS ADOPTS BUDGET PROPOSAL WITH BIG TAX CUT 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10 

 BODY:
A budget plan close to what President Bush proposed won final Congressional approval today, clearing the way for the first big tax cut in 20 years.
 Some of that reduction will probably result in lower taxes this year, but how that will happen and how much taxpayers will gain this year are still to be debated. 
 The Senate adopted the budget plan, 53 to 47, with five Democrats voting for it and two Republicans against it. The House passed the measure on Wednesday, also on essentially a party-line vote. 
It allows $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years, slightly less than the $1.6 trillion the president sought, and it calls for nearly $2 trillion in federal spending in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, almost precisely what Mr. Bush proposed.
"Now that both the House and the Senate have acted, it's clear that the economic recovery package that the president has talked about is on the way," Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said. 
Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee said they expected the committee to approve a detailed tax-cut bill next week. Tax legislation has already passed the House, and Republicans hope to have a tax bill ready for the president's signature by Memorial Day.
No doubt remains that a large tax cut will be enacted this year or about what its main elements will be: an across-the-board reduction in income-tax rates, lower taxes for many married couples, an expanded tax credit for families with children and eventual repeal or lowering of the federal estate tax.
The only remaining questions are in the details, including exactly how much the top tax rate will be reduced and how quickly the lower rates will be put into effect.
The measure adopted today, called a budget resolution, is not legislation and does not require the president's signature. It is essentially a nonbinding planning tool that is supposed to set the boundaries for tax and spending legislation this year.
In recent years, Congress has ignored the budget resolution once it was adopted, and this pattern seems likely to be followed this year.
The measure, for instance, calls for a 4 percent increase in spending in the next fiscal year for all programs except interest payments on the debt and automatic benefits like Social Security and Medicare. Lawmakers from both parties agree that the 4 percent spending figure is certain to be exceeded, and Republicans are already talking about tax cuts beyond the $1.35 trillion.
The wording of the measure is intentionally vague in many places. For example, the resolution allows the Senate to interpret it as requiring a $100 billion tax reduction in this calendar year to stimulate the economy and the House to assume that the $100 billion in cuts can be spread over 11 years.
While the numbers and language in the budget resolution have little practical significance, the measure is very important politically.
Mr. Bush made it the first test of his ability to hold Republicans together and get his agenda through the closely divided Congress. He clearly passed the test.
And under budget rules, any tax cut that fits within the boundaries established by the resolution can be passed by a majority vote in the Senate after limited debate instead of facing the prospects of a filibuster requiring 60 votes to end. Because of strong Democratic opposition, a tax cut almost certainly could not get 60 votes in the Senate, which is divided 50-50 between the parties.
The five Democratic senators who voted for the plan were John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Max Baucus of Montana, Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Zell Miller and Max Cleland, both of Georgia.
Republicans are expecting them to cast the decisive votes again when the actual tax-cut legislation is before the Senate. But it is not clear whether Republicans will be able to rely on them on other issues as the year wears on.
The Republicans who voted against the budget plan were Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island and James M. Jeffords of Vermont. They seem comfortable breaking party ranks and will probably be allies of the Democrats on issues like education and the environment.
Mr. Breaux was the power broker who delivered enough Democratic votes for the measure to be approved. Today, he told the Senate that the measure should be approved largely because the most objectionable aspects like the money for education were sure to be changed.
"This is an imperfect document," he declared. "But it is written on paper; it is not written in concrete."
For Republicans, in control of the White House and Congress this year for the first time in 50 years, the vote today was a milestone in advancing their principles of lower taxes and smaller government.
"Spending got out of hand in the last couple of years," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader, and the budget measure allows taxpayers to "keep some of their own money."
"It doesn't just benefit the rich," Mr. Nickles said. "It benefits taxpayers."
Democrats who think otherwise, he added, are committing "class war demagoguery."
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, put the Republican philosophy succinctly.
"This is a budget for prosperity now and prosperity in the future," Mr. Domenici said. "For America to prosper, we have to have low taxes."
The credit for the victory, he said, belongs to the president.
"You have made us change direction," he said, addressing Mr. Bush directly from the well of the Senate. "You have moved us in the direction of giving back taxes to the American people."
Democrats countered that the budget plan was dishonest and reckless. They accused Republicans of repeating the mistakes of 1981, Ronald Reagan's first year as president, when taxes were slashed, military spending was increased and the budget deficit mushroomed.
Using charts as visual aids, Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee, listed six reasons why he said the plan was disastrous.
In Mr. Conrad's view, the plan has insufficient money for education, allows unaffordable tax cuts, does not count the large increase in military spending Congress is sure to pass, raids the Social Security and Medicare trust funds, lowers spending for domestic needs and fails to set aside money for overhauling the Social Security and Medicare programs.
"This budget is unreal," he said. "This budget is irresponsible."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, left, talked with President Bush by cell phone yesterday after the budget vote. With him were two legislative aides to the president, Nick Calio and Ziad Ojakli. (David Scull for The New York Times)(pg. A29)

HEADLINE: Myanmar's Incorrigible Leaders 

 BODY:
A few months ago it looked as if the military junta in Myanmar might ease its repressive rule slightly. The regime was talking with the country's courageous pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and there even seemed to be a possibility that she would be liberated from the prolonged house arrest the government has enforced. But those hopes have all but vanished. If the Bush administration means to speak out against human rights abuses abroad and pressure governments to treat their citizens humanely, Myanmar would be a fine place to start. 
 The military leaders of Myanmar, formerly called Burma, are among the world's cruelest violators of human rights. The junta has tortured and executed political opponents, exploited forced labor and condoned a burgeoning traffic in heroin and amphetamines. In the clearest indication that the regime has little intention of reforming, the United Nations special envoy who acted as a catalyst for the talks between the government and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has been denied permission to visit the country since January. Also, an anticipated release of political prisoners has failed to materialize, as has a pledge by the junta that Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy, would be allowed to resume activity. 
 Earlier this year the junta released 120 mostly youthful members of the party who had been imprisoned the previous year, but it is still believed to be holding as many as 1,700 political prisoners, including 35 people who were elected to Parliament in 1990. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party won more than three-quarters of the seats in that election, but the junta annulled the results. 
The United States and the European Union have cooperated to isolate Myanmar, and in 1997 the Clinton administration banned new American investments there. But some Asian countries have been reluctant to join in sanctions. China, in particular, has helped sustain the junta with military aid. Regrettably, last month Japan broke ranks with a Western-led 12-year ban on non-humanitarian assistance to Myanmar by approving a $29 million grant for a hydroelectric dam. 
Last year the International Labor Organization, responding to concerns about forced labor, voted to urge governments and international donors to impose further sanctions on Myanmar. Washington should consider a ban on imports from that nation, including textiles. Myanmar is rapidly increasing apparel exports to the United States. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's allies have argued that the hard-currency earnings primarily benefit the military, not the laborers who make the garments. Washington should certainly be using its influence with Japan and other Asian countries to deter any further non-humanitarian assistance.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Japan Says The Economy Is Worsening

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 11 

 BODY:
The Japanese government lowered its assessment of the economy's health today for the fourth consecutive month, citing falling production, bloated inventories, declining prices and weak employment trends.
 The outlook underscores the significant economic challenges that face Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's new administration and suggests that the political challenges in devising a resolution to Japan's longstanding economic woes will be daunting. 
 "We're getting an intensification of a hard landing in Japan," said Jesper Koll, chief economist at Merrill Lynch here. 
On Thursday, the government reported that wholesale prices dropped 0.7 percent, the sharpest decline in 19 months, which suggests that deflation is quickening. Mr. Koizumi's advocacy of stringent structural reforms is only likely to exacerbate that.
"Economic conditions have weakened since April," said Heizo Takenaka, the new minister for economic policy.
The cabinet office blamed the deceleration in the United States economy for a loss in Japanese exports. It said that supplies of electronic components like semiconductors had risen and that industrial production was slowing in response.
Core machinery orders, a measure of capital spending, dropped 3.6 percent in March from the previous month, the government said today. Machinery orders for the first quarter were down 7 percent from the previous quarter, the first decrease in almost two years.
Overtime and job offers are also diminishing, factors that can be expected to deepen deflation. The government did not revise its expectations for consumer spending, which accounts for more than 60 percent of economic activity in Japan, but the prospect of weakening employment will almost certainly put a crimp in consumer purchasing power.
"It is difficult to expect that consumption will pick up the slack when capital spending falters," said Haruhito Arai, a cabinet office official.
The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recently warned that Japan was increasingly at risk of slipping into a downward economic spiral. The group, made up of 30 market-oriented nations, forecasts Japanese growth of 1 percent this year, although the government's official forecast stands at 1.7 percent.
Mr. Takenaka, the economic policy minister, has repeatedly said that the forecast is too optimistic, but he has yet to revise it. 
Still, Mr. Koll and other economists predict that the first-quarter gross domestic product figures, to be released next month, will be strong. The first quarter is traditionally a good one in Japan, and consumption in particular is expected to show strong gains, as buyers have hurried to replace old appliances before a new law took effect that made the disposal of such items expensive.
