HEADLINE: A Match Not Made in Heaven; 
How a Rabbi's Foray Into Online Dating Ended Up in Court

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
Rabbi Shmuley Boteach just wanted to bring Jewish men and women together -- and if he could get rich in the Internet boom, all the better.
 So when Rabbi Boteach, the Hasidic author of "Kosher Sex" and "Dating Secrets of the Ten Commandments," was introduced early last year to the Israeli founders of an online dating venture that was about to go public, it seemed like a match made in heaven. 
 But like so many dates arranged by mating services, the rabbi's ended in bitter disappointment. Rather than serving as the well-paid matchmaker in chief for MatchNet.com, Rabbi Boteach -- who counts Michael Jackson as a friend (they were introduced by the spoon-bending psychic Uri Geller) and has had his Talmud-inspired writings serialized in Playboy -- is suing the company and its founders in federal court in Los Angeles for fraud and breach of contract.
His lawsuit is just a taste of the conflict that swirls around MatchNet. The intrigue stretches from Beverly Hills to Israel to the German stock market. The characters include a phone sex entrepreneur, the former convict who took control of his business and a disbarred lawyer obsessed with exposing the underbelly of the online dating industry. 
"It was a short, awful experience," Rabbi Boteach, 34, said recently of his dealings with the company.
That seems, roughly, to be the attitude of everyone involved. MatchNet moved in early March to dismiss Rabbi Boteach's lawsuit, denying all the accusations. Its chief executive, Joe Shapira, pledges to fight the case to a conclusion. 
"Most businessmen would settle these claims, but we're Israelis," said Mr. Shapira, who founded MatchNet in 1998 with a partner, Alon Carmel, now the company's president. "We want justice. I don't want to pay someone that I don't owe anything. I put my faith in the justice system."
The clash between odd bedfellows is a parable for the Internet bubble, when money lust seemed universal and newly minted companies were racing to lay claims to eyeballs and investors' dollars. 
And MatchNet, while no eBay or Amazon.com, is not a negligible presence in its corner of the Web. The company claims three million members around the world. One of its sites, Americansingles.com, is among the 10-most-visited Web dating sites, according to Jupiter Media Metrix. Jdate.com, MatchNet's Jewish dating site, says that one of every 10 Jewish singles in the United States uses it and that the site has been responsible for 300 marriages in its four years of operation.
But that is getting ahead of the story.
In March 2000, according to Rabbi Boteach's lawsuit, he entered into a written agreement with MatchNet to serve as its spokesman for three years, at an annual salary of $216,000. He was to receive 250,000 stock options in MatchNet, a British corporation with headquarters in Beverly Hills, Calif., that was preparing to sell stock on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt, the German hub of the Internet boom.
There was also an understanding, the lawsuit says, that Rabbi Boteach would become part-owner of an affiliated company to develop and sell content related to relationships and spirituality, including a "loveprophet" Web site he had already developed.
Those promises, and others, were broken, the suit contends. It also accuses MatchNet of besmirching Rabbi Boteach's reputation -- and exaggerating its own popularity -- by wiring its dating Web sites to count as users people who were actually visiting pornographic sites. 
This last assertion, according to Rabbi Boteach, was based largely on information he received unsolicited from a stranger, Daniel Nicherie, the former convict in this yarn.
Last summer, at a lecture Rabbi Boteach was giving in Santa Monica, Calif., Mr. Nicherie introduced himself as an Israeli investment banker with information about MatchNet. Later, Mr. Nicherie told the rabbi that Mr. Carmel and Mr. Shapira were pornographers who had been sued nearly 40 times.
The latter was true, or close to it; individually, or together, the two men -- like many active business executives -- have been sued repeatedly over various financial disputes. The claim that they were pornographers is something that the men vociferously deny.
"I have never done anything that I cannot tell my children," Mr. Shapira said.
There was an unfortunate occasion when the pair's Israeli videocassette manufacturing company, Matrix Video Duplication, shipped copies of a program called "The Best Christmas Pageant Ever" recorded imperfectly over old sex tapes, with telltale scenes left behind. That was an aberration, Mr. Shapira said. "Matrix Video's main business was children's videos," he said. "We were working with Betty Boop, Dr. Seuss, Popeye." 
In any event, Mr. Nicherie did not volunteer to Rabbi Boteach details of his own resume, which included a conviction on federal bank fraud charges in 1994, followed by a year in prison. Nor did he tell Rabbi Boteach about the feud brewing between himself and another Israeli entrepreneur, Ami Shafrir, who played a critical role in MatchNet's early development.
When MatchNet's founders could not secure an arrangement with a bank to process credit card transactions for the company's Web sites, it used -- for what MatchNet's prospectus calls "a small fee" -- the account of a company jointly owned by Mr. Shafrir. Another of his companies was MatchNet's Internet service provider. And Mr. Shafrir and his wife, Sarit, were MatchNet's landlords in a granite- and glass-clad building on Wilshire Boulevard in Beverly Hills.
The heart of Mr. Shafrir's business empire was another company with headquarters in the Wilshire Boulevard building: Amtec Audiotext, an operator of telephone sex lines that he says generated revenue of $60 million in its best year, 1995.
Late in 1999, Mr. Nicherie happened into the Shafrirs' circle. About the same time -- and just months before the MatchNet stock offering on which Rabbi Boteach was counting for his Internet payday -- the Shafrirs' pending divorce, till then amicable, grew ugly. Mr. Nicherie took Mrs. Shafrir's side in the split, and the two men went to war.
In January 2000, Mr. Shafrir says, he was barred from the Wilshire Boulevard building by armed guards hired by his wife and Mr. Nicherie. Mrs. Shafrir took control of Amtec. Her husband says that she installed Mr. Nicherie at the head of the company; lawyers for Mr. Nicherie and Mrs. Shafrir, trying on his behalf to encourage a criminal investigation of Mr. Shafrir, told federal prosecutors the same thing, though they now say Mr. Nicherie was only a consultant.
This, roughly, is when the disbarred lawyer came into the picture. In the spring of 2000, Rabbi Boteach -- back home in Englewood, N.J., oblivious to the behind-the-scenes tumult at MatchNet -- received an e-mail message from the lawyer, Will Knedlik. Mr. Knedlik, who lives near Seattle, echoed Mr. Nicherie's accusations about pornography and added various financial high jinks to the catalog of MatchNet's supposed misconduct.
A onetime tax lawyer who ran unsuccessfully for lieutenant governor of Washington State in the early 1970's, Mr. Knedlik is an alumnus -- and self-appointed scourge -- of the online dating industry. In 1999, his partners sold their stakes in a company that ran two dating sites to Mr. Carmel and Mr. Shapira, giving them the properties that would form the core of MatchNet. Mr. Knedlik voted against selling, demanded shares in MatchNet instead of cash and, and when Mr. Shapira and Mr. Carmel refused, sued the company in a Los Angeles court. Litigation over the matter is pending.
His tenacity in such fights is indisputable. He takes pride, for example, in the role he played a few years ago in pushing a Boston-based dating company called the Together Development Corporation into bankruptcy -- though that campaign was one of the episodes that led in January 2000 to his disbarment in Washington State. 
A court there ruled that his behavior in that case and others had included "bringing several frivolous claims; contacting represented parties directly; using litigation to embarrass, delay or burden third parties; and failing to diligently represent a client." Mr. Knedlik said his offense was "telling the truth."
A year ago, escalating his dispute with MatchNet's owners, he forged an alliance with Mr. Nicherie and Mrs. Shafrir. On June 26, the day before MatchNet was scheduled to sell shares on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt, they forced the company into involuntary bankruptcy in Los Angeles. 
"They went from I.P.O. to bankruptcy in 24 minutes," Mr. Knedlik said recently, with more than a trace of glee. To get out, MatchNet placed $900,000 in escrow in the Los Angeles County Superior Court, where it remains today. The share sale proceeded on schedule in Germany, with the company selling three million shares at a little less than $8 each, raising $23.8 million.
Shortly after the stock sale, according to Rabbi Boteach's lawsuit, he was asked to relinquish his duties as MatchNet's primary spokesman. The rabbi was invited, the suit says, to stay on as spokesman for Jdate, but at a significantly lower salary. 
When he refused to renegotiate his deal with MatchNet's owners, Rabbi Boteach says, he was fired last September -- just before his stock options were going to vest. His lawsuit contends that MatchNet had used him to add "legitimacy" to its stock offering and never intended to make good on its promises.
Mr. Shapira said there was no ill will in MatchNet's dealings with the rabbi. "We employed him, it didn't work out; we paid him the last penny," he said. "I didn't marry the guy. I just employed him."
Amid a sea of dot-com failures, MatchNet has survived, bobbing along with investor sentiment. 
The shares jumped 13 percent in January when a German company that sells an audio version of the Bible issued a news release saying it would try to take over MatchNet; the offer never materialized. MatchNet rose 18 percent one day in March on a report that it expected to show a profit this year after acquiring a rival and doubling membership in its online services. Even so, the stock now trades for about $1.10. 
Mr. Knedlik spent five days in the Los Angeles County Jail last December after being held in civil contempt of court for ignoring a judge's order not to comment on the case. On March 12, he was sentenced to another 140 days in jail on the same ground and ordered to pay MatchNet $80,000 in damages. For now, Mr. Knedlik remains in the Seattle area; he said this week that he had not been served with any papers ordering him back to jail.
In February, Mr. Shafrir filed a federal racketeering lawsuit against Mr. Nicherie in federal court in Los Angeles. He claims that Mr. Nicherie has run Amtec into the ground.
Mr. Nicherie's lawyer, David A. Katz, responded, "We obviously strenuously disagree with that, and there is no factual basis for it."
As for Rabbi Boteach, he is still looking for ways to supplement his income. His latest book, "Why Can't I Fall in Love?," is due in stores from the HarperCollins division of the News Corporation on May 22. And he dreams of acquiring Jdate and going back into the Internet matchmaking business.
"Ideally, I'd love to get a group of investors and buy it," the rabbi said. "It would allow me to do what I love doing, and feed my family."

HEADLINE: Consumers Still Spending With Gusto 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Despite job cuts and constant reminders of a slowing economy, consumers have continued to spend with surprising resilience and may continue to do so, two reports suggested yesterday.
 Retail sales rose 0.8 percent in April, according to the Commerce Department, much more than forecast and the biggest gain in three months. The increase was led by automobiles, without which sales climbed 0.7 percent. 
 Also, a closely watched gauge of consumer sentiment rose unexpectedly, ending a long slide that began last year. 
Some economists said the data indicated that the Federal Reserve had accomplished its short-term goal of propping up consumer spending to carry the economy through its slowdown. But others said Americans had been acting on a blind faith, one that is slowly eroding in a manner that has tricked the economic barometers.
"The consumer is, I think, in somewhat slow-deterioration mode which doesn't show up month to month," said David Levy, vice chairman of the Levy Institute Forecasting Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. "Consumers have an enormous pile of debt."
Many economists have predicted that soaring energy prices, slumping manufacturing, imploding demand for high-technology equipment, falling stock prices and bloated inventories would cause Americans to put off purchases and maybe even start saving some money.
Instead, they have continued to make purchases. The gain in consumer spending in April, which came after a 0.4 percent decrease in March, was paced by purchases of spring clothing, barbecue grills and gardening equipment. Americans also bought more cars and trucks, an increase of 1 percent in April after a 0.2 percent decline in March.
But some economists questioned the true strength of the numbers.
Some purchases were postponed because of an unseasonably cold and rainy March, they said, and the gain in spending on building materials and gardening supplies, 1.5 percent, was distorted by sales to construction companies and to people who got a late start on outdoor projects. And the surge in auto purchases, some economists suggested, came in part because of deep discounts from carmakers. Rising gasoline prices also increased the value of goods sold.
Despite those caveats, consumer confidence appeared to be rising. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, which has become more closely watched since Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, referred to consumer sentiment in testimony earlier this year, jumped to 92.6 in May from 88.4 in April. 
"It gives a sense that consumers are feeling a little more confident and quite willing to dip into their pockets," said Oscar E. Gonzalez, an economist at John Hancock Financial Services. While that feeling was part of what the Fed hoped to accomplish by cutting interest rates four times this year, "I think that capital spending is what Mr. Greenspan would like to see." The Fed is widely expected to cut rates again at its meeting next week.
Whether consumers can carry the economy until corporations regain their footing elicited some debate, but economists first questioned how confident consumers felt.
The Michigan report was an improvement over April's number, the worst since November 1995, when it was 88.2. In July, the index, which is based on a telephone survey of about 300 people, was 108.3. 
"I would describe the upturn as precarious, mostly grounded in hope rather than fact," said Jade Zelnick, chief economist at Greenwich Capital Markets. "Lower interest rates and higher stock prices are helping to boost optimism, particularly in high-income families. At the same time, two-thirds think the economy is still in decline."
More optimistic economists acknowledged that while the gains in confidence and spending might not be as strong as they appeared, they still provided a basis for growth later on. "The fact that consumption is holding up -- I'm not asking for it to have a boom -- sets a tone for a recovery in the second half," said Kathleen Stephansen, director of economic research for Credit Suisse First Boston.
The Labor Department also reported yesterday that wholesale prices for finished goods rose 0.3 percent in April after a 0.1 percent decline in March. The Producer Price Index soared 1.1 percent in January, and the more recent signs that inflation is under control have eased the Fed's path.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Shares Slip on Fears That Fed's Rate Cuts Will Soon End

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday after reports of unexpected strength in retail sales and consumer confidence convinced some investors that the Federal Reserve would not reduce interest rates as aggressively as expected.
 General Electric and Intel led the decline, while the New York Stock Exchange had its slowest day this year. All three major gauges had a losing week for the first time since April 6. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 89.13 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,821.31, led by I.B.M., after a Bear, Stearns analyst said the company's 30 percent rise in the last six weeks made further gains unlikely. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 9.51 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,245.67. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 21.43 points, or 1 percent, to 2,107.43.
For the week, the Nasdaq declined 3.8 percent, the S.& P. 500 fell 1.7 percent and the Dow dropped 1.2 percent.
The reports released yesterday that retail sales rose 0.8 percent in April and consumer confidence rose to its highest level in four months suggested that people are not feeling the pinch of a slowing economy and rising unemployment. That may persuade the Fed to hold off on additional rate cuts after a widely anticipated reduction next week.
"The primary concern is what do any new data mean" for future Fed actions, said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. Stocks' biggest gains this year were incited by surprise rate cuts on Jan. 3 and April 18.
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday on the stronger-than-expected economic reports. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 14/32, to 96 20/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.45 percent from 5.30 percent on Thursday. The 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 9/32, to 93 10/32. Its yield rose to 5.85 percent from 5.76 percent on Thursday.
Four stocks fell for every three that rose on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq. Some 894 million shares traded on the Big Board -- the fewest since Dec. 26.
I.B.M. fell $3.39, to $111.81, after Andrew J. Neff, a Bear Stearns analyst, said the stock might not gain much more this year. I.B.M.'s profit growth will be less robust in the second half of the year because earnings a year ago were so strong, said Mr. Neff, who cut his rating of the stock to attractive from buy.
I.B.M. executives met with analysts yesterday and did not offer any new financial forecasts.
Software stocks fell, making them the biggest drag on the S.& P. 500. Microsoft declined 60 cents, to $69.40; Oracle dropped 49 cents, to $15.90; and BMC Software slid $1.29, to $22.17.
Intel, the biggest semiconductor maker, lost $1.07, to $27.94. G.E., the largest company by market value, fell 82 cents, to $49.01.
American General, the life insurer, gained 48 cents, to $45.10. American International Group, the financial services concern, said yesterday that it would buy American General for about $23 billion in stock, or $46 a share. American International's offer topped a bid from Prudential P.L.C. of Britain. American International fell 90 cents, to $82.10.
PG&E, owner of the largest electric utility in California, rose $1.48, to $10.58, and Edison International, owner of the No. 2 utility in the state gained $1.30, to $10.21.
Gov. Gray Davis of California signed a bill on Thursday allowing the state to issue $13.4 billion in bonds to buy electricity. The state is buying power for the utilities, which have run up $14 billion in debt because wholesale power prices have outstripped the rates they can charge retail customers.
Schering-Plough rose $1.20, or 3.2 percent, to $38.30, after Business Week, citing an unidentified investment banker, said Merck had offered $91 billion in stock to buy Schering-Plough.
Schering-Plough had gained as much as 7.3 percent, but pared that gain after a Food and Drug Administration panel said the company's Claritin prescription allergy drug is safe enough to be sold over the counter. Insurers want the drug to be sold without a prescription, but Schering-Plough opposes the move.
World Wrestling Federation Entertainment Inc. gained $1.04, to $14.19, after it canceled the XFL football league less than a month after its first season ended. The W.W.F. said the league, which it co-owned with the NBC television network unit of General Electric, would have a loss of about $35 million.

HEADLINE: Top Executive Stepping Down At Audit Firm 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
James J. Schiro, the chief executive of the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, announced unexpectedly in Paris yesterday that he planned to step down as soon as a successor was found.
 Mr. Schiro did not offer a reason and was unavailable for comment, the firm said. 
 Mr. Schiro, 55, oversaw the merger of Price Waterhouse with Coopers & Lybrand in 1998, one of the biggest mergers in the professional services industry. More recently, he was instrumental in persuading accountants to negotiate new rules governing auditors' independence from their clients with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
However, Mr. Schiro presided over an embarrassing scandal involving the independence issue after the S.E.C. issued a report in January 2000 regarding the investments held by PricewaterhouseCoopers partners in companies that the firm was auditing. He also oversaw a failed attempt to sell the firm's consulting arm to Hewlett-Packard last fall, a deal that would have taken care of at least some independence concerns by separating consulting from auditing. 
The most recent bad news came last week when the firm announced a settlement of $51 million with shareholders of MicroStrategy who contended that the accounting firm conducted a flawed audit. And there is speculation in the industry that the economic slowdown has hurt the company's finances.
"There are problems inside this firm," said Arthur W. Bowman, editor of Bowman's Accounting Report. "They still haven't gotten it together" since the merger, he said.
No successor to Mr. Schiro is likely to be named for several months, the company said, because the partners will have to approve a new chief executive. Mr. Schiro was on a plane to New York yesterday and was unavailable for comment.
The announcement from Mr. Schiro surprised partners at PricewaterhouseCoopers, which held a meeting of a group of senior partners in Paris this week, said Peter Horowitz, a spokesman for the firm. But Mr. Horowitz said the firm's restructuring plan would not be affected by Mr. Schiro's departure.
"It puts nothing on hold," he said. Currently, he said, revenue is growing 8 percent to 10 percent, compared with 13 percent last year. The firm had revenue of $21.5 billion in 2000.
PricewaterhouseCoopers is still trying to sell or spin off its consulting arm, which announced layoffs of about 8 percent of its consultants in the United States last month.
"If there's a black mark on the Schiro legacy, it's the faltering strategy" to deal with the consulting business, Mr. Bowman said. 
Mr. Schiro's success, analysts say, resulted from his willingness to seek middle ground between accountants and the S.E.C. Arthur Levitt, the commission chairman in the Clinton administration, voiced concern about the independence of accountants who audit corporations' books.
The problem Mr. Levitt sought to address was the conflict of interest created by auditors' excessive involvement with clients. Accountants who hold stock in a client, for example, would be less likely to criticize that client because doing so would depress the stock's value.
Another concern involved accountants who also provided consulting services to clients. The concern is that an auditing firm, hoping to keep serving the client in both capacities, would be reluctant to criticize a company, especially for following advice given by the firm's own consultants.
The accounting industry generally opposed new regulations on auditor independence, but PricewaterhouseCoopers was one of a few firms that took a less combative approach.
"Where Schiro was important was, even though the rhetoric was so heated on both sides of the issue, he and the people at Ernst & Young were sensible enough to know that they had to find a middle ground," Mr. Bowman said. The move paid off because the rules that were ultimately adopted were relatively lenient, Mr. Bowman added.
"Both firms agreed that a compromise was in the best interests of everybody," said Philip A. Laskawy, chairman of Ernst & Young. He said that he and Mr. Schiro worked together to develop a compromise with the S.E.C. "The rule, even though it has its shortcomings over all, is a rule the profession can live with."
The issue of auditor independence was largely driven by reports that partners in PricewaterhouseCoopers owned stock in clients of the firm's audit services. The reports embarrassed the firm and led to investigations at other firms to determine whether accountants were violating independence rules.

HEADLINE: Panel Says 3 Allergy Drugs Should Be Sold Over the Counter 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
A proposal to make the three most popular and expensive allergy drugs available without a prescription won strong support yesterday from a government medical advisory panel.
 The panel voted overwhelmingly to advise the Food and Drug Administration that Claritin, Allegra and Zyrtec were just as safe as many nonprescription allergy medications that have long been sold in drugstores and supermarkets. 
 The decision was a setback for the makers of the drugs, which advertise heavily and sell millions of pills for a total of $5 billion a year. It was a victory for the health insurance industry, which passes on a large portion of the cost to consumers and employers in insurance premiums and out-of-pocket payments. 
Surging use of effective but costly new drugs has been a primary cause of the double-digit rise in health care costs. 
Industry executives said they would pursue the fight over allergy drugs inside the Bush administration, which has not yet appointed a commissioner of the F.D.A. They said the issue was also likely to come up in Senate hearings when the president does appoint a commissioner.
"We are disappointed, but we are sure this is not a done deal," said Dr. Francois Nader, a senior vice president of Aventis S.A., which makes Allegra. "The next step is for the F.D.A. to look at all the reservations and comments presented by the panel" and witnesses. 
Dr. Robert Seidman, chief pharmacy officer of Wellpoint Health Networks, which brought the issue to the F.D.A., said the recommendations were "history making."
But Schering-Plough said in a statement that the panel's 19-to-4 vote on Claritin, its top-selling allergy drug, was "a nonbinding recommendation." The vote margin was similar for the other two drugs. Dr. Robert J. Spiegel, chief medical officer of Schering-Plough, said "the prescription status of these medications is necessary to protect and optimize public health."
Pfizer Inc., which makes Zyrtec, boycotted the meeting and refused to say why. "We are exploring our options," a Pfizer spokeswoman said last night.
The issue has provoked a battle with few heroes, said Ira A. Loss, an analyst with Washington Analysis, which monitors federal agencies for investors. "Wellpoint has a clear vested interest in getting the cost of the drugs off their books," he said. "The drug companies are against it. And the doctors don't like the idea that the number of office visits might fall. It's hard to find an honest broker in the whole deal."
Some panel members said that if approved for general sale, the drugs should carry warnings to elderly patients and parents of young children to consult a doctor about their use.
Critics of over-the-counter sales warned that symptoms associated with allergies might actually be asthma, a more serious condition that a doctor would recognize. But the manufacturers were unable to produce data showing that this confusion had caused widespread problems with the many nonprescription allergy drugs already in stores. 
Some panel members contended that the F.D.A. should review and re-evaluate the existing nonprescription drugs. But the drug companies found it difficult to argue that their products were not safe, with or without a prescription. If the safety of any drug was in doubt, federal officials told the panel, its approval for sale would be swiftly revoked. 
The manufacturers advertise that the three drugs are vastly superior to older remedies because they do not cause drowsiness. The companies spend millions of dollars each year to take their message directly to consumers. "All that direct-to-consumer advertising came back to bite them," said Barbara A. Ryan, a health care securities analyst at Deutsche Bank. 
Steve Francisco, a drug industry consultant, and editor of Switch, a newsletter, said Claritin accounted for 56 cents of Schering's earnings of $1.63 a share last year. "If they were forced to switch, that would go to 6 cents and there would be a huge hit in the price of the stock," he said. "It could result in a takeover."
The current price of Claritin is about $2.13 a pill, or $192 for 90 pills, in the United States. In Canada, where it is already available over the counter, it can be purchased for about 70 cents a pill before taxes.
Shares of Schering-Plough rose $1.20, to $38.30, yesterday after Business Week said that Merck & Company was seeking a merger. Both companies declined to discuss the report.
But most analysts said they doubted the F.D.A. had the legal authority to force the companies to change the status of the drugs. They expect the companies to defend their products in court, and the cases could last for years until the drugs lose the patent protection that makes their high prices possible.
Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, an economist who specializes in pharmaceutical issues at the University of Minnesota, said: "There are a lot of land mines in the politics of this. The law says the F.D.A. should give preference to making drugs over-the-counter products if they can be shown to be safe and appropriately used. But it has never been implemented that way. Selling over the counter has always been left to the discretion of the drug companies."
Proponents of the change pointed to Canada, Germany, Britain and other countries where Claritin has been sold without prescriptions for more than a decade at much lower prices. "Is the industry saying that American consumers are not as wise in using medicine as consumers in Canada or Mexico or England?" Dr. Schondelmeyer asked.

HEADLINE: FRIENDSHIP OF CONVENIENCE: A special report.; 
Pursuit of Cash and Influence Linked Torricelli and a Donor

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN and DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. May 11

 BODY:
Even by the freewheeling standards of Washington fund-raising, Bob Torricelli and David Chang made the oddest of couples.
 Mr. Torricelli, the articulate, ambitious Democratic senator from New Jersey, prides himself on the sophisticated company he keeps. His supporters have included Calvin Klein and Donald Trump; Bianca Jagger was once his girlfriend. There is no way he would rather spend a Sunday morning, some of his aides say, than talking foreign policy on a television news program. 
 Mr. Chang, a Korean-American businessman, is known for dropping the names of famous people he has never met. He has enough difficulty with English that Mr. Torricelli complained he was unintelligible. His behavior is eccentric enough that his own lobbyists sometimes tried to shield him from government officials, lest he say something off-the-wall. 
Yet for several years in the late 1990's, Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Chang shared a close relationship, forged of Mr. Chang's need for political influence and Mr. Torricelli's need for political cash. They got together on weekends. They talked frequently on the telephone. They did each other favors.
Now, the nature of that relationship and the terms of those favors have emerged as central issues in a wide-ranging federal investigation into the activities of Senator Torricelli, some of his political supporters and a few current and former members of his staff.
A close examination of the ties between Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Chang, based on campaign documents, court filings and interviews, suggests that while they did share a kind of friendship, it was complex and contradictory -- and opportunistic even for a political world that has long anguished over the power of wealthy contributors.
Initially, people who know both men said, Mr. Torricelli treated Mr. Chang as a prize catch. During his 1996 campaign, he courted the businessman attentively, inviting him to high-profile fund-raising events and trying to help Mr. Chang with his most urgent business problem, a $71 million debt owed to him by the North Korean government. Hoping to win further help, Mr. Chang has told the authorities, he lavished the politician with gifts and cash.
Mr. Torricelli has denied doing anything illegal or improper in his contacts with Mr. Chang. But as the relationship wore on, Mr. Torricelli sometimes hid those contacts almost as a married man might hide a mistress, people involved in the case said.
While the senator's aides sometimes whispered about Mr. Chang, few ever met him or spoke to him. He and Mr. Torricelli generally met alone, according to Mr. Chang and some of his former employees, on weekends at the senator's Englewood home.
Mr. Torricelli continued to do political favors for Mr. Chang, acting as a reference with important business contacts and helping him to meet with Clinton administration officials. At times, though, Mr. Chang was told to contact Mr. Torricelli through a discreet back channel by sending unaddressed memorandums to the senator's former wife, Susan Holloway Torricelli, a political consultant who often works for him, one of Mr. Chang's former employees said.
As federal prosecutors pressed their case against Mr. Chang in 1999, Mr. Torricelli grew more careful still. According to Mr. Chang's account, Mr. Torricelli remained outwardly solicitous and even invited Mr. Chang to an intimate Thanksgiving dinner only weeks after Mr. Chang's offices were raided by federal agents.
At the same time, Mr. Torricelli kept a close watch on Mr. Chang's legal troubles, speaking frequently with a defense lawyer whom Mr. Chang said he hired at the senator's urging. According to Mr. Chang and two former associates, both Mr. Torricelli and the lawyer strongly discouraged him from cooperating with the government -- something both men now deny.
According to people involved in the federal investigation, prosecutors are focusing in large part on allegations that Mr. Torricelli took tens of thousands of dollars in unreported gifts and cash from Mr. Chang between 1996 and 1999. The prosecutors are also looking at Mr. Torricelli's efforts to help Mr. Chang with business deals, and at indications that the senator's supporters may have tried to thwart the inquiry.
Mr. Torricelli has not denied taking gifts or cash. Rather, he has said he never took "illegal" gifts, refusing to discuss specific allegations and attacking the credibility of Mr. Chang, who has been cooperating with prosecutors in return for leniency. Mr. Torricelli has also said pointedly that he once considered Mr. Chang a friend; federal laws that bar public officials from accepting expensive gifts make a partial exception for gifts received from personal friends.
But only a few months ago, Mr. Torricelli was still sometimes describing Mr. Chang as a supporter like so many others, a man he did not much help and never really knew. Mr. Torricelli said he was shocked when Mr. Chang pleaded guilty last June to making illegal campaign donations and obstructing justice and turned out to have wildly exaggerated his image as a dynamic global entrepreneur. But he was quick to suggest that people like David Chang were an occupational hazard of big-money politics.
"You end up meeting a group of people that, otherwise in your life, you'd never know, never want to know, never meet, and David Chang would go in that category," he told CNBC's Chris Matthews.
A lawyer for Mr. Torricelli, Ted Wells, would not discuss details of Mr. Torricelli's relationship with Mr. Chang yesterday, but said, "The assistance given David Chang was of the type commonly provided by members of Congress to their constituents."
A lawyer for Mr. Chang, Bradley D. Simon, declined to discuss his client's dealings with the senator, but he asserted in earlier comments that the senator's attacks on Mr. Chang were at odds with the relationship the men shared in the past.
"Bob Torricelli didn't seem to think David Chang was such a liar when he was taking his money," Mr. Simon said. "It is obviously in Torricelli's interest now to discredit David at any cost, but the truth of what happened is going to come out in due time."

An Unclear Beginning

Tracing the History Of a Relationship
In interviews and public statements, Mr. Torricelli and his aides have been vague about how he and Mr. Chang met, saying they probably contacted him after finding his name on a Democratic fund-raising list. But the detailed account that Mr. Chang has given to investigators, as well as other evidence, indicates that each man's agenda was clear from the start.
Throughout the early 1990's, Mr. Chang was a strong supporter of Republicans, and in 1991, he prevailed on the Bush administration to waive American trade sanctions so that he could sell grain to North Korea. 
The arrangement was at first profitable, but by 1994, Mr. Chang claimed to be owed some $71 million, records show. Eventually, he obtained a letter from North Korea assigning him about $15 million in assets frozen by the United States, one of his former associates said. But the Clinton administration was unmoved, saying the funds were not North Korea's to assign.
Mr. Chang said he sought help from one of his New Jersey lawyers, Berek P. Don, a former Bergen County Republican chairman. He said Mr. Don pointed him to Mr. Torricelli, then his local congressman and a ranking member of the House International Relations Committee.
By Mr. Chang's account, which one of Mr. Torricelli's lawyers disputed, Mr. Don introduced the two men in the summer of 1995 at the Hilton hotel in Fort Lee, N.J., which Mr. Chang bought two years earlier. Mr. Chang said he laid out his problem to Mr. Torricelli, who promised to try to help. But he said Mr. Torricelli asked for some help in return.
"Bob said, 'Can you help my campaign?' " one person familiar with Mr. Chang's account quoted him as telling investigators.
For Mr. Torricelli, the North Korean matter was a tricky one. He had made a name for himself, and attracted big political contributions, as the most visible Democratic advocate of economic sanctions against Cuba.
At the same time, he was preparing for what was expected to be an unusually tough Senate race. Mr. Chang, who claimed to be the son-in-law of powerful industrialists in Japan, seemed to have deep pockets and a willingness to help, aides to Mr. Torricelli said. 
On Sept. 22, 1995, the congressman wrote to North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations urging his government to pay up and offering to meet at any time. Mr. Torricelli did not wait to call in the chit: on Sept. 26, he sent a senior aide, Georgianna Evans, to meet with the businessman about being the host of a fund-raising event. Mr. Chang had asked to meet with Mr. Torricelli himself, but the congressman, who found Mr. Chang's English difficult to understand, demurred.
"Bob said: 'Why don't you have lunch with him? Maybe you can figure out what he's saying,' " recalled Ms. Evans, who left the campaign in a dispute soon thereafter.
Mr. Chang had no experience soliciting contributions, but agreed to try. On Dec. 14, he gathered a small group of employees and friends on the top floor of the Fort Lee Hilton. They had drinks, listened to remarks by Mr. Torricelli and wrote $21,000 in checks -- which Mr. Chang illegally reimbursed.
Mr. Torricelli's chief of staff, Eric B. Shuffler, said in an interview last year that while Mr. Chang was named to the campaign's finance committee, he was never in the "inner circle" of Mr. Torricelli's team. "Not in any way, shape or form anything close to that," he said. 
But other campaign staff members said Mr. Chang quickly emerged as a donor who got special attention. 
"Torricelli was always meeting with him or talking with him on the phone," said one former aide. "Torricelli was in with him deep." 
Internal campaign documents leave a similar impression. In a memorandum listing fund-raising events planned for the first four months of 1996, Mr. Chang is at the top, with a goal of $100,000. On a separate list of "non-event fund-raising" expected by March 31, Mr. Chang is listed second, at $50,000. On a third list that June, Mr. Chang is again at the top with a new goal of $60,000.
While Mr. Chang apparently never met those goals, he did spend lavishly on Mr. Torricelli's behalf.
In March, at what he said was Mr. Torricelli's request, Mr. Chang donated $20,000 to the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee and gave the campaign another $5,000 in checks written by some of his employees and associates. On July 18, Mr. Chang wrote an $11,000 check to the law firm of Berek Don, to reimburse checks written by employees of the firm and others. 
In early September, Mr. Torricelli also began flying around New Jersey on private planes that one of Mr. Chang's companies chartered for his campaign.

The Usual Bond

A Friend, Yes, But Not a Close One
As lawyers for Mr. Torricelli described his relationship with Mr. Chang in interviews earlier this year, it was the usual sort of bond between a politician and a supporter.
"They have had some social contact with each other," said one of those lawyers, Robert F. Bauer. "He has been to Bob Torricelli's house. He has had lunch with Bob Torricelli. He has had dinner with Bob Torricelli. It was not a profound social relationship. He was a friend. Was he one of Bob's closest friends? No."
But there is little question that Mr. Chang was a generous friend.
On July 15, 1996, Mr. Chang bought Mr. Torricelli an $8,100 Rolex watch, presenting it shortly after his election victory on Nov. 5, he has told investigators. A few weeks later, Mr. Chang has stated, he began making $9,000 in payments on a new Mercedes-Benz sedan that Mr. Torricelli had pointed out to him. Lawyers for Mr. Torricelli said he had not known about Mr. Chang's payments and ordered them refunded when he learned of them. Then he bought the car himself.
Former associates of Mr. Chang said the candidate led him to believe that his debt problem could be resolved after the election. Two longtime Torricelli supporters said that if he left that impression, he was probably stringing Mr. Chang along.
Mr. Torricelli was sworn in on Jan. 7, 1997, and soon after he became vice chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee -- a rare leadership position for a freshman.
Mr. Torricelli threw himself into the job, and according to several of Mr. Chang's associates, the businessman was occasionally along for the ride, attending big Democratic fund-raising events, sometimes sitting beside the senator.
Soon after Mr. Torricelli joined the campaign committee (he later became chairman), Mr. Chang donated $10,000 to the committee. Over the next two years, he donated nearly $200,000 more to Democratic party causes, either directly, through employees or through his companies.
In spring 1997, Mr. Chang has said, he had his favorite local tailor begin fitting Mr. Torricelli for the first of at least 10 off-the-rack Italian suits. He also said he bought jewelry for Judy D. Balaban, who was then Mr. Torricelli's girlfriend, and an Oriental rug and a large-screen television for Mr. Torricelli's home.
Not long thereafter, Mr. Chang told investigators, Mr. Torricelli called him on a cellular telephone from Lambertville, N.J., a small town on the Pennsylvania border that is a favorite of antique shoppers. The senator had found a 100-year-old grandfather clock that he loved, but it cost more than $4,000. Could his friend help? 
Mr. Chang said he gave Mr. Torricelli cash to cover the cost of the clock. 
Later that year, Mr. Chang has told investigators, he drove Mr. Torricelli into Manhattan to buy Ms. Balaban some earrings. According to two people familiar with Mr. Chang's account, he said Mr. Torricelli insisted on waiting in the car while Mr. Chang went into Tiffany & Company on Fifth Avenue. 
When Mr. Chang could not find the right earrings, the senator asked him to go back in and pick up a set of cuff links for him, these people said.
To what extent Mr. Torricelli reciprocated Mr. Chang's generosity is unclear. But Mr. Torricelli did vouch for Mr. Chang with other politicians.
In late spring 1998, when Mr. Chang approached President Clinton's friend Terry McAuliffe about working for him as a consultant, Mr. McAuliffe called Mr. Torricelli for a reference. "Bob said, 'He's a legitimate person, a legitimate businessman,' " Mr. McAuliffe recalled.
When it came to making contacts with the Clinton administration, former associates of Mr. Chang said, Mr. Torricelli was more circumspect.
In late 1997, at Mr. Torricelli's direction, one of Mr. Chang's former lawyers sent an unaddressed memorandum to the senator through his former wife, Susan Holloway Torricelli, seeking help in setting up a meeting with a senior State Department official, Stanley O. Roth.
In an interview, Mr. Roth said he had granted the meeting to associates of Mr. Chang who were seeking permission to organize zinc mining in North Korea as a way to recoup some of his debt. Mr. Roth also confirmed that he had done so after being contacted by Senator Torricelli or one of his aides, but that he would have granted the meeting anyway because "it sounded like an interesting idea."
Messages left for Ms. Torricelli yesterday asking for comment were not returned.

Growing Problems

Staying in Contact After a Subpoena
As Mr. Chang's legal problems grew more serious in early 1999, Mr. Torricelli remained in close touch. But he also became more discreet, Mr. Chang and some of his former associates said.
Mr. Chang received his first government subpoena on Jan. 23, 1997. At the time, court records show, federal prosecutors were looking into allegations of a fraudulent business deal involving Mr. Chang's former lawyer, Mr. Don.
According to Mr. Chang's account, he quickly told Mr. Torricelli about the January subpoena. But Mr. Torricelli became more involved in Mr. Chang's legal matters after a new federal grand jury was impaneled in Newark on Feb. 5, 1999, to continue the investigation into illegal donations to his campaign.
At a meeting at the Fort Lee Hilton that June, set up by Mr. Torricelli and one of his lawyers, Abbe D. Lowell, Mr. Chang sat down for the first time with the lawyer who would subsequently represent him, Michael Critchley.
On the advice of Mr. Critchley, who had been a Torricelli supporter and fund-raiser, Mr. Chang entered into a joint-defense agreement that called for him to share information about his case with the Torricelli campaign, people involved in the deal said. Another of Mr. Torricelli's lawyers, Mr. Bauer, also acknowledged that Mr. Torricelli spoke repeatedly to Mr. Critchley about Mr. Chang's case, but he described those conversations as entirely appropriate.
Over the next six months, the government's pressure on Mr. Chang rose steadily. People familiar with Mr. Chang's account said he told the authorities that both Mr. Critchley and Mr. Torricelli urged him not to cooperate with the government. Mr. Critchley dismissed that assertion.
"If I ever thought there was a conflict that would have prevented me from zealously representing my client as he instructed me," he said in an interview, referring to his prior relationship with Mr. Torricelli, "I would never have accepted the case." 
But according to two of Mr. Chang's former employees, he had told several of his associates that he wanted to fire Mr. Critchley because he felt that the lawyer was acting on Mr. Torricelli's behalf. One of the former employees said that on Friday, Dec. 10, 1999, after F.B.I. agents arrested the businessman, Mr. Torricelli repeatedly telephoned another of Mr. Chang's lawyers, urging thatMr. Critchley be kept on the case.
The following Monday, with Mr. Chang still in custody, Mr. Critchley announced to the court that his client had no incriminating information about Mr. Torricelli, Mr. Clinton, Mr. McAuliffe or any other politicians. But Mr. Chang dismissed Mr. Critchley the next day. When Mr. Torricelli learned of the firing, an aide said, he exploded in anger, slamming something against his office wall. 
Mr. Torricelli's lawyer, Mr. Wells, would not comment on this account.
At the suggestion of his next lawyer, Mr. Chang rehired Mr. Critchley early in 2000 to help prepare for trial. Not long thereafter, prosecutors tried to disqualify Mr. Critchley and his co-counsel on procedural grounds. In a sealed hearing that spring, a federal judge also emphasized to Mr. Chang that he needed to be fully aware of Mr. Critchley's prior relationship with Mr. Torricelli.
According to two people familiar with the case, Mr. Critchley remained on the case even though Mr. Chang stopped paying his monthly retainer in the fall 1999. Their association finally ended when Mr. Chang agreed to cooperate with the government.
Since last fall, Mr. Critchley has stood alone among nearly a dozen former lawyers for Mr. Chang in fighting a government subpoena for some of his records about the Chang case, even though Mr. Chang has waived the attorney-client privilege.
Mr. Critchley would not comment on the issue. But according to two people familiar with his motions, he has argued that he cannot disclose some information about the Chang case because of the joint-defense pact with Mr. Torricelli's campaign.

(Associated Press); Robert Torricelli, left, after winning the Democratic primary for the United States Senate in 1996. During the campaign, David Chang was prominent on lists of fund-raisers, but apparently never met his goals. (Associated Press)(pg. B4)

PUB-DATE: May 12, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section A; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1581 words

HEADLINE: Big Store, Seen as Interloper, Wins Over a Neighborhood 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
The floors were clean and shiny. The seafood counter was stocked with Alaskan snow crabs. A wide-screen television overhead offered cooking tips. Even Gertrud Wittingham, who had been dead set against the Pathmark supermarket, was singing its praises at the tomato sauce display.
 "There is nothing bad I can say," Mrs. Wittingham said the other day at the store in Springfield Gardens, Queens. "It has good sales, and it has enhanced the neighborhood." 
 More than a year after the Pathmark opened on the site of a former telephone company warehouse, the fiercely disputed grocery store has become a favorite shopping destination in southeast Queens. The largely middle-class communities near Kennedy International Airport had been without a major suburban-style supermarket for a quarter century. Pathmark says the 60,000-square-foot store is exceeding all earnings projections, drawing shoppers who had previously traveled to Nassau County for their groceries. 
But as in so many neighborhood disputes across the city, there were predictions of calamity during the decadelong struggle to get the Pathmark built. Now, the ubiquitous not-in-my-backyard refrain has been turned on its head. The neighborhood is enjoying the beginnings of a commercial renaissance, and the arrival of the supermarket is getting most of the credit.
"There were many people against it because we expected so many problems," said Mrs. Wittingham, a retired church secretary who has lived in Springfield Gardens for 32 years. "But none of it happened."
The fears were familiar ones, echoed over the years at public hearings and neighborhood meetings about other building projects from Harlem to Williamsburg, Brooklyn. There would be drug dealers roaming the parking lots, especially if the store was open around the clock. Traffic would grow intolerable. The shopping center would emerge as an island in a sea of retail failure. It was even suggested that Pathmark's merchandise would be second-rate because that part of Queens is mostly black.
The reality? The police report that crime is down 19 percent this year in the precinct that includes the 24-hour supermarket, which has its own security patrols. Traffic has increased, but road improvements made by the developer have kept it moving. A Burger King has opened across the street, and a Walgreens not far away. Behind the Pathmark, a Home Depot is going up.
Pathmark, at the intersection of Springfield and Merrick Boulevards, already has company in the shopping center it anchors: Party City, Radio Shack, Blockbuster, Payless Shoe Source and other businesses, including a bank and a health center. And a pharmacy in nearby Laurelton, whose owner had opposed the Pathmark, is doing well and has been sold to Duane Reade, another indication, some community leaders say, that things are getting better, not worse.
"A picture is worth a thousand words, and all we have to do is look at the community and see the magnificent progress," said the Rev. Edward Davis, the pastor at the Presbyterian Church of St. Albans, where many of the negotiations for the shopping center took place. "This has been a case of the survival of the fittest -- we started 12 years ago, I think -- but whatever you call what has occurred, it is progress." 
The developer and landlord of the supermarket, Joseph M. Mattone Sr., the chief executive of the Mattone Group, said that getting the shopping center built was grueling at times. "I attended meetings almost monthly for four or five years, and it nearly drove me nuts," Mr. Mattone said.
But answering questions and keeping residents involved, he said, were crucial to winning them over eventually, however grudgingly in some cases. The project, which Mr. Mattone described as "an unqualified success," has become so well known that the company is consulted about its experience in getting it built. Next month, Mr. Mattone said, he will speak about building in Queens at a real estate seminar at the Bernard M. Baruch College in Manhattan.
Enthusiasm for the supermarket has been so unbridled that many officials, from the City Council to the local community boards, have openly ignored a requirement imposed in 1995 that Pathmark set aside $400,000 to help small businesses cope with their big new competitor.
If there is any lingering controversy about the Pathmark -- aside from complaints that shoppers must make a 25-cent refundable deposit to get a shopping cart -- it is what should become of the development fund.
The provision was instrumental in quelling business opposition to the development, which some critics feared would hurt local merchants, especially some blacks, at a time when another high-profile Pathmark project, in East Harlem, had become entwined in racial politics.
In the end, the Springfield Gardens development pitted the City Council against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who said the $400,000 amounted to blackmail and vetoed construction because of it. The City Council overrode the veto, but nearly six years later, the committee meant to oversee the fund has yet to meet or collect any money.
According to a payment schedule in the legislation, $125,000 is overdue. The payments were supposed to start last year, with the first of 20 annual installments to be deposited in an interest-bearing account in the office of the city comptroller. The money is for projects like facade renovations and sidewalk improvements.
A spokesman for the comptroller's office, David Neustadt, said no account had been set up or requested. City officials acknowledged that Pathmark had not been approached about making good on the payments.
"No one has pressured Pathmark to come up with the money," said Yvonne Reddick, district manager of Community Board 12 in Queens, one of two community boards that include Springfield Gardens.
"Of course it is necessary," she said. "But it has not happened."
Some supporters of Pathmark say the payments were never a good idea but have been rendered especially irrelevant because the supermarket has done so much to revitalize the neighborhood. Local business leaders say there have been some unhappy merchants, but their numbers are small and there have been no reported instances of stores going out of business because of competition from the new development. 
Pathmark says it has been a good corporate citizen, making donations to Little League teams, churches, programs for the elderly and a fund for Christmas decorations in the nearby business district. Even the flowers on Springfield Boulevard have been planted and maintained with the help of the grocery store, said Harvey M. Gutman, Pathmark's senior vice president for retail development at the company's headquarters in Carteret, N.J.
"We are more than fulfilling our promises and the expectations of our customers and the local community," Mr. Gutman said.
The Queens Citizens Organization, a church-based advocacy group that was the first to approach Pathmark about building in southeast Queens, opposed the $400,000 requirement when it was brokered by Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins, who represents Springfield Gardens. Now, with more than 275 people employed at the supermarket and scores more at the adjoining stores, the group suggests there is no point in revisiting the emotionally charged issue, said Mr. Davis, the Presbyterian pastor who was chairman of the organization's economic committee.
"We were happy that we were bringing in jobs and a meaningful commercial entity in the community," the pastor said.
But there are some local merchants who see things differently. Not far down the street from the Pathmark, Kamil Mohammed, who owns the Midway Deli and Grill, was arguing one day this week with a customer who complained that a can of corned beef cost more there than at Pathmark.
Mr. Mohammed said he spent much of his day trying to convince customers that "we are not robbing everybody." Not long ago, Mr. Mohammed said, he explained his predicament to one of his soft-drink suppliers. The salesman suggested that Mr. Mohammed buy his soft drinks at the Pathmark. Mr. Mohammed took the advice, and on a case of 24 cans of Pepsi, he said, he saves $2.99. He also discovered he could save money doing the same with tea bags and breakfast cereal.
"I don't know anything about this fund, but are you kidding? Of course I would want to take advantage of it," said Mr. Mohammed, who bought the business last year from a cousin and said it could use a face-lift. "The only thing that is keeping me going is the grill."
Inside the Pathmark, some shoppers said they sympathized with small merchants like Mr. Mohammed and suggested that Pathmark honor its agreement about the fund. Across the street, at Hopkins' Barber Shop, Neville Wallace, one of the barbers, said the Pathmark was good for most businesses because of the increased traffic on Merrick and Springfield Boulevards. But some other businesses, he said, have not been so lucky.
"The little guy always needs help," Mr. Wallace said. "Pathmark knew they were going to hurt the little guys when they came here, so they should help them now."
Ms. Watkins, the councilwoman who negotiated the development fund, said she remained committed to collecting the money, but she also suggested there was no hurry. Pathmark has turned out to be "community-friendly," she said. Even Ms. Watkins -- once one of the project's most consistent critics -- spends her grocery dollars there.
"We are not worried that Pathmark or that the money is going to run away," she said.

HEADLINE: Despite European Unity Efforts, to Most Workers There's No Country Like Home 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 11 

 BODY:
Three years ago, when Catalina Martinez was finishing her doctorate in economics at the University of Barcelona, she could not find work in Spain. So, with a British professor's help, she got a job in London. The next year she moved to Brussels. The year after that she arrived in Paris.
 For the young and the highly educated like Ms. Martinez, Europe's borders mean very little. Those people flit from city to city and discuss the relative attributes of Berlin, London and Paris much the way that New Yorkers might debate the benefits of choosing to live in Manhattan, Brooklyn or the suburbs. 
 But experts say that for the vast majority of Europeans, the treaties that guarantee them the right to work and live anywhere in the 15 countries of the European Union do not really mean much. 
Locked in by culture, language and a host of soft barriers like differences in the recognition of professional licensing, trouble transferring pension rights, access to public housing and varying tax codes, few Europeans are actually working outside their own countries in Europe.
On paper there are big incentives to move around in what European leaders envisaged as one huge market. Rates of unemployment vary widely in the European Union -- more than 14 percent in Spain, for instance, but less than 3 percent in the Netherlands, where the labor shortage is so severe that the government is sponsoring programs to get retirees back into the work force.
And still the unemployed are not flocking from, say, sunny Andalusia in southern Spain to the gray, rain-whipped shores of the North Sea in the Netherlands.
"For the tourist, there are no borders," said Catherine Wihtol de Wenden, the director of immigration research for the French Center for International Research. "But for the rest there has been much less mobility than we had expected. There are many, many things that keep people at home, and that is only changing very slowly."
In the 10 years since treaties were signed supposedly eliminating the barriers to free movement within the Union, only 2 percent of European Union citizens work in Europe outside their home countries. Surveys estimate that Americans move from state to state more than five times as often as European Union citizens change countries.
"In the U.S., the unemployed move to find jobs," said John Salt, a migration expert at University College in London. "But in Europe the unemployed tend not to move. In fact, you have a phenomenon where those who least need to move -- those on the high end -- are the ones who move the most."
Studies done for the Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels have shown that the barriers to mobility are in fact numerous. 
Case studies showed that European Union citizens trying to get information about working in other countries often were shifted from pillar to post and tangled in slow-moving bureaucracies.
In one case, a German teacher who wanted to work in Austria was told that he could submit an application for recognition of his German credentials only after he had found a job. Of course, no school was ready to offer him a job until his credentials had been approved. He was also told that applications for recognition were allowed only once a year and if the deadline had passed, he had to wait until the next year.
A German pharmacist had to wait 18 months for approval of her qualifications in France, despite Union directives that provided for the automatic recognition of her license. 
A Spanish citizen with a German degree in architecture fared no better when he tried to go home. The Spanish authorities said they did not know what the equivalent of his diploma was, although it, too, was accounted for in a European Union directive.
Some experts say Europe's preoccupation with clamping down on illegal immigration has far overshadowed the attention paid to the difficulties citizens face when they want to move from country to country.
"The problems were identified years ago," said Dr. Joanna Apap, a research fellow with the Center for European Policy Studies, "but nothing has been done about them."
European Union officials say the issue is about to get the attention it deserves in part precisely because of the imbalance between areas of chronic labor shortage and those of high unemployment. Part of the problem is a mismatch of skills. But lack of mobility is worrying enough that the European Union is creating a high-level panel to study solutions.
Experts say there are few statistica about who is moving where and for what, though most believe that mobility is on the rise for the young and for high-ranking executives, both groups that tend to speak several languages and have often been educated in more than one country.
The estimates that are available suggest that a mere 0.4 percent of European Union citizens -- about 1.5 million people -- move country to country each year. In 1998, migration between states in the United States was 2.4 percent.
Attitudes about such movement vary widely within Europe. Citizens from the north seem most at ease, with migration from Germany and Denmark reaching about 1.2 percent a year.
In France, by contrast, that rate is below 0.2 percent, and some experts contend that French people who have worked abroad and other European Union citizens face a subtle bias.
"People who have not always followed the traditional path here can have problems," said Ms. Wihtol de Wenden. "There is always the idea that if you go elsewhere, it is because you were running from a problem, that you have an adventurous side and that you are not really serious. These ideas have to change but they have not yet."
Ms. Wihtol de Wenden said that at her university, Germans and Italians looking for jobs were likely to be considered after French applicants.
"We are not quite ready for this new life," she said. "We are used to working with our own."
Executive search firms say high-level European executives run into few technical difficulties in moving around. They find all sorts of ways to transfer their pensions and other benefits. 
In fact, few are strictly focused on Europe. Where they move and why has more to do with training and opportunity. They are just as likely to take a job in Hong Kong or the United States as they are to stay in Europe, although European Union citizenship can play a big part in what jobs they take. Many might like to work in the United States but find it easier to stay in Europe and avoid the struggle for visas.
Francesco Faiola would have preferred to go to America when he was starting out. But he found it much easier to be hired in Brussels. Now, at 32, he is a vice president of Moody's Investors Service in London, and at the end of the year he expects to move to Paris.
His moves have been easy, he says, though he has some concerns. He is anxious, for instance, about whether he and his Belgian wife will be able to get a mortgage from a French bank. "We are looking at building up a credit history that will be transferable," he said. "We could have a lot of problems with this."
But most of the difficulties of working in other European countries border on the comic. Mr. Faiola says that in Italy, for instance, offices are loud and there is lots of consultation. In Brussels he soon learned not to shout across the office.
"Whatever you say about the E.U. -- the one flag, the one currency, whatever -- we are still 15 different cultures," he said.
Once such adjustments are made, some wonder whether they will ever go back home. For Ms. Martinez, the issue would be finding the right job, which she does not expect to happen. 
"There is only one consulting company in Madrid that does what I am expert in," she said. "So there isn't much chance of me going back. Besides, I like Paris." But others, like Vania Schleef who also works for Moody's in London, believe that the process of working in several different countries with colleagues of all nationalities has changed them.
Ms. Schleef says she no longer feels at home when she goes back to Nice, where she was born. "When I go back, I don't quite fit in the picture anymore," she said. "They think I am a posh girl. And I don't think that is true, but I am not the same."

GRAPHIC: Photos: International mobility for workers within the European Union is highest among the young and the upscale. Vania Schleef, left, who works for Moody's Investors Service in London, is French; Francesco Faiola, an executive there, is Italian. Catalina Martinez, from Spain, is a Paris economist. (Fabien Calcavechia for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
British Telecommunications Encounters Two Setbacks

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 11 

 BODY:
A day after British Telecommunications announced bold moves to cut its $43 billion in debt, the company sustained two surprising setbacks today. 
 A British regulator freed the company to sell its Yell directory services division, but imposed a cut in its advertising rates, possibly jeopardizing the sale or reducing the $4.2 billion price that British Telecom had hoped to get, executives close to the deal said. 
 And Moody's Investors Services lowered the company's credit rating by two notches, to Baa1 from A, adding as much as $42 million to its interest payments, according to a British Telecom spokeswoman. Moody's action followed a more modest rate cut by Standard & Poor's on Thursday. 
British Telecommunications said on Thursday that it would seek more than $8 billion from investors by selling them discounted new shares as part of a package of measures that included spinning off its wireless division and selling Yell. 
Two private equity groups, Apax Partners and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., have been in talks about acquiring Yell in one of Europe's biggest leveraged buyouts, people close to the talks said earlier this month. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is also said to have had discussions.
Today, a British government competition regulator said that it approved the sale of Yell. But it did so on condition that the division hold increases in advertising rates at the level of inflation minus 6 percent. With British inflation running about 2 percent at an annual rate, that ruling, in effect, orders a 4 percent cut in advertising revenue. 
The regulator made its ruling ostensibly because Yell dominates the directory services market and could crush competition. Its nearest rival, Thomson Directories, has only a 15 percent market share, mainly in regional directories. Yell also owns the United States' biggest independent Yellow Pages business. Last year, the company had a profit of $:208 million ($295 million). The reduction in advertising rates could cut profits as much as 10 percent, some analysts said, making it a less attractive purchase. The sale is nonetheless expected to go ahead next week, according to executives close to the discussions, but the final price is not yet clear.
"The ruling will affect revenues of Yell and that could affect the sale of Yell," said Andrea Paradine, a spokeswoman for British Telecommunications. But, she said, the company was awaiting more details on the cuts sought by the regulator to work out the full implications for the sale of Yell. She indicated that the company was not abandoning the sale, arguing that with several unidentified suitors bidding, Yell was still seen as a valuable asset.
In the past, British Telecommunications has indicated it was interested in either spinning off or selling the business. The spokeswoman said the company was "very surprised, very disappointed" by Moody's downgrade. British Telecommunications had promised its investors that it would maintain an A grade rating by reducing its existing debt.

HEADLINE: Italy's Moment of Decision 

BYLINE:  By Alexander Stille; Alexander Stille is the author of "Excellent Cadavers: The Mafia and the Death of the First Italian Republic" and writes frequently about Italy.

 BODY:
The fact that Italy is about to elect its 59th government since World War II is regarded with almost complete indifference in the United States. Since the end of the cold war and the dissolution of the Italian Communist Party, Italy has virtually disappeared from the radar screen of American foreign policy. But the potential consequences of tomorrow's election are far more important than many realize.
 The hodgepodge center-right coalition that appears likely to emerge victorious includes a small neo-Fascist party of Mussolini nostalgists and a northern separatist party that routinely inveighs against immigrants, Muslims and homosexuals in phrases that Jorg Haider of Austria would not repeat in public. Paradoxically, the most measured member of the team is the "post-fascist" party, the National Alliance, which is anxious to appear as respectable as possible. 
 The real danger for democracy, however, is the coalition's leader, Silvio Berlusconi, the media magnate who, since entering politics in 1994, has rewritten the rules of democratic governance in ways that could have serious repercussions well beyond Italy.
The problem is not Mr. Berlusconi's ideas -- a confusing but unremarkable set of proposals to lower taxes while raising retirement pensions and undertaking an ambitious public works program -- but the massive conflict between private and public interests he poses for Italy.
With a business empire estimated at $12 billion, Mr. Berlusconi is probably Italy's richest man; he is 14th wealthiest in the world, according to Forbes. More important, his key holdings are the three largest private television networks, which have an audience share of 45 percent. As prime minister, he would effectively control the three main public stations, giving him a hold on 90 percent of the television audience. He also owns the Mondadori publishing group, which controls a third of both the magazine and book markets; a championship soccer team; and a leading mutual fund company. He transferred ownership of one major daily newspaper to his brother; another is largely controlled by his wife.
Imagine that President George W. Bush owned CBS, ABC, NBC, CNN, the Conde Nast publishing group, Fidelity Investments and the New York Yankees, and you begin to get an idea of the power Mr. Berlusconi wields. Mr. Berlusconi's television empire is now run by his children and, not coincidentally, he has received four times as much air time as has the center-left candidate, Francesco Rutelli, the former mayor of Rome. (The state networks have given each candidate equal time.) Moreover, Mr. Berlusconi's television networks are more openly partisan than any medium in the United States short of talk radio. The anchorman of one of Mr. Berlusconi's networks wept openly with joy when Mr. Berlusconi was elected prime minister in 1994 and vowed to leave the country if Mr. Berlusconi failed to win re-election in 1996 -- a promise he failed to keep.
The situation is greatly complicated by the fact that Mr. Berlusconi made his fortune during one of the most corrupt times in Italian history. He and his companies came under investigation after Italian magistrates started to investigate crimes of political corruption in the early 1990's. Various probes have turned up bribes, under-the-table payments to judges and politicians, illegal financing of political parties, off-shore dummy companies and tax evasion schemes. There are at least eight cases still open against Mr. Berlusconi.
Mr. Berlusconi's media empire has succeeded, in part, in portraying the Italian investigating magistrates as part of a Communist-inspired plot to destroy him politically. And his influence on the state media -- his own and allied parties partly administer the state networks, which run on a partisan spoils system -- has meant that he has never been forced to answer rigorous questioning on the investigations. (Italy's justice system is in genuine need of reform, but its rules should not be rewritten by one of its leading defendants, who has proposed placing prosecutors under executive control and eliminating crimes like false accounting. Mr. Berlusconi is himself under investigation for false accounting.)
Examining the charges against Mr. Berlusconi, The Economist concluded recently that he was "not fit to lead the government of any country, least of all one of the world's richest democracies."
Many Italians had hoped that their country's integration into Europe would reduce some of its anomalies. There is evidence that just the opposite is happening: Mr. Berlusconi is succeeding in exporting his conflicts of interest to Europe. He has major business alliances in Germany (with media giant Leo Kirch) and Spain, in both cases with ambitions to build pan-European companies large enough to counter American rivals in film and television production. Spanish prosecutors have uncovered evidence suggesting that Mr. Berlusconi used a series of front companies to gain more than his legal limit of a 25 percent share of Tele 5, a leading Spanish broadcaster, and evaded tens of millions of dollars in taxes.
These Spanish investigators have not been able to go further because Mr. Berlusconi enjoys immunity as a member of the European parliament -- and the Spanish government, allied politically with Mr. Berlusconi, has failed, for months, to forward prosecutors' request for a waiver of immunity on to Brussels.
The explosive mixture of unlimited money, media control and political power is a growing issue worldwide. Mr. Berlusconi has simply been the boldest figure in pushing the equation to its limits in a country with weak public institutions and little tradition of putting aside partisan differences for a larger good.
Members of the Bush administration acted commendably in selling off stock and private business holdings in order to remove any doubts about the propriety of their governance. Mr. Berlusconi claims he is in favor of anything American and announced this week that as prime minister he would hope to be America's "biggest friend and ally in Europe." So perhaps he might be persuaded that strict norms against mixing private and public power, like those widely accepted in the United States, might be best also for Italy. He has resolved to solve the conflict-of-interest problem in his first 100 days of office, but says in the same breath that it is "a false problem." He needs to be persuaded, should he be elected, that anything short of total divestment of all private holdings -- to a third party unconnected to him or his family -- places him outside the accepted norms of modern democracy.
