HEADLINE: Gambling Industry Battles McCain Ban on College Bets 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11 

 BODY:
Only weeks after he dealt a blow to the capital's money culture, Senator John McCain is facing the strong possibility of a defeat at the hands of a few well-heeled corporate lobbyists who want to kill his bill to outlaw betting on college sports.
 The gambling industry has waged an aggressive campaign, backed by more than $10 million in campaign contributions last year, to defeat Mr. McCain's effort to close a loophole: Federal law bans betting on college sports in every state except Nevada, where sports betting parlors handle millions of dollars a day in wagers on college and professional games. 
 Mr. McCain's bill was nearly derailed on May 3 when the Senate Commerce Committee narrowly defeated an amendment that would have kept the Nevada loophole open. The vote in the committee, which Mr. McCain heads, was 10 to 10, meaning the amendment failed. 
Among those voting for the amendment -- and against Mr. McCain -- was the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, who can control when, or if, the bill is taken up on the Senate floor.
The overall bill, which was sought by the National Collegiate Athletic Association and many prominent coaches and athletes, was approved by the committee on a voice vote and sent to the floor.
Mr. McCain has portrayed the fight over the gambling ban as additional proof of the need to restrain the influence of money in politics.
The McCain-Feingold campaign finance bill approved by the Senate last month would ban soft money, the unlimited contributions that can be made to political parties and campaign committees.
"We're up against millions and millions, and perhaps tens of millions, of dollars in campaign contributions," Senator McCain, an Arizona Republican, said in an interview about the gambling bill. "It's no more complicated than that. This is a graphic example of the influence of big money in American politics."
A study by Public Citizen, a research group that supports an overhaul of the campaign finance system, found that the gambling industry had given $3.9 million in soft money to the Republican and Democratic Parties last year, more than double its soft-money donations in 1996, the last presidential election year.
The industry's overall political contributions, including direct hard-money contributions to individual Congressional candidates, jumped to $10.7 million last year from $6.9 million in 1996, according to a study by the Center for Responsive Politics. It found that contributions last year were about evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans, 52 percent to 48 percent respectively.
The gambling industry says Mr. McCain's bill would drive betting on college athletics out of the Las Vegas casinos, where it can be monitored by law enforcement agencies, and into the hands of illegal bookies.
Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., president of the American Gaming Association, the industry's trade association, said it was unfair to suggest that the industry's increased political donations explained the support it had received in trying to defeat the bill.
"It's just not the case that campaign contributions are doing the talking here," said Mr. Fahrenkopf, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee.
He noted that many other industries had also significantly increased their political contributions last year as a result of hotly contested races.
Mr. Fahrenkopf said that eliminating legal gambling in Nevada "would simply make things worse by driving this underground" while doing serious damage to the economy of Nevada. 
According to industry figures, casinos and other gambling outlets in Nevada took in about $2.3 billion in sports bets last year, with an estimated one-third of that on college games. Law enforcement agencies say that represents only a tiny fraction of all betting on college sports.
"Somewhere between 97 and 99 percent of all the gambling on sports is done illegally," said Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada. "To think that doing something about this tiny percentage in Nevada is going to do anything constructive is ludicrous."
The N.C.A.A., which has been overwhelmed by corruption scandals involving some of its members, has argued that legalized betting in Nevada encourages more corruption. 
"We think it's inappropriate to bet on the athletic success of young people, many of whom are teenagers," said Doris Dixon, the association's chief lobbyist in Washington.
In lobbying in support of Mr. McCain's bill, Ms. Dixon was reminded of the influence in Washington of the gambling industry. 
Because of its nonprofit status, the athletic association cannot make political contributions. So Ms. Dixon sought the help of seven consulting and lobbying firms to help her press her case; all turned her down, several citing a conflict of interest because they did other work for the casino industry.
"I've always believed that money was a big part of the industry's strategy that we had to work around," Ms. Dixon said. "I continue to believe that our voice will be heard above the money."

HEADLINE: Bush Says U.S. Will Give $200 Million to World AIDS Fund 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the United States would contribute $200 million to a global fund to attack AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis, but critics and some members of Congress said the initial donation was paltry.
 Mr. Bush made the announcement in the Rose Garden during a visit by Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, and the secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, who has called for a global fund to raise $7 billion to $10 billion a year. 
 While Mr. Annan praised Mr. Bush's announcement as a first step, United Nations officials have made clear that they expect the United States, Japan and other wealthy countries to make far larger donations. 
"We must all show leadership and all share responsibility," Mr. Bush said, adding that the $200 million was an initial donation and that future contributions would depend on the success of the fund.
In making the announcement today, the United States becomes the first country to commit itself to the fund, and some outside experts praised Mr. Bush for acting quickly.
"This is a new approach," said Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Center for International Development at Harvard, who recently completed a study of why past AIDS efforts had fallen short. "Until now we've had 23 donor countries dealing with 49 sub-Saharan African countries, and that means more than 1,100 tedious, time-consuming negotiations. Now you have a chance for an organized, global attack on the problem, bringing real science to it."
Mr. Bush also used today's meeting to complain to Mr. Annan about the removal of the United States from the United Nations Human Rights Commission.
"The decision was an outrageous decision," Mr. Bush said. "To me it undermines the whole credibility of this commission -- to kick the United States off, one of the great bastions of human rights, and allow Sudan to be on. And I think most reasonable people in the world see it that way."
But Mr. Bush reaffirmed the commitment by the United States to pay its back dues to the United Nations, despite a vote in the House on Thursday to withhold $244 million if the United States does not regain its seat on the rights commission. And Mr. Bush's embrace of Mr. Annan's initiative on AIDS is itself indicative of Washington's reliance on the United Nations, even though the global program is conceived as a public-private partnership.
Mr. Bush made no reference today to another such partnership, the World Bank AIDS Trust fund, which Congress voted last year to help finance with a $150 million donation. President Clinton signed the law in August, but only about $20 million was actually appropriated.
"There is clearly not enough money going into any of this," said Representative Barbara Lee, a Democrat from California. "I think we should be putting up at least a billion dollars, at a minimum," she said. "That is the only way to challenge the international community to do even more."
Mr. Bush's budget, now before Congress, calls for $480 million for AIDS treatment here and abroad, an 8 percent increase from the current fiscal year. But some popular AIDS treatment programs, such as the $1.8 billion Ryan White project, will not be increased. Instead the administration is focusing on developing vaccines as part of a $2.5 billion AIDS research budget at the National Institutes of Health.
As Mr. Bush met today with Mr. Annan and President Obasanjo, there were small clusters of protesters outside the White House. 
Dr. Peter Lurie, the deputy director of Public Citizen's Health Research Group, said in a statement that "even if every penny of this money went to AIDS, for the government of a country that produces 26 percent of the world's wealth to offer less than 10 percent of what U.N. AIDS experts say is needed to adequately respond to the epidemic is just miserly."
But a few months ago there was no discussion within the Bush camp of taking part in an international AIDS effort at all.
Mr. Bush sidestepped some of the more controversial issues relating to AIDS research, a topic that has not ranked high on the national Republican political agenda. But he said today that "prevention is indispensable to any strategy of controlling a pandemic such as we now face."
Mr. Annan was more specific, calling on countries around the world to find ways to care for 13 million children who have been made orphans by the spread of AIDS and "to ensure that people everywhere, particularly young people, know what to do to avoid infection."

HEADLINE: German Parliament Votes To Revamp Pension System 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 11 

 BODY:
After years of deadlock on the issue, Germany's Parliament passed a ground-breaking law today aimed at overhauling the country's extremely generous but financially strained retirement system.
 The new law tries to wean Germans from their almost total reliance on government pension programs that currently pay people 70 percent of their working income once they retire. The system has been an anchor to Germans, and most other European countries have similar systems. But all of these systems have been headed toward collapse, because the pool of younger workers paying in is being swamped by the retirees collecting from it. 
 The new law provides incentives for Germans to contribute some of their own money to private retirement accounts, similar to those that Americans and British have used for years. A separate law, passed earlier this year, will slightly reduce the level of government-paid pensions over the next 30 years. Though the pension revisions are modest, they nonetheless represent a political breakthrough that strikes at a central pillar of Europe's postwar social welfare system.
In what may be another sign of changing times, the lower house of Parliament also took an initial step toward approving a law that would allow prostitutes to collect social security and retirement benefits as well as to sue customers who refuse to pay.
The pension measure is a major victory for Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, leader of the center-left Social Democratic Party, who had to navigate past objections from traditionalists within his own party and dogged opposition from the center-right opposition, led by the Christian Democratic Union.
This was Mr. Schroder's second big economic reform aimed at reducing the scope of German government. Last year, he managed to push through a sweeping measure to reduce individual and corporate taxes.
For the past three months, the Christian Democrats had managed to block pension reform in the lower house, because they controlled just enough state governments to deprive Mr. Schroder and his coalition partners in the Green Party of a majority in that chamber. But Mr. Schroder succeeded in breaking the logjam by offering extra money to state governments and persuading Christian Democrats in a handful of major states to defy their national party.
Though neither the tax cuts nor the pension reform amount to radical changes, they represent a retreat from the comprehensive social programs and high taxes that have been a hallmark of European government for decades.
Today's vote highlighted the continued weakness of the once mighty Christian Democrats, who had controlled the German government for 16 years under the former chancellor, Helmut Kohl. Mr. Kohl's party, defeated by the Social Democrats in 1996, remains bogged down in a scandal over illegal political contributions that Mr. Kohl apparently collected and distributed through much of his last decade in office.
Even more frustrating for the Christian Democrats is the fact that, five years ago, their own plan for pension reform was blocked by Social Democrats in almost exactly the same manner as Christian Democrats were attempting today. Mr. Schroder broke the blockade by offering to give states an extra one billion marks, or about $440 million, by readjusting the complex division of tax revenue between federal and state governments.
The pension changes approved today are cautious. Tax incentives will be phased in to encourage people to invest money in private retirement accounts, but they will not be allowed to put aside more than 4 percent of their gross pay and this will only take effect gradually over the next six years.
To win support from Germany's powerful labor unions, government officials had to water down their plan for benefit reductions. Retirees will eventually be entitled to 67 percent of their working income, compared with 70 percent today, but they will have ample time to plan ahead: the reduction will not take full effect until 2030.

HEADLINE: An Unlikely Mexican Foreign Minister 

 BODY:
Jorge Castaneda, Mexico's new foreign minister, finds himself upbraided by Cuba and warmly received by the United States these days, a once unthinkable position for a onetime Communist supporter and critic of American foreign policy. But then it is equally improbable that Mr. Castaneda would become one of the main architects of a constructive new partnership between Mexico and the United States. Yet he has done just that, and the two nations are the better for it. 
 The son of another Mexican foreign minister and a graduate of Princeton and the Sorbonne who has taught at a number of American universities, Mr. Castaneda is at home both in Mexico and the United States. In the early 1990's Mr. Castaneda, a political scientist, was one of the most outspoken opponents of the North American Free Trade Agreement. His views by then had become more mainstream and he had renounced his earlier admiration of Fidel Castro, but he remained strongly wary of American intentions. In an influential 1993 book, "Utopia Unarmed," Mr. Castaneda called the idea of a hemispheric free-trade zone a "euphemism for the creation of a U.S. zone of economic influence." 
 Eight years later, as foreign minister, Mr. Castaneda is energetically working with Washington to create such a trading bloc. He is also working to help ease tensions over the drug trade and illegal immigration. 
Mr. Castaneda is not alone in his conversion. The growing economic interdependence brought on by Nafta, the rise in Mexican-American political power in this country and the end of one-party rule in Mexico have changed attitudes on both sides of the Rio Grande. 
To understand Mr. Castaneda's own evolution, it bears noting that he did not oppose Nafta because he felt globalization could be averted. He wrote extensively about the melding of cultures and interests before it became fashionable in Mexico to dwell on the exodus of people across the Rio Grande. He recognized that Mexico and the United States were becoming intertwined, but worried on what terms.
Vicente Fox, Mexico's president, has shared this concern since he ran for governor of the state of Guanajuato in 1995 and attacked the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, for failing to insist on development assistance as part of Nafta. Mr. Castaneda came to know Mr. Fox while trying to forge an alliance between Mr. Fox and the leftist opposition so a single candidate would run against the PRI. 
The effort foundered, but Mr. Castaneda concluded that Mr. Fox was the only viable opposition candidate, and one whose conservative thinking on issues was far more nuanced than he expected. Mr. Castaneda has since served as an influential political adviser to the president, most significantly in helping him develop a long-term vision of a Nafta modeled after the European Union, with its freedom of movement for labor and strong economic development programs. Americans will be seeing a lot of Mr. Castaneda in the months ahead. They should welcome him as a friend.

HEADLINE: Bush Says Tax Cut Is the Quickest Way to Help Consumers With Energy Costs 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the surest and swiftest way to help Americans cope with rising gas and oil prices was to enact a sweeping tax cut, which he said would give them more money to pay for the increases.
 "If I had my way, I'd have it in place tomorrow, so that people would have money in their pockets to deal with high energy prices," Mr. Bush said at news conference in the White House. "The Congress needs to act." 
 Mr. Bush's comments came a day after the Senate, like the House, approved a budget plan that calls for $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years, and Mr. Bush sought to seize that momentum, urging both chambers of Congress to pass the tax cut itself before their Memorial Day recess.
Mr. Bush also sought to link his push for a tax cut to the nation's energy woes more strongly than ever before. He cited those woes as a rationale for a reduction in taxes, and he cited a tax cut as an answer to those woes.
After several weeks in which administration officials had cautioned Americans that there was little if anything that their energy policy, to be unveiled on Thursday, could do to help consumers in the short term, Mr. Bush today pitched his tax cut as, in fact, a ready-made remedy. And he did so at a time of growing worry among Republicans that rising gas and oil prices could seriously damage his presidency.
"Let me say it again, see if I can be more clear," the president said in response to one of many questions about other approaches to dealing with energy problems. "To the Congress, who is interested in helping consumers pay high gas prices: 'Pass the tax relief as quickly as possible.'
"We've set aside $100 billion to help consumers with high energy prices," Mr. Bush continued, referring to a part of the suggested tax cut that would be distributed among taxpayers this year. "That's the quickest way to help consumers. I am deeply concerned about consumers. I'm deeply concerned about high gas prices. To anybody who wants to figure out how to help the consumers, pass the tax relief package as quickly as possible."
Many low-income people, who are least able to afford a steep escalation in the cost of cooling their homes or filling their cars, would receive only modest amounts of money from the tax cut Mr. Bush has proposed. Beyond that, the poorest of these people, who pay no taxes, may not receive any financial relief at all from a tax cut.
But Mr. Bush and his advisers clearly craved an opportunity for the president to appear empathetic and in charge of the situation amid predictions by some analysts that the price of a gallon of gas could reach $3 this summer.
Today's news conference, which was almost 30 minutes long, was the third in the White House the president had held since his inauguration nearly four months ago.
Mr. Bush also wanted to claim victory for the Congressional passage of a budget plan with a tax cut only slightly smaller than the one he initially proposed. And he expressed support for Attorney General John Ashcroft's decision, announced shortly before Mr. Bush spoke, to delay until June 11 the planned execution of Timothy J. McVeigh.
"He is lucky to be an American," Mr. Bush said of Mr. McVeigh. "This is a country that will bend over backwards to make sure that his constitutional rights are guaranteed, as opposed to rushing his fate." 
The president added that the failure of F.B.I. officials to turn over documents to which Mr. McVeigh's defense lawyers were entitled had neither persuaded him that Mr. McVeigh was unjustly convicted nor shaken his faith in the fairness with which the death penalty is meted out. As the governor of Texas, Mr. Bush presided over more than 150 executions in six years.
Asked about the recent expulsion of the United States from the United Nations Human Rights Commission, Mr. Bush grew more animated than usual, his anger evident.
"The decision was an outrageous decision," he said. "To me it undermines the whole credibility of this commission."
Like Mr. Bush's two previous White House news conferences, this one was announced only shortly before it began, and Mr. Bush for a third time eschewed the formal trappings of the East Room for the less formal press briefing room. He seemed determined to maintain a jocular demeanor even about grave subjects, smiling and laughing for a moment before answering a question about a 4-month-old Palestinian baby killed by Israeli fire this week.
The issue he discussed most was energy, as he set the stage for his administration's announcement of its policy, one that will call for the construction of power plants and more oil and gas exploration on federal lands.
Many voters are concerned about the environmental repercussions of such measures, and Mr. Bush sought both to address those concerns and to assert that energy problems were long in the making and would be long in the solving.
"This is a situation that's been developing over the years, and it's going to take a while to correct," Mr. Bush said, presenting himself as the blunt bearer of mixed tidings and later adding, "I'm going to tell the truth when it comes to energy: that we have a serious problem, that we need to do a couple of things."
"We need to be more conservation-minded in America," he said. "But I'm also going to say, as plainly as I can, we won't conserve our way to energy independence. We must also increase supply."
Mr. Bush's discussion of the nation's energy problems in some ways mirrored his evaluations of the economy, in which he has gone out of his way to document that he inherited a troubling situation.
He said today that he hoped an economic recovery would be imminent, but that "there's no question that the minute I got elected, the storm clouds on the horizon were getting nearly directly overhead."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
AT&T Details Breakup Plan, But Valuations Are Unclear
AT&T provided new details of its plan to split into four companies, showing that its money-losing AT&T Broadband business, the smallest of the four operations in terms of revenue, will be saddled with the largest debt load.
 The 401-page filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission provided some new financial details but left unclear some of the most interesting questions for investors in valuing the operations. Page C3. 

Nasdaq Drops 3.8% for the Week
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 21.43 points, or 1 percent, to 2,107.43, as stocks fell on reports of unexpected strength in retail sales and consumer confidence. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 89.13 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,821.31. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 9.51 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,245.67. For the week, the Nasdaq declined 3.8 percent, the S.& P. 500 fell 1.7 percent and the Dow dropped 1.2 percent. C3.

Two Setbacks for British Telecom
A day after British Telecommunications announced bold moves to cut its $43 billion in debt, a regulator permitted the sale of its directory services division but imposed a cut in advertising rates, possibly jeopardizing the sale or reducing the $4.2 billion price. And Moody's Investors Services lowered the company's credit rating by two notches. C2.

Japan Lowers Economic Assessment
The Japanese government lowered its assessment of the economy's health for the fourth consecutive month, citing falling production, bloated inventories, declining prices and weak employment trends. The outlook underscores the significant economic challenges facing Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. C2.

Teligent Layoffs Ahead of Deadline
Teligent laid off 900 workers, almost 40 percent of its work force, ahead of a debt payment deadline next week that requires it to obtain $350 million in financing. Along with the layoffs, the company, a telecommunications concern, is evaluating plans to cut back service in some of its 34 retail markets. C3.

Bush Links Tax Cut to Energy Woes
President Bush said the surest and swiftest way to help Americans cope with rising gas and oil prices was to enact a sweeping tax cut, which he said would give them more money to pay for the increases. The Senate and the House have approved a budget plan that calls for $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years. Mr. Bush sought to link his push for a tax cut to the nation's energy woes more strongly than ever before. A13.

President Bush has filled several senior environment-related jobs in his administration with pro-business advocates. A10.

Nortel to Lose Two Top Executives
Nortel Networks said its chief executive, John Roth, left, would retire next April and that his top lieutenant, Clarence J. Chandran, had resigned because of health reasons. As Nortel searches for Mr. Roth's successor, he will take over Mr. Chandran's chief operating officer duties. Mr. Chandran was on medical leave, recuperating from surgery related to a stabbing in Singapore in 1997. C3.

Fund to Take Over Japanese Resort
Ripplewood Holdings, a private equity fund in New York, said it would take over a financially troubled Japanese resort complex. C2.

HEADLINE: More Tax-Cut Follies 

 BODY:
In the latest chapter of Washington's budget wars, a bipartisan group of senators on the Finance Committee yesterday put forward a tax cut designed to look more fair and digestible than the one advocated by President Bush. Their proposal for $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over 11 years does contain some elements more favorable to lower-income groups than earlier versions. But over all it amounts to another gross abdication of fiscal responsibility. The new tax-cut ideas actually underscore the lack of realism with which Congress has approached budget and tax matters this year. 
 The proposal was offered by Charles Grassley of Iowa and Max Baucus of Montana, the Finance Committee's chairman and ranking Democrat, where there has long been a tradition to approach tax matters in a bipartisan way. It improves the plan put forward by Mr. Bush and the conservative Republicans in the House in several ways. The top income tax rate would be lowered from its current level of 39.6 percent to 36 percent instead of the 33 percent that Mr. Bush wanted. More important, several provisions including a child tax credit and a credit for pension savings would be geared to low- and moderate-income families. 
 But the main problem with the Grassley-Baucus approach is that it would enact huge tax cuts whose cost is disguised because many of them would not take effect until years from now. For example, the measure would defer lowering taxes on the wealthiest taxpayers to 36 percent to 2007. It would gradually modify the estate tax downward for several years but not repeal it until 2011. This backloading disguises the fact that there will be no money to pay for the cuts when the bill falls due. With the Grassley-Baucus compromise, the tax-cut battle enters a new and contentious phase. Thanks to Mr. Bush, it is also a phase of confusion as to the rationale of the tax cut. The president keeps trying to justify an excessive, unaffordable tax cut with new arguments. First he said it was needed to revive the economy, a hollow assertion since most of the tax cut is to take effect years from now. Then he said it was to help Americans pay their credit card debt. Yesterday he said the tax cut would help Americans cope with higher gasoline prices. These are not policy pronouncements. They are desperate rationalizations.
The Senate must serve as a firewall to this nonsense. When the Grassley-Baucus tax cuts come before the full Finance Committee next week, and later before the Senate, reasonable Democrats and Republicans need to take a more rational approach. They should reject squandering the surplus with a tax giveaway to the richest taxpayers that does nothing for the economy. Then they can bring some rationality back to the spending side of the ledger as well. 
Even many of those who supported the budget resolution for the next fiscal year say that when it comes time to pass individual spending bills later in the year, they have no intention of respecting the restrictive spending ceilings they voted for. More money will have to be found for education, health, the environment, energy conservation and public safety than is in the budget that they passed. Once they confront that fact, they should reconsider this lopsided, backloaded and excessive tax cut.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush News Conference on Tax Relief, McVeigh and Energy 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 First, let me begin by talking about how pleased I am that a budget has been agreed upon. And it's now time for the Congress to act quickly. It's time for the Congress to pass meaningful, real tax reform. And I urge them to do so before Memorial Day. 
 The tax relief will be good for our economy. But tax relief is also a very important way to help deal with high energy prices. And so the Congress needs to act. I'm confident if they have the will to do so that they can, that they can get this done before Memorial Day. 
And, secondly, I believe strongly the attorney general made the right decision today. Any time we're preparing to carry out the death penalty we have a solemn obligation to make sure that the case has been handled in full accordance with all the guarantees of our Constitution. The very foundations of our democracy depend on our ability to assure our citizens that in all criminal cases, and especially in the death penalty, defendants have been treated fairly.
This decision is going to create some frustration amongst the people whose lives were destroyed and turned upside down by Mr. McVeigh. But it is very important for our country to make sure that in death penalty cases people are treated fairly.
I'll be glad to answer some questions. . . .

McVeigh Execution

QUESTION -- Attorney General Ashcroft, on the topic you were just talking about, said, "There is no doubt in my mind or anyone's mind about the guilt of Timothy McVeigh." As far as someone who has signed 152 death warrants in Texas, do you agree that there is no doubt that McVeigh is guilty? And, secondly, did Louis Freeh know about these documents when he tendered his resignation?

ANSWER -- Director Freeh never brought this up to me. I found out about this last evening. Now in my conversation with Mr. Freeh when he came and said he was leaving, the subject never came up. Secondly, Mr. McVeigh himself has admitted to the crime. Mr. McVeigh, as I recall, said he did it. And I take him for his word. . . .

Energy

Q. A lot of families are struggling to pay for gasoline at record prices. What can you do to help them in the short term? Will your energy report address that? And do you agree with your energy secretary that OPEC bears some responsibility for these prices?

A. The price of crude oil has got something to do with the price of gasoline but not nearly as much as the fact that we haven't built a refinery in years. What this nation needs to do is to build more refining capacity. And we're prepared to work with the industry to encourage capital development -- capital be deployed to develop more refining capacity. And that may require us to analyze all regulations that discourage development.
But the best way to make sure that people are able to deal with high energy prices is to cut taxes, is to get people more of their own money so they can meet the bills, so they can meet the high energy prices. . . .

Q. Your party in the past has argued in favor of either suspending or rolling back the federal gasoline tax. Will you consider doing either?
And, secondly, what would you say to American families who may pay as much as $3 at the pump this summer, at the same time the oil companies in this country are experiencing and enjoying record profits?

A. What I say is I worry about the fact that hardworking people are paying high prices at the pump. It concerns me a lot. And, therefore, the Congress needs to cut taxes as quickly as possible to give people money to be able to deal with this situation.
I also say we need to build more refining capacity. We need more supply. We need to meet -- meet the increasing demands with better supply. I'm optimistic in the long term, not only will we increase supplies but that our automobiles will become more technologically adept at dealing with the energy situation we have now. In other words, we'll have new types of automobiles. Hybrids. And in the energy plan I'm going to be discussing you'll see some incentives for hybrid automobiles.
But the quickest way to get money in people's pockets to deal with prices is tax relief. . . .

Q. Mr. President, are you really going to let Republicans and Congress go home for the next recess without some kind of other short-term relief? You know the Democrats are after you and the vice president, saying you're a couple of former oilmen protecting the industry. Would you at least support the Republican bill in the House which would ease some emission standards in California?

A. I'll listen to everybody's suggestions. But I want to remind the members of Congress, both Republican and Democrat, who -- all of us are concerned about high energy prices and prices at the gas pump being too high. Let's get the tax relief done and do it quickly. I hope there is no intention to delay. There needs to be money in the pockets of our consumers as quickly as possible. We've got the wherewithal to do so. But as to suggestions, I'm open-minded for any suggestion somebody may have.

Q. What about an emissions

A. I'll look at all options. But the clearest way to get things done quickly is tax relief. Now the American people have got to understand that this is a situation that's going to require some long-term planning to get the situation in hand for -- to have a stable future. There's no such thing as immediate supply. This is a situation that's been developing over the years, and it's going to take a while to correct. The quickest way to help people with their energy bills is tax relief. . . .

Death Penalty

Q. Fifty-one percent of the American people now, according to a recent poll, support a moratorium on executions. And support for the penalty in general has dropped considerably over the past couple of years. Does what happened in the McVeigh case, coupled with the more than 75 people now who've been released from death row when evidence of their actual innocence came to light, does all of that lead you to reflect at all on the fairness and accuracy of the death penalty and the way it's actually administered day to day?

A. Well, I am pleased to be able to report as for the first case that came to my desk at the federal government that our -- my administration has -- is going to take its time to make sure that justice has been administered fairly.

Q. But do you reflect at all on the general accuracy and fairness of the death penalty and the way it actually works day to day?

A. I was the governor of a state that had a death penalty and as far as I was concerned, I reviewed every case and I was confident that every person that had been put to death received full rights and was guilty of the crime charged.

Q. So no second thoughts about the death penalty?

A. Not as far as I'm concerned. So long as the system provides fairness. And today is an example of the system being fair. . . .

Q. Mr. President, there are a number of people, including Senator Leahy who was here today, who are suggesting that there needs to be much tighter oversight of the F.B.I. Aside from the McVeigh matter, there have been a number of things over the years -- the F.B.I. labs, the Hanssen case and a number of other things. Do you believe it's time for a more sweeping look at what is going on at the F.B.I.?

A. There are two looks at what's happening in the F.B.I. One, of course, is the commission that Louis Freeh put together headed by Judge Webster. I'm confident that that commission will take a full look at the proceedings within the F.B.I. as -- in regards to security matters. And secondly, the attorney general is going to be conducting an investigation as to why the documents were not given to Mr. McVeigh's lawyers. And I look forward to seeing what those findings reveal.

China

Q. Mr. President, what is your level of concern about U.S. citizens who are being held in China? And what are you doing for them?

A. We've sent clear signals to the Chinese that we expect our citizens that have been detained and/or citizens who've been detained with U.S. relatives that we expect them to be treated fairly and we'd like for them to have whatever due process the Chinese can offer. We have made our -- we have expressed our concerns.
Now, sometimes they listen, sometimes they don't. Our relations with China are relations that are going to be based upon a consistent message with the Chinese: one, we expect there to be trade and I hope there is trade, but, two, that we expect people to be treated fairly inside that country. And hopefully they'll respond. 

Energy

Q. You're developing closer relations with Nigeria, Mexico and Canada. Could you use your leverage with these countries to have them convince Saudi Arabia to open the spigots and provide more fuel?

A. The reason why we have a problem at the gas pump at this particular moment in history is because we haven't built any refining capacity. When you don't increase supplies of a commodity and demand continues to increase, the price is going to go up. And so our nation must expand refining capacity. And we've got to do that within our hemisphere. It's -- otherwise when you transport refined product from far distances it doesn't meet market tests. So we need more refining capacity.
I am working with Canada and Mexico to increase the supply, particularly of natural gas. We have a serious situation in the State of California, as you're very aware. We've been working with the officials of California to expedite the development of new electric generating capacity. We're also doing our part, as a good citizen, to reduce demand for electricity in peak hours. But the new plants that are being brought along -- being brought onstream in California are going to be driven by natural gas. And we need more natural gas to make sure there's fuel for those plants. 
And so I am working with Mexico and I am working with Canada to try to figure out ways for us to encourage exploration in our own neighborhood. I had a good discussion today with the president of Nigeria, who is talking about increasing their amount of production coming from Nigeria. That is positive news for U.S. consumers. The more supply on the market, the lower -- the less pressure there'll be on price.

Q. Given what's going on with the energy crisis and the difficulties in the economy, can you assure the American people at the start of your term that they'll be better off at the end of it than they are today? And if they're not, should they blame you?

A. Well, I certainly hope they're better off. There's no question that the minute I got elected the storm clouds on the horizon were getting nearly directly overhead. In other words, the economic news started to deteriorate. Now the truth of the matter is the market started to adjust March of last year. In other words, the so-called downturn has been in the making for a while.
I believe with good policy from the Fed, as well as good fiscal policy, that we can recover. That that robust growth we all hope for will come back. I wish I could tell you when. I'm not an economist. But if I were I'd probably say there's a 50 percent chance it would happen soon and 50 percent chance it wouldn't.

Q. And if it doesn't work out, does that mean it's not your fault?

A. Listen, presidents, whether things are good or bad, get the credit or blame. I understand that. But, I'm not really that concerned about standing in polls. I'm doing what I think is the right thing to do. And the right thing to do is to have proposed a tax relief package that is an integral part of a fiscal policy that makes sense. I proposed the plan. I campaigned on the plan. Many of you, the truth be known here, didn't actually think it was going to happen. Now there's a budget in place: $1.25 trillion of tax relief coupled with $100 billion of immediate stimulus. That's now available. If I had my way I'd have it in place tomorrow so that people would have money in their pockets to deal with high energy prices, so people would have money in their pockets to be able to plan for the future.
The Congress needs to act. I'm confident that that will help an economic recovery.

The F.B.I.

Q. Sir, how are the recent controversies in the F.B.I. affecting your search for a new director? And just what kind of person are you looking to head the F.B.I.?

A. Well, we've just started, Bob. I look forward to seeing what the Webster report says. I look forward to hearing what the attorney general says about the reason why Mr. McVeigh's attorneys did not get -- did not see certain documents. And I'm looking for somebody who will do a couple of things: one, enforce the law; two, keep morale high at the agency. Somebody who's a good manager. And somebody who can work with the attorney general and my administration.

Q. What's your timetable?

A. As soon as possible. I'm not sure what that means, though, to be perfectly frank with you. I mean we're beginning to look at different candidates and it's a -- obviously, it's a process that's going to take a while. Director Freeh assured me that the No. 2 person there could do a good job if we took us a while to find a replacement.

Q. Mr. President, some of those who have interviewed Tim McVeigh say that he will actually revel in what happened today, that ----

A. Really?

Q. ---- it'll be a sign of F.B.I. incompetence. What message should he take from this whole episode, in your mind?

A. He should say he's lucky to be in America, is what he ought to say. That this is a country who will bend over backwards to make sure that his constitutional rights are guaranteed. That as opposed to rushing his fate, that the attorney general, with my strong support, said we'd better make sure that all guarantees are fulfilled. Mr. McVeigh is lucky to be in a country like this. It's unfortunate that he would feel like reveling at all after what he supposedly has done.
There's a lot of people's lives he affected in an -- there's a lot of people in Oklahoma City -- I went to the memorial. I got to see the faces of people, the pictures of people whose lives were lost. I talked to relatives who still weep when they think about a relative. This isn't a time to revel. . . .

Q. Mr. President, is your confidence in the F.B.I. undermined by this episode?

A. I'm obviously concerned about an incident where documents have been misplaced. But I withhold judgment until I find out the full facts, to find out what the attorney general's investigation finds out.

Middle East

Q. Mr. President, you would not equate the baby that was killed in retaliatory Israeli fire in the Gaza Strip with a 13- and 14-year-old Jewish boy, one of them a U.S. citizen, who were tied up, beaten to death and mutilated near Tekoa, would you?

A. I was kind of smiling, sounded kind of like an editorial. But the death in the Middle East is abhorrent and our nation weeps when people lose their lives. And what we must do is work hard to break the cycle of violence. It's going to be very difficult for us to be able to bring people to the peace table so long as there's violence. And we'll continue to work to break the cycle of violence.

United Nations

Q. Did you speak to Secretary General Annan this morning about the United Nations vote to kick the U.S. off the Human Rights Commission, and if so, what did you tell him?

A. I did. I told him it was hard for me to envision a human rights commission without the United States on it and Sudan being on it, let me put it that way. We're off and Sudan is on. I'm not so sure -- you know, it sent an awfully, awfully strange signal to the world, it seems like to me. Yes?

Q. Did you or do you believe that some U.S. back dues to the United Nations should be withheld as a result of that vote, as some in Congress ----

A. I do not. I think we had made an agreement with the United Nations, an agreement that had been negotiated in good faith and I think we ought to pay our dues.
Having said that, the decision was an outrageous decision. To me it undermines the whole credibility of this commission, to kick the United States off, one of the great bastions of human rights, and allow Sudan to be on. And I think most reasonable people in the world see it that way. And -- but I did bring up the subject. Thank you for pinning me.

Q. Did he listen?

A. Oh, he listened carefully. . . .

Energy

Q. What would you tell an American citizen who is suspicious that your energy policy is going to benefit the oil industry because of your background and Vice President Cheney's background in the industry?

A. I would tell the American people I'm going to tell the truth when it comes to energy, that we have a serious problem, that we need to do a couple of things. One, we need to encourage the development of technologies to help us conserve. We need to be more conservation-minded in America. But I'm also going to say as plainly as I can, we won't conserve our way to energy independence. We must also increase supply. It's in the consumer's interest that we do so. The more supply there is relative to demand, the less the price will be. And I believe that we can have exploration and sound environmental policy go hand in hand.
The only thing I know to do, sir, is to tell the truth of the way I see it. And we can play like there's not an energy crisis or hope there's not a problem. There is a problem. And there's a problem that's going to confront this nation. And my job as the president is to take the problem on and propose the solutions I think necessary to solve the problem.
And again I repeat, it's a combination of good conservation and an increase in supplies. And I believe we can do both. And so I think most of the American people understand that.

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine; Pg. 79

HEADLINE: CELEBRATION; 
Santa Fe

BYLINE:  By Brad Leithauser; Brad Leithauser's most recent novel is "A Few Corrections" (Knopf).

 BODY:
Spanish settlers arrived in Santa Fe, now the capital of New Mexico, early in the 17th century. The city has flown the flags of Spain, Mexico, the United States, the Confederacy and the United States once more. It's a rich and mingled history, as befits a city that is older than Philadelphia or Boston or New York. And one that is -- in its explosive growth -- newer than they are.

THE MOOD
 Call it gallerification -- the transformation of what had been ordinary houses into galleries selling a diverse array of upscale art. In recent years, there can't be any place in the country where this metamorphosis has been going on more steadily and spiritedly than in Santa Fe. 
 The artwork you're most likely to notice, on first arriving in this rapidly growing but still compact city of roughly 70,000 people, is the eye-catching blue of turquoise jewelry, largely the work of American Indian artisans; you may soon start to wonder whether there are more turquoise necklaces on sale here than necks in the world on which to deposit them. It takes a few hours to begin to understand that the art available in this city has journeyed from all over the world to get here. That this is, for artists and artworks, a place of pilgrimage.
Artist-pilgrims have been searching it out for a long time. D. H. Lawrence and Georgia O'Keeffe are perhaps the most celebrated. His brief life reached an apotheosis here. (He wrote: "I think New Mexico was the greatest experience from the outside world that I have ever had.") Her endless life (or as close to endless as most of us can imagine; she lived to be 98) was largely devoted to the New Mexican landscape -- a devotion that the city of Santa Fe has reciprocated by building the splendid Georgia O'Keeffe Museum, holding the world's largest collection of her work.
For all of its explosive growth in recent years, Santa Fe still has a small-town, even rustic, atmosphere -- an impression enhanced by the snowcapped mountains in the clear-aired distance. As such, Santa Fe is one of those American towns -- like Provincetown, Mass., Key West, Fla., Telluride, Colo. -- that foster the happy fallacy that sizable subpopulations of the nation are professionally involved in the arts. Of all such places, Santa Fe may well be the least raffish. At least in the off-season, it's a town that goes to bed early, showing all the prudent reserve of a city of bankers and claims adjusters. In the historic center, a visitor searches in vain for tawdry traces of the hard-drinking, wild-womanizing, heavy-gambling cowboy town this once must have been. 
The city begins to make more sense once you realize that it has wed a passion for art to the pursuit of New Age spiritualism. If it's a place to shop for oil paintings, it's also a place to buy crystals and tarot cards, to investigate various schools of yoga and massage, to discover new ailments that require innovative new therapies. A city of artists? The chain-smoking, tubercular bohemians of popular imagination? It's as if they've traded in their cigarettes for aromatherapy vials, their wine for Perrier.
Most tourist brochures locate the city's heart in the Palace of the Governors, a k a "the oldest continuously occupied public building in the United States," originally built in 1610. (Santa Fe was founded around 1604, when wandering Spanish explorers, evidently giving up on their heavenly cities of gold, decided to settle for mere earthly beauty.) The low building occupies the north side of the central plaza; its long veranda is reserved for Indian artists selling jewelry, black Pueblo pottery and textiles. The Palace is chock-full of muskets and photographs and pre-Columbian sculpture -- all of it interesting, but for me less compelling than the exhibitions on display at the Museum of International Folk Art. This marvelous collection must be one of the greatest tributes to Anonymous ever constructed. The core of the museum is the Girard Wing, drawn from the collection of the architect and textile designer Alexander Girard. The core of his collection was toys, gathered from all over the world -- puppets and paper dolls and masks and miniature models. There are more than 10,000 objects in all, most of them assembled by artists who, it seems safe to say, were strikingly unsuicidal. The emphasis here is on merriment and mischief, brio and brightness. 

THE FOOD
 I live in Massachusetts, where a waitress once tried to warn me away from a dish she thought I might find too spicy because it had "a lot of cinnamon in it."
Our signature meal, the New England boiled dinner, comes from the Pilgrim days. It was originated by Puritan housewives as a quick, easy, reliable and economical means of eliminating most flavors from the family table. So it made a kind of defiant sense that I resolved, in Santa Fe, to operate on the bold, sinus-clearing principle that no meal should be eaten in which chili peppers didn't play a major and colorful role. 
I vowed to make no exception for breakfast, which you might suppose would have presented a problem but didn't. One day I had huevos rancheros (fried eggs on a corn tortilla, topped with a Christmassy blend of red and green chili sauces), and one day huevos Mexicanos (similar eggs, with a side order of spicy pork) and one day a breakfast burrito (scrambled eggs were in there somewhere, under a laval blanket of red chili sauce) and one day a couple of poached eggs on duck hash, under a jalapeno hollandaise. 
I needn't have worried about any shortage of peppers. They were ubiquitous and conspicuous. Red peppers -- as red a red as Nature has devised -- were gathered into necklacelike, leilike loops, which decorated restaurant walls and the doorways of storefronts. Rendered into plastic, they became refrigerator magnets in the cheaper souvenir shops; turned into glass, they became strings of lights -- just the thing for brightening up a sagging, despondent-looking cactus in the back of a margarita bar.
I came to Santa Fe looking for culinary heat, and found it. What I didn't expect to find, and found in abundance, was delicacy. At the restaurants I liked best -- Geronimo, the Anasazi, Fuego -- I was repeatedly struck by how prettily food was arranged on the plate, how subtly powerful flavors were blended. It made sense, I guess, that a city so devoted to art galleries would regularly turn food presentation into an art form. It was a chicken-or-the-egg situation. Had a penchant for visual art fostered a heightened appreciation of food, or had a heightened appreciation of food eventually led to a taste for all the objets d'art in the galleries along Canyon Road. Of course, the contented diner doesn't much care whether the chicken preceded the egg or vice versa, provided both are tasty. 
In Japan, where I once lived for three years, you constantly had the feeling that a process of culinary experimentation -- the evolution of some wild new "Pacific Rim" or "fusion" cuisine -- was occurring right before your eyes. So you accepted the occasional spectacular failure (the sweet pancake sandwich, the maraschino-cherry-topped pizza, the sugared omelet) as setbacks in a noble cause. In Santa Fe, likewise, you feel that serious chefs (who tend to be inveterate matchmakers) are busily setting out to marry off different cuisines: Spanish, Mexican, hints of Japanese and French -- while paying their respects to local produce and cooking. There's an on-the-range feeling to some of the meat available on the best menus (rabbit, duck, venison) and some of the accompaniments (Navajo flat bread, root vegetable ragout).
Admittedly, much of what has come to seem local to Santa Fe isn't really so. The limes in the ever-present margaritas, the rice in the staple beans-and-rice, the avocados in the guacamole -- none of these grow in the city's often frosty environs, nearly 7,000 feet above sea level. But it seems that all serious cuisines, however local in heart, are exotic in fact. Take a couple of specialties of the Geronimo restaurant, for example: grilled lobster with candied habanero peppers and tiny greens, or roasted veal tenderloin stuffed with sweet red chilies and foie gras. 
My personal pursuit of peppers came to a close when I discovered a menu that offered pumpkin-and-chili-pepper ice cream. I decided -- perhaps unwisely -- to pass that one up. Dessert? the waitress asked me. No thanks, I said. Just some coffee. Black. And a glass of water.

THE STYLE
To drive from Albuquerque into the historical heart of Santa Fe is to undergo an act of visual purification. The billboards melt away as you approach town -- they are restricted, I suppose -- and, as you get closer still, most of the garish colors dissolve into shades of brown. In the historic district, the palette is restricted by city ordinance to earth colors: terra cotta and maize, coffee and caramel, brick and mud. As the eye adjusts, the range of colors actually begins to seem quite broad, but never so variegated that you lose sight of a common parentage -- as though the whole town were ultimately sprung from adobe, or, back farther still, from the surrounding gold-brown mountains, in which, long before the Europeans arrived, the cliff dwellers made their hollowed-out homes. Human beings are rarely more ingenious than when devising spectacular ways to showcase their wealth, but the people of Santa Fe have banned many of the more ludicrous forms of ostentation. Dwellings in the historic district must conform to the city's architectural heritage. You won't find the hulking faux-Tudor manor, the elaborate faux-Italian villa, the gargantuan faux-antebellum Southern mansion. There's plenty of money here -- real estate prices have soared with the city's expansion -- but most of it is secreted away behind dun walls, low and unimposing facades. Even the chain stores have done a mostly successful job of blending into the architecture. Walking around Santa Fe on a sunny afternoon, you might almost succumb to the happy, restorative illusion that McDonald's, the Gap and Starbucks are not colossal, competition-swallowing international chains, but local concerns. I don't know if I've ever seen another town where the one-of-a-kind and the corporate franchise are so well blended. 
Or you might say that Santa Fe is a place where most of the incongruities are apt to be human rather than architectural. On a recent visit in March, with the sun out and temperatures in the 50's, I saw people dressed in hats and down jackets and others dressed in shorts. I also saw people dressed in down jackets and shorts -- seemingly a case of the upper torso not knowing what the lower torso was doing (perhaps not all that uncommon a condition). You enter a fancy bar and spot somebody wearing what formerly would have been considered work clothes -- boots, blue jeans, denim shirt and cowboy hat -- who is sipping an $11 glass of chardonnay. Not five minutes later, you step outside and spot a family who have clearly come from far away. A little boy is tugging resentfully on his father's arm. "But where are the cowboys?" he is asking with near-tearful indignation. And what you want to tell the boy is, "The cowboy's in that bar over there, drinking French wine and eating escargots." Actually, by drinking wine the cowboy may have been helping out with the water shortage. The town has grown too fast for available water reserves, precipitation has been down the last few years, the Santa Fe River looks less like a river than the runoff after somebody has washed his car, and meanwhile water-guzzling golf courses are going up in the desert. There's a faint sense of imperilment (a hint of wells and throats gone dry) in the city's prosperity -- as there is in cities lying on geological fault lines or on hurricane-visited coastlines. This is one of those places where the earth preaches a steady humility. 
"There may be trouble ahead," Irving Berlin advised us, and added, "Let's face the music and dance," which is what was going on the night I visited El Farol, a bar and restaurant that offers flamenco dancing and guitar. I sat beside a vast wall painting in which a grinning skeleton was doing a lusty pas de deux with a serpent-haired woman in a red dress. In my job as an English professor I often hear about Southern Gothic -- that world of the grotesque and bizarre brought so vividly to life by William Faulkner and Flannery O'Connor -- but here was a reminder that Southern Gothic pales beside South-of-the-Border Gothic, with its annual Day of the Dead festivities, its skull-and-bones cakes and candies.
I left El Farol with guitar music thrumming pleasantly in my head. More pleasant still, it had begun to rain on this thirsty, thriving city. It had to be a heaven-sent message. This year, again, flowers would bloom in the desert.

HEADLINE: Making Ends Meet 

BYLINE:  By Dorothy Gallagher; Dorothy Gallagher's most recent book is "How I Came Into My Inheritance: And Other True Stories."

 BODY:
 NICKEL AND DIMED
On (Not) Getting By in America.
By Barbara Ehrenreich.
221 pp. New York:
Metropolitan Books/
Henry Holt & Company. $23.
 In the good times of 1998, with the clock on welfare benefits running out, Barbara Ehrenreich had a question: How, she wondered, would the four million women (most with children) soon to be pushed off the rolls and into the labor market make their way on wages of $6 or $7 an hour -- an amount that it was universally agreed was not a living wage? 
Ehrenreich, who has a dozen books behind her dealing with the social and political hallmarks of our economic system, has here, with "Nickel and Dimed," followed in an honored journalistic tradition and written a valuable and illuminating book. Presenting herself as an unskilled worker, a homemaker needing to earn a living after divorce, she entered the low end of the labor market and spent one month in each of three different sections of the country. She looked for the best-paying unskilled job she could get, and hoped to earn enough money at it to pay her rent for a second month. "So," she writes, "this is not a story of some death-defying 'undercover' adventure. Almost anyone could do what I did -- look for jobs, work those jobs, try to make ends meet. In fact, millions of Americans do it every day, and with a lot less fanfare and dithering." 
Ehrenreich's first stop was her hometown of Key West. She figured that with a $7-an-hour job, and a place to rent costing no more than $500 a month, she would have $400 to $500 a month remaining to spend for food and gas. There were lots of want ads for service jobs in this resort area. Ehrenreich filled out about 20 applications for jobs at supermarkets and hotels. No one called her. So her first revelation was that the vaunted abundance of ads is not a reliable measure of available jobs but serves employers as an insurance policy against the high turnover in the low-wage work force. 
Ehrenreich finally got a job as a waitress at an inexpensive family restaurant. Her shift ran from 2 p.m. to 10 p.m. Salary: $2.43 an hour plus tips. To find an affordable rent she had to move 30 miles out of town, a 45-minute commute on a crowded two-lane highway. How did her co-workers manage housing? One waitress shared a room in a $250-a-week flophouse; a cook shared a two-room apartment with three others; another worker lived in a van parked behind a shopping center.
"There are no secret economies that nourish the poor," Ehrenreich writes. "On the contrary there are a host of special costs. If you can't put up the two months' rent you need to secure an apartment, you end up paying through the nose for a room by the week. If you have only a room, with a hot plate at best, you can't save by cooking up huge lentil stews that can be frozen for the week ahead. You eat fast food or the hot dogs and Styrofoam cups of soup that can be microwaved at a convenience store." Without health insurance you risk a small cut becoming infected because you can afford neither a visit to the doctor nor antibiotics. 
In the summer tourist slump, Ehrenreich found that her income -- salary plus tips -- dropped from about $7 an hour to $5.15. At that rate the only way to pay her rent was to get a second job. So for a while she worked an 8 a.m.-to-2 p.m. shift at a second restaurant, then rushed to her regular shift at the first -- a 14-hour day of brutal physical work, as anyone who has waitressed for a living knows. With such a schedule she could not, of course, keep her decent housing so far from town. Ehrenreich's new home was an eight-foot-wide trailer parked among others in "a nest of crime and crack" where "desolation rules night and day. . . . There are not exactly people here but what amounts to canned labor, being preserved between shifts from the heat."
So much for waitressing in Florida. On to Maine and scrubbing floors. Despite plentiful ads for jobs, Portland turned out to be "just another $6-$7-an-hour town." Ehrenreich again took two jobs to make ends meet -- a weekend job in the Alzheimer's ward of a nursing home and a full-time job with a housecleaning service. 
At the Merry Maids, the economics were as follows: the customer pays $25 an hour per cleaning person to the service; the service pays $6.65 an hour to each cleaner. "How poor are they, my co-workers?" Ehrenreich asks. Half bags of corn chips for lunch; dizziness from malnutrition; an impacted wisdom tooth requiring frantic calls to find a free dental clinic; worries about makeshift child-care arrangements because a licensed day care center at $90 a week is beyond any cleaner's budget; no actual homelessness, no one sleeping in a car, but everyone crowded into housing with far too many others, family and strangers: signs "of real difficulty if not actual misery." 
And soon, even with two jobs and no children to support, Ehrenreich starts having money trouble. Housing is the killer. She foresees a weekend without food unless she can find charitable help. More than an hour on the phone with various charitable agencies (cost of calls, $2.80) nets her a severely restricted food voucher -- no fresh fruits or vegetables, chicken or cheese -- worth $7.02.
Minneapolis is Ehrenreich's last stop. In this city, as in the other two, finding affordable housing was a major problem. Across the nation the supply of apartments for low-income families is decreasing: 36 units available for every 100 families in need. Like many of the poor, Ehrenreich is reduced to an overpriced motel, more like a flophouse in terms of cleanliness and safety. Borderline homelessness is how she describes it. The old rule that one should pay no more than 30 percent of income for rent has become inoperative; for most poor renters, the figure is now more than 50 percent.
In the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, where the "living wage" for a single parent and one child was calculated to be $11.77 an hour, Ehrenreich has a job at Wal-Mart paying $7 an hour. Many of her fellow workers, even those with working spouses, hold two jobs. 
In this way three months went by, and Ehrenreich's investigation was finished. What does she conclude? No surprises here. Even for a worker holding two jobs, wages are too low, housing costs too high for minimally decent survival. "In the rhetorical buildup to welfare reform, it was uniformly assumed that a job was the ticket out of poverty and that the only thing holding back welfare recipients was their reluctance to get out and get one." But if a living wage for one adult and two children is, according to the Economic Policy Institute, $30,000 a year, a total calculated to include no luxuries unless health insurance and licensed child care are considered luxuries, this amount will never be provided by the private sector to entry-level workers. 
"Most civilized nations," Ehrenreich writes, "compensate for the inadequacy of wages by providing relatively generous public services such as health insurance, free or subsidized child care, subsidized housing and effective public transportation." So what should we think about the fact that in America we are sending the poor out to make it on their own on little more than a quarter of a living wage? Shame, Ehrenreich suggests, might be an appropriate response.
Ehrenreich's picture of the working poor was taken during the best of times. Yet the comforting economic cliches offered by our pundits failed even under those boom conditions: a rising tide does not lift all boats; trickledown economics stops just south of the middle class. So much for tall theories. Now we have entered a downward slide, with all economic indicators pointing to the toilet.
We have Barbara Ehrenreich to thank for bringing us the news of America's working poor so clearly and directly, and conveying with it a deep moral outrage and a finely textured sense of lives as lived. As Michael Harrington was, she is now our premier reporter of the underside of capitalism.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Mont Blanc Tunnel To Reopen, Carefully

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
BY September, the French and Italian governments plan to reopen the tunnel that pierces soaring Mont Blanc and connects France and Italy, two and a half years after a refrigerator truck burst into flames inside, setting off a conflagration that left 39 people dead.
 But the plan is running into a wall of opposition, especially on the French side, from an alliance of environmentalists concerned about the effects of truck traffic on Alpine landscapes and political leaders who argue that the tunnel traffic lowers the quality of life in their villages and harms the beauty that lies at the heart of the tourism industry nurturing their constituencies. 
 The decision to reopen the seven-mile tunnel, a favorite of tourists driving the Alpine routes from France and Switzerland to northern Italy, was largely the result of a compromise struck between the French and Italian governments at a recent summit. France agreed to press ahead with renovation work on its side of the tunnel in order to extract a commitment from Italy to support an ambitious project to dig a rail tunnel to connect Lyon in southeast-central France with Turin in northern Italy. Work is now progressing apace to complete restoration of the Mont Blanc tunnel, which was opened to traffic in 1965, and to introduce new safety features that will include enlarged refuge areas in the tunnel, improved warning systems and fewer trucks. 
The motivation for the governments to reopen the tunnel is clear: as Europe integrates its economies, the Alps have the effrontery to lie smack between several of the Continent's most economically dynamic regions, in northern Italy and southern France and Germany.
What complicates matters is that Europe, while a showcase for fast and comfortable passenger train service, limps far behind other industrial regions in handling rail freight. By the late 1990's, while rail's share of total freight movement in the United States was 41 percent, thanks to computerized systems and new technologies like intermodal transport that move containers by road and rail, in Europe it hovered at about 16 percent. And the trucks needed to make up the difference are the bane of tourists driving European highways.
By 1998, the most recent year for which full statistics are available, more than 160 million metric tons of freight crossed the Alps, two-thirds of it by truck. According to European Union projections, that traffic, barring dramatic change, will increase by 75 percent over the next 15 years. In 1998, 800,000 of the 2 million vehicles that used the Mont Blanc tunnel were trucks, hauling 13 million metric tons of goods -- French machinery for northern Italian factories, Italian clothing for French and German stores. 
To tackle this problem, European government leaders and railway planners are breaking up the old inefficient state rail monopolies and introducing new rail freight technology. In recent years, big new rail freight shuttles, hauling hundreds of truck-size containers, travel regularly between cities like Milan and Verona in northern Italy and northern European ports like Rotterdam and Hamburg. And they are trying to make the Alps more porous.
Indeed, the agreement by France and Italy to tunnel under the Alps in southeastern France, known as the Mont Cenis project for the mountain it will pierce with a 32 mile long tunnel, is only one of several major rail tunnel projects for the Alps that are in various stages of planning. Austria and Italy have been studying the possibility of drilling a 33-mile railway tunnel under the lofty Brenner Pass on Austria's frontier with Italy; in 1995, Switzerland approved the digging of two railway tunnels under the Alps, through the Gotthard and Lotschberg massifs, at a total cost of roughly $12 billion.
The idea is clear: by shifting freight from trucks to rail, European industry can relieve Alpine passages, like the Mont Blanc tunnel, which will then be able to accommodate passenger car traffic more easily and more safely. But the reality is trickier. The immense costs of the proposed tunnels make it hard for governments to raise the construction money needed. Moreover, environmental groups, arguing that rail tunnels will drag even more industrial traffic into the Alps, have been largely opposed. Then too, even when projects are approved, years pass before they are completed. The Mont Cenis tunnel, for instance, connecting southeastern France and northwestern Italy, is not expected to be operating before 2015.
All of this, of course, makes little impression on people in Alpine towns, like Chamonix on the French side, who discovered after the closing of the Mont Blanc tunnel just how peaceful life could be without the trucks. City officials there, who have always protested the heavy truck traffic, say they will seek court orders to block the tunnel's reopening, arguing that the tunnel is still vulnerable to disastrous fires without adequate means of evacuation.
Few give the court suits much chance of success, but local leaders remain adamant. 
"People around here don't want the trucks -- period," said Michel Charlet, the mayor of Chamonix. Xavier Chappaz, who heads an association of mountain guides in the Mont Blanc region, recently suggested, only half facetiously, that the tunnel could be reopened as a symbol of European unity, but only for pedestrians -- and maybe Rollerbladers.
