HEADLINE: SUMMER FILMS/BACK TO THE FUTURE; 
New Apes, New Planet, Old Story: Simians Still Rule

BYLINE:  By BILL DESOWITZ; Bill Desowitz's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the cinematographer Jack Cardiff.

 BODY:
WHEN "Planet of the Apes" first crash-landed in movie theaters in 1968, it was more than a popcorn picture or a sci-fi flick. Exploring such hot-button issues as civil rights, racial violence, the Cold War and Vietnam, it embodied the turbulence of the time -- a blunt reminder that in terms of "human" relations, we still had a lot of progress to make.
 It was light-years from that other 1968 landmark about evolution and exploration, "2001: A Space Odyssey." Where Stanley Kubrick's psychedelic mind trip reached for infinity and beyond with the grace of, well, "The Blue Danube," Franklin Schaffner's simian saga about an upside-down world where apes dominated humans aimed for the gut, with social satire and political allegory and the eerie punch of "The Twilight Zone." 
 But like "2001," "Planet of the Apes" struck a chord. At a time when science fiction barely had a box office pulse, it did blockbuster business ($32.5 million, or about $100 million when adjusted for inflation) and became a lucrative franchise for 20th Century Fox, spawning four sequels and two television series well into the mid-70's. "Planet of the Apes" proved that the genre could successfully engage filmgoers in a critique of American society and make them take a hard look at man's inhumanity to man and nature. 
And it did so in daring fashion, with the startling image of a half-naked and mute Charlton Heston being led around on a leash by a bunch of talking gorillas. This was no ordinary man they were ape-handling. This was Moses and Michelangelo and Ben-Hur. This was America's heroic icon of the 50's and 60's. If he couldn't free humanity and lead us to the Promised Land (or at least the film's Forbidden Zone), then nobody could.
Sure enough, when he finally regained his strength and voice midway through the film and shouted, "Get your stinking paws off me, you damn, dirty ape!" it was the rallying cry everyone was waiting for, including the compassionate chimpanzee, Zira, played by Kim Hunter. Now Mr. Heston was ready to stand up to Maurice Evans's holier-than-thou orangutan, Dr. Zaius, "the defender of the faith" and keeper of the terrible dark secret that eventually shocked all of us: that the planet of the apes was none other than our own Earth in the distant future, after a nuclear war had toppled us from the pinnacle of evolutionary development.
Among the many moviegoers who fell under the spell of the original "Planet of the Apes" was the adolescent Tim Burton. For one thing, Mr. Heston terrified him because of his intensity. For another, the premise was so weird and fascinating and absurd. When Mr. Burton was offered the chance to direct a new version of the film a couple of years ago, after Fox had spent 10 years, on and off, trying to develop the project with other directors (Oliver Stone, James Cameron and Chris Columbus among them), part of him wanted to turn it down. At the same time, Mr. Burton couldn't resist revisiting and reinventing the myth of humans and apes reversing roles. He accepted the assignment.
So how do you compete with a cult classic that has been spoofed twice on "The Simpsons"? We'll soon find out, because Mr. Burton's new version of "Planet of the Apes" opens on July 27.
One thing's for certain: Mr. Burton's "reimagining" will have little to do with the original. No Taylor, no Zira, no Zaius, no Cornelius (played by Roddy McDowell, the eventual star of the series) and no apocalyptic ending with Mr. Heston pounding his fists in the sand before a half-sunken Statue of Liberty. For that, at least, we can be thankful, because "Planet of the Apes" was a film uniquely tied to its time and wouldn't translate well into a conventional remake. Times have changed, movies have changed and audiences have changed.
In fact, the new film is closer in setting and philosophy to the original film's source, Pierre Boulle's novel "Monkey Planet," whose theme was less about humanity's misuse of technology than about its propensity for stagnation. In other words, humans could eventually be overtaken by another intelligent species. But it still came down to simians behaving more like Homo sapiens than humans do. Readers could see themselves in these talking apes, which is probably why the original film's producer, Arthur P. Jacobs, was so passionate about making it.
After being rejected by nearly every Hollywood studio throughout the 60's, he finally found a receptive ear in Richard Zanuck, who was then head of production at Fox. But Mr. Zanuck, like the other studio executives, feared that the sight of talking apes would generate howls of laughter from audiences. So he suggested that Mr. Jacobs film a five-minute screen test (at a cost of $5,000) to see if the initial ape makeup was convincing. It was, in a primitive sort of way.
But the apes in the new film hardly resemble their predecessors. Technological advances in makeup design have allowed Rick Baker to go way beyond John Chambers's ground-breaking, Oscar-winning work in the original film. Mr. Baker's creatures look and act more like real apes. They are faster, quicker and more powerful. And they run, jump and attack ferociously. They even move their mouths more freely. Yes, they still speak English and treat humans like animals, but this is a whole new adventure on a whole new planet. In fact, it's not Earth at all, but a parallel world that's darker and more primeval, with lush forests, treacherous jungles and Cubist-inspired architecture.
It is, in other words, a Tim Burton film. Mr. Burton, the director of "Edward Scissorhands," "Batman," "Ed Wood" and "Sleepy Hollow," is an old hand at bizarre reversals and the blurring of primitive and civilized behavior. "It's about apes and humans creating a new behavior," he said by telephone during a break from editing. "It's about how we perceive ourselves and how we perceive apes. They terrify us because they are so close to us and so far away."
Mr. Zanuck was seduced by the apes all over again. This time, he is the producer. When Fox came calling, he said, he couldn't resist, especially since it was an opportunity to work with Mr. Burton. "I always felt that that world set up in the original picture was left open for revisiting," Mr. Zanuck said by telephone. "In fact, several years ago, I inquired at Fox about making a new version, but they said it wasn't the right time."
The new film, with a script written by William Broyles Jr. and revised by Lawrence Konner and Mark D. Rosenthal, is like the ultimate episode of "Survivor." Humans on this side, apes on that side; may the best team win. The plot turns on an experimental space mission in 2029, as humans and genetically altered apes get lost in an electromagnetic storm. Mark Wahlberg plays the pilot who crash-lands on the planet of the apes, where he meets a chimpanzee human-rights activist played by Helena Bonham Carter.
AS you might expect in the age of can't-we-all-get-along, this ape world is more socially and professionally integrated, with less animosity among the species. The chimpanzees, however, clearly rule the planet, which would have delighted Zira and Cornelius (except for their mistreatment of humans, of course). The tyrannical chimpanzee general played by Tim Roth breaks all of the usual stereotypes associated with chimps. Volatile, unpredictable and lonely, he would have been a gorilla in the original film.
Credit Mr. Burton, who made his own study of ape behavior in preparing the film. "Part of the reason they have survived so long is that they are so strong," Mr. Burton said. "And the chimps aren't what you think at all. They can be scary. They may smile at you and look cute, but there is darker behavior beneath the surface."
In Mr. Burton's film, apes are a lot more cunning than civilized. And on this planet, where humans and apes compete in the wild, guess which species is more adaptable, more evolved? At least the indigenous humans can talk in this version, though instead of caged beasts they are now slaves and pets. 
What a time warp it has been for the 66-year-old Mr. Zanuck, who found himself on location again in Lake Powell, Ariz., where parts of the original film were shot. Only this time he won't need an approving preview audience in Phoenix to convince him that "Planet of the Apes" really works.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
When Ego Crushes All Before It

BYLINE:  By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
WITH so many people talking about what American orchestras should look for in a music director, please note the fortuitous arrival of recorded material from Sergiu Celibidache. It tells us what we might try to avoid.
 The job in this country is famous for its multitasking: upholder of tradition, forger of the future, manager of fractious work forces, stage actor, glad-hander, fund-raiser. We have bright young men who make good music and interest musicians but who exhibit the stage presence of gym teachers. Then we have the Celibidaches, who cast their heavy spell on the musical public but who, on closer examination, evanesce into negligibility. 
 Celibidache (pronounced cheh-lee-bee-DAH-keh), played the theater of self-effacement to grandiose effect. He acted like no other musical actor before him. And no conductor contradicted loudly stated personal principles with more sublime presumption.
The packaging of a new boxed set from Deutsche Grammophon tells us most of what we need to know: "Celibidache" in large letters at the top; "Dvorak, Sibelius, Franck, Hindemith, Richard Strauss, Shostakovich" in significantly smaller type. At the bottom of the box's back cover in three languages: "The Celibidache Edition: The Recording Legacy of a Musical Genius."
Clearly this is the trickle-down theory of economics transferred to music. Heap riches of attention on the conductor's throne, and they will gradually descend on composers. Here was a man of enormous gifts pretty much destroyed by the monstrousness of his ego. Conducting offers enticements in that direction, but most practitioners have the sense of when to draw back.
Celibidache publicly rejected recorded performances, yet his recorded performances are everywhere. The nine CD's in that set and in another, devoted to Mozart and Bruckner, are by the Swedish Radio Symphony and the Stuttgart Radio Symphony: standard repertory pieces from concerts played some 20 to 30 years ago. The conductor, who died in 1996, once said that hearing electronically a concert that had already happened was like "sleeping with a picture of Marilyn Monroe." Yet these events took place with full knowledge that they would be transcribed and broadcast.
It was not the first time that Celibidachian word and deed had collided. Once, a reporter, suspicious of Celibidache's laments and regrets over a 1983 videotaping, went to the program's producers, who made clear that the conductor had meticulously and enthusiastically cooperated with all the retakes and lighting adjustments required.
Make no mistake. This was a man who could work wonders with second-class, or young and impressionable, orchestras. People still talk of his concerts with the Curtis Institute in the mid-1980's. The Swedish and German players perform on a relatively high level here.
Celibidache began conducting at the top, falling more or less into the top post at the Berlin Philharmonic, which he shared with Wilhelm Furtwangler from 1947 to 1952. His prosperity seems not to have suffered under the Nazis during the war years, but let us move on from that.
As Celibidache's career progressed, major orchestras had less and less to do with him. Deutsche Grammophon gives us an unintentional clue by including a recorded rehearsal in which the great man belabors a single phrase from Bruckner's Fifth Symphony for 17 minutes. Professional players despise conductors who talk, and one cannot picture any top orchestra in Britain or America putting up with the kind of bloviation exhibited here.
CELIBIDACHE'S frequent requests for 20 rehearsals might have had a ring of authenticity when he was dealing with semicompetent musicians. But 20 for the best professionals? Most great interpreters let performances happen as much as they impose their will on them.
The performances here are heavy with import. Mozart's "Haffner" Symphony opts for (and achieves) excitement over all else. The Stuttgart players are pushed to the wall by fast tempos, but there are listeners who will revel in the excitement. The opening tempo in Franck's Symphony takes "Lento" to its extreme, but it is very effectively done by the Swedish orchestra. The second movement's "Allegretto" is slowed almost to a funeral march. The finale, marked "Allegro non troppo," is off to the races.
Foremost in the listener's ear is the conductor. Celibidache claimed to be a servant of the composer's intentions, but he acts more like a decision maker working from compositorial suggestions. His portentous approach is not out of character in Sibelius's Second Symphony or in Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler," which here has a sense of leisure too often lost in current car-chase aesthetics.
Other items include Sibelius's Fifth, Shostakovich's Ninth and Bruckner's Third, Fourth and Fifth Symphonies, and Strauss's "Till Eugenspiegel" and "Don Juan." Celibidache's range, perhaps like that of his coterie of devotees, is not wide. When listeners know the notes by heart, it frees them to concentrate on crucial matters -- like conducting.
There are added issues running through these performances that go beyond good and bad interpretation: namely, not enough interpretation or, more often, too much. The present version of Dvorak's B minor Cello Concerto raises such questions. Jacqueline du Pre plays the solos with heart-stopping intensity and clean musical values, but add in Celibidache's oppressiveness, and what we hear is Dvorak's songful, lyrical, altogether lovely concerto crushed under the weight of its interpreters. Musicians who truly love music get out of its way.
Mr. Celibidache had a lifetime contract as music director of the Munich Philharmonic, and his work as an orchestra builder is recorded there in the near shambles he left behind for his successor, James Levine. American orchestras beware.

HEADLINE: BACKSLASH; 
Survivor: The New Economy

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL; Matt Richtel reports on technology for The Times. His column about living and working in the technology maelstrom appears the second Sunday of each month. E-mail: mrichtel@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
REALITY-BASED television shows are heavy with sexual themes and romance, with the action often set against exotic backdrops. It's captivating stuff, no doubt, but the formula is growing a bit tired.
 In order for reality TV to thrive, it needs new material, inspired by action found closer to home, and in a world filled with the elements of great television -- big money, power struggles and heated intellectual property disputes. 
 Yes, this is reality TV drawn from Silicon Valley. Real shows about real people, all watching their stocks tank. The lineup might look something like this:

TECH SUPPORT ISLAND -- On a tiny island, a man finds himself stranded with a laptop computer and an ample power supply. To walk away with a cool $1 million, all he has to do is install a new software upgrade. Fortunately, a crack seven-member technical support staff is marooned with him.
The man needs only to get the support staff's attention and to enlist its help in installing the software. Following is a sample of dialogue from the season opener. 
Man: "Excuse me, can I get some help with this upgrade?" 
Tech support staff member: "For technical assistance, press 1." 
Man: "Press 1? On what? You're standing in front of me!" 
Tech support staff member: "I'm going on break." 

REBOOT CAMP -- Eight people in their 50's try to log on to the Internet while their drill instructor, a tech-wise 10-year-old, yells at them. ("It's an internal modem, maggot! Now drop and give me 20!")

VIRTUAL REAL WORLD -- Silicon Valley's answer to MTV's "Real World" chronicles the daily adventures of six young people living under one roof in Palo Alto, Calif. The twist is that the residents are all electrical engineers. The fast-paced action centers on 20-somethings dealing with growing up, romance and taut, sexually charged discussions of the alternative minimum tax.
A synopsis of the first week: Noel calls a house meeting after someone spills a juice shake on his algorithm. Annie and Rick argue over the value of "X." Jay wants to use the garage for a keg party, but Andy wants to use it for a start-up. 

THE WALKER -- A team of nine strangers is assembled to track down one man. That man has been set down on one coast and is trying to cross the country, undetected. He is Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. The team is equipped with cellular phones, radio-tracking devices and the Consumer Price Index.
If Mr. Greenspan is not found, he wins a season-long reprieve from public scrutiny. If he is found, the team splits $1 million in Treasury bills, while Mr. Greenspan must announce a lowering of interest rates on national television and read excerpts from his diary. 

ULTIMATE POWER STRUGGLE -- Twelve Californians are locked in an opulent Silicon Valley mansion. At their disposal are the latest technology gadgets -- so advanced that they surpass anything at NASA's disposal. There are ultrafast computers, an electric toothbrush that doubles as a global positioning system, and a microwave oven that can receive e-mail messages. There is one catch: they have no electricity. The object is for the participants to figure out how to feed themselves, communicate with the outside world and elect a legislature with a clue.

CHAINS OF ANGST -- A die-hard user of a Macintosh and a die-hard user of a Windows-based PC are chained together. The room is empty except for two computers, one of each variety, at opposite ends. Each player must use his wile, zeal and muscle to drag his opponent to the computer with the preferred operating system. The winner is the first to log on. Nothing is at stake, but the winner can be completely secure in the notion that he has no life.
Next season: a 12-year-old video-game enthusiast is chained together with someone addicted to chocolate. 

LOW-COST-OVERSEAS-LABOR ISLAND -- Thousands of indigenous laborers, vying for H-1B visas to come to the United States, work in factories that make computer goods for distribution around the world. The big American companies that employ these contract workers do not pay benefits and provide wages far beneath the wages available in the United States. Shot on location in Taiwan.

MULTITASKING SURVIVOR -- Fifteen people race around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. As they drive, they must talk on cell phones and place day trades constantly. The object is to make the most money in the stock market while making the fewest number of pit stops (during which tires are changed, gas is replenished and hands-free headsets are returned for ones that actually work). All the cars are sport utility vehicles.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Englewood Seeks to Transform an Industrial Zone

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD 

 BODY:
TUCKED in the far southwestern corner of this Bergen County community are 60 acres occupied by gas stations and businesses operating in low-slung distribution centers, factories and warehouses dating to the 1930's and 40's.
 The area is bounded by Route 4, Interstate 95 and the 147-acre Overpeck county golf course. And it is just two miles from the George Washington Bridge. 
 Hoping to capitalize on this location, Englewood officials declared two years ago that the site, just south of Route 4, was an area in need of redevelopment, with the goal of reshaping it into a new mixed-use neighborhood for their city of 30,000. Last month local leaders signed a letter of agreement with S. Hekemian Kasparian Troast L.L.C., a development company in Paramus, to help realize that goal. 
Envisioned is a $500 million plan, which still must secure all local and state approvals. It calls for 1.2 million square feet of offices in two 12-story buildings; two lodgings, one a full-service hotel with 300 rooms, the other an extended-stay hotel with 150 rooms; 346 rentals in eight four-story structures; and 142 condominium town houses. There would also be 90,000 square feet of retail space, 12 acres of open space and perhaps even a trolley station and light rail stop.
Under the plan, developed by LDR International Inc., an urban design firm in Columbia, Md., which also designed the Inner Harbor of Baltimore, the project would take shape in phases on the site from which the 30 property owners must be relocated. The area must also be examined for environmental considerations like wetlands and contaminants, which ultimately must be cleaned.
The pace of the development will depend on market conditions and demand, said Michael N. Kasparian, president of the development company. He said construction could begin by 2003, and the city is requiring that his company start 400,000 square feet of commercial space by 2004.
"Redevelopment is the future for many New Jersey communities," he said.
Englewood is among a growing list of municipalities with plans to reinvent large parts of their community; another is Harrison, with a $4 billion plan to reshape 275 acres of its Passaic River waterfront. But while most current plans deal with waterside properties, Englewood's 60-acre site is considered the largest inland redevelopment project in the state. It is also part of a larger redevelopment zone in the city, which includes nearly 100 more industrial acres on the north side of Route 4.
Such plans reflect the tenets of "smart growth" promoted by the state development and redevelopment plan, which steers growth to where roads and utilities exist and away from where they are missing. For most communities the goal is the same: bolster the economic base without impairing residents' quality of life. 
That is the case in Englewood where Mayor Paul T. Fader said homeowners bear the brunt of the tax burden. "To shift that burden, we need to increase the revenue from commercial and industrial properties," he said, adding that the 60-acre site "is underutilized."
And its redevelopment would be carried out without providing the developers tax abatements, added Douglas Bern, a City Council member.
Most residents welcome the promise of tax relief, but are wary of potential side effects, particularly traffic. Some businesses that would be relocated also have worries, including finding comparable properties elsewhere and being justly compensated. 
Two years ago residents opposed plans for a Home Depot on the north side of Route 4, contending it would, among other things, make traffic insufferable and hurt downtown merchants. The site for the unrealized store is in the 160-acre redevelopment zone.
Mayor Fader said the current plan focuses on what residents back then said they wanted -- office, hotel, housing and limited retail operations -- and meetings will be held to hear the public's reaction now. Estimates are that taxes from the area, when redeveloped, will rise to $5 million a year from $1.13 million, which "will help stabilize residential property taxes," he said.
While there will be additional traffic, Mr. Kasparian said improvements are planned that will help minimize the impact, including adding a Route 4 acceleration-deceleration lane into the site as well as a service road. An additional ramp off I-95 is also being explored. 
MR. BERN said a light rail link to the Hudson River waterfront would also help as would the mix of uses, which will provide opportunities for people to live and work in Englewood.
Donald Aronson, a former mayor and current head of the Englewood Chamber of Commerce, which sued to block the Home Depot project, said of the redevelopment, "It may be terrific for the city if it does exactly what it promises." Can that happen, he asked? The answer is, "I don't know."
He said he was concerned about the displacement of businesses, many of which have been in the area for 50 years and are third-generation, family-run companies. Some of the companies have formed Englewood South Tenants and Property Owners Association.
One organizer is Jeffrey L. Fisher, president of the Fisher Brothers Steel Corporation, which has been operating from its five-acre site on Nordhoff Place since the 1950's. Mr. Fisher, who is the third generation of his family to run the steel service and distribution company, said some properties had been excluded from the redevelopment and not everyone in the area had been properly notified of the plan. City officials said all parties had been notified.
A statement issued by the group listed a number of concerns. They range from why the area, which they say "is far from blighted" is part of a redevelopment plan meant to improve unproductive properties, to the loss of the 1,000 jobs they say the 65 existing businesses generate. While "some businesses may prosper," the statement said, "others will suffer undue hardship, be forced out of business or possibly into bankruptcy."
State law requires that property owners be paid a fair market price for their property as well as relocation expenses and dislocation benefits. But the law does not provide for the cost of "business interruption, extreme stress or old-fashioned aggravation," the group's statement said.
"Isn't there something wrong with a system that takes this number of people who are making a living and throws them out?" Mr. Fisher asked. "And if we must relocate, where are we to go?"
City officials said that most of the buildings are obsolete and that efforts to attract private investment were unsuccessful because no one wanted to be amid an industrial area. They also said the project's potential benefits outweighed the perceived negatives.
Some commercial brokers said the project's 1.2-million-square-foot office component is ambitious in light of a slowdown in the pace of leasing. "I question the timing," said Dennis Gralla, a vice president at the Paramus office of Alexander Summer/ Cresa, a commercial brokerage. He added that the project would be competing with established office hubs nearby, including Fort Lee, "where several blocks of space have hit the market." More is expected, he said, noting that the office vacancy rate in southeastern Bergen County is 13 percent, up from 3.2 percent a year ago.
Insignia/ESG, a brokerage in Saddle Brook, reports a similar rise. But Jeffrey Babikian, a senior managing director, said that while most of the vacant space was made up of blocks of 10,000 to 20,000 square feet, there is still a limited supply of larger blocks.
The competition in that size will also increase if other large proposed projects in the county, with a total of more than two million square feet, proceed. 
Mr. Kasparian, the developer, remains optimistic because, he said, "whatever sluggishness there is now, the fundamentals of the real estate market remain strong." Rents have not been set, but he said they would be on par with those for prime space, which is about $29 a square foot annually.
And his company, he added, could start first on the hotels or housing, which would also be competitively priced. He said the apartments, with 800 to 1,200 square feet, and the town houses, with 2,000 to 2,300 feet, would be designed to appeal to individuals or couples, rather than to families with children to lessen the impact on schools.
Recognizing the challenges ahead, Councilman Bern said, "We are listening to the public to arrive at an appropriate balance to move the plan to fruition."

HEADLINE: MEMO FROM HARTFORD; 
Well, At Least the Title Is Impressive

BYLINE:  By Paul Zielbauer; Paul Zielbauer is the Hartford bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
HELP WANTED
 Shrinking Northeastern city seeks energetic replacement for top city hall job. Successful candidate must enjoy receiving P/T salary for F/T work, political back-stabbings and frequent beatings in local press. Benefits include travel (citywide), important title (mayor) and free laser eye surgery. No experience necessary. 
 EOE except for Republicans.
That, in brief, is the job that Hartford's mayor, Mike Peters, will give up after eight years when he resigns later this year. Why he would voluntarily relinquish such a lofty political berth is anyone's guess.
For the first time since Lowell Weicker was governor, there will be serious competition for Hartford's top elected office, though only political adolescents and perhaps Bob Backlund would believe anyone but a hard-core Democrat has a chance of winning it. Whichever Dem that may be, however, he or she is hardly kicking down Mayor Mike's door. 
To the contrary, more than a week after Mr. Peters, 52, announced his forthcoming resignation and officially became a lame-duck incumbent, the campaign fax machines remain on standby, their spokesmen silent. No one has publicly declared an interest in being the city's next mayor. 
"There are a lot of difficult things you got to overcome," Mr. Peters said Tuesday, in a burst of understatement.
In Hartford, the mayor has no vote on the City Council, holds no power to hire or fire anyone other than his secretary and makes so little money -- $30,000, which is a shade more than double the state's minimum wage -- that only a handful of city residents qualified to hold the office have even considered running for it.
They know Mr. Peters inhabits what is called a "weak mayor's" job, a mostly ceremonial assignment with almost no direct authority over anything more important than the unfortunately named Hooker Day Parade and with daily duties that typically range from nothing to standing beside businessmen in suits, holding a gold-painted shovel.
And yet, Hartford's nascent candidates-in-hiding are out there. Most of them have received more media attention in absentia over the past 12 days than they have in the past two years. Two names in particular are heard most often. 
John Wardlaw, the decades-long executive director of the Hartford Housing Authority, has said he's too busy ridding Hartford of its crumbling public housing units and is all but not interested. As a respected leader of an important agency integral to the city's history and fabric, Mr. Wardlaw is seen as a formidable potential candidate. His days as a Boy Scout can't hurt either.
It is still early in the soon-to-be-post-Peters era, and Mr. Wardlaw's nondenial denial of interest in the job should not taken as his last word.
Eddie Perez, the executive director of the Southside Institutions Neighborhood Alliance, is young, ambitious and Puerto Rican, three helpful qualities for anyone wanting to improve a mostly Latino city with world-class economic and social problems. Out of public view, Mr. Perez, 43, who recently moved back to Hartford from suburban Bloomfield, has been noticeably taking his fellow Democrats' political temperatures to determine the strength of his candidacy.
There are other potential mayoral candidates, too, including one former mayor, Thirman L. Milner, one former city councilor and fire chief, John B. Stewart Jr., and, as a self-described last resort he-can't-find-anyone-better, one current Democratic Town chairman, Bob Jackson.
Though it's early intthe mayoral election year, Mr. Milner, whose served as mayor from 1981 to 1987, and Mr. Stewart, who became the city's first black fire chief in 1980, would have to be considered long-shot candidates. In a word, they are retreads, old-schoolers in leisure suits who are disruptions to Hartford's waxing notion that, for all the good Mr. Peters did for it, his departure offers this city a necessary segue to fresh-faced, next-generation candidates like Mr. Wardlaw and Mr. Perez, among others.
Moreover, everyone believes that two things will differentiate the Peters era in Hartford government from the next mayor's: a united City Council (for one) that will (for two) give the new mayor the official powers, the absence of which weighed heavily in Mr. Peters' decision not to run for a fifth term. 
The only way the new mayor will be effective, according to several prominent Hartford Democrats, is if he puts his own council together. Two City Council members, including Deputy Mayor Frances Sanchez, who helped scuttle a change to a strong-mayor form of government last year, said they won't run for another term. 
Their departure only makes room for more first-time councilors, which, regardless of who becomes mayor, are probably going to favor putting a strong-mayor referendum on the same city ballots as next year's governor's race. Last year, with Ms. Sanchez's support, the City Council voted against placing the strong-mayor question on November's presidential ballots, when the most residents would show up to vote on it. Instead, a special citywide vote was held in December, and though a huge majority voted for a strong mayor, not enough registered voters cast ballots to officially change anything, and the measure failed.
Of course, predicting who will run and what will happen inside Hartford's City Hall is like betting on which direction your goldfish will swim next. There are still more than four months before September's Democratic Party primary.
On May 2, Mr. Jackson, the Democratic town chairman, held a political open house at a local high school to give City Council candidates the chance to tell him why they deserved his considerable support. Mr. Jackson said 17 City Council candidates showed up and spoke. Nobody showed up to talk about being mayor. 
In his next open house, Mr. Jackson said he expected all the serious mayoral candidates to show up ready to discuss their specific vision for leading the city. 
"Why do you want to be mayor?" is the first question Mr. Jackson said he would ask prospective candidates, followed by "What are the skill sets you bring to the position? And how do you propose to use those to solve the top three problems the city of Hartford has?"
While the candidates are answering those questions, you just might find, over in the back row with his hand in a large bag of popcorn, Mayor Peters casually observing Hartford's new political theater. Who will replace him as his party's top fund-raiser, though, is a serious question for Democrats here.
On the first Tuesday in December, Mayor Mike will pull on his suit jacket, pack up his crossword puzzles and flip off the lights of his second-floor corner office for the last time. 
Save the tears, please. He has already gotten a few job offers from businesses in Hartford and one outfit in Washington, though not from the Federal government. "President Bush has not called," he said.
Most of the offers are from lobbyists or public-relations firms, places where Mayor Peter's affinity for vulgarisms would not work as well as they did from his big leather office chair. 
"I may end up driving a cab, for all I know," he said last week. From mayor to cabbie in eight years flat. Is this a great city or what? 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Mike Peters of Hartford has said he will not seek another term. Now the city has to find a replacement. (C. M. Glover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fresh Air Fund Offers Lessons for 2 Families 

BYLINE:  By JUDY TONG 

 BODY:
WHEN Jim and Havilande Whitcomb of Southport first welcomed Quintasha Watson, 9, to their home as part of the Fresh Air Fund, they knew they and their three children, James, 12, Ashton, 10, and Christiana, 8, would also gain from the experience. But they also were about to be introduced to an understanding of prejudice.
 One day the oldest child, James, 12, heard a racist remark from a friend and asked his mother, Havilande, an interior designer with Beinfeld Wagner architects of South Norwalk, why someone would say something like that and what it meant. 
 "I'd never felt anything like that inside of me before," James said. "It's just the meanest thing you could ever do to somebody, to say something prejudiced." 
His parents said they believed that if James hadn't been close to Quintasha, the remark might have gone completely unnoticed by him. But, because of their relationship, Ms. Whitcomb said, when he overheard the remark, he felt it personally and became protective of someone he considers like a sister. She remembers him coming home confused and angry. It was completely new territory for him, and they had to sit down twice and have long discussions to work through it.
Obviously, the purpose of the program is to get the children out of the city and into a wonderful summer environment, Ms. Whitcomb said. But, it's also a chance for all four of the children to be prepared for life. When all four children grow older, they'll have to interact with people from different racial, cultural, and economic backgrounds.
"Hopefully, the program gives them a little window to different kinds of worlds," said Mr. Whitcomb, an investment banker for Shattuck Hammond Partners.
The Whitcombs had been back in the states for a year after living in London for seven. After reading an article in a newspaper, they decided to volunteer with the Fresh Air Fund. But the youngest of their three children, Christiana, was only a year-old at the time, and the program requires the youngest child to be at least 6. So they waited and when they could, they asked their friend, Lori Sprous, then the program's area coordinator, to help them.
The Fresh Air Fund provides more than 10,000 disadvantaged New York City children with free summer vacations annually. Since 1877, more than 1.7 million inner-city children have visited host families in small town communities or attended one of five Fresh Air camps in Fishkill, N.Y.
In July 1998, Quintasha Watson, then 6, arrived to spend two weeks in their home. This July will be the fourth summer she's visited. 
"I'm excited to go back and see their new pet," Quintasha said. "And, I'm looking forward to seeing Christiana and her birthday party."
Last summer, Quintasha and Christiana took acting lessons at a summer camp at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield. Drama class seemed a perfect fit for the two girls, who are very close. Christiana wants to be an actress when she gets older and Quintasha had always seemed to be a natural performer to the Whitcombs.
Quintasha's natural talents showed the very first summer at Christiana's sixth birthday party. It was a dress-up party, with clothes, shoes, bags and jewelry bought from Goodwill, and at the end she rallied a group of the girls together for an impromptu performance. As mothers arrived to pick up their daughters, Quintasha, Christiana and several other girls began a song and dance on the back porch, some of them even playing improvised instruments.
"We knew she was very talented from that moment," Mr. Whitcomb said. "She had that spark to her." 
At the end of the two weeks, the Whitcombs invited Quintasha's mother, Pamela, and her older brother, Jamal, 14, who also goes on Fresh Air Fund vacations, to Southport for the drama camp's last performance.
Pamela Watson, an administrative assistant at the Harlem Hospital, first heard about the program from an elderly woman she was working for as a home aide. Her son had been a Fresh Air Fund child, and she suggested enrolling Quintasha's older brother, Jamal.
When Quintasha and Jamal went away for the first time, Ms. Watson was anxious. After a suggestion from the elderly woman, she gave them both a special word -- a code. Then, if anything was wrong, all they had to do was say that word when they spoke on the phone, or write it on a postcard and send it to her. Then she would come for them.
The code word was never needed. Ms. Watson and the children can't even remember what the code is.
"It's hard when you first let your children go," Ms. Watson said. "But then, when they get where they're going, once you speak to the family and you speak to your child and your child is letting you know everything's okay, then it's a lot better.
"I spoke with Ms. Whitcomb the other night," Ms. Watson said. "I told her Quintasha needed help with reading. So, she said she was going to look into some programs that might be able help her out. They go way beyond just dealing with the two weeks for the summer. They contact us all throughout the winter. And, if there's anything we ever need any help with they always seem to be there."
Quintasha lists all the things she loves about visiting her Fresh Air family: learning to swim, waking up and playing right away, playing with the dog, Leopold, who reminds her of the dog she used to have but had to give up, even tidying up before going out.
"When I'm there, I'm happy all the time," she said.
For more information about being a Fresh Air Fund host family, or to make tax-deductible donations, please contact their offices at 800-367-0003 or 212-897-8900, 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, NY, 10017. The Web address is www.freshair.org.

HEADLINE: Southwest Flexes Muscles and Others Fall 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: ISLIP 

 BODY:
IN the airline industry it is called the "Southwest effect," an explosion in passenger traffic at formerly sleepy, out-of-the-way regional airports that predictably occurs when Southwest, the industry's wildly successful discount-fare giant, comes to town.
 But as recent passenger figures for Long Island MacArthur Airport are beginning to attest, there is another, less-publicized aspect of Southwest's dominating presence: A dwindling of competition that can spell a reduction of service as other airlines cut back or head for the exits. 
 In what industry experts said was a familiar pattern, the number of passengers flying Southwest between Islip and an array of domestic locations has been on the rise since the Dallas-based discounter set up shop in the New York market at Islip two years ago.
In March, the most recent month for which figures were available, Southwest carried 113,682 passengers to and from Islip, up from 82,955 a year earlier. 
Just as familiar a part of the pattern, the experts said, was an overall decrease in total passengers at Islip that followed the initial surge as other carriers, unable to compete with Southwest's bargain fares, began to lose business and retreat. Even as Southwest's numbers continued to climb, total passenger volume at Islip slipped in March to 175,801, down from 196,553 a year earlier.
Other factors including labor disputes, weather and a cooled national economy come into play in the fluctuating passenger numbers, and competitors are loath to admit that they blinked in the face of Southwest's challenge.
But with passengers voting with their feet, Southwest has quickly become the ten-ton gorilla, and flying the ticketless Southwest way -- with de rigueur pre-flight queuing to get first dibs on non-reserved seats and with meals and movies traded for peanuts and plastic-wrapped snacks -- is more and more the only way to fly into or out of Islip.
"They whip the other guys' butts," said Darryl Jenkins, director of the Aviation Institute at George Washington University. "We see that a lot with Southwest. If they are very, very successful in a market, they really kill everyone else."
In a paper last August, Mr. Jenkins predicted that Southwest would match Delta Airlines, a full-service goliath, as the country's largest domestic carrier within five years, and would thereafter overtake Delta.
Southwest and Delta are already grappling at Islip, and Southwest appears to be on top. Comair and Florida-bound Atlantic Southwest Airlines, wholly owned Delta subsidiaries, and Delta Express, Atlanta-based Delta's low-fare operating unit, all fly from Islip.
Recent numbers suggest Southwest is beginning to draw decisively ahead. In a comparison between the first three months of 2000 and 2001, Southwest passengers were up by more than 113,000 while combined totals for Atlantic Southeast, Comair and Delta Express were off by nearly 11,000.
With service overlaps, particularly on the well-worn routes from Islip to Florida cities serving the so-called polyester trade that has long been Islip's forte, fares are part of the reason.
The departure of Spirit Airlines in July ended service to Florida by a carrier that transported more than 40,000 passengers through the first four months of 2000.
Fort Lauderdale-based Spirit left Islip after Southwest commenced Florida service. But a Spirit spokeswoman, Lynne Koreman, said the airline's exit from Islip was not because of Southwest. "We had opportunities to add to our service at LaGuardia, so we consolidated our New York operations," Ms. Koreman said. "That was our real reason."
But while competitors at Islip put on a brave face publicly, an airline spokesman who spoke on the condition he and his company would not be named said Southwest was taking a heavy toll. "We are not unique in this," the spokesman said. "All the other airlines are facing it."
Southwest, already heavily in the Florida market, quickly took up the slack. The airline has announced it will begin new service between Islip and West Palm Beach on Sept. 12, adding to the 66 cities it currently flies to from Long Island. Southwest has also added flights to Providence.
Now Southwest would like to expand at Islip by building a new, four-gate terminal area and a new 2,400-space parking area. A Southwest spokeswoman, Christine Turneabe-Connelly, said the airline was in discussions with an architect and general contractor and negotiating with the town for a project that would cost about $42 million. Southwest would pay 90 percent of the cost and Islip would apply for federal financing to pay the remaining 10 percent, she said.
A group representing airport neighbors, Citizens for Enforcement of MacArthur Airport Controls, opposes the expansion and has urged the town supervisor, Pete McGowan, to block it. 
The group president, Deborah Slinkosky, said the plan appeared to be in a lengthy holding pattern. "Pete McGowan knows he'll be committing political suicide if he allows this to happen," she said.
Otherwise, it has been smooth sailing for Southwest.
US Airways, which made a run at Islip in the 1990s but pulled out its jets in 1997 as part of an overall restructuring, now offers service to Albany, Philadelphia and Boston on limited-seating prop jets. The company, which says it holds an untenable niche between major full-service airlines and discount carriers like Southwest, has staked its future on Justice Department approval of a merger with United Airlines. The implications of the merger, which Southwest opposes, are unclear for Islip.
Another Southwest competitor, Continental Express, a wholly owned subsidiary of Texas-based Continental Airlines, barely has a toe in at Islip. Twice-daily flights to Continental's Cleveland hub connect to Midwest and West Coast cities and elsewhere. There were no plans to expand.
A Continental spokeswoman, Julie Gardner, said her airline welcomed the Southwest challenge. "We have effectively competed head-to-head with Southwest for decades in Texas," she said. "Competition is what this industry is all about."
Ms. Turneabe-Connelly said the airline held fares down with 20-minute airport turnarounds, 10 minutes faster than the industry average, lower training and maintenance costs for a fleet made up exclusively of Boeing 737's, no-frills service and no assigned seating.
"As a company, everything we do is aimed at keeping our costs low," Ms. Turneabe-Connelly said. "But we don't purport to be all things to all people. Some travelers want their seats assigned and we can't be that way. That's not who we are. And we don't serve meals."
Ms. Turneabe-Connelly said Southwest believed competition was healthy for the flying public. "The more competition in any marketplace, the more choices a consumer has," she said. "It not only gives more travel options, but it tends to keep fares down."
Asked if there were any signs Southwest success at Islip had lessened competition there, she replied, "I haven't seen that. We hope that doesn't happen."

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC; 
Look to the Internet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A lot is happening in new classical music, but the economic and social realities that once fostered the performance of music in concert halls no longer support that system of distribution. Many Americans have never attended a live concert. 
What Virgil Thomson derisively called "canned music" has become the standard way in which nearly all of us hear music. 
 New audiences for contemporary music -- for all music -- can be built, but that will depend on changes in the dissemination of music, through ways suggested by Napster. I may not want to own the complete music of Conlon Nancarrow or Morton Feldman, but I would love to call them up over the Internet and have a chance to purchase pieces individually.
With listeners caught between formal (and inconvenient) concert halls and costly compact discs, it is no wonder that so few people are listening. Increase availability and let us listen at home. The future isn't in concert halls; it's on the Internet.

NOAH CRESHEVSKY
Manhattan

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
New Roc City Developer Has Plans for White Plains

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AFTER a decade of store shutdowns in stretches of the once-thriving downtown area of White Plains, officials at City Hall and downtown property owners are welcoming plans by the developer Louis R. Cappelli to build a $250 million movie, residential and retail development where an abandoned Macy's department store now stands.
 City officials see the project providing new life in the downtown area, as well as new sales tax revenues for the city's coffers. 
 Business owners like Leon Silverman, the president of the Silverman Realty Group, which owns 300,000 square feet of retail space in 11 buildings downtown, are also eager for Mr. Cappelli to begin his project. Mr. Silverman, who now charges $15 to $20 a square foot annually for property he leases, predicts that with new activity downtown, real estate values will rise and he will be able to attract new tenants eager to be close to Mr. Cappelli's White Plains Town Center. 
But individual shopkeepers like Manny Polloni, who owns American Terrain, a sporting goods store on nearby Post Road, are not so sure that they will benefit from the project. Mr. Polloni is worried that yet another mall in a city where three malls have already siphoned off most of the retail business from the streets would mean even more competition for small business owners -- especially if the new stores duplicate the merchandise that existing businesses already offer. "It could cannibalize us," he said. "I hope Mr. Cappelli takes into consideration the shops that are already here and offers a complementary mix of retail."
The developer, who built New Roc City, the sports and entertainment complex in New Rochelle, revealed his latest plans to White Plains officials on April 24, after acquiring the property from the Manhattan developer Tishman Speyer Properties for $17 million. The plans for the 495,000-square-foot retail complex include a 3,500-seat multiscreen movie theater, a major clothing chain, a home improvement outlet, an electronics store and a Target discount store.
Mr. Cappelli, who acquired the Concord and Grossinger's hotel properties in the Catskills in 1999, also plans to build 500 apartments in two 18-story buildings in downtown White Plains on nearby E. J. Conroy Drive. Rents would range from $1,700 for a one-bedroom apartment to $2,400 for a two-bedroom unit. Bruce M. Berg, executive vice president of Cappelli Enterprises, said the company had received inquiries from interested rental apartment developers, lending credence to the notion that there is strong demand for high-end rental units in Westchester. 
Mr. Berg said the apartments, which would be within walking distance of the Metro-North train station, would appeal to career couples, single professionals and empty nesters. The commute to Grand Central Station is 33 minutes.
"Compared to rents in New York City, this would be a bargain," he noted.
MR. BERG observed that 500 apartments would "bring to White Plains 750 or more new residents with significant disposable income, who would generate all kinds of buying power." He also said that the downtown, which tends to be deserted after the office buildings empty out, would see new evening activity.
The project would also include a 2,038-space garage to replace an existing 1,045-space parking structure.
In addition, Cappelli Enterprises has begun talks to acquire other properties near the Macy's site, which is at Mamaroneck Avenue and Main Street. Among the properties is a Fleet Bank branch on Main Street, which may become part of the project. Mr. Berg said the company was in active negotiations with property owners and there were no plans at present to take any property by eminent domain, a legal tool sometimes employed in urban redevelopment projects.
Cappelli Enterprises is also in talks about purchasing a vacant former A&P store on Main Street, and the developer is seeking to acquire a Citibank branch on Main Street.
For the retailing portion of the current plan, Cappelli Enterprises is negotiating with two home-design chains: Expo Design Centers, a subsidiary of the Home Depot, and Sears Great Indoors, a home-design offshoot of the catalog giant, which has a department store across the street from Macy's on Main Street.
Two clothing chains, Gap and Old Navy, and two electronics chains, the Wiz and Circuit City Stores, have also made inquiries about locating in the Town Center.
All of the retail stores and restaurants on the main level of the four-level retail-entertainment center would have entrances to the street. The theater would be on the third floor.
Mr. Cappelli, who plans to start razing the 328,000-square-foot former Macy's store in August, expects to gain building approvals from the city within three months. After the demolition is carried out, the project would take 18 months to complete.
City officials have indicated that approvals will be granted quickly, especially because they are eager for the redevelopment of the downtown to begin. "Any delays on the city's part," Mr. Silverman warned, "could doom this project. The economy is favorable now to developers." 
Tishman Speyer had planned a similar complex on the site, but dropped its plans for a residential component. Then last September, it backed out of the deal altogether, when Loews Cineplex, the prospective theater manager, filed for bankruptcy, reflecting the industry's troubles after years of overbuilding large multiplexes. White Plains has been without a movie theater for 10 years, when a twin-screen theater at the Galleria mall shut down.
Cappelli Enterprises has talked with five movie exhibitors: Clearview Cinemas Inc., a unit of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, which has the Cinema 100 in Greenburgh and the Rye Ridge Twin in Rye Brook; National Amusements Inc., which operates multiplexes in Elmsford, Hawthorne and Yonkers; Regal Cinemas, which runs an 18-screen movie theater and IMAX theater in New Roc City; Muvico Theaters of Boca Raton, Fla.; and Star Theatres of Grand Rapids, Mich.
Thrilled that his city may once again be home to a movie theater -- but aware that roadblocks could still be erected -- Mayor Joseph M. Delphino said recently, "I won't be happy until I am served my first bag of popcorn."
To provide incentives for the developer, the city has agreed to spend $23 million for the new parking garage.
"That's a lot of money for a city like White Plains," said City Councilman William M. King. "I worry that we could give away the store."
Mr. King was concerned that the developer might raise the ante in the coming months. "It's not unheard of for developers to end up asking for more," he said. "An incentive package should never be so good that it depletes the city coffers and taxpayers have to make up the difference."
UNDER Tishman Speyer's proposal, which entailed a payment of $13 million by the city for the parking garage, the city would have seen a net gain of $40 million by the time a bond for the garage was paid off, said Eileen Earl, the White Plains budget director. The gain would have been realized through sales taxes generated from the project and new property taxes from the development.
Ms. Earl anticipates that under the Cappelli proposal, the net gain to the city after 25 years will be "at least as much and maybe more since there's more retail in the newest proposal."
Cappelli Enterprises is still negotiating with the city about the amount of payments it will make in lieu of property taxes.

HEADLINE: The Underbelly Of a City In Transition 

BYLINE:  By LINDA OCASIO 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
SANDONNA BRYANT still bristles when she thinks of one former employer, who asked if she lived here because she wanted to. Yet today her pride in how Newark is newly regarded is tempered by her knowledge of how much still must be done.
 "The city turned a corner in that people are realizing its investment potential, both for commercial and housing development," said Ms. Bryant, who recently completed a five-year stint as coordinator for the Newark Community Development Network since 1996. "Unfortunately, there is resentment by long-term residents. They don't feel they are necessarily a part of the renaissance, because the focus is on downtown." 
 Ms. Bryant's sentiments are echoed by many who live and work in Newark. They can, of course, recite the litany of achievements in recent years: the opening of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the restoration and occupancy of several downtown office buildings, the return of the minor league Newark Bears baseball team and their new Riverfront Stadium. 
Even the streets are safer, the Newark Police Department says, noting that homicides, robberies and burglaries have declined by more than 50 percent since 1995.
Still, many of those improvements have had little effect on the city's poorest residents, insists Ms. Bryant and others who work in the city's social service agencies. Three decades of social upheaval -- race riots, drug dealing and muggings and carjackings -- have taken their toll. And while Newark's long-awaited revival has blossomed somewhat in recent years, most residents of this depleted industrial city live deep within the shadows of the arts center and baseball stadium.
For his part, Mayor Sharpe James takes issue with those who say that Newark's revival has been focused on downtown at the expense of the neighborhoods.
"That's false political rhetoric," Mr. James said in exasperation. "People always want to compare downtown to the neighborhoods, but that's completely false."
The city itself is divided into five wards: the North, home to most of the city's Hispanic population; the East, a bustling neighborhood of Portuguese and newcomer Brazilian groups; the West, which touches part of South Orange, and is home to working-class and low-income families; the South, once home to the middle-class Jewish community immortalized in Philip Roth's novels, now predominantly middle-class and working-class black families with many single-family homes. The Central Ward, where the riots erupted in 1967, destroying the Springfield Avenue shopping district, has seen many of its high-rise public housing buildings demolished, replaced by low-rise, mixed-income homes.
As for the mayor, he pointed out that many community development corporations, like New Community Corporation, received land, money or both from the city for neighborhood projects. As an example, he cited the city's partnership with New Community to build a $4.8 million community center on Hayes Street, although "our name doesn't appear anywhere."
In addition, the mayor said that the lion's share of the federal block grants that the city received went toward neighborhood housing, and that homeownership in the city rose to 26 percent today from 14 percent in 1986, the year he took office; nationwide, that rate is 49 percent.
Indeed, increasing homeownership has been part of the city's successful strategy to reduce crime, the mayor said. "You can't put a cop on every corner. The best cop is a homeowner. They won't tolerate nonsense in the neighborhood."
That is one point on which the Rev. William J. Linder, director of New Community Corporation, agrees with the mayor. "We're getting more home ownership in the city, and I think that will be a significant change agent," said Mr. Linder, who has been the pastor of St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in the Central Ward for nearly 38 years.
He started New Community in 1968 to help the Central Ward recover from the devastation of the riots. Over four decades, he estimated that New Community had built about 3,000 housing units -- primarily rentals -- in the Central and West Wards, with more homes on the drawing board that would be for sale.
In addition, in 1982, after years of petitioning the city for a new supermarket, New Community decided to go into commercial development itself, and the result was a $19 million Pathmark Shopping Center that serves about 50,000 shoppers a week with a supermarket, doughnut shop, mailbox store and food court.
Yet Mr. Linder parts company with the mayor on the issue of the community center, which he said cost $2.6 million, half of which New Community put up when the city's original plan to convert a former bathhouse and pool into a center fell through.
"We made a commitment to run it," he said. "It's not the Sharpe James Community Center."
Mr. Linder said the surest sign of the city's failure to revitalize the neighborhoods was most apparent in the public schools, which have been run by the state since 1995. 
"It's more about power and control than it is about children," he said. With $1.5 billion in state funds coming into Newark for school construction, there has been "a frenzy for control," he said, citing April's school board elections, which saw three allies of the mayor win seats on a school board that is slowly being empowered once again under state guidelines. "Money gets everyone excited, but not the quality of education."
Ms. Bryant, the development coordinator, was born 30 years ago and reared on South 11th Street in the South Ward, attended the city's Science High School and went on to graduate from Yale University in 1993 before returning to Newark -- a decision that not everyone understands.
"I feel a lot of pride," she said of the city's renaissance.
But like others, she fears that the prosperity -- which was beginning to take shape downtown before the economy recently began slowing -- is for the most part not trickling down to the people who call Newark home, primarily those of color or who speak Spanish.
"I don't want to perpetuate that division, but that's how people feel, whether it's reality or perceived," she said. "They want parity and they want to see resources applied to the neighborhoods."
But the deputy mayor for housing and economic development, Alfred Faiella, said that 90 percent of federal block grants, which total about $11 million in Newark, go to community agencies.
On the other hand, private investment in the downtown area, which is closest to the East and North wards, is in the $200 million range, Mr. Faiella said -- half of which has gone toward construction of new office buildings, and half toward renovating existing structures.
Moreover, Ms. Bryant, like many others in the city, say they worry that the lack of regional planning to address problems in older outlying areas like Irvington and East Orange will undermine Newark's revival.
The deputy mayor also countered critics who said the city had done no planning with the neighboring communities. "We've taken a lead with regional planning involving transportation, highway and waterfront development," he said.
But the experts who monitor such activity say Newark has not done enough -- either locally or regionally.
"There hasn't been a lot of planning at all that considers how to build and sustain a community, how to make Newark livable long-term," said Baye Wilson, director of the New Jersey office of the Regional Planning Association. "That kind of planning demands open space, recreation space, housing that is built to scale, all of which is part of the fabric of a community." 
James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said in particular there had been "precious little" regional planning.
"Everyone is grappling for themselves," Mr. Hughes said. "New Jersey has a tradition of home-rule and lack of cooperation, but substantial competition."
Dennis Gale, director of the Joseph C. Cornwall Center for Metropolitan Studies at Rutgers in Newark, agreed. "Newark may have a regional approach when it comes to transportation, a 'benign issue,' " Mr. Gale said, "but when it comes to housing, crime and education, look out. Everyone wants home rule when those issues come up."
THE persistence of the drug trade is evident on street corners, where on some blocks new housing and drug dens are neighbors. One brazen dealer advertised "Cowboy Crack," with a spray-painted sign on the doors of a turquoise house at the end of Holland Street near Springfield Avenue in the Central Ward.
Many new homes in the Central and South Wards have elaborate gates on windows and doors, a testimony to residents' lingering fears for their safety. On one recent spring day, Fairmount Street at South Orange Avenue in the Central Ward, close to West Ward, was barricaded as part of a police strategy to stem drug traffic. In the Central Ward, the huge Stella Wright housing project awaits demolition, and looms behind a row of new townhouses like a bad dream that will not go away. 
According to figures compiled by the New Jersey State Police, Newark averaged more than 10,000 violent crimes a year from 1989 to 1995. By 1999, the number of murders, rapes and aggravated assaults had fallen below 5,000 a year. In January, the city trumpeted that its increase in crime for the year 2000 was the lowest since the agency has began reporting annual statistics 33 years ago. Rapes, assaults and robberies were down by more than 50 percent from 1995, and homicides were down 43 percent -- from 101 to 58 -- for the same period.
Corene Sampson 68, who has lived here since she arrived from Florida 1952, wonders if the renaissance will ever reach all of Newark's residents -- or simply benefit the outsiders who did not stick by Newark in the gloomy aftermath of the 1967 race riots.
Ms. Sampson said that although she can see some improvements from her house -- built by the Corinthian Housing Development Corp., one of the community development corporations spawned by area churches -- she still doesn't feel safe because of the drug dealing going on in the open in her neighborhood.
Long separated from her husband, Ms. Sampson has been living in the development since 1998 with her 14-year-old great-granddaughter. Her son died several years ago of pneumonia; her daughter and granddaughter have been incapacitated by chronic illnesses; she also has three other great-grandchildren.
Ms. Sampson said she was frustrated because there was no supermarket within walking distance. "So many things are supposed to be started, but it's not reaching people yet," she said.
Carol Williams, 40, who has lived in Newark since arriving here from Tacoma, Wash., as a small child, had her own definition of the word that now seems permanently affixed to Newark: "Renaissance -- it means to keep us out. You're building it up, but are you building it for us or our children? There's no way you can afford a townhouse on welfare."
For Ms. Williams, the struggle to raise her two daughters, ages 20 and 18, and a 16-year-old son, has been documented in the book "No Easy Walk: Newark, 1980-1993" (Temple University Press, 1994) by Helen M. Stummer, a photojournalist.
Ms. Sampson and Ms. Williams can both attest that any number of problems continue to bedevil the city. For instance, figures compiled by the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University show that the city's unemployment rate is twice that of the state, and that one in four Newark residents earns less than a poverty-level income, and more than 40 percent of all low-income renters pay more than half their income in rent. 
While Newark, like many old Northeastern cities, has seen a major decline in its non-Hispanic English-speaking people in recent years, blacks have also left in large numbers.
From 1980 to 2000, the number of residents who considered themselves non-Hispanic white declined by 33,950, or nearly 50 percent. At the same time, the non-Hispanic black population decreased by 46,637, almost 25 percent.
Most of this decline occurred during the 1980's; what has helped stabilize the city's population has been an influx of Hispanics, who grew by more than 10,000 in the 1980's and by almost 9,000 in the 1990's. Put another way, in 1980 about one in five Newark residents was Hispanic, as against one in three today.
DEEP within the neighborhoods of Newark, no one is more vulnerable than the children. About 80 percent of the students in the Newark public schools, or 35,172 of them, receive a reduced or free breakfast and lunch at school, according to figures supplied to the school district and compiled in Newark Kids Count 2000, a report published annually by the Association for Children of New Jersey. The organization also found that Newark's infant mortality rate was double that of the state, and that preventative care for impoverished children remained an issue.
"Immunization rates are still near the bottom of the list, compared to other municipalities and states, lead poisoning is still a concern," said Gina Lucas, Newark outreach coordinator for the association. "I'm excited that there's more attention being paid to the city and more development going on, but we continue to be concerned about Newark's children, and the needs of children are not being met. We need to see these indicators improve. Until children and their families are thriving, I wouldn't call it a renaissance."
Nor are the adults -- particularly those without jobs -- having an easy time of it.
"We are seeing an increase in the number of working people seeking help, people coming in because they can't make rent," said Jeannette Page-Hawkins, executive director of Newark Emergency Services for Families. Indeed, a 1998 study by the Institute for Children and Poverty found that 44 percent of the homeless families in Newark were never on welfare. Newark Emergency Services, situated in the renovated Continental Ballroom building on Broad Street, serves about 45,000 people in Essex County with a homeless drop-in center, food vouchers and temporary assistance for rent, utility bills, child care and transportation. 
What surprised many experts, however, was the increase in the number of people with jobs who were still struggling to find affordable housing and pay their bills.
"No one foresaw the working poor," said Maria Vizcarrondo-DeSoto, president and chief executive of the United Way of Essex and West Hudson, who expressed concern about what would happen when those who had not found employment by the spring of 2002 were dropped from the rolls, as mandated by federal law. "We're waiting for the other shoe to drop. We may find ourselves in a major crisis."
Moroever, Ms. Vizcarrondo-DeSoto said that many residents lacked the technical skills for the jobs available, so that organizations "can't match families with the opportunities that are there."
To be sure, Newark's unemployment rate has fallen, though the numbers are still troubling: Last year, 8.1 percent of city residents -- or more than twice the state's overall unemployment rate of 3.8 percent -- who sought work could not find it. While the unemployment rate was much higher five years ago -- 12.9 percent -- the decline was caused by an increase in about 2,000 jobs coupled with a reduction of 3,800 in the number of residents considered to be in the job market.
As for the city's public schools, which have been under state control for nearly seven years, the dropout rate has hovered at 7 to 8 percent over the last five years, as against from 3 to 4 percent for the average high school in the state. At one high school, Weequahic in the South Ward, the drop-out rate was almost 14 percent last year, state figures show.
"It will take a number of generations to truly transform the schools," Ms. Vizcarrondo-DeSoto said.
Ms. Vizcarrondo-DeSoto was among 22 civic leaders on the 21st Century Task Force -- formed in 1997 to evaluate what steps were necessary to improve the city -- which last year recommended several steps to implement a far-reaching and enduring revival:
* Improve the city's image among nonresidents.
* Increase the city's role in, and contribution to, the regional economy.
* Improve the city's ailing public schools.
The recommendations included insuring that residents had access to the jobs generated by new investment in the city, especially in construction; cleaning up such eyesores as the abandoned Pabst/Hoffman bottling plant on South Orange Avenue; and establishing a citizens' panel to monitor school management and financial issues.
"We've got to find a way to strategically plan things," she said. "There's no regional approach to development, and when one group benefits, another group suffers."
She said she was particularly disturbed by the problems facing Orange, East Orange and Irvington. 
"They used to be the suburban connection, and those areas are now becoming blighted and depressed," she said, noting that Newark's progress may have an unintended "rippling effect" that simply relocates poverty. 
Despite the challenges, Ms. remains Vizcarrondo-DeSoto is optimistic.
"At this point, I'm encouraged," she said, making a point of crediting the work of such community-based organizations as New Community Corporation and La Casa de Don Pedro that were advocates for impoverished residents long before private investors jumped in. 
OVER the years, Gerard Joab has worked hand in hand with many of those groups as senior program director of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, which provides financial grants to such local organizations as La Casa de Don Pedro, the Corinthian Housing Development Corporation and the St. James Development Corporation, which build affordable housing -- notable for quality and affordability -- for renters and buyers.
Mr. Joab remembers that when he arrived here in 1986, "everyone cleared out after 5 p.m., but today it's changed. People are walking around and working late."
He also cited improved city services, especially the police. Still, he said he thought that there was too little planning going on to ensure that longtime, low-income residents were not priced out of their city. "A healthy neighborhood has a blend of mixed incomes," he said. 
Many nonprofit organizations depend on the city for at least some financial support, and the directors of those groups are cautious in their criticism of Newark and its main cheerleader, the mayor.
Mayor James "has been attentive and accessible to us, and certainly put up money for what we're doing," Mr. Joab said, "but in some cases the city didn't have the ability to move as quickly as we want."
Moving quickly -- to take advantage of the current momentum and attention being focused on Newark -- is important to Mr. Joab and others who have long waited for this moment. From his office in the North Ward, Raymond Ocasio, president of La Casa de Don Pedro, sees firsthand the influx of Ecuadorians, Dominicans, Mexicans and Peruvians.
In addition to building homes, La Casa offers an immigrant rights program, English classes, job referrals, nutrition information and child care. The new immigrants are joining the long-established Puerto Rican community and putting down their own stakes by opening restaurants, travel agencies, repair shops, beauty shops. He knows that there is still much to be done, but Mr. Ocasio compares Newark with Harlem, which is also attracting new investors and fresh excitement about its possibilities.
"Harlem is hot, and Harlem is still hell," he said. "You're always transitioning into something. Right now I believe we're on the upswing."

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: THE ECONOMY; 
TOURISM REVENUE

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
Tourists' spending in New Jersey increased last year by 7 percent over 1999, compared with an average increase of only 1 percent nationwide, according to a study released last week. 
Tourists spent $30 billion in New Jersey in 2000 by making 169.1 million trips to or within the state, an increase from the 166.9 million trips the previous year. Canadians accounted for the largest number of tourists from a foreign country with 710,000 trips. 
 Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: Fatter Horse Race Purses Are Good for the Economy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "They Subsidize Horses, Don't They?" (Soapbox, April 29), about state subsidies to purses at racetracks, Jon Shure doesn't seem to understand why the state of New Jersey decided to provide a financial boost to its horse racing industry at this time. 
 It was somewhat gratifying to read that he did recognize that the horse industry has a major, positive impact on the state's economy. The direct infusion of money from the state will obviously enable New Jersey racetracks to offer larger purses and keep pace with racetracks in other jurisdictions that have either done the same (Maryland) or have other financial tools that produce money for the tracks to raise purses (slot machines in Delaware and Ontario, Canada, and off-track and telephone-account wagering in New York and Pennsylvania). 
Parimutuel racetracks are only the tip of the iceberg. There are hundreds of thousands of acres of open farmland being preserved by horse farms and millions of dollars of tax revenue to the state from purchases of supplies and feed, not to mention the horses themselves.
This purse supplement is a much-needed boost for racing and for the state. It will pay for itself many times over and prove to be one of the best investments made in New Jersey. This is quite a bargain when one considers racing is not a high-cost franchise, and the residual effects help the economy.
The reason that the recent law was enacted is that New Jersey lawmakers have so far not been able to agree on legislation to adopt those other financial tools. If the state had enacted other laws that would create new revenue for horse racing, the purse supplements would not have been needed.

ANTHONY J. PARENTI
Freehold

The writer is president of the Standardbred Breeders & Owners Association of New Jersey.
