HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chrysler Sebring convertible; 
Like Summer, Sunny and Mild

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
A WARM Michigan spring prompted the early arrival of blooming flowers, budding trees and convertibles emerging from winter storage.
 Spring brings births, too, and there are some newborns in the convertible nursery, with other deliveries set for later this year and next. Several of these -- the 2002 Lexus SC 430 that recently went on sale, the reborn Ford Thunderbird coming this fall, a Cadillac roadster due in 2002 -- are on the pricey side. 
 But what about the masses? Shouldn't open-air motoring be available to those who weren't born into privilege or didn't bail out of dot-coms before the collapse? 
A few years ago, several convertibles were sold in America for less than $20,000, including the tiny Geo Metro, the appealing Toyota Paseo, the jaunty Honda del Sol, the economical Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunfire. Now, though, the least expensive convertibles are the $21,025 Volkswagen Cabrio, the $21,660 Mazda Miata and the $23,010 Ford Mustang.
There are also the $25,175 Chevrolet Camaro and the $26,050 Pontiac Firebird, but these dated cars will soon be phased out. The Toyota MR2 Spyder is great fun for two people, if they don't bring more than a change of underwear. The Mitsubishi Eclipse Spyder will handle two more passengers -- if they are small and wiry. 
If you expect practicality with your sunshine, and your budget won't cover a Saab or a Volvo, your convertible choices are pretty much limited to the Toyota Camry Solara or the Chrysler Sebring. The Solara is a perfectly nice car, but its $25,550 base price gets you only a four-cylinder engine. (And good luck finding a car at that price.)
That leaves the Sebring, which comes with a V-6 and a lot of features for $24,995, as the convertible for all occasions. A stalwart of car-rental fleets in sunny vacation destinations like Hawaii, Florida and California, it is elegant enough to look at home in exclusive resorts, but lacks the pretensions of convertibles from importers like BMW, Jaguar and Mercedes.
Redesigned for the first time since it arrived in 1996 as the LeBaron's replacement, the 2001 Sebring still has everything that made it the nation's best-selling soft top. It is stylish -- even sexy, some might say. It has roomy, accessible accommodations for four adults. The trunk is generous, at least by convertible standards.
While the styling is new, the look is not terribly different from last year's model. A redesigned hood and deck lid put more edge into the wedge shape. Front-end changes, like an oval egg-crate grille, chrome moldings and a retro Chrysler badge set between chrome wings, give it a greater resemblance to other cars in the Chrysler family. The rear also incorporates the winged badge and chrome license-plate trim found on other Chryslers. The deck lid is better integrated into the design.
The interior also got a needed freshening. In back-to-back drives of 2000 and 2001 models around Detroit's suburbs, I was struck by how dated last year's car already felt, with its flat dashboard panels and materials that looked and felt cheap. The new Sebring has curved surfaces, better materials and touches of bright trim around the door handles and gauges. All this contributes to the look and feel of a more expensive car.
Two adults can truly sit comfortably in the rear seat. Getting back there is relatively easy, too, because the front shoulder belts are integrated into the seats, so they don't pose a barrier that you have to climb over or crawl under. And the integrated belts give the car a clean, uncluttered look when the top is down.
There are three versions: LX, LXi and Limited. All have more standard features this year, but side air bags are, unfortunately, still not available. The Limited comes only in royal blue with a matching top, plus a cream leather interior trimmed in blue. The look evokes fine European convertibles, like Aston Martins.
The most significant difference between the '00 and '01 Sebrings is the way they ride and drive, which is where engineers made the biggest changes. The convertible shares its underbody with the new Sebring and Dodge Stratus sedans, and it is built with those models in Michigan. (In contrast, the Sebring and Stratus coupes are stepsiblings of the Mitsubishi Eclipse and are built in a Mitsubishi plant in Illinois.) The '01 has a more solid body structure than before, and the greater rigidity was the first thing I noticed in moving from the old car to the new one. Like Jerry Lee Lewis, the 2000 model had a whole lotta shakin' goin' on.
Still, my '01 test car, an "inferno red" LX with a beige interior and a $26,280 sticker, had some mild jitters, too. The handling has been improved -- the suspension was revised, and larger wheels and tires were added -- but not as much I would have liked. Enthusiasts will be happier with the exceptionally solid BMW 325 convertible, but they will have to pay $10,000 more.
The new Sebring is markedly quieter inside. The power top is well insulated, and the glass back window comes with a defroster. One button lowers the top and all four side windows.
The '01 has also received a more refined engine. An aluminum 2.7-liter twin-cam V-6 replaces the 2.5-liter, single-cam unit of last year, providing a needed boost in power (to 200 horsepower, from 168) and torque (192 foot-pounds, from 170). Still, the Sebring won't set any speed records, even if it is named for the Florida racetrack. The fuel economy rating is slightly better: 20 m.p.g. in town and 28 on the highway.
The transmission is a four-speed automatic. An AutoStick shifter, which allows manual shifting without a clutch, is standard on the Limited, optional on the LXi.
All models get four-wheel disc brakes this year, but you still pay extra on the LX and LXi for an antilock system. The Limited comes with ABS Plus, a stability-control system that helps to keep the car from skidding out of control in sudden maneuvers.
Of course, drivers of this mild-mannered summer cruiser aren't likely to push its limits very often. The Sebring is more sunny than hot, and as casually stylish as a small but relaxing house on the beach. 

INSIDE TRACK: A sexy, well-priced ragtop for Everyman, Everywoman and a couple of Everyfriends.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK HARBOR; 
Think Parking Is Scarce? Pity the Poor Oil Tanker

BYLINE:  By ERIK BAARD 

 BODY:
New York City's time-honored way of greeting visitors -- sending them circling for parking -- can frustrate the most resourceful driver. But try cruising into town with a blocklong oil tanker or an aircraft carrier (Fleet Week starts on May 23) and you'll know how cramped this town really is.
 The parking jam in New York Harbor, a result of economic factors and cleaner local waters, extends to commercial and recreational vessels. 
 In January and February, typically the harbor's busiest months for commercial activity, requests by ships and barges for spots to anchor shot up 85 percent over the comparable 1999 period, said Lt. Michael Day, chief of the Coast Guard's waterways oversight branch for New York.
One reason is oil prices. The harbor is the largest American port for petroleum products, and many local refineries that hoped last autumn's high prices would soften by winter bought heating oil at the last minute.
But other goods are also arriving at record levels. "The amount of cargo coming in through here is projected to double by 2010 and more than quadruple by 2040," said Dan Maynard, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
And, as more ships come in, they must wait longer for the overwhelmed barge fleet to unload them, added Capt. Andrew McGovern, who guides ships into the harbor and is chairman of the harbor operations committee, an umbrella group. 
Commercial ships and barges can currently anchor in three areas of deep water near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, and two small, shallower areas, one surrounding Liberty Island and one near Ellis Island. Lieutenant Day says the Coast Guard plans to ease the anchorage squeeze by limiting the time ships can linger in the port and by nudging owners of smaller barges to use the shallower anchorages. To sweeten this medicine, the Coast Guard also wants to merge the two smaller anchorages, swallowing a 200-yard wide channel between them that is no longer much used.
As for recreational boats, the waiting list for slips at the 79th Street boat basin has surged 30 percent in six months. This has forced the city to limit stays and to expand its mooring field little by little into a Navy anchorage by the Upper West Side.
"The idea is that everyone who has a decent boat should have a place to tie up," said Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern. The city also has mooring fields in Brooklyn and Staten Island, and along with the Coast Guard is exploring other possible anchorages for pleasure boats. ERIK BAARD

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE; 
When a Stamp Was 2 cents and Their Tuition Was Free

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
Rebecca Abramson remembers well her first teaching assignment at Manual Training High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The year was 1931, and Ms. Abramson was 22, a freshly minted graduate of Hunter College. 
 On the first day, her students, big, hulking boys who played craps in the back of the classroom, told her they planned to leave school as soon as they could join the Navy. But within weeks, "the teach," as they called Ms. Abramson, had them quoting from "Macbeth" and offering commentary on his wife. 
 "They said, 'Ooh, what a dame!' she recalled. "They said, 'I wouldn't want to be her husband.' "
Ms. Abramson, 91, was one of 22 women celebrating the 70th reunion for Hunter College graduates at the Sheraton New York Hotel last weekend. They recalled when a postage stamp cost 2 cents and unemployed men sold apples on the street, but tuition at Hunter, all of whose students were women, was free. Many of the 800 who graduated in 1931 could not have attended otherwise. 
Many were daughters of immigrants, the first in their families to attend college. Many went on to professional careers as teachers, chemists, judges, musicians, statisticians and engineers. But for young women seeking work during the Depression, when unemployment hovered around 20 percent, the road was hard.
"No matter what job it was, you were overqualified and overeducated," said Rose Apfelberg, who became chief probation officer in Brooklyn Family Court. 
Sophie Bobb, a mathematics major, described an interview with "one man who said, 'If I were you, I'd look for a job elsewhere, because I don't think we'd hire a woman.' "
Like many classmates, the only job Ms. Bobb found after graduation was at Macy's. She later joined the Navy, finally getting work as a teacher after World War II.
Sometimes the biases ran closer to home. Mildred Cohn Primakoff, a chemistry major, recalled advice from her department chairman.
"He told us that he didn't think it was ladylike for us to become chemists," she said. "He wanted us all to become teachers of chemistry."
But Ms. Cohn Primakoff worked as a chemist and later became a professor of biochemistry and biophysics at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.
As the women exchanged stories, Dorothea E. Donaldson, a retired judge, asked: "Do you remember Annie Hickinbottom, the dean of the school? She used to say, 'If you tell a Hunter girl that she can't do something, she just takes away the T' " from can't.
That saying applied to deans too, Ms. Donaldson said. "She retired at 70 and got married." TARA BAHRAMPOUR

CORRECTION-DATE: June 17, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on May 13 with an article in the Neighborhood Report pages about the 70th reunion of the Hunter College class of 1931 misidentified two members. The woman at the left was Tessie Karper, not Sophie Bobb. The woman at the center was Mollie Polinsky, not Rose Apfelberg. A classmate's letter dated May 17 pointed out the error; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for MARTIN REYNOLDS; 
A Computer Price War Leaves Buyers Smiling

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
 PERSONAL-COMPUTER shoppers may not realize it, but they are benefiting from a price war among suppliers desperate for their business. Price cuts on PC's may seem like business as usual. After all, the PC industry routinely pares prices as components improve. But the new bargains also reflect a brawl unlike any the industry has seen. Martin Reynolds, an analyst at Gartner Dataquest in San Jose, Calif., spoke last Thursday about the causes and effects. BARNABY J. FEDER

Q. How did the PC price war begin?

A. We reached a situation where the market was saturated in 2000. People who needed computers had them. It might have begun in 1999, but it was masked by companies buying new computers to prepare for Y2K. Vendors are living on sales of replacements, at least in the United States. But that doesn't give you the kind of the growth these companies were used to. In the past, most price cuts came from falling prices for processors and other components. In addition, manufacturers have been narrowing profit margins for the last couple years. But when demand dried up last fall, the more aggressive manufacturers decided to try to gain market share by cutting prices to the bone. This is an all-out battle for market share.

Q. How far and how rapidly do you expect PC prices to drop this time?

A. They've gone about as far as they are going to. It will stay at $600 PC's at the low end of the business market for a while. At that level, even a $20 price cut can move markets. For a buyer purchasing thousands of machines, that's worth having. But it might also be enough to make a manufacturer walk away. It's hard though to really separate out how much of what we are calling a price war is margin cutting and how much is the normal downward trend in pricing. The average price has probably dropped about 20 percent, but what's more important on the business side is that purchasers are buying more of the cheapest machines, which have the narrowest profit margins. It hasn't bitten so deeply in the home segment. I.B.M. left a bit of space there when it exited the residential market last year. Prices actually rose early last year. The others didn't overbuild, so when Christmas was disappointing, there was less of an adjustment.

Q. How do PC price wars affect brand perception?

A. Compaq and H.-P. Hewlett-Packard are taking all of the oxygen out of the home market. These are fearsomely efficient companies. They've starved out the marginal suppliers in the stores. There was a real variety of manufacturers in the mid-90's that were viewed as acceptable brands. They're gone. Gateway and Apple are still somewhat viable because they have distinct markets. Gateway's stores give them good access to first-time buyers. Apple has a product line that appeals to the education segment. Apple is not as pricing-constrained as long as they offer distinguishable features. The growth days of 30 to 40 percent aren't going to come back. There won't be room for marginal players to get back in.

Q. Is this price war linked to pricing of other consumer electronics products?

A. Digital cameras and hand-helds like Palm have been good alternatives for consumer spending. They were very attractive when computers cost up to $2,000. But as the PC price drops, the others feel more competitive pressure. The slow sales of hand-helds this year are a function of the economy but also the aggressive pricing of the PC's.

Q. How do you expect the price war to end?

A. Someone is going to have to exit the market. But it will be a slow death requiring many quarters of punishment. Everyone is seeing how long they can hold their breath under water. It will probably be I.B.M., H.-P. or Compaq. Gateway has nowhere else to go, nor does Dell. The manufacturers have only got a few tens of dollars of profit in the box to start with. But it's hard to tell how much they are hurting. Some of them seem to be in the red now, but it could be supporting other parts of the business. So it's not just a question of getting out automatically making you more profitable.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Peter J. R. Trapp; 
Needham Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
STORMY weather ahead? Peter J. R. Trapp, who runs the $170 million Needham Growth fund, has a full complement of foul-weather gear.
 Unlike most other fund managers, Mr. Trapp is permitted by the fund's charter to short stocks -- that is, to bet on price declines. The approach was especially profitable in April and May of last year, when technology stocks were being routed. He can also hedge his portfolio against falling prices with options and can retreat into cash when the stock market looks particularly dicey. 
 Cash now accounts for 25 percent of the fund's assets, a record high. Short positions are just 10 percent, mostly in health maintenance organizations, restaurants and a few technology companies, businesses that have been hurt by the economic slowdown. An additional 10 percent is hedged in other ways. "It's not a lot," Mr. Trapp said from his office in Midtown Manhattan, "because I think we're through the worst of the earnings season, and the market feels that it wants to continue lifting."
All the storm gear serves one purpose, he said: "We short stocks and hedge the portfolio as a way to offset risk and reduce volatility, especially in technology stocks. This fund can be run very conservatively."
Mr. Trapp's ability to maneuver through good and bad markets has served investors well. The fund returned 33.5 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Thursday, compared with 9.2 percent for its midcap growth peers and 5.6 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. It returned 7.6 percent for the 12 months ended Thursday, compared with a loss of 14.6 percent for its peer group and a loss of 8.2 percent for the S.& P. 500.
The investment style of Mr. Trapp, 55, can be described as growth at a reasonable price. He starts by searching among what he calls new-economy growth industries -- areas like health care, media, leisure, entertainment and technology.
The technology stake, at 57 percent of assets, is down from about 75 percent or 80 percent at the start of 2000. "We've been scaling back as the bear market hit," he said.
The 60 to 120 stocks in the fund are mostly American companies with market capitalizations of up to $1.5 billion or so. He first looks for companies whose multiples of price to earnings, or price to earnings before interest, depreciation, taxes and amortization, are no more than half of the companies' three-year earnings growth rates.
"We're not necessarily looking for low-priced stocks," Mr. Trapp said. "We're willing to buy a stock selling for a 20 multiple if we're convinced that it's a 40 percent grower."
TO kick the tires of companies, he gathers information from the 20 technology analysts employed by Needham Investment Management, the fund's investment adviser, as well as from Wall Street research and visits to companies.
Mr. Trapp estimates that he spends 30 percent or more of his time on the road. "I find that getting out and meeting management is absolutely the best way to get a handle on the company and its prospects," he said. "Especially in the small-cap area, you need to make sure that management is driven, has vision, is properly incentivized and can pass the 'sniff test.' "
He starts to consider selling a company when its price-to-earnings multiple equals its earnings growth rate, and generally starts trimming positions when the P/E ratio is 150 percent of that rate. Stocks are typically sold when the P/E reaches 200 percent.
The fund's turnover rate is high -- 145 percent in 2000 -- because of Mr. Trapp's short-selling, but he manages his sales with an eye on taxes. 
Mr. Trapp began buying shares of Legato Systems of Mountain View, Calif., in April 2000 at an average of $12 a share. The price of Legato, which makes storage-management software, became depressed in early 2000 after the company failed to meet earnings estimates because of what Mr. Trapp called "an overly aggressive sales force." The company named a new chief executive, David B. Wright, who restructured the sales force and hired new management.
"The key is that when you talk to everyone in Silicon Valley," Mr. Trapp said, "you find that people really like the product, even though Wall Street put the company in the doghouse for missing their numbers and for the management turnover." He called the company "a diamond in the rough" and projected that it would have a 30 percent annual earnings growth rate for the next three years.
He expects a stock price in the mid-30's by year-end. The shares now trade at $14.48.
Another favorite is Thermo Electron of Waltham, Mass. He began buying the stock in September 1999 at $16.50, saying it was "like a mutual fund of single-purpose specialty device and medical companies." At one point, the company owned as many as 25 other public companies, he said. 
"Wall Street likes things simple," he said. "It became so complicated that analysts drifted away and the stock price traded down to what we thought were unreasonably low levels." In the last year, he said, the company began selling noncore businesses and reorganizing into a unified operating company focusing on its optical, testing and medical device businesses. That ignited new interest on Wall Street. On Friday, the stock closed at $25.92.
Mr. Trapp began buying shares of Advanced Micro Devices, the maker of integrated circuits, at $9.25 in June 1999. The price was beaten down, he said, because of competition from Intel, a series of manufacturing problems and questions about management succession.
"We talked to semiconductor analysts and became convinced that the market was discounting the company almost as if it were going out of business," Mr. Trapp said. Instead, it hired new management and opened a new semiconductor plant. "Consequently, when chips became scarce and prices started increasing, they were perfectly positioned," he said. He expects earnings to increase at an average of 20 percent a year over the next three years. The shares now trade at $27.68.

HEADLINE: Business; 
As Power Prices Surge, Montana, Too, Asks Why

BYLINE:  By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: BUTTE, Mont. 

 BODY:
THE last large-scale metal mine is silent in this city perched in the Rocky Mountains. The 170-ton, house-sized ore-hauling trucks, which once rumbled with loads 24 hours a day, have not fired up their engines since last summer. Nor have the conveyors, the crushers, the concentrators and the grinders. And most of the 320 workers who carved out a living extracting copper, molybdenum and silver from the 600-foot deep Continental Pit have scattered to other states and other jobs. 
 Montana Resources Inc., which owns the mine, has been out of affordable power for nine months. At the beginning of 2000, the mine was paying $26 a megawatt hour, up from $19 the year before. Last week, however, a megawatt hour cost $320. 
 While California has grabbed most of the national headlines for a power crisis caused by deregulation gone awry -- rolling blackouts resumed there last week -- another power deregulation crisis has been unfolding here in Montana. And in some ways, it is far more striking in its impact. While Californians may be somewhat protected from skyrocketing costs, Montanans are not. Paper companies, mines and other large industrial companies in Montana have been laying off workers because they cannot afford to pay their electric bills. Residents are expecting their household electric costs to as much as double by July 2002. 
A growing number of Montanans want to return to a time when their state, with its own sources of cheaply produced power, had some of the lowest electricity rates. Many residents are angry at the Legislature, which in their view deregulated the market solely at the behest of the Montana Power Company, once the state's dominant utility.
Under deregulation that took effect three years ago, Montana Power sold its hydroelectric and coal-fired generating plants to the PPL Corporation, the Allentown, Pa., company that sells power in 42 states and in Canada, England and Latin America. 
Like other owners of power generation sites, PPL has been profiting immensely under deregulation by charging rates based on the forces of supply and demand. Montana Power still distributes electric power around the state, but will soon be getting out of that business as well. 
The change has left large power consumers like Montana Resources scrambling to survive. They have scoured the region for affordable alternatives. They have asked PPL to make at least some cheaper electricity available but it is unclear if that will happen. And they have lobbied the Legislature to reregulate electrical power. 
"We've got to play all of our cards," said Greg Stricker, president of Montana Resources, as he gazed over the company's open mining pit and a giant statue of the Virgin Mary that sits high on a mountain above it. "We're faced with extinction." PPL, however, says it has no choice but to sell its power at market prices.
On a national scale, the plight of Montana, which has fewer than a million people, is not as visible as that of California, which has nearly 34 million. But Montana's experience shows what can happen when power prices spiral out of control and businesses and consumers are not protected.
Montana's power crisis is rooted in the history of the Montana Power Company. It was formed in 1912 by Anaconda Copper Mining to ensure power for Anaconda's extensive mining, milling and sawmill operations. Montana Power built hydroelectric dams on 11 rivers across the state, dams that still create power at low cost.
Anaconda was also accustomed to getting its own way. The company owned most of the state's daily newspapers until 1959 and wielded tremendous influence among elected officials. Anaconda, the historian Bernard DeVoto wrote, "maintained a more thorough-going ownership of Montana's wealth, government and inhabitants than any other corporation has ever been able to maintain in any other state." 
The Anaconda era ended in 1977 when the company was bought by Atlantic Richfield, the oil company that has since been acquired by BP P.L.C. ARCO closed the mines in 1980 and the smelter in 1983. Montana Power, which had become the state's regulated utility, outlived its creator.
By the mid-1990's, however, Montana Power was worrying about its own future. Power deregulation, a national trend, looked inevitable, and the company's big industrial customers were already shopping for sources of cheaper electricity.
So, trying to make a virtue of necessity, Montana Power began the process of getting out of the power business. It diversified, creating an Internet service provider called Touch America. It also began to push for power deregulation, saying it would result in lower costs and more customer choices. The company was hoping that deregulation would make itself attractive to investors and potential buyers.
A deregulation bill, the Electric Utility Restructuring and Customer Choice Act, was introduced in March 1997, when the legislative session was nearly over. Lawmakers, most of them farmers and ranchers and businessmen, approved it hastily.
To some critics of deregulation, the passage smacked of the era when Anaconda dictated what the Legislature should do. Ken Toole, a Democratic state senator and an opponent of the deregulation, called it a "steamroller with the mantra of free market." Montana Power disputed that interpretation. Jack Haffey, its president and chief operating officer, said, "it was not a bill pulled out of somebody's pocket and foisted on the public."
Still, Montana Power emerged with marketable power plants and its thriving Touch America business. The company sold its power plants to PPL, investing much of the proceeds in Touch America. Montana Power's shares, adjusted for an August 1999 split, soared to nearly $65 in March 2000 from less than $20 before deregulation. (The shares have since returned to a below-$20 range, closing on Friday at $16.48) Company insiders cashed in their stock options at the peak and some became rich.
And for a while, deregulation appeared to be working. Competition among power suppliers was pushing down the price of electricity. In January 1999, Montana Resources' power costs fell to $19 a megawatt hour from the regulated price of $30. 
But starting in June 2000, Mr. Stricker said, "the market started to go nuts." Rising demand, coupled with a lack of new supply, pushed up prices sharply. A megawatt hour spiked as high as $680 and then settled back into the $200-to-$400 range. Buyers of long-term contracts for electricity could get somewhat lower prices, ranging from $100 to $150, but even that was unaffordable for many. 
The region's power crisis has been aggravated recently by a drought that has reduced the amount of hydroelectric power generated. Steve Walsh, a Montana Resources spokesman, said the company's suppliers told it that rates could reach $1,000 a megawatt hour in the third quarter.
Montana's labor force, meanwhile, has suffered. Since last summer, according to the Montana affiliate of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., more than 1,000 workers have lost their jobs in layoffs caused by power price inflation. 
BUT the increased prices have been a boon to PPL. Last month, it reported its sixth consecutive quarter of record earnings. William F. Hecht, the chairman and chief executive, told the shareholders meeting on April 27 that "we are in the midst of the strongest growth period your company has ever known."
When the Montana Legislature convened this year, for the first time since power prices soared, it was besieged by worried citizens and businesses. Bills to change the law were introduced; one measure would have imposed a windfall-profits tax of 3,200 percent on power suppliers.
In the end, just one bill passed, supported by Montana Power and PPL, that shields both companies from most financial risk by giving them a right to recover costs they incur to find power for Montana consumers. In exchange for that protection, PPL tentatively agreed to sell 500 megawatts of power in Montana, up to two-thirds of what the state needs, at $40 a megawatt for five years, starting July 1. But the agreement could collapse -- Montana's Public Service Commission opposes it on grounds that power suppliers got too much. Bob Anderson, a Democratic member of the commission, said it looked as if the power suppliers had written the bill. 
Dan McCarthy, a spokesman for PPL, said it has done what it could for lower prices but had a "responsibility to our shareholders." And Ed Bartlett, who was Montana Power's chief lobbyist during its push for deregulation and is now Gov. Judy Martz's chief of staff, said many industrial consumers in the state "might be looking for a price of power that is just too low."
States in the Northwest that did not deregulate are now counting their blessings. On May 1 in Idaho, the state's Public Utilities Commission approved an increase in power rates. For large users, the cost of a megawatt hour will go to $41 from $29, to cover the 40 percent of its power that Idaho must buy on the market. That is a far cry from what Montana has been paying.
"That's what going to the market does for you," said Marsha Smith, a public utilities commissioner in Idaho. 
Throughout the Montana ordeal, Montana Power has said it has done nothing wrong, and has expressed optimism that the cost of power will fall eventually, as deregulation evolves. The current problem, Mr. Haffey said, "wasn't caused by deregulation," but rather by "a dysfunctional market."
Others, however, say the company and its influence over Montana lawmakers have created a mess in a state where power was once plentiful and eminently affordable. "Montana held the four aces of cheap power," said former United States Representative Pat Williams, a prominent critic of deregulation. "And a corporate-lackey legislature demanded a new deck of cards."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the electrical power crisis in Montana reversed the closing dates of the mines and smelter once owned by Anaconda Copper Mining, which created the Montana Power Company. Atlantic Richfield, which acquired Anaconda in 1977, closed the company's smelter in 1980 and its mines in 1983.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
Generating Much Heat But No Kazakh Profits

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ALMATY, Kazakhstan 

 BODY:
NEARLY five years ago, when Kazakhstan was hailed as a new democracy with great potential wealth, an American energy company bought one of the world's largest coal-fired generating plants in the northern part of the country and started to modernize it.
 Today, some people in Kazakhstan are prospering from its oil resources, though the country's credentials as a democracy are in doubt. But the American multinational, the AES Corporation, is struggling to turn a profit on an investment of more than $200 million. 
 "It's a very tough operating environment, especially considering the low income of the general population and the regulators' desire to keep the rates low and ignore the needs of the company to invest in upgrading," Vitaly Lee, the AES country director, said in an interview in his office here. 
AES has plenty of experience in difficult environments. Much of the growth that turned the company into one of the largest independent energy providers has come in locales that others considered too risky, like Colombia, Tanzania and India. 
The challenges in Kazakhstan range from bartering with customers for goods like cars, eggs and vodka to trying to persuade people to pay for electricity. AES has also tried to persuade tightfisted regulators to raise rates and dodged constant demands for bribes, company officials and Western diplomats said.
Obstacles are common. The promise of riches from oil and gas resources attracted billions of dollars in foreign investment. But despite progress, Kazakhstan is far from developing a transparent, Western-style business climate.
"There are still some sticking points for foreign investors, and bribery is as big a problem as it ever was," said an American business executive, who insisted that his name not be used because Western companies signed an agreement with the government not to criticize it in the press.
Bribery is a widespread problem in the developing world. Central Asian nations fare poorly on the annual ranking of corrupt countries by Transparency International, an organization trying to fight corruption. 
In a widely publicized case, the United States Justice Department is investigating whether James Giffen, an American lawyer, transferred $30 million in commissions from foreign oil companies to bank accounts controlled by President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan and other government officials.
Mr. Giffen, an adviser to Mr. Nazarbayev, has denied wrongdoing, and Kazakh officials have called the accusations false and malicious.
IN a lesser-known case that reflects many of the hazards of doing business here, prosecutors in Belgium and Switzerland are investigating $55 million paid to Kazakh business partners by Tractebel, the energy arm of the French conglomerate Suez. 
Tractebel's former chief executive acknowledged in a radio interview last year that he had authorized the payments as commissions to win projects in 1996 and 1997. A company spokesman said Tractebel was cooperating with the investigation, but declined to comment further.
The Tractebel case is interesting because the payments did not protect the company once it started providing electricity to Almaty, the country's largest city, and operating a 6,000-mile network of gas pipelines. 
"They gave a very large commission payment up front and didn't pay after that," Anthony Mansfield, a former Tractebel executive in Almaty, said in an interview. "The authorities made it virtually impossible for the company to operate."
Regulators refused requests to raise electricity rates. The regional governor, a self-described former boxer, said in a local TV interview that he had threatened to beat up a Tractebel official at a reception. At one point, Tractebel asked an international arbitration court to force regulators to increase the rates.
While the electricity business was losing money, Tractebel was making a profit transporting gas through the pipeline. But when it got rid of the local partners, Kazakh banks froze its accounts and the government started a public campaign against the company.
Mr. Nazarbayev criticized the company as not investing enough in Kazakhstan, and Tractebel soon began negotiations to withdraw from the country. Last December, it sold its holdings to a state-owned company for $100 million, about half the amount invested.
The president's criticism was part of a perceptible shift in attitude toward Western companies and governments evident in some Central Asian countries. A decade of assistance and investment has not produced prosperity, and there is growing impatience in some quarters. In Kazakhstan, for instance, Mr. Nazarbayev recently questioned some financial benefits accorded foreign companies, and government officials reacted sharply to the recent State Department human rights report, which was critical of Kazakhstan.
Martha Brill Olcott, an expert on the region at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the Tractebel episode demonstrated the risks of doing business where laws were undeveloped and governments could be fickle.
"Payments get you in the door, but it doesn't create the business environment that a Western firm needs," she said in a telephone interview from Washington.
AES has yet to earn anything in Kazakhstan. When the company started selling electricity in northern Kazakhstan, even big commercial customers did not have the cash to pay. AES agreed to barter arrangements, trading electricity for cars used by its staff, rail transportation and, in some cases, vodka and other products that could be sold by middlemen.
"That was the only way to do business," Mr. Lee, a Kazakh national, said.
AES needed all the revenue it could muster. The huge coal-fired plant in Ekibastuz was only 16 years old, but the roof had fallen in, and the turbines were in poor shape. It was built to supply electricity to vast regions of the Soviet Union, but AES spent $90 million to approach 25 percent capacity.
The company also bought the rights to operate two thermal plants and four hydroelectric plants near Ust-Kamenogorsk, in eastern Kazakhstan. Mr. Lee said additional money had been invested there.
AES prides itself on providing clean, safe energy at reasonable prices. In Kazakhstan, it sells electricity for 0.6 cents a kilowatt hour, one of the lowest rates in the world. Still, Mr. Lee said, the company could not persuade regulators to let it raise rates and pass on to customers the cost of revenue-generating improvements like new meters.
Part of the problem is that customers are unaccustomed to paying for electricity.
"The mind-set in Kazakhstan is that electricity is a right, not a privilege that you have to pay for," a Western diplomat in Almaty said.
In Kazakhstan, the company has been criticized as not investing enough. "They have not fulfilled a series of conditions," Kanat Berentayev, a government economist, said in an interview.
Before increasing its investment substantially, AES officials said, the company needs the assurance of a better revenue stream. Still, Dennis W. Bakke, the company's chief executive, refused to complain about the business environment.
"I think Kazakhstan wants us, though it is not always easy to tell," Mr. Bakke said in a telephone interview from AES headquarters in Arlington, Va. "Business can be risky everywhere."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: 'Getting Amazoned,' And Other Fantasies; 
Eek! What Have E-Consultants Wrought?

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
JUST over a year ago, America's biggest, oldest, most prosperous corporations were about to be slaughtered by the dot-com insurgents.
 Retailers fantasized about trading acres of floor space for a slick Web site. Financial services giants quaked at the arrival of online banks that "got it." Media executives fretted that online newspapers and Internet broadcasters would arise from the ether to capture their audiences. Consultants everywhere were prophesying doom for the Fortune 500. 
 "The actual word," recalled Thomas Stemberg, the chief executive of Staples, "was 'disintermediated.' It meant you were going to be taken out of the equation." 
Mr. Stemberg is one of hundreds of executives at large, publicly held companies who spent millions of dollars over the last three years to fend off what now looks like a Nasdaq-fueled mass hallucination. Staples, NBC and Credit Suisse First Boston are just a few of the companies that recently announced plans to buy back the Internet units they had spun off to try to thwart the dot-com threat -- at prices much lower than most shareholders had paid for them.
The specter of "getting Amazoned," which justified many a spending spree in the name of warding off Web-based competitors, lost its zing as the shares of Amazon.com plummeted -- and as another online bookseller, Barnesandnoble.com, started taking some of its market share. Toys "R" Us, for example, has poured $260 million into Toysrus.com, according to regulatory filings, only to watch eToys, its online archrival, file for bankruptcy this year.
Hindsight in the wake of a 60 percent Nasdaq correction is easy, of course, and there has already been much finger-pointing amid the popped-com compulsion to explain a market bubble that, however briefly, valued Amazon over Barnes & Noble, eToys over Toys "R" Us and Palm Computing over its venerable parent, 3Com.
But if Wall Street analysts and venture capitalists are blamed for spinning unrealistic tales of dot-com success for investors, the most outspoken Internet boosters in corporate America were the strategy consultants who supplied the buzzwords and business rationales that seemed to justify what might otherwise have been dismissed as a market aberration.
In a raft of books, newsletters and seminars, supposedly impartial experts from consulting firms and academia extolled the virtues of entrepreneurialism among 20-somethings. They warned corporate managers of the disruptive power of technology, and urged them to embrace it. And many of them went on to reap extraordinary profits over the last few years, advising corporate clients to invest in online ventures that turned out to be largely unprofitable.
"The consultant fraternity was after everybody," said Brian T. Moynihan, executive vice president of FleetBoston Financial, who said he discarded most of the advice, although he paid for much of it. "They were all pushing that the Internet was going to change everything." 
The Internet missteps of many established companies, which emerged as winners in an ultimately not-so-epic battle, have largely been glossed over in the aftermath. But now, as corporate executives assess their own performance during the boom time -- or are forced to by shareholders -- many lament the expensive Internet advice that didn't pan out.
With big corporations trimming spending on Internet initiatives, and on the advisers who helped conceptualize them, the consultants may finally be asked to account for their previous miscalculations before being invited to submit new ones.
"It's the same story all over again with wireless," said Janey Place, an executive vice president at Mellon Financial, referring to recent admonitions that "mobile commerce" requires companies to make banking and other services available over wireless networks. "We've learned not to take some of these projections seriously."
Facing this increased skepticism, some consultants have turned openly apologetic. But others are unrepentant, and most, being consultants, are simply offering a new spin on the not-so-new economy.
"This was a tough way to learn important lessons," said Chunka Mui, co-author of "Unleashing the Killer App: Digital Strategies for Market Dominance," and chief innovation officer at the consulting firm DiamondCluster International. "Given what the markets have done, there's a risk that people will say we don't have to worry about this anymore, and I think that would be a fatal mistake. The real lesson here is to recognize that the technology itself is of a transformational nature."
BESIDES, some consultants note, managers are free to take or reject their advice as they please.
"I'm sure there's somebody out there who thinks they should blame the consultants," said Bob Gett, chief executive of Viant, a start-up consulting firm that specializes in technology strategy. "They may feel a little embarrassed about how enthusiastic they got about the digital imperative. But these are executives. They make their own decisions, and they live with the results."
Of course, the Internet strategies of many established companies were largely based on time-honored motives that require no consultation -- fear and greed. What may now look like excess spending on Internet operations was in many cases an effort to take advantage of inflated market valuations, executives said.
But continued confirmations, from a thriving consulting corps and a proliferation of business books -- with titles like "Leading the Revolution," by Gary Hamel; "Digital Capital," by Don Tapscott, et. al.; and "Living on the Fault Line" by Geoffrey A. Moore -- helped explain away nagging doubts about the notion that rules of business had fundamentally changed.
That axiom became part of the feedback loop that catapulted the valuation of Internet companies. That, in turn, convinced corporate managers that they needed to spend more to compete, according to experts in market psychology. 
"When the market goes up, people want a plausible story to explain why this is real," said Robert Shiller, the economist at Yale University who compared the Internet stock boom to a Ponzi scheme in one of the rare critical books about the phenomenon, "Irrational Exuberance" (Princeton University, 2000). "If a friend makes money and there's no story, that doesn't do it," he added. "The story is why the Ponzi scheme works."
Consultants, those shadowy figures who flit from client to client and who typically are blamed when managers look bad and ignored when they look good, tend to make the most money at times of great uncertainty -- when clients are more likely to seek guidance. This time, though, consultants may have known little more than the managers. 
In the heat of the bubble, firms like Razorfish and IXL, originally hired because their young programmers knew how to design Web sites, promoted themselves as strategy consultants. For several million dollars a pop, they told dozens of multinational corporations how to conduct business online. Many such "e-consultants" have made drastic cuts in staff recently as their share prices plunged more than 90 percent.
Still, even among the more august firms, the conventional consultant wisdom held that if established companies were to compete with the fast-moving visionaries in the parade of online banks and pet stores and office supply chains, they needed to move onto the Internet immediately. And they needed to set up separate divisions to do it, far away from the parent company that was enmeshed in its old analog culture.
But many companies that put those strategies to work have reversed course. "The major themes the management strategists were pushing were mistakes," said Michael Porter, a professor of business administration at Harvard, who, in a recent Harvard Business Review, lambasted popular Internet strategies espoused by high-profile consultants. "The real advantage established companies had was established brands, product lines, relationships. By setting up Internet operations as separate, they essentially walked away from those things."
That did not stop consultants of all stripes from charging fees as much as $600 an hour, or tens of millions of dollars over the course of a year, to conceptualize and carry out an Internet strategy for major corporations.
Robert Howe, chief executive of Scient, one of a group of new "e-consultants," certainly had a good year in 2000. Known for teaching his young staff to "accentuate the fear factor" with large clients by telling them, "You have money, but you don't have time," his salary and bonus came to $500,000 that year and his roughly 10 percent stake in the company at one point exceeded $500 million.
IN an industry where annual growth hovers around 20 percent, revenue rose by 60 percent a year from 1997 to 2000. Last year, Internet consulting alone brought in $10 billion in revenue for the top 10 consulting firms, and about 40 percent of their total earnings, according to Consulting Information Services, a research firm in Keene, N.H. 
Major consulting firms like Accenture and McKinsey also started venture capital groups, taking equity stakes in some of the "dot corps" that they helped get off the ground. "When consultants get into venture capital," said Tom Rodenhauser, president of Consulting Information, "you know things are good."
And in a measure of how lucrative it was to be a consultant, most everyone from 15-year-old Web site designers to journalists to technology companies like Cisco Systems began marketing themselves as one.
"Anyone who had an interest in making money tried to insert themselves into the gap created by where we were now and where we should be," recalled Josh Grotstein, who left his position as division executive for e-commerce programs at Citicorp last year to join Silicon Alley Seed Investors, a new venture capital firm. "Whoever they were, they all called us dinosaurs."
Not all the advice was bad, of course, and even some executives who were made queasy by the Internet roller coaster say that it was better to have taken the ride. Mr. Stemberg of Staples said the bright-colored decor and entrepreneurial spirit of Staples.com has had a beneficial effect on the entire company now that it is being reintegrated into the whole. Marty Yudkovitz, who is president of NBC's digital media division, described himself as a "bloodied optimist," whose company stands to profit from the lessons of Internet investments gone bad.
Still, many executives said they would welcome some self-reflection from their consultants as well.
With the benefit of hindsight, here is what some influential authors, professors and prominent consultants say about their Internet analyses.

CLAYTON M. CHRISTENSEN -- Professor of business administration, Harvard Business School.
Influential book: "Innovator's Dilemma: When New Technologies Cause Great Firms to Fail" (Harvard Business School Press, 1997).
Key concept: Disruptive technologies will topple incumbent companies unless an independent organization is created to address them.
Mr. Christensen wants to state for the record that the Internet is not necessarily a disruptive technology. He says that both the terms "disruptive" and "technology," which he put together to coin what became one of the era's most famous buzz-phrases and the rationale for its most popular strategy -- the Internet spinoff -- "may have been misleading."
Still, he stands firmly by his disconcerting thesis: that because dominant companies focus on products that earn the highest margins, they inevitably miss the opportunity to develop more convenient, less costly offerings that are initially less profitable. The blind spot is perilous, because those "disruptive technologies" can undermine the established way of doing business.
As prime evidence, his book explained how big mainframe computer companies like Digital Equipment lost out in the PC revolution. To avoid a similar fate, Mr. Christensen said, established corporations should set up independent organizations to handle disruptions.
Many readers assumed that the Internet fit the definition. Not necessarily so, Mr. Christensen says now, noting that the book did not address the Internet: "The misinterpretation is, 'anything that is different or radical, you better create a separate company,' and that's not true."
For discount brokers like Charles Schwab, the Internet was a "sustaining" technology, he said, because it let them perform their existing business more efficiently. Merrill Lynch, which has rolled out an online brokerage service of its own, is different, Mr. Christensen believes.
"Merrill Lynch over time, in their retail organization, will get killed, just like Digital, because they only implement to sustain their business and they haven't caught the disruptive wave," he said.
The difficulty, it seems, is in determining what is and is not "disruptive." And by the way, disruptions do not necessarily take the form of technology, he added. The use of the term came from his initial study of the rise of PC's, and he just kept using it.
"I never went back and said, 'I'm going to take the "technology" word out,' " Mr. Christensen recalled. "Similarly, the word 'disruptive' connotes in many people's minds a breakthrough, and that's confusing. I don't know what a better word would be. There are just so many prior connotations to too many words."

JOHN HAGEL III -- Chief strategy officer of 12 Entrepreneuring; former partner at McKinsey & Company.
Influential works: "Net Gain: Expanding Markets Through Virtual Communities," with Arthur G. Armstrong (Harvard Business School Press, 1997), and "Net Worth: Shaping Markets When Customers Make the Rules," with Marc Singer (Harvard Business School Press, 1999).
Key concept: Exploiting online communities and tailoring service offerings to consumers are key to making a profit on the Web.
Like many executives he advised as founder of the e-commerce practice at McKinsey, Mr. Hagel faced a paradox: the strategies that made the best business sense for the long term were being punished by the capital markets.
"I would be told in countless meetings: 'Your ideas sound very plausible, but I just spoke with the financial analyst or the funder or whatever and they're telling me something totally different. Who do I believe?' " Mr. Hagel recalled. "I should have been more forceful at that point and said, 'Well, the market's wrong.' "
In part because of market pressure, and in part because corporations resisted setting up Web communities because they did not want consumers saying bad things about their products, his ideas were rarely carried out fully, Mr. Hagel said. Almost none of the dozens of community-based Web sites made the leap from a social forum to a profitable one, which disappointed clients. "I put a lot of emphasis in the book on how hard this was," he said. "I hope the notion of the challenges was as strong as it needed to be."
His effort to convince suspicious corporate managers of the value of virtual operations tilted his advice too far in another direction, he said. "In consulting with clients," he recalled, "I probably underestimated the value of the physical assets that were already available to them." 
But he reserved some criticism for the managers. "I saw more and more people, and it wasn't just in the dot-com space but also in the large traditional company space, creating Internet initiatives not because they saw a general business value, but because they wanted to cash in quickly on what the market fad of the moment was," he said. "So I actually think some of the spin-outs were not about the belief that you had to spin out to create a viable business. It was a more base, material goal, and it has hurt them in the long term."

KEVIN KELLY -- Former editor, Wired magazine, and author, "New Rules for a New Economy" (Viking, 1998).
PETER SCHWARTZ -- Chairman, Global Business Network, and author, "The Long Boom" (Perseus, 1999), with Peter Leyden and Joel Hyatt.
Key concept: The network economy, the acceleration of technological innovation and rampant globalization are setting the stage for a 20- to 30-year period of global prosperity with new economic rules.
Mr. Kelly knows that people have soured on the once unassailable notion of a new economy. Just last summer, he made speaking appearances almost daily, explicating rules like "Feed the Web first," "Let go at the top" and the one that has given him the most grief lately, "Follow the free." Not any more.
As the executive editor of Wired from its inception in 1993 until 1999, Mr. Kelly was responsible for what seemed even then like an extreme form of technological optimism. Every month, the magazine promoted the notion that the world would be turned upside down -- fast.
He says he would not change a word of any of his rules. As for the failure of dozens of companies that gave products away: "I said you begin with the free," he explained. "The problem was, people haven't figured out what to charge for."
Wired's evangelization of everything new hit its peak with "The Long Boom," which started as a long cover article by Mr. Schwartz, Mr. Leyden and Mr. Hyatt, published in July 1997. Mr. Kelly came up with the article's title, and he said he still believes that a decades-long period of global prosperity has just begun.
So does Mr. Schwartz, who notes that there were 1,000 car companies in America in 1920, and five in 1930.
"That's when all the real growth happened," said Mr. Schwartz, unruffled by the recent downturn. "There will be another takeoff in about a year. It's actually going remarkably well." 

ROBERT HOWE -- chief executive, Scient.
Old key concept, 1998-2000: "The Scient approach," building complete e-businesses within a few months.
New key concept: to integrate the Internet into existing businesses.
If the problem with consultants is accountability -- they can always say a client did not follow their advice -- e-consultants like Scient are being taken to task more than most. Scient shares have dropped roughly 99 percent since their peak of $130 in March, 2000. Last month, the company said it would cut its work force.
Scient cultivated large companies as clients and became known for telling them that their time was more important than their money. "Now they all believe they have more time," Mr. Howe says.
He said several assumptions that drove his client strategy over the last three years "turned out to be slightly off, or more than slightly off."
"We always tried to talk about real business models with our clients," he said, "but it was just a time when everybody believed if you put something out on the Internet, people would come." Mr. Howe said Scient's clients were now more interested in integrating technology into their existing businesses.

PHILIP EVANS -- Senior vice president, Boston Consulting Group.
Influential work: "Blown to Bits: How the New Economics of Information Transforms Strategy," with Thomas S. Wurster (Harvard Business School Press, 1999).
Key concept: The Internet dispenses with the need for established middlemen, leveling the playing field for all competitors to vie for a direct relationship with the customer.
A couple of weeks ago, Mr. Evans said he received an e-mail message from the founder of Wine.com, Peter Granoff, one of the earliest sellers of wine online, and an example Mr. Evans has often used of how traditional retailers would be "disintermediated" by the Internet. Mr. Granoff's company, originally called Virtual Vineyards, was folding.
"Although we did not come right out and predict that Virtual Vineyards would be a big success, I think if I'm honest we thought they would," Mr. Evans said, "and obviously we're rather disappointed that they aren't."
"Blown to Bits" was written as a warning to traditional companies, and Mr. Evans says it should still be heeded. What he and others got wrong, he said, was the timing of the impending doom. "It's not a tidal wave that you can see coming and it's going to overwhelm you in a few hours," he said. "It's more like a tectonic force that will eventually cause an earthquake."
Mr. Evans does have some comfort, however cold, for those who rushed to meet the tidal wave on his advice: "Every revolution, whether political or economic, eats its own children," he said. "We shouldn't be surprised that when fundamental change occurs there is a tremendous amount of experimentation and most fails."
Besides, part of the reason that things look so rosy now for big corporations is that they did follow his advice, Mr. Evans said.
"The danger of a dot-com displacing General Electric or Wal-Mart or Citibank is much less than it looked like it was in the days when they were being very complacent," he said. "The risk is that they'll go back into complacency."
As for "Blown to Bits," "The title is now a little bit embarrassing," Mr. Evans said. "We shrug our shoulders and say, 'We didn't say who was going to get blown to bits.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Two books that were evangelical about a high-tech revolution came out in 1999. Philip Evans, far left, was the author of "Blown to Bits," while Peter Leyden, Peter Schwartz and Joel Hyatt wrote "The Long Boom."; Marty Yudkovitz, president of NBC's digital media unit, says he is a "bloodied optimist" after some hard lessons about Internet investments. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)(pg. 14); Among the prominent advisers who influenced many corporations on Internet strategy are Clayton M. Christensen, left, a professor at Harvard Business School, and John Hagel III, chief strategy officer of 12 Entrepreneuring Inc. and a former partner at McKinsey. (Lloyd Francis Jr. for The New York Times); (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)(pg. 1) Drawing (Illustrations by Stuart Goldenberg)(pg. 14) Chart: "An Internet Guru's Lexicon" AMAZONED -- What happens when a large, established company is overtaken by a Web-based start-up. As in, "we don't want to be Amazoned." BUSINESS MODEL -- Usually a vague idea that outlines how a company plans to generate revenue. Criticized by Michael Porter, a Harvard Business School professor, who said it "becomes an invitation for faulty thinking and self-delusion," because it allows executives to duck the harder problems of developing a strategy and competitive advantage. CORPORATE STRATEGY SOURPUSS -- What e-business consultant Larry Downes called Michael Porter, the Harvard business school professor, in a recent column in The Industry Standard. Strictly, an old-style business strategist who doesn't take account of how the Internet requires companies to have flexible strategies that can change rapidly with the technology. DISINTERMEDIATED -- What happens to big traditional companies after the Internet cuts out the middleman and removes obstacles to the speedy flow of information and goods. FEAR FACTOR -- An emotion shared by corporate executives who think that they will look stupid because they don't understand technology. Commonly cited by consultants as a means of talking clients into paying high consulting fees. FIRST-MOVER ADVANTAGE -- The theory that being first on the Internet is all that matters, no matter how much money it takes or how bad the product or service is -- or the fact that switching allegiances was easier on the Internet than anywhere else, because clicking to another site is easy. GET BIG FAST -- The dominant business model (see above) of the Internet boom era. GREED -- Far more than any consulting jargon, what might have motivated corporate executives to invest in Internet businesses. INTERNET TIME -- The pace at which Internet businesses evolve, or devolve. Typically thought to be approximately seven times that of the off-line world. KNOWLEDGE GAP -- The yawning gulf between the stunning acumen of young Web designers and the total ignorance of Luddite executives with 30 years of management experience at traditional companies about how to do business online. NEW ECONOMY -- A world where information products have different properties than physical, Industrial Age products, so the rules of how to make and sell them must be different, too. WE'RE STILL IN THE EARLY INNINGS -- What consultants say now to bitter and disillusioned executives who have spent millions of dollars on failed Internet strategies. HEADLINE: The World; 
Rudeness Awakens America

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS 

 BODY:
OVER the last decade, as the United States looked down from the peak of world power, its officials may have overlooked some currents rising below. While the demise of the Soviet system left only one superpower standing, it also freed scores of other nations from the gridlock of East-West confrontation, and they began to build new or stronger alliances outside Washington's reach.
 In the developing world, a bloc known as the G77 that now includes 133 African, Asian and Latin American countries can command a two-thirds majority in the United Nations. Across the Atlantic, the European Union has 15 members and will grow more. 
 Diplomats and American officials say it was these two groups, not normally allies, that came together for one startling moment to jolt the United States in the last week and a half, snatching away American seats on the United Nations Human Rights Commission and the International Narcotics Control Board in a secret vote in the Economic and Social Council.
The event symbolized a much larger phenomenon: the evolution of a whole new set of relationships between the United States and two emerging power blocs with strong interests of their own that may frequently come in conflict with American interests. Most of the world's nations may now be democratic to one degree or another, but that does not unite them. The challenge is to learn how to manage the differences and to separate the truly crucial ones -- over economic needs, peace, the environment, for example -- from irritants.
In this light, the sabotaging of American membership on the Human Rights Commission -- apparently an act of cumulative annoyance after years of American rejection of international agreements, the hounding from office of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and Congressional blocking of dues that beggared the United Nations -- looks like overkill to many Americans. But it has also sounded an alarm.
"This is one of those seminal events -- like Zionism equals racism -- that is going to haunt us for a long time," said Richard N. Gardner, a Columbia University law professor who was in last year's American delegation to the General Assembly. The fear is that poisoned feelings on all sides could make it more difficult, as Israel-bashing did in the 1970's, for the United States to work with the United Nations on critical matters, like containing Iraq, for which Americans have needed the United Nations in the past.
The House of Representatives did strike back last week, voting to withhold $244 million in overdue payments to the United Nations, but paying a $582 million bill.
Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, President Ronald Reagan's United Nations ambassador and a frequent critic of the organization, nevertheless thinks Congress aimed at the wrong target. "Kofi Annan didn't cause our problems, and the U.N. secretariat didn't cause our problems," she said in an interview. "Withholding funds from the U.N., we don't really affect the people whom we would like to affect." Those responsible, she said, were the Europeans, who didn't relinquish a seat to America when there were four candidates for three slots on the Human Rights Commission, and apparently voted as a bloc for Austria, France and Sweden.
Since the end of the cold war, Dr. Kirkpatrick said, one of the most important changes in the world has been the consolidation of the European Union, and "with that has gone an increased influence of France, with its characteristic exclusiveness."
Among the developing nations, an Asian ambassador said, votes were cast against the United States for several reasons, including what many see as a paucity of American aid and opposition to American efforts to hold individual countries up to human-rights scrutiny, in particular China. Arthur C. I. Mbanefo, Nigeria's ambassador and last year's chairman of the G77. said poor countries were only flexing muscles in their national interests as Americans do.
Concerted attacks on the United States are, of course, nothing new in international bodies, but rarely have such strong efforts been made to exclude Americans from what they have come to consider their rightful place at a lot of tables.
In some ways, the global advance of democracy is part of the problem. In many more nations, public opinion matters, and television audiences can see -- and resent -- how their presidents are treated on visits to Washington or how Americans rank their concerns. So even if many countries now share an interest in advancing democratic principles, one Asian ambassador said, "no one has said we must vote for each other" when interests clash.
At Freedom House in New York, the president, Adrian Karatnycky, differed, saying it should be possible to build coalitions based on political and civil liberties and adding that there is a danger when "a bunch of countries are playing with these rather sacrosanct values to make other kinds of extraneous points." He dismissed European explanations that the Bush administration's rejection of the Kyoto treaty on global warming was reason enough to punish the United States. "If you link the Kyoto treaty to human rights, you're doing it to the detriment of both," he said.
MR. GARDNER and some foreign diplomats fault the American mission here for inept handling of the campaign for the Human Rights Commission seat. But Bill Richardson, chairman of Freedom House's board and a Clinton-era ambassador to the United Nations, pointed in an interview to other issues. He recommended courting the developing bloc, "perhaps by renewing our efforts to expand the Security Council to include them, and build coalitions" among its members when their interests clash with Europe's, as on trade and immigration.
In any event, he and other former American ambassadors to the United Nations seem in agreement that the worst message to send would be a threat of blackmail, as in the congressional demand that the United States be re-elected to the Human Rights Commission before final bills are paid. "It gives another tool to those who deprived us of the seat," Mr. Richardson said.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Then and Now; 
Allow Us to Demonstrate: Student Protest Comes of Age

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN

 BODY:
SINCE they finished finals at the end of April, Ben Royal and three fellow University of Michigan students have been driving around the Northeast in a green 1992 Toyota Corolla, trying to make a movement.
 They went to Pennsylvania State University, where death threats to black students recently inspired a sleep-in at the student center. They stopped at Brown University, where protesters outraged by an advertisement concerning reparations for slavery confiscated copies of the student paper and formed human chains to block its distribution. And they made several visits to Harvard, where 26 smelly students emerged Wednesday after a three-week sit-in over how much the nation's richest university pays its janitors. 
 Mr. Royal and his comrades, cell phones at their ears, are recruiting for a June conference on their Ann Arbor campus. They hope for attendance of 200 -- twice, they note, the number that gathered for the founding conference of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in 1960. 
There is a fine line between a march and a movement, and with students, in the glare of springtime, that line can be hard to see -- particularly in a culture that has become inured to the endless variations on chants that begin, "Hey hey, ho ho." There is, cynics will say, always a hardy band of leftists decrying something or other on every college campus, like background noise on the soundtrack of a liberal education. But if the activism of the late 1960's signified a more profound challenge to the fabric of society, today's demonstrations -- focused, tolerated and relentlessly coordinated -- may be more efficient at achieving their goals.
Student protest has a long history in Europe and Asia, dating at least to the 19th century. American campuses were slower to simmer, with the first sparks coming over economic issues in the 1930's and 1940's. It was only as universities opened up to a more diverse student body, in the 1960's, that a true student movement took hold, focused first on civil rights and then on the Vietnam War. A second generation arose in the 1980's, when students erected mock shantytowns and pushed many universities to divest themselves of their holdings in apartheid-era South Africa.
In both cases, the involvement of the young intellectual elite served to grab public attention. But the linkages between the student efforts and more established adult groups -- businesses and antiwar veterans, Democratic politicians and civil rights leaders -- were crucial to creating actual change.
"Students very often are the most publicized element, and very often they engage in the most dramatic actions because they are young and free and more ready to take risks because they are young and free," said Howard Zinn, the radical historian who visited the Harvard encampment several times. "If that movement doesn't go beyond students, then it doesn't go very far."
THE latest rumblings, dating back about five years, focus on economic justice and globalization, with a dash of environmentalism. Students have rallied against the use of sweatshop labor to make their sweatshirts; now, at Harvard and across the country, they are aligning with union organizers to call for a "living wage" for the universities' lowest-paid employees. Mr. Royal and his friends, meanwhile, are trying to defend affirmative action.
Students were a major element of the recent civil disobedience disrupting world trade meetings in Seattle and Quebec, and unions have also stepped up their organizing among professors, graduate students, and even undergraduates across the country. In both the actions on campuses and the highly publicized protests of globalization that have targeted political and diplomatic conferences, students have forged an unusually strong alliance with labor.
This new partnership comes in part from the increasing interest among union leaders in direct action, and labor has reached out to young people with programs like Union Summer, an echo of the 1964 Freedom Summer, with college students organizing workers this time instead of registering voters. It also reflects the outward-looking ideology of today's students, who are rallying for the rights of low-wage workers even though, with their expensive degrees, they are unlikely to confront such problems personally.
ELECTRONIC communication has also revolutionized the revolution. Organizers now coordinate activities through e-mail and Web sites; the Harvard protesters spent much of their time on cell phones, blitzing the media and urging celebrities to come to the daily noontime rallies outside the window (they also frequently called their parents and assured them they were all right).
Whether the series of campus demonstrations in recent years will escalate into a sort of third wave of student movement, on the order of antiwar or divestment, remains a question. Harvard did not yield to the students' demands to pay all workers at least $10.25 an hour, instead just naming a new committee to reconsider the question. Still, the high-profile action at the nation's most prestigious university has already spurred copycats at the University of Connecticut, and could prove a bellwether.
At the same time, where once student protests shook the nation to its core, they have now become common enough to feel like a springtime rite of passage, prompting yawns or dismissive contempt. In the 1960's, students were questioning the foundation of American society, protesting the very authority of the institutions that governed their lives. Today, the questions seem far narrower, the protests somehow safer.
When Students for a Democratic Society occupied administration buildings in the 1960's, the abiding image was of long-haired hippies smoking cigars with their feet propped on the university president's desk. This year, many students brought books and laptops into Massachusetts Hall so they wouldn't fall too far behind in their schoolwork. In 1969, during a demonstration against R.O.T.C. recruiting at Harvard, the police stormed University Hall and threw the students out after 24 hours; officers brought today's protesters deodorant and dinner.
And many student protests are about far less cosmic, more self-interested concerns, like the recent University of North Carolina march over budget cuts, or last weekend's demonstration at Boston University complaining that construction on a soccer field was a noisy disruption during exams.
Donald Kagan, a classics professor at Yale University, said that administrators -- many of whom came of age in the 60's, some through sit-ins -- have gotten soft, and that by failing to discipline students for acts of civil disobedience, are "miseducating them morally."
"In the real world, your acts have consequences," Professor Kagan said. "At Yale and Harvard, they don't. If you don't risk anything, it costs you nothing. You're not a hero, you're a bully."
THE cynics say that students protest in the spring because they prefer it to studying, that students protest because they have more time and less to lose, that rallies and demonstrations are like so many other extra-curricular activities.
But if they don't do it, who will?
"This is going to sound like what adults say when they're patronizing students, but when you're older, you're saddled with a lot of different responsibilities," said Ari Weisbard, a Harvard junior from Madison, Wis., who was among the sitters through Day 21. "You can't really throw everything aside for several weeks to devote to something important. It's not just that we're more idealistic because we haven't had as much world experience. It's that we have a real chance to act on our ideals."
Mr. Weisbard, whose father was among the protesters at Harvard in1969, acknowledged that skipping two and a half weeks of classes was unlikely to hurt his law school applications. The only homework he managed to get done inside was reading two chapters of a text titled "Political Equality," but he was able to get an extension on his philosophy paper until next week.
Then there's his social studies tutorial, a seminar called Community Organizing and Civic Democracy. He is hoping the professor will understand why he missed class, gathering primary research for his final paper.
